reviews.review: Don't go to Prague unless you stop here!. Since the walk uphill is a bit vigorous, you can take a tour bus (Hop on-Hop Off) and spend as much time as you want. The gardens are beautiful and the walk down is easy and beautiful. You end up in a delightful village area with unique shops and restaurants, so plan lots of time.
Wonderful way to absorb the culture. The buildings and history and culture are so easily absorbed here after the Castle visit. My mind exploded with stories and fairy tales and old movies.

Lots to See. Lots to see and do in the area including some stunning views over Prague.Also good views of Strahou monastery and the river. Visit Golden street when here. Walk down the steps to the lesser quarter and visit the Chocolate factory at the base of the steps. Free samples and they sell wonderful hot chocolate for 60 k

The Castle District. Put on your good shoes and start walking around the district, not only watchin this castle but all the surrounding alleys and buildings.
Awesome and highly recommended.

Great view from above. Another beautiful Prague district with elaborate buildings and great for a walk through.
There is a great view of the rooftops from the castle garden.

Step back in time. Walking around the castle area is like taking a step back in time. Glorious architecture and stunning scenery. The walk to the castle is quaint and pretty with narrow cobbled streets. Lots of fabulous restaurants enroute. The views from this area are simply beautiful. The castle can be accessed by tram 22, but I would recommend to travel by foot if physically able or risk missing out on some hidden gems on the way.

Plethora of places to visit and things to see. At least one or two days are needed to fully absorb what Prague castle and its environs can offer. Castle environs are additional attraction, less overwhelmed by tourist crowds then the castle area itself. There are Castle (southern) gardens that can be reached by scenic old stairs (Stare Zamecke schody, close to metro station Malostranska) from which breath-taking city views open. The gardens themselves are serene and beautiful. Then, there is Castle square with several palaces, museums and galleries, also cafes and restaurants, if hungry.

a very beautiful truly medieval area. the area surrounding the castle is very picturesque with little shops and cafes on either side of the great many steps leading up to the castle area . From the top you can see a breathtaking panoramic view of the town below

Lovely view. There are many nice old buildings in this area. A visit here is a must whne in Prague. The view of the city is very nice and the walk down (or up) is also good with some nice restaurants along the way.

Wear comfortable shoes and walk. There is so much to see that the curious tourist could spend the entire day and not cover the sights. The cathedral is gothic yet the guide said some 20th century additions have been made. The grounds are impressive with a panoramic view of the city. Most of the gardens were in the winter mode but the landscaping befits a palace. The Golden Alley is full of little cottages that offer every souvenir sold in the city but the cobbled streets give the place an old world charm.

not to be misseed. Walk across the bridge and approach "the castle" district. So much to see. Museum, government buildings, Kafka's sisters place, medieval armor, old alchemical workshop, outdoor cafe, magnificent cathedral, view of the city. Stunning.
Look for the hidden alleys and gardens. Forget the crowds. Stay on the perimeter of the castle. Walk the alleys and search for hidden gardens.

Great area. Castle District includes the entire area around Hradcani, the Prague Castle.I see people here writing about the Castle only (please see my separate review for that).The Castle district is famous for it's old streets and hidden alleys around the Castle hill, with many restaurants, cafes, art galleries, beer cellars,...It's an area you'll pass when going or coming back from the Castle itself. The area is very picturesque and not so crowded, specially the small, side, secluded alleys.

Worth the queueing . Be sure to have enough time. You can expect to be queuing for an hour to get through security to get into the area - but it'll be worth it. Inside you can buy combinations tickets - so you are free to choose if you want to see everything or nothing. I would recommend the B-tour which will give you the old castle, the cathedral, the goldworkers lane and the basilica. I especially loved the cathedral and the old castle.There are a few cafees inside the area, but don't expect too much of the food. And if it's cold it will be difficult to get a place to eat inside.
Stunning!. Wherever you go in Prague, the architecture is just amazing and this is a photographers dream. History just oozes out of it and you can watch the changing of the guard.

Castle District. Again, lots of shopping and walking but in the end it was well worth it. Prague, as a whole, is a very history-laden city. Catholicism is depicted everywhere you turn as there are churches and shrines in almost every corner.

Easy walk from Center City. I enjoyed strolling through the area eating in a gellato shop. A must see is the John Lennon Wall where students during Soviet occupation would post comments protesting the occupation. There are current political comments there.

Castle District Offers Great Souvenirs. We spent the whole day in the Castle District, there's lot to see and do, from small souvenirs shops to the beautiful castle. Make sure you take your own shopping bags, most shops are eco friendly and want to save trees! Wear comfortable shoes, and take an umbrella. It is very cold and lots of rain in March!
Beautiful area for a stroll. Lovely architecture, wonderful views, a truly nice area to stroll and look out over the city...and maybe stop for a pilsner somewhere and relax!
It Highlights the town.. Every time you look up you can see the castle, and church. They dominate the horizon. The security lines are huge but move relatively quickly. Its worth the wait.

Lots to See. We were on a river cruise and the views and history were just outstanding. Looking down from the castle the views were excellent. Again, you must do it with a tour so you get the full story.

good walk down hill. Stayed on the number 22 tram to brusnice -dont be put off by the few shops and cafes -stay on the right hand side past the goverment building (bar opposite has a lovely viewpoint across the valley to the viewing tower) and just keep wandering down . Arrived at the castle for the changing of the guard (12 noon exactly)well worth watching . Vantage point of the bar on the corner is supposedly the best in prague -cant argue -down the steps and back into the little quarter. Took our time and it lasted at least 2hrs .
Very unique in Prague. The Castle district is what Prague is all about. Should not be missed as it is very interesting, lots of history there.
Great walk. Not a walk for the faint of heart but if you persevere there are many rewards! Try walking to the monastery for a beer- great vistas on route.

Another must see in Budapest. The Castle District can be seen from across the river and the best way to reach it is on foot by crossing Charles Bridge and straight up through the main street which is lined with interesting shops and eateries. The Castle District is crammed full of interesting buildings and entry into the Castle grounds is free although you need to purchase a ticket to view many of the interiors of the buildings. Allow about 4 hours to see everything that the ticket covers. For those that cannot manage the climb up the hill you can take a tram which does not go up the main street but goes round and up the the side of the hill. So much to see, so little time so we had to go twice and still did not see everything.
Real hilly. Castle district nice but not for people with walking disabilities . very steep hills and slidey . there's a lot bikes and electric segways around so be careful .

Enter from the rear. The line for the security check from main Hradschin Square into the castle district is usually massive. Better to enter from the Belvedere to the northeast or the Stary zam schiody, a stairway into the Bastion in the east. The St. Vitus Cathedral is big, but on a European scale not particularly interesting. In order to understand the importance of the the Old Royal Palace you need to know a lot about Central European and Czech history. Be advised that one or the other (or the Basilica of St. George) can be closed arbitrarily and without warning.

Lovely but crowded. Security has been recently added and, if you are not there right when it opens, you can wait for 30-45 minutes to get in. Our savvy guide knew where to go that the lines were not so long but it was a longer walk. We were told that late afternoon is better, probably because the school kids, of which there were many, many, were gone. Still worth it. St V is extraordinary. Beautiful views and enjoy the quiet gardens which surround the castle after you are finished.
Lovely place with great view of city and river. Great walk with lovely structures.View from top of the city and river down are just great.Many eateries and bars and shops.
Amazing history and views. Worth the walk. The district has a hundred fun shops and restaurants. Make sure to tour the history of the castle and not just the cathedral.

Simply fairy tale material!. The castle area is stunning to see from all around the city. We took tram 22 to the castle and walked back down, which was pretty easy. We got some great photos of the grapevines in the foreground with the entire city in the background. This is a must-do attraction while in Prague.

A must visit. I like that you could purchase a ticket based on how much of the castle complex you wanted to visit. The views from the castle grounds are amazing and worth the visit alone but don't miss St. Virus Cathedral. St. George Basilica is also beautiful in its own right.

astonoshing place. view is astonishing, people are very friendly, helpful and respectful, some people say they are racist, but I do not agree with them, I always received help from people, they are nice people
Must go there. This is a wonderful area. So much ATMOSPHERE !! Views are wonderful. Don't forget the market area - and have some food and drink there !!

Wonderful buildings, all within easy reach of each other.. We spent a whole day around the Castle Hill, as there is so much to see. You need to go through security to get in, which included the southern gardens. The northern Royal Gardens are separate, but even here there are police casually checking everyone going in. The highlight has to be St.Vitus Cathedral. Tickets can be bought just inside the 1st courtyard, for different groups of buildings. The entrance to St.Vitus is free, but to have a good look all round the interior, you need a ticket.
A must see. It's a long walk uphill or by steps but it is worth it. The views of the city are fantastic from there. Lots of nice pictures can be taken.

So much to See. Walk up the hill and see this great area, there is the castle, the changing of the guard at 12 noon, it is where the president lives, there is the cathedral and the golden row. Buy your tickets based on what sites you want to see. Also no the name of your hotel for the audio guide or you can use the Rick Steves guide which we did which worked very well

Another great area of Prague.. Use another bridge to approach the area other than Charles Bridge. The bridges either side have equally great views and the walk along the river once on the other side is very pleasant. Once in the castle approach area there is loads to see and do including lots of quirky bars and restaurants.

Good history, must see. Definitely a must if visiting Prague for longer then 2 days. Offers great cultural knowledge and also has nice quaint shops and cafeterias. I also saw some small hotels for anyone wishing to spend a night.

So Many People, So Much Hype. The Castle District and Castle Complex is very crowded. Just walking across the Charles Bridge is close to overwhelming. I found that using the next bridge north, the Manesuv most, to be more pleasant. To get to the castle complex itself you have a couple of options. Because the President lives in the complex, there is significant security and you need to think strategically about getting in. Near the Malostranska tram stop (six different trams stop here) you can walk up a long, but not steep, series of stairs. There is seldom a security back up on this route. Tram 22 will drop you off at "up the hill" at Prazsky hrad where these is a main entrance to the complex and lines could be 1 hour long--or 2 minutes--hard to figure. You can stay on the tram one stop further to Brusnice and follow U Brusnice (cross the street and head sort of south) to the main palace entrance--could also be ridiculously crowded. Or, if you are following U Brusnice, look for a green area on your left before you get near the palace. There will be a guard and some steps down into a garden. The guard will check you out--open backpack, wand for metals, etc.--and then let you enter the garden which will take you, in less than five minutes, right into the main castle complex by a cafe. Go figure--so easy. So--go through the garden or up the steps--avoid the lines. Once "inside" you need to decide what to do--and much of it costs money. St. Vitus is interesting. Once when I walked by it was closed for a church service, the second time there were hundreds of people in line, the third time I just walked in and was able to ogle the stained glass and surroundings as long as I wanted. You only need to pay if you want to do a serious circuit around the whole church. If you are a Mucha fan, the Mucha stained glass is on the left as you face the altar--the third one in from the ropes that keep the non-paying sightseers from the main part of the church. Easy to see and there were several other fairly modern stained-glass windows that are really interesting. You will not see the famed Golden Lane without paying--they have an actual turnstile!

Lovely Place to Walk Around. Wear a good pair of walking shoes (the ascent to the castle is a bit steep in places and the cobblestone in Prague can be difficult to walk on) and cross the bridge to explore this area. There are wonderful shops, cafés, churches and buildings to enjoy along the way to the castle on the top. Make sure you stop at one of the little bakeries to watch Trdenik "chimney cake" being made and then sample some with a variety of fillings to choose from. It was not as good as we thought but it was fun to try this Prague specialty. The castle itself is enormous and still guarded; walking around outside is free but there is a price to enter the castle. We got there too late to go in but just in time to enjoy a parade marking 700 years of the coronation of the King. It began at the castle and went all the way to the old town square across the Charles Bridge.

Another historical place to visit in Prague.. Great location across the Vitara river.In good water a great place to visit by walk. (cross Charles Bridge) from Old Town.You have an option to go to the top by using the public stairs. ( a lot of then). You need to be in good physical condition.A great view of the Old town, the river, and many shops and restaurants to visit.Safe to walk.
Lovely architecture. Went on a tour in September and loved the city. Hope the other several thousands did as well! Everyone got along well but aren't the Chinese rude and noisy.

Enjoyable Sight and Surrounding. The castle has various program in encouraging visitors to see the important sites of their interest. However the complex is relatively large and lacking highlight in order to motivate the majority of tourists is the problem. We did our tour of the place from the exterior without entering into the interior. We came away without any strong impression of the whole district.

Highly enjoyable walk. We wandered on our own through the Castle District and we loved it! We did go late in the day and some of the sites/shops within the castle were closed, but we had a lot of fun walking around and the church inside is beautiful! Wish we could have gone inside, but have lovely exterior pictures.
Fabulous buildings and views.. The views of the city are amazing from the castle, trams are great to take you there. Lovely old buildings and many churches.

Good Afternoon Stroll. This area is less touristed than crowded Old Town so it is a nice break from the heavier crowds for an afternoon walk. Beautiful architecture and plenty to see. The castle admission is worth it completely if you have the time! Also check out the Lennon wall while on that side of the bridge.
Excellent for photos. Prague is a magnificent city to just walk and take lots of photos. The cobble stone lanes and markets are a dream.

Alternatives to visiting the castle.. If you don't fancy standing in the heat to go through security or are on a budget there are other ways of exploring this district. Take the 22 Tram and enjoy the views as it climbs the hill on the western side of the city, get off at Pohorelec it's much easier way to the castle. Cross the road from the tram stop and wander down the cobblestoned street passing lovely shops en route, restaurants and bars, we even heard a choir practicing in one of the nearby building which sounded beautiful on the night air. En route is the Loreta Church and grounds, there is an entrance charge but a totally unacceptable photographic charge as well. Frankly don't pay it, just take the photos! Again there are beautiful artefacts and works of art representing the history and wealth of this particular order nof the Roman Catholic Church. By now you may be thirsty or hungry the Uzavesenyho Kafe has a cooling terrace to look over the city or towards Petrin Hill. Afterwards, duly fed and watered stroll down to the castle and marvel and the hundreds willing to stand in the baking sun to go into the grounds. There is a flight of stairs to the right and left of the food outlets that leads down to the old town area with fascinating shops en route. After a while it leads to Charles Bridge which to be honest is not worth the pushing and shoving during the day.

amazing walk مكان رائع للمشي والتقاط الصور. أحببت المنطقة كثيراً ، صحيح هناك مشقة الصعود لأكثر من 200 درج ولكن المنظر يستحق اكثر من ذلك. تستطيع أن تشاهد مدينة براغ من الأعلى وأنت تحتسي قهوتك من ستاربكس الموجود على القمة. مكان جميل للمشي والتقاط أجمل الصور لمدينة براغ الساحرةI loved this experience although I had to climb 200 stairs but totally worth it. you can take the most beautiful pictures to the charming city from the top while having a coffee from Starbucks. nice walking area where easily you can spend two hours there

Remarkable. This was a remarkable place to be and to see. The buildings in the area were magnificent. The view from this area towards the center of the city is wonderful. This side of the city/river seemed much more attractive and visitor friendly that the other. The walk down to the river is well worth the time and effort.

Not to be missed. Our first day was to the castle and its surroundings. From the top, the scenic view of Prague is outstanding with all those famous landmarks around. Take an umbrella with you as the weather is quite unpredictable. The beautiful walk downhill towards the river is very rewarding in terms of quaint shops, views, coffee shops and the local scene. On your way down, use the side hand rails as the way down, over the pebbled roads and ways can be unstable and tricky.

Nice area. Anywhere around the castle is impressive, every building is different and there is so much history that goes with the city. You can either take a tour or wander around on your own. The cathedral in the centre of the castle dominates most photo opportunities as it is very spectacular. The streets are cobbled and the architecture is out of this world. Plenty of bars and restaurants and cafes in the area as well as parks and shops. A walk up to the castle area at the top involves 200 steps which is not for the faint hearted but you can take the tram if you wish.

Beautiful to walk around.. Lovely walk up to the castle and around the area from the large open square with the street entertainers to the walk up to the Monastry along the cobbled streets and beautiful archways with little shops and restaurants. Just lovely.
Incredible history. We rented audio guides so we could be independent of the very large walking tour groups. They were excellent. The whole area is amazing. Such interesting history and architecture.

Beautiful building, great views, better with a guide. We were lucky enough to have a private tour guide for a tout of Prage which I would recommend most highly. He told us about the history of the city over the centuries which made such a difference.

Spend at least a day. If you want to see even half of what it has to order come early, and do your home work on what is your intetst, loads of galeries and exhibitions, some at addible rate, we missed the actual Castle, so we'll have to come again

a great walk. Be sure to walk over one of the bridges to the Castle District. The scenery is really nice, and you see a variety of architecture. Also, once you cross into the park, you walk through an amazing apple and pear orchard.

The main thing to visit in Praque. The castle district with the castle is a must when you visit Praque.Take a guide because they can tell you a lot more about history and special things about the castle.It takes 2-3 hours for visiting everything there

Very Scenic. The Castle Grounds are Free to enter, and the Castle itself is beautiful to look at. There are lots of little shops etc within the castle that are worth a look although maybe a little over priced. The gardens surrounding the castle are also worth a look. Overall would recommend this if you're interested in the history or just like to look around new places.

Spend the day. There are gardens, castles, churches, palaces, restaurants. Don't rush through it. If you can spare the time buy the ticket that gets you in to all the buildings then when you think you are ready to go home....you find the garden. The garden is free and it's great to get views of not only the flowers but the views back to the castle.

Great to walk around even without castle tickets . We got there too late to get tickets to go inside any of the buildings, even though we were there 1:45 before closing time. So, we just walked around, took pictures, went into some shops. We took the #22 street car train up there and then took the stairs back down. You can go into the cathedral without a ticket and just look around from the back.

Castle District. Especially during sunny days and also at evening it is very nice to walk around.If outside temperature is fine it is also very nice to rent a boat on Vltava and enjoy view to Castle and rest of old city.
Beautiful Walk. A walk that is worth the experience, beautiful scenic surroundings, buildings people, faces, getting to live and taste the local culture. Life experience you won't forget.
Wonderful. This is the top of the heap! This is the section of town that overlooks the whole city. Here religion and politics are number one!
Stunning views from the castle. This is an absolute must! The scale of the castle and it's surrounding area is unbelievable. The views are simply amazing!
Lots to see. This district has many aspects - the cathedral, the squares, the buildings themselves. Easy to reach using public transit as well, but be prepared for walking inside the complex.
Very nice. Don't matter if you have to wait in a lane more than an hour! It deserves it! Beautiful! You can have lunch if you wish, there are nice places to do it. Lovely things to buy!
Beautiful area where you can wander for days. Stunning little hidden gems, gardens, buildings, churches etc. Great cafes and places to sit and take in the history or even just people watch. Stunning!
Beautiful beyond words. The big church has incredible stained glass windows. We also highly recommend the Lobkowicz Palace. Also, don't miss the gardens.

Great Place to wander. Lots going on here from great architecture, Castle Steps and plenty of places to eat and shop. Terrain is steep (best to catch bus of fenicular up) but a doddle to come down. Just impressed with the scale of everytjhing and the views out over the city.

Prague visit 2015. We have been to Prague before and loved it so we returned to stay at the Jurys Inn in November to see a concert.The staff in the hotel could not do enough for you, and the hotel was big and beautiful with a huge dining area that was very up to date First class would stay again, and it is handy for the City Centre. One word of cation though, do not use the under ground if you do not have your wits about you as we had an accident on an escalator which was going well in excess of the speed it should have been, very dangerous, not like Britain at'll.
Cool Castle. Had a nice stay in Prague and made it up to the castle to check it out. Really cool place and has a lot of history. A must do activity in Prague

It's a must.... When you're in Prague it's a must to go here. Last time was 3 years ago. The security check takes now a long time. Last time there wasn't but of course time changed and the risk is high. Sadly all over the world nowadays the psychos. So please be patient and calculate a long time for queueing.
Fascinating. What a city, the architecture and the colors of the buildings take your breath, you will enjoy every moment there.

Worth a visit. Wear appropriate footwear to climb the hilly streets leading to the castle district. Can be slightly slippery with flip flops as the ground is smooth cobble stone.Surrounded by original and beautiful architecture, the castle district is worth the climb.Unfortunately, we missed the opening time to visit the castle itself (closes at 5pm daily), but were able to visit the castle complex. Not much to say except that it was large and a little interesting with the gothic architecture that was the church (that we saw from the outside), within the castle complex.

Great way to spend a day. A highlight of Prague that you must see. We didn't do so during our previous visit. One important tip is to go early as they have security checks in place now on entering the castle and these take quite some time to get through.

Lovely shops and gruesome chamber. The shops where goldsmiths had worked have been made into very attractive shops where hand made items are for sale. Such wares are also available in town, but this is a nice shopping experience. On the second floor is a huge exhibit of medieval armor and a small collection of instruments of torture which everyone lined up to see.

Interesting. Prague Castle is very interesting, and you can catch the change of the guards at certain times. The walk down the hill is also interesting and you end up at Charles Bridge and then into the old Town area.

Only One Word: I LOVE this place!!. D epic view of Prague city..& only one of few places where you can see humans :PLove this place!from here you can also visit St. Vitus Cathedral church as it is near by...

Huge. This castle complex is huge and will take at least half a day to walk around. The views from the top are great and the buildings are full of history. Visiting during the day means it is full of tourist groups and crowds so try to visit off peak if you want to get the best pictures.

Romantic walking. This area is beautiful. We were there in the end of august, but the weather was a little bit rainy. We went there on foot, and loved the walking in the little cozy streets. Imposing buildings, many sights... so if you are there, take enough time (hours) for it!

A highlight and deservedly so. This is huge - the biggest castle in the world and you can really believe it. It's a town really. with so much history packed it. I wish I had read up about the Hasburgs beforehand because of their role in the development of the city.
Pretty area surrounding Prague Castle. We walked along the river from our hotel to this area. Like a lot of Prague, it is a mixture of beautiful buildings and parkland. Well worth seeing.

Beautiful city. If your going to Prague, you'll have a ball. The city is stunning, with beautiful building full of history, statues and eating places.
Enjoy

Terrific. Wander the quaint streets, and admire the vista from the top of this old, fortified castle. It is quite a climb, and those with weight problems, or mobility issues will find this tough going.
Lovely place to walk.. We found this a lovely place to walk around with the gardens, the castle and Golden Lane. I loved Golden lane and found it quite fascinating and charming in equal measure.

Best views in town. If you want to visit the castle or the gardens, come early since the lines are long. And don't forget to visit the monastery up the street, god food and beer with the best views in town.

Lovely in the Early Morning. The castle district has a very different feel than Old Town Prague. It's crowded, but not as crowded as Old Town. It's possible to rent a car/driver to take you around, but if you're up for it, I would suggest walking. You'll run into many beautiful little streets and there is a lot to see; Hradčanské Námestí, the charming square, Prague Castle and the Palace Gardens (heading down from the Castle), Basilica of St. George, St. Vitus, The Loreta, Cernin Palace, Loreta Square, John Lennon Wall, multiple charming restaurants and on and on and on. I don't feel you've seen Prague if you haven't walked around the Castle District.

The biggest castle complex in all of Europe!. This place is incredible! A vast complex of buildings and palaces, dominated by the beautiful St. Vitus cathedral. We did not go into all the attractions, it would need at least a day! It is wonderful to wander around the courtyards and gardens and to enjoy th wonderful views back across to the old centre and the river.

take the walk. you should visit Prague step by step
visit this district no matter what, you will like to walk the streets

Just walk and soak it in. It is nice to get across any one of the bridges that take you over from Old town... too crowded to the castle district. It is a bit quieter here... at least during my visit and there is still a lot to see. Walk up the hill to the castle area and see the great view overlooking the city. Stop in shops or walk the riverfront and back streets. The flavour here is a bit different on this side of the river and there are many attractions, museums, etc to see.
a days visit. best to take a day to visit the castle district. It's beautiful and immense. And don't forget the golden street

Go early when it is cool, I walked there from Hilton Old Town, it is amazing. Many quaint shops and restaurants. Amazing architecture and a big slice of European history. It is as much fun to watch the people as it is to sight see. Once the guided tours get there, it becomes crowded in a hurry. If you are going to the castle, take the time to explore here

Would not miss it for the world .... So much to see and do here and it is best when it could be enjoyed at leisure. Fortunately, this time we were able to do just that. We did not stand on lines to get into the Castle. We have seen it all many times before and in every season. So what do we do there since we have seen it all ? We enjoy the gardens that surround the palaces, eat in the great restaurants, stop for coffee and cake often and look for the ones with the views.We watch the Changing of the Guard ceremony. Visiting the Strahov Monastery and the Library is always on our list. The numerous Palaces, for a concert or an art exhibition. Drink the oh, so good and cold monastery beer.. visit the Cathedral in the morning.Listen to Loreto bells. We stroll in the Zlata Ulicka after most tourist are gone....We like the many different ways to get to the Castle. From Petrin, or Nerudova street or Pohorelec and the Novy Svet route. Even if you don't have time to see every attraction, enjoy the architecture and all the beauty that surrounds you, the amazing views... I love to return to this beautiful part of Prague.I would not miss it for the world....

A Lovely and Historic District of the Old Prague. While the Prague Castle complex occupies almost half of the entire district and is understandably the main attraction, it is by far not the only place worth visit in this historic district.The Strahov Monastery (founded in 1143) houses an exhibition of paintings in its picture gallery among other works of art.The Schwarzenberg Palace and the Sternberg Palace are part of the National Gallery in Prague, which has its collection scattered throughout several places in Prague. Both are beautiful palaces that exhibit large collections of art.But the hidden gem of this district is Novy Svet (New World). This little picturesque narrow street with small houses has preserved it's unique character. While the Prague Castle and its immediate surroundings were packed with loud crowds of tourists, we were the the only people in this quiet and almost hidden part of the Castle District.There is also the Loreta, with the clock tower and the famous chime, and the Church of St. John of Nepomuk, but I did not have the chance to enter those. But even without them - I had a great few hours spent without even entering the castle.
So much to see!. The castle district includes the church and it covers a large area. Recommend a guided tour - we did it with the Hop On/Hop Off bus.

Worth a visit. Lovely views when you reach the top, quite a climb but there is a tram ( line 22 ) that will take you up. Impressive buildings ( St Vitus Catherdral / Archbishops palace ) we didn't pay for the tour but you can go into some parts of the Catherdral, watch the Changing of the Guard and stroll around the courtyards.

Attractive. The areas and the attractions you can visit freely is limited. If you are willing to pay and enter, there are lot of things you can see and enjoy. You can see the town from a nice view from the castle as well. Worth climbing up
Will be worth the queue wait. Personally I loved this part of Prague the most, but yes, you will probably end up waiting quite a while before you get to enter.

Hop On Hop Off - Castle Tour. Our tour guide was wonderful, except I have forgotten her name! She helped us navigate the long line up and explained the very basic history and some unique features of the Castle. She explained how the different political situations have given rise to some interesting generational perspectives in Czech Republic. She also gave us a mini- lesson in Czech with a small card of frequently used words. VERY HELPFUL. If you can add her name to my description I would be grateful.
Nothing much to see. this place looks good only from charles bridge rest is just an average city view for some clicks according to me

The best part of the city. Still very busy during the day but at night there's great restaurants, wine bars and pubs to visit.Plenty to do during the day with lots of shops and cafes. The walk up to Strahov Monestry via Charkes Bridge is an excellent walk. Once finished there's a walk up to Petrin Tower and some lovely gardens together with th observatory. A slow walk through the gardens down the hill makes for a really lovely day.
Top notch. The castle district is a must for visitors. Very crowded but great buildings and plenty of space. You can imagine what medieval Prague was like.

Worth a visit. Even though there was a long queue to get in the castle district, it was worth it. Nice architecture and lovely place to wonder around. When you leave the castle take the vineyard path - it has a better view to the city and also less busy!

A Great Day out. What a great day from walking upto the castle from the Bridge. The Castle district was spread over the top of the city. All the buildings are worth a visit, I climbed the steps (370) of the South tower to the top for wonderful view's over Prague. Try some of the small cafes and take a walk back down to the river via the back exit.

Fantastic Views from on top. If you take the tram up --- which you need to do if you cannot physically walk up a steep street of cobblestones --- you'll need to walk to the other side of the castle grounds to look over the old town. Fantastic views! The castle grounds are lovely, but walk back down the winding cobble stone street from this side of the castle. It's such a quaint, lively street of pubs and shops, and at the bottom you'll find yourself at the Charles Bridge.

Avoid hills get tram 22 no need of cab!. Walking down the hill is easier. Prague is in hills maps won't show there is more of them than bridges seventeen or so, therefore I recommend to take a tram 22 to station Pohorelec and then zig zag down to castle then to Charles bridge and across to Old town it takes less than hour easy stroll. There is plenty things to be seen and also places to take a rest

Well worth a slow wander . We loved walking around Lesser Town between the Castle and the river. There are some fascinating artisans shop and galleries along with beautiful buildings and parks. The area was much less crowded than up near the castle.

Hradcany - The Castle District. Probably the biggest castle in the world. It's history goes back to the 9th century. There are several historical palaces and St.Vitus Cathedral - founded in 930. Come to see the place in the evening (it is not crowded and you can enjoy a special atmosphere).

Fantastic Views - Mind the hills. The castle district in Prague is a truly unique and breathtaking area that will have you wandering the streets absorbing the atmosphere for hours. With the castle, St Vitius cathedral and views of the red tiled rooftops of Mala Strana this really is an area I'd plan to spend at least half a day in to admire.Do be sure to wear decent footwear as some of the streets are traditionally cobbled and there are plenty of hills (how else would you get great views!)

Lovely to wander around.. But lots of hills! . The castle and district is breathtaking. It looks beautiful at dusk all lit up. There are some big hills and steps to climb so not for the faint hearted! Find the medieval tavern on castle steps it has a great atmosphere and a mean beer! Just don't be startled when they bash the glass down on the table! The prices of food and drink are slightly cheaper here. We found a great place to eat and drink opposite St Nicolas Church. Go to the toilets and get to wander down to the old cellars where they made their own beer. Definitely a worthy visit.
Amazing. Best part of the city. You can spend almost your whole day in the castle district. It is also recommended to go back in the evening.

Cannot leave this city without seeing it. Full of nice architecture, history, splendid views. It might be crowded, but so is the Eiffel Tower and still it would be considered an absurd not to see it when you visit the city.

Wonderful history, great guide, interesting setting. That pretty well summarizes it. For history sake, I'm glad we visited Prague first before St Stephen's in Passau and Melk Cathedral. It seems King Leopold was mentioned everywhere we went.

Wonderful place.. This is an excellent spot to observe history, explore the little alley ways and get incredible views of Prague from elevation. We bought plenty of paintings up there .. this is a must visit spot.

Up hill walk from Charles Bridge. Interesting complex, castle forecourt had street performers --King, Jester and Knight.St. Vitus cathedral was free, other buildings in the large complex were a charge.Views were fantastic! Great overview of the city.Some shops and restaurants were outside of the complex

Just explore the Castle district. It is beautiful with all the Embassies, the beautiful houses, nice little shops, cafes and restaurants. If you want to have a lunch or dinner try to go away from the main streets and you will find some nice places!
Wonderful historical complex. Very nice and monumental buildings castle. A fine example of the ideal of the Czech architecture. Wonderful views from the terraces.

Wonderful Day Touring. This is such a beautiful part of Prague with many attractions, restaurants, shops, and exhibits. We were lucky enough to be able to enjoy a regional native dancing festival with dancers from all over Europe (Spain to Finland).
Steep climb and full of cafes. You won't go hungry in the castle district! Almost every other store is a cafe or sovenier shop. The road is steep and cobbled so be prepared for some exercise!!
crowded, but beatiful. The district is crowded during july, but during the offseason it could be more magical. the parks surrounding the district are a nice place to escape the heat.
Beautiful Charles Bridge. This area is visually stunning. Charles bridge and the surrounding buildings, bars, restaurants and atmosphere are amazing. This is my first choice area for Prague.

Huge area with lot of historical buildings. You can spend hours here to walk around and look at old buildings that were created either as a part of the castle or build to support the castle. Obviously a lot of the buildings has been restored and expanded, but imagining all this 4-600 years ago is just amazing.I suggest researching a lot about this area before going there to get a better insight to what went on in this area.

Beautiful. Lovely and peaceful area of Prague. A trip to the top where the castle is is achievable on foot and there is plenty to see on the way. Look out for the eateries with a view, including a Starbucks next to the castle with an outside terrace.

The Castle District - a great walking tour. Map out your day using Rick Steve's walking tour guide. It is a day activity. Your will see the Castle, historic buildings, the Strahov Monastery and the Loreto Church.

Better value than other areas in Prague. Depending on where you are the district its probably not as picturesque as other parts of Prague, that said its far better value and there is some excellent restaurants here. Worth considering here for lunch.

Another Beautiful Castle. It is worth going to the Castle District if for no other reason than the views of Prague. Also there are several nice little places to get lunch and a glass of wine or the local beer. If you want to go inside the castle get their early as the lines can get VERY long!

The Castle District side of Prague. This side of the Vltava River is less traveled than the Old town side and can be quiet in parts if you venture off the beaten path.There are many sites to see and if you go to top of the area into the hills there are amazing views of Prague!!

A wonderful part of the beautiful city of Prague.. This is a real must see if you are on vacation in Prague. You can walk around in this part of the city for days and find new and gorgeous houses and streets, and lovely restaurants and interesting places all the time.

The Castle is beautiful. but the services to accommodate thousands of people are so poor. What would it take to have drinking water fountains with a tap and a splash pad to cool feet for little kids and elders to refresh. Selling bottled water is good for business of only two restaurants available. But really this is a top of the Czech country, place where czechs can show off to the whole world.

Castle District. We walked up to the Castle District and loved our way up. We are over 65 and we found the walk easy. Go slowly, know your way, stop and smell the roses. We did take a trolley back down. Another day we took the trolley / bus up to the Castle District, explored a different area and walked back down. Probably better to Trolley up and walk down.

Worth a visit!. Historic cobblestone streets with beautiful buildings, shops and eateries. I spend almost an entire day exploring the area while discovering some beautiful subjects to photograph apart from the main attractions. Make sure to wear comfortable shoes because walking on uneven cobblestones can be a challenge. When you get to the Castle, you'll get a stunning view over the red roofed city. There is also a daily changing of the guards at the Castle which is worthwhile waiting for.There are many ways to getting there and the cheapest one would be the tram. I was advised to take tram 22 that takes you all the way up to the Castle in case you don't feel like climbing the hill.
Picturesque. The gardens within the Castle District are stunning! Little mazes of gardens with fountains, animals and lovely buildings.

Excellent! Step back in time!. You can easily spend a day or two discovering all that this area has to offer. The view of the city is wonderful from several of the cafes. The optional accompanying audio tour is worth purchasing when you tour the area inside of the castle grounds. Such history and architecture!
Really nice walk. Really nice walk across the river and in the district itself.Very Crowded but worth it! There's a Franz Kafka museum nearby

Put on your walking shoes. It you have the energy you can walk for miles and not get bored by all the attraction. Gardens, historical buildings, churches, the river and many restaurants and beer houses. To name all the attractions is impossible. Start early and be prepared to take it slowly to experience the beauty of history, culture and preservation. Impossible to get bored !

Another must-see mob scene. The castle and its neighborhood are must-see places, with interesting views and deep history. That attracts other tourists, who make maneuvering challenging. The area is quite touristy, but not so much as to interfere with a walk through. It's hard to criticize Prague for its great history and success as a destination. You just have to accept it as the price of admission.

Great day for a walk. We got the tour bus up to the castle from the centre of town and walked back, what a great day. The castle tour was very good we learnt so much about the history of the castle and town. The walk back to the town centre was exhausting but well worth it.

Worth the climb. The only downside to this visit is the numbers of people trying and vying for the same space. I visited on a wet day and it was bus. You do need a bit of time and some patience to visit this attraction, I saw it very busy in the morning and a little quieter I the afternoon.

Overrated and way over popped w tourists!. Only a glimpse of castle, cannot enter. Long lines of pushy line cutting tourists. Americans, Brits and Aussies of the most courteous and line respecting group. Stay away in July and August at all costs. Prague is great to visit - maybe June, Sept or October.
Great. another place you don't have to miss when you are in Prague cause these Castle is another place of interest and so nice in and out I recomend it
Always fun to stroll around. The entire Castle District is a jewel, and even if you don't go inside a single palace, church or other building, just walking around will make you smile.

A must do when in Prague. The castle district on the high ground above the town is an area not to be missed on any tourist itinerary. It offers excellent vantage points over which to view Prague, and has a fair amount of history associated with establishment and ongoing management of Prague. The changing of the guard at the castle is a regular activity, and worth waiting for. Its a lovely walk down from the castle area through the small vineyard area to the river and 'lower' Prague

One of the best places in Prague. Amazing view from the top of the hill. Castle district is the main attraction in Prague, with lot of opportunities to watch. There are few restaurants as well, but bit pricey. Do not miss the beautiful gardens and the Jeleni prikop. There is a nice gallery close to the castle as well full of the medieval pictures and sculptures.

beautiful view. easy to spend a few hours wondering around this lovely area. Everyone should wonder up to the top and see that wonderful view across prague city - day or night you will be impressed. Watch the sunset if you can! Great architectural throughout the area!
WHAT A BEAUTIFUL VIEW.. It's just like the brochures - fabulous. Take plenty of photos, absorb the atmosphere, people watch to your heart's content. One of the highlights of our tour.
Amazing views. Amazing views of an amazing city. The castle district has many architectural marvels of its own, but also offers a fabulous view of the city. A must!

Lovely architecture quiet and very interesting . This part of the city has a complete different vibe than the one around the old town square but still very interesting and it's lovely to stroll around see the great buildings, palaces, churches and have a local beer and visit the castle. I really enjoyed it

Must see. Amazing area of the castle-so many different things to see from all areas of life during this time. Especially loved the tiny houses and torture chamber along with all the weapons on display .

Must Go. This is the part of Prague that provides the most beautiful panorama views of the city. The Bohemian architecture is put on display - front and center - which allows you to see why Prague is considered one of Europe's most breathtaking destinations. Without a doubt one of the most important spots to hit while here.
Beautifull castel. A lot of history and wery beautifull castel complec. we went by segways and i was a great experienc for the whole famile.

Loved the castle district!. We were staying on the Old Town side of the river and didn't get to the castle district until our third day in Prague. Wow! Loved the cobblestone streets and the cafes and the views from the hillside. There are so many things to do here. We took the funicular up to the top and saw the locals call their Eiffel tower. We didn't go up but instead, we wandered the upper gardens and visited the cloister, then went to the castle. We missed the changing of the guard at noon and on the hour, but we've heard the noontime change is well worth it. Going inside the palace grounds is free, but you must have a ticket to enter many of the buildings. You can go into the church for free but you are limited to a small area without a ticket.
Awesome Place. The Castle Complex is the biggest of its kind in Europe and absolutely worth seeing. The Golden Lane is cute, but overcrowded at daytime. Go there after 5pm.

Walk 'til you drop. Starting from Old Town, heading over the Vlata River and into the castle district, you can find so many interesting sights in this area. Views from the tower (a replica and design of Eiffel in Paris) over the hills into the city are spectacular before sunset. St. Vitas' Cathedral, other churches, palaces, and gardens offer insight into the height of old world craftsmanship and design.

There's a lot to see!. We decided to walk from our hotel in Wenceslas Square to the Castle Complex via the Charles (Karluv) Bridge. It's a long walk, and the hill is quite steep. The streets are not very well marked, and the way is winding and confusing at times. The maps we had were not so great either. If you walk, plan to spend the whole day doing this. When we got to the top (complex) we had a very hard time finding some of the places mentioned in our guide book. A ticket is required for visiting the interiors of the buildings in the castle complex. By the time we figured out where we were, we chose to just wander around the streets and gardens, which are charming enough. We stopped at one of the small cafes for cappuccino and cheesecake, which were quite respectable in spite of the plain surroundings of the cafe. It is possible to enter the cathedral without paying an entry fee, but going further in requires purchasing a ticket. A quick look was enough for us. I was disappointed not to have time to visit the National Gallery exhibitions at two of the palaces in the complex, but we simply did not have enough time, and were worn out by the walk. The sheer scale of the complex is daunting. I would recommend taking the tram instead (#22 from Old Town) and expecting to spend the better part of a day there. This is an impressive place, but time, planning, and energy are required.

DON'T MISS THIS!. It would be a shame to visit Prague and NOT see the Castle District! Gorgeous and chocked full of interesting history! It gets extremely crowded in the summer months so go early if you're visiting during peak tourist season.
Lots to do . Lots to do. Lots of cafes, bars and restaurants. Shops. There are also gardens to visit with free walking peacocks wandering around. Just go.

Great place to visit.. We walked up the hill to get to the castle district. There is plenty of buildings to visit whilst up here. You can buy tickets up the top, depending on what buildings you want to visit. Spent half a day up here.
Quite Hilly. You cannot beat the architecture in this whole city. This district doesn't disappoint you either. Go off the beaten path. You will find some hidden gems.

Cultural Immersion!. The Castle District of Prague has been one of my favourite locations throughout all my European travels, the number of boutique stores, merchants, food venders, dessert stores and a grand myriad of other stores are just the beginning of your journey. The whole walk to the hill top, and castle / cathedral once at the end of your walk is a marvel of Czech Architecture, and is definitely the cherry to top off a wonderful experience.

Amazing!!!. One of the most beautifull area in Prague. The view is amazing! You can see all the city with the Moldava river with the beauty bridges! Excellent area for photos and to enjoy a coffee, meal and dinner! At night time, the whole area is fantastic!

Confusion of architecture. Castle district seems built in early middle ages, cathedral is Gothic, rest of the city seems to be built in Cold War.. Maybe it's because of the movies I felt this way. Obvious discrepancy and dilemma of architecture as you see in the picture..

Well worth the visit. If you don't visit here, you have not seen Prague. It's that simple. It's a long way up (seemingly not as far down - I wonder why?), particularly on a hot and humid day. But well worth the trip. Take it you won't regret it.

Fabulous Views. We took the long route across the river via Jiraskuv bridge near the Dancing House: this let us walk up Petrin Hill and see the amazing views from the hillside. Taking in the Strahov Monastery on the way down to the castle district. The castle district was very busy and would take a full day to really explore, but we enjoyed the spectacular buildings and the stunning views.

Lovely walk , beautiful area and jam packed tram travel ideal for pick pockets. The local guided tours are recommended. The guide has a good sense of humour, Will warn you of pick pockets, but you will still lose your money. So, don't carry passports & money etc etc.specially when you are in the tram going up to the castle & the cathedral. Enjoy the monastery brewed beer, relax & walk around, take lots of photographs. Enjoy the weather too. Walk back to down town via Charles bridge, enjoy the sight of markets & wind up with a beer, before setting out for dinner after resting a bit
Good panorama from the Castle District. On our tour of Prague we were taken through the Castle District. It is a beautiful part of Prague. It has a good panorama of the city.

Castle Visit. We visited the castle over 2 days, day one with a guide and day 2 we purchased the audio guide to visit the inside of the cathedral. I would recommend getting their early to avoid the bus tours. Well worth the visit and lost to see

A great vintage point. A good place to visit to have a peak in the castle as well as the view of the entire city on a clear day... Quite a bit of steep climb but the view is magical from up there.... For viewing the castle, there is surely a long que...
Wonderful. A very beautiful area nice for walk in every time of the day. The panorama to the city is wonderful.
Nice place. It's all about the architecture here, some of the buildings in this district are very impressive. Worth visiting this district.

A Must See in Prague!. Definitely enjoyed our time here. While it was busy with tourists, it wasn't so "touristy" as some of the other parts of the city. Beautiful architecture, great history, definitely recommend!
So much to see. There's an endless amount do things to see here. Small shops, grand cathedrals, nice restaurants, amazing views. Don't miss this. Bring comfy shoes, it's kind of steep at places.

Views, history, charming.. We did this as part of a tour and are so glad we did. Beginning with a short walking tour, we took the number 22 tram up the hill (hard work if you are walking) and alighted at the entrance to the Castle precinct. St Vitus in all it's glory was our first stop then a charming tour through the old historic area and museums behind it before exploring monastries, memorials, parliament buildings, cafes and even the doors to a building used during the filming of the movie "Armadeus". Our teens were most suitably impressed also on this tour.Prior to leaving the castle precinct, we took in glorious views of the City of Prague and the Vlatava River before winding our way back down the hillside on foot to the Charles Bridge and a further exploration of this magic City. A must for any visitor to Prague

Fascinating . The castle district is definitely worth an afternoon in Prague. Really beautifully landscaped and so culturally rich. There are clearly marked signposts and easy to follow. Do remember to bring change with you as all toilets have a charge to enter. Otherwise, really lovely!

IF YOU VISIT THE CASTLE, STROLL AROUND THE AREA. We did the castle tour and then decided to stroll this area on the way to St. Charles bridge. Historical Prague and streets and shops around the castle. Very nice and there is always something going on.

Worth a visit – plan on spending a 1/2 day!. The best way to reach the Castle District is to take a tram — otherwise you are climbing upwards for a long time! The Prague Castle is actually made up of a bunch of buildings (monestaries, parliament building, etc) so its a great area to walk around and explore.

Interesting enough !. Gets really nice when you get off the grid and take the little lanes mostly used by the locals. Charming vibe and a lot nicer than the busy main streets overrun by hordes of tourists and Segway tours.
A MUST!. One of the places that you need to spend time in Prague is this place. Here is where you will find St. Vitus Cathedral, Prague Castle and other attractions all in one place.

Loved walking around the castle grounds. Definitely worth visiting, but be sure to be prepared to walk a lot, the complex is massive. The grounds are stunning and there is plenty to see whilst walking around
A Beautiful Spot Not to Be Missed. When in Prague, Just Do It! By foot, tram, Uber but get here and enjoy this magnificent area. Way less crowded than Old Town & Charles Bridge.

Back to old time. When you actually walking along the streets in the castle district, you wouldn't think that it's 21st Century, coz all the buildings and stony streets were so well preserved. Be careful not to wear any high-heel when walking in those streets (unless u r very skillful )
Best views of Prague. The area surrounding the Prague Castle and Cathedral is home to many historic landmarks such as the Golden Lane. Its a must visit area in the city.
Prague is beautiful. The castle district is adorable. I kept wondering if it was fake like being at disney world! It is so worth a visit.

You just have to!. This must be the best area in Prague and historical quarters around and with the castle. You can make a small walk or several and still explore new alleys and roads and shops. Very nice and there is always something going on. But you won't be alone.

A beautiful place. It's a great place to enjoy a nice morning at. You should start from the top of the place and walk around till you get to the castle, you get to see the old city around it with the church and have a bit of history of the royal family that goes with it. If you're there around noon I believe you get to see the change of the guards with the whole ceremony and band. Short but nice to see. The view is breath taking of the entire city from the top, and then you go down the stairs and if you want you can take the metro back to the other side of the river.

Magic.. I enjoy nothing more than jumping the trusty tram number 22 up to the castle area and just marvel at the great architecture and take in the history of this amazing district of Prague. The Strahov Monastery is superb and it's so nice wandering around the grounds and just escaping from the crowds of the Old Town,in the monastery they also have a great brew pub were you can sample their delicious beer and have a traditional Czech meal.Walking down the Golden Mile and the narrow streets are packed with pubs, bars and restaurants but be aware of some of these as they will rip you off,if no prices are displayed on the menu card then avoid as you will inadvertably be had away.That said some of the restaurant's are superb and although a tad more expensive are well worth going to.The architecture is awesome and if your into taking photographs your in the correct area.A great area of Prague and one I highly recommend you visit on any holiday to this amazing city.

While Visiting Prague Castle --there are other Castles to View. A beautiful place to see other castles---an easy to see and view at least from the outside beautiful structures sharing the same hilltop as the Prague Castle.

Great sights. Prague's Castle District occupies a hillside overlooking the city, offering great views and photo opportunities. Saint Vitus Cathedral is a MUST see with its gothic architecture and stained glass windows! A tour of the district took us roughly 3 hours, but it included St Vitus, the Golden Alley, and watching the changing of the guards. There are multiple photo opportunities throughout. We ended our tour with a short walk over to Strahov Monastery for lunch and a Saint Norbert bier. Easy tram access to downtown, or take the scenic walk down to Mala Strana.

The place to explore.... Simply fabulous. And there is so much to see here. BTW, you do realise pretty soon in the trip that the city is not all that big. You can practically cover the most on foot. So, you can actually take a cab to the castle and work your way to the Charles Bridge area, or simply walk up the hill and explore the entire area.You are rewarded with a slice of world history.and a fabulous view of the City below. Not to be missed. And if you can, do the exploring on foot.

Lots of historical and cultural sights.. There's plenty to see and do in the Castle District of Prague. Situated in the New Town (Mala Strana) section, it is home to attractions such as St. Vitus' Cathedral, the Prague castle, the monastery where the monks brew their famous beer, Petrin hill, etc.

Castle tour. I booked Castle tour through Sentini hostel. Tour guide was Amanda. Weather was less than ideal. Amanda was very professional and obviously done much research. I enjoyed the tour and listening to her knowledge. The money was well spent since merely walking I would have missed out on history and Amanda. Best on a sunny day

Wander the streets. Just wander the streets. It's quite hilly but go up to Petrin Hill and take in the views. Get a coffeee in Bella Vista. Visit the monastery. We stayed in a hotel on this side just under the castle called Alchemyst Castle Suites - stunning.
Walk of delight. Wander across Charles Bridge and up into the castle district. Plenty to see and do. Wonderful places to pop into on your way up and great views back across the city

The must-see part of Prague. If you are staying in Prague you cannot miss the Castle DIstrict. If you have in your mind a single castle building, stop right there. The Castle District is a whole complex of buildings within the fortified walls. The most stunning is St Vitus Cathedral, a soaring, breathtaking Cathedral which is well worth exploring and will keep your camera busy both inside and outside the building, but there is also St George's Basilica; a number of smaller palaces/galleries/exhibitions; and a Royal Palace. (There is also Golden Lane, a collection of small dwellings, and this was the only disappointment for us - ok but not great.) The views of Prague from the battlements are incredible. There are also gardens and a treasury, which we didn't get round to exploring because we ran out of time. Entry to look around the outsides of buildings is FREE but if you buy a ticket to let you into the buildings its well worth it. Cafes and restaurants inside and also just up the street (free to get into the area, remember, so you can drift out and back in again if you go outside for something to eat.) Easy to get to by tram if you're trying out the (cheap) public transport.

Take a walk. Take a walk after visiting the castle in this area. Beautiful houses and small streets. We have been there on a Saturday at 11:00 in high season and saw less people walking around there (same time the castle became horribly crowded).

a historical experience. a full day walking tour of castle district is a must ending with a tour of prague castle(at least 3 hrs}sensible shoes,cap n a windsheeter with sunscreen a must.the monastery is worth walking thru too.the st vitus cathedral thou being restored is magnificently carved n must see.

Cathedral is the twin spires in the picture. Full day required to see if not more. Palace grounds are evidently largest in Europe and lots to see. Suggest you consider tram 22 to get up the hill as quite a walk or simply take a cab from the square just past the end of Charles bridge. Make sure you confirm the fare in advance as some drivers love to scam you. We found the fare should be around 100 Czk koruna or about $5.00 but were charged double on earlier trips before we figured out the deal. Still cheap at either price. Once you enter the grounds you need to decide what ticket to purchase. We opted for the tour 1 which included about 5 different sites. Must see is the Cathedral and old palace. Ticket is 350 Czk koruna or about $17 US. Treasury visits extra. Ticket is good for 2 days which is helpful as lots to see if you read everything...... many exhibits have multi-language sign. Building II houses display on history of Prague. If really into it, history of various kings, who when why and where, plus clothes, of the period, video of whole complex history....need a couple of hours just this one building. Consider renting the audio guide for $17 plus refundable deposit of about $25. Particularly good in the Cathedral.

So much to see. There are so many things to see here with your pass that you could be up here all day and never get down into the city. Make sure you visit the re-created old shops and see all the nooks and crannies and explore this delightful place. It was beautiful and sunny when we were there so bring water.

Beautiful, historic and pristine. A hilly area, a mixture of residential, commercial, tourism and governmental buildings. Whatever the purpose, the buildings are beautiful and worthy of your full appreciation. The people are very friendly and welcoming, it is well worth a traipse around the area, before or after a visit to the Castle.

Fairy tale city. Rich in history, fantastic architecture, stunning views. Hundreds of photo opportunities. The peaks of the buildings can be seen from miles around. Majestic city which you really need to explore on foot.

Deep in the Heart of Prague. The Castle District is the heart of Prague. It offers many opportunities for great views of the city as well as a glimpse into the rich culture and history of this great city! We got a little turned around on our way down from the castle and ended up walking through a nice little park with a pathway, fountain and perfectly manicured grass.P.S. You can't walk on the grass. The views were incredible here with a walk out overlook area that is great for photo ops. On the way down the stairs back to the town there is a little cafe. Stop in for a coffee!

castle district was so beautiful and filled with history. the castle district was gorgeous and so beautiful and I found it very peaceful and safe , I had a tour guide which was great but is easy accessible to do on your own lots of public transport or by foot

Absolutely a must when in Prague!. The Castle District of Prague is beautiful as well as interesting with the Monastery, restaurants, the Castle, and St. Vitus Cathedral. A trip to Prague wouldn't be complete without a visit to this area. If hot it's nice to get a ride up to the castle and then walk back to the Old Town across the Charles Bridge.

TAKE TIME TO EXPLORE. This is the area surrounding the castle from which you can get a great vantage point view of Prague Castle, Old Town, Charles Bridge, etc. and stroll among the many government buildings, embassies, stunning gardens, shops and restaurants. Take time to just wander and explore the entire area and its many architectural delights.

Extensive district with monastery, castle and tower on Petrin Hill. We caught a tram up to 2 stops past the castle. We walked all over the area, then through the castle. Next day we did it on a Segway with a guide and that was awesome, covering the whole area more easily and learning the history.

Good for long walks. We had a nice 2 hour long walk in the vicinity of the castle - which can be recommended. There are so many nice places to see - and would definitely recommend to go through the Royal Gardens - which can be accessed through the 2nd court yard of the Castle - this has two "stunning buildings" - the Summer Palace and the Ball Game House. The gardens are nice too - for a stroll.

An interesting area which should ideally be seen on foot. This is a very huge complex and is worth spending a few hours here. the view is amazing from the top and the entire complex has an unique charm. It is fairly crowded though on weekeds especially.

Great views. Even if you don't want to pay to go around the whole castle it is definitely worth walking around the outside for the stunning views of the exterior and of the whole of Prague. St. Vitus Cathedral is also beautiful. It does get busy later in the day so it is worth going early

Magnificient architectures on Castle hill. Must go, may be take the funicular to go up. The Palace, the St Mathias Cathedral , the Fisher Bastion and the panoramic view of the river and the Pest side is not to miss.

Free City Tour. We highly recommend this tour; although we are sisters in our 60's the guide made sure that he didn't go to fast so we never had to hurry. The guide's name was Cullam & he was one of the best guides we have ever had. He was intelligent, professional, humorous & very well informed about the history of Prague. His tour was very well organised & other tour guides would be advised to go on one of Cullam's tours to see how it is done!

River views. The architecture along the river are simply breath taking?Be sure to be aware of the history of Praha to appreciate what the communist regime did to the most beautiful buildings and how Praha is fighting back.
Highlight of Prague. Tremendous sight. To see the area in a casual, relaxed but not overly detailed way takes several hours. Climbing the tower (287 steps) is worth the views.
Lovely place to visit. Would highly recommend this lovely place . It was our first visit to Prague & will be going back soon .

Worth a visit. A must visit when in Prague. Quite a steep climb to the castle but views over Prague amazing. They have changing of the guard at 12 noon everyday which was fantastic and very colourful gets busy so get there early to get a good spot!

A nice place for passing time. The castle complex itself is indeed impressive.However, for someone who has visited quite a few castles of different kinds already, it was rather boring. The money spent does not match the expectations.The only thing that I truly enjoyed was the cathedral.Castle, basilica, golden alley - you can do without in my opinion.(We booked the least expensive tour which still included the most important sights.)

THE WHOLE AREA IS OF INTEREST. The Castle stands very imposingly overlooking the river and just beckons to you. Take my advice though, if planning to walk, I suggest you take the tram up there and walk back down after visiting the Castle itself, as it is all downhill and you can explore the shops, bars, and places of interest at your leisure after spending a lovely time visiting the castle at the top

Charming and crowded. Like most of central Prague, this district is very beautiful and charming - a favorite of Hollywood movie directors - but as is the case with all places in central Prague, it is tightly packed with tourists of various nationalities. It is a must visit however, so do visit it, but be prepared. You will run into and be stalled by crowds of tourists. You will also be overcharged at restaurants, the closer to the castle the more ridiculous the prices get. You may also be swindled by being talked into buying a traditional Czech trinket that was actually made in China.

History and more history. We were lucky on our first day to enjoy perfect weather here, so much to see and do, so many tourists, but just take your time and see as many of these beautiful buildings as you can. The history and age of some of these buildings is amazing. Incredible views from so many spots.
Great views and peaceful. Offers great views over Prague and is relatively peaceful, save the occasional group passing by. Felt comfortable exploring.

Entire area is gorgeous and worth the visit. The castle and its surroundings are amazingly beautiful and rich with history! the gardens and district are beautiful! Excellent visit! Great views from the castle entrance!

Free entry but certain areas within the Castle do charge an entry fee. We spent several hours walking around this amazing site. We chose not to pay to go into the various parts as the day was so good and there was plenty to see outside. We could access the gardens and part of St Vitus cathedral.

Old Castle and New Palace building. The castle is old and definite visit though many parts are restricted by fees. The palace looked like a 5 star hotel though inside view requires Ticket. The change of guard ceremony is nice but nothing great. Spend time in Old staff quarters behind castle which houses torcher chamber, canons, spears, armory etc which are more realistic and historical.
Excellent views from the top of the hill. quite a walk if you do not want to queue for the funicular railway. Once there you get stunning views over the whole city
Lovely city. The castle areas is full of lovely buildings and everywhere you turn there is more amazing architecture, statues, gargoyles and beautiful carved doors

Impressive view. Impressive view to the town. Great cathedral, a beautiful basilica and interesting street representing the ancient living in the district. The castle, was very cold, dark and unhospitable.

Great and take time to visit the Castle .... There is the monastery ( for the library ) and the castle plus you may walk aroud without too many people. There are many restaurants were you may eat on a terrasse and they are not expensive and very good . Walk down to the old town using the stairs instead of the road ... you could miss some boutiks

Very rude staff at ticket office and not really a castle. We had a look around, for one I wouldn't really consider it a castle. There are certainly a lot more grand castles. The only part which was really worth seeing was the Cathedral. The other buildings in Old Town are much more beautiful to look at!Furthermore, the staff member at the ticket office refused to accept my student ID because it was on my phone. He wouldn't take any of my explanation that it was a valid student ID validation site: myunidays.com, and offered no apology. Every other place I used it in Prague accepted it.
Beautiful area. Stay away from the castle and walk around the district which is just as beautiful and (sometimes) quieter!

Fairyland castles. For whatever reason, WWII bombings did not destroy Prague castles, or most other Prague buildings. At first I thought the Castle District was on the other side of the river, near Prague Castle. TripAdvisor identifies, however, Castle District in the heart of Old Town so I’m not sure which side of the river is the true location.Regardless of which side of the river is the true location of Castle District, I enjoyed both and regret that the tour company allowed only three days to explore this fascinating city.

Formidable!. No matter that one can hardly turn around thanks to a bizzillion tourists. It is still an impressive place to visit. A must! Views are great. We were there on a sunny day which was great.

lots to do. to get here by public transport you need metro line A Malostranska, or trams 22/12/20/18. In this area there is not only the castle and cathedral but the Hunger Wall and John Lennon Wall, as well as a quaint little water wheel. Lots of places to eat and drink, plenty of toilets. You can easily spend over a day here.
Great insight into Prague. Discover the roots of Prague, experience local culture, authentic cuisine, beauty everyplace, exquisite galleries, classic views.
Just so amazing. I wish I knew how they built all of these amazing places 100's of years ago. I know, they tell you but it's just so hard to believe. The views are outstanding.
Worth a vusut. So much to see here - one ticket to cover various sites - it could take a long time to see everything so allow time. Also have a stroll through the garden.

Great view of the city. During the city tour, we signed up for the view from the Castle District was wonderful. Prague is one city that was never bombed during WW2 and visitors are so lucky to see the old and the new part of Prague. The Czech people should be so proud of there city.

the beutiful view. the view that you will see from this castle is something from heaven , you will not remove your eyes from the city.
walking there is one of the best tour in Prague , do not miss the opportunity to be there
Must see. This is an amazing area in Prague. The architecture is amazing in this area and there is so much history to take in.

Must see!. The Castle District is a combination of buildings and gardens that include the massive St. Vitus church and numerous government offices along with a monastic brewery and many food and drink options. There were also about a dozen little stands selling food and souvenirs that I had not seen before and might be seasonal?The "changing of the guard" ceremony is fun but not essential.Wear comfy shoes and be ready to walk a bunch.

Must Experience . It is amongst the main tourist attractions. One can see the castle, change of guards, Cathedral, quaint stores and stunning view of the city below. We walked down the many alleys savouring the beautiful views.

Prague Castle district. We did not have enough time here and if we go back we would spend more. We mainly saw the cathedral and an overlook of the castle gardens. If we go back, I would want to explore golden lane.
