Visit the place on a weekend and enjoy the extra parades. The 'modern' Prague castle (don't confuse it with Praszky Hrad) is more a palace than a castle, with extensive outbuildings, a cathedral and various squares. The walk up from the Charles bridge is not strenuous and it is worth doing a circular walk coming down on the right end. You can catch a tram to near by if you need to. There is usually a soldier change of the guard parade on Sundays, at least when I went.

Very nice place - do not miss it!. Not many turists go ther and it is a shame! The view from ther is amazing , the cemetary is impressive and also the catedral ther (the bells did not ring on the day we came and we were dissapointed).

Worlds Biggest Castle. Its a matter of ultimate fun and exceptional feelings walking around in a place which hardly ends. You can view the city from there and visit the Presidential office, Museums, old church and above all, a quite and calm Christmas market.
A testing walk up to the castle area. The views from here across the city make it worth the testing walk up here. The buildings reflect the period when this waas the main part of the city.

Strong legs required !!. Some of the routes up to the castle are quite steep and cobbled pavements give for a good workout!Lovely area to explore with lots of restaurants, cafes and little shops overlooked by the fabulous castle buildings.

Always pleasant -- no graffiti. I live in Prague and various events through the year involve a walk to or through the castle district. The experience is always pleasant because my eyes are constantly full of architectural detail or stunning vistas--and no graffiti!

The biggest castle in the Europe. I live in Prague more than 10 years but the view on the Prague Castle from Novotneho lavka will not bored me. I am going quite often around and at night it is on of the most beautiful views in the world. Prague castle is very big and all the buildings are ligthened. And on the lest side you can see Petrin tower as well.
The best district to stay. It's a bit out of the way to the main city centre but perfect if you want to easily travel to the main city centre which is a bit more lively but stay somewhere more quiet.

Fairytale. If you can, take your time strolling along the streets to go up to the castle, you will have beautiful enchanting streets with magnificent architectural building to see, restaurants, shops and picture opportunity which are all there to enjoy.

Steeped in History. The mere fact that it is a district speaks volumes! Plenty to see and do, love the cobbled streets and quaint little shops and café's in this areas. Fabulous views of Prague from up here, well worth a visit!

lOBOWITZ AT CASTLE DISTRICT. Much enjoyed lunch time concert in the Lobowitz having eaten delightful lunch on the balcony of the restaurant. This was followed by a visit to the most interesting museum with original scripts of the Messiah and Eroica

Worth the trip for the view of Prague alone. If you do nothing else go here for the view of Prague from high on this hill! In addition there are so many other castles and houses to see here. You are just outside the Prague Castle, so you might as well take the time to see that also.

Stunning... Breathtaking.... Even during the winter in a bittercold night, the castle district is still a gorgeous sight to behold with so much to see! I was here last Christmas and was awestruck by the beauty of the place. There's just so much to see in the area so make sure to set aside one whole day if you want to really explore and go inside the castle and cathedral. Otherwise, half a day is good. Make sure to dress up EXTRA warmly during the winter nights!
Buzzing with tourists. This is the heart of tourism in Prague with lots of done-up vintage cars and limos, segway rides and hordes of people milling around the bridge and square.

Worth the climb. Walked up the second set of steps ... should of turned right over the bridge rather than left . An excellent atmosphere when you get there , went to a recital in one of the churches .... well worth the energy to get there , but if you don't fancy walking get a tram or taxi ... don't miss it !

Amazing. Wear good supportive walking shoes. Take the tram to the top of the hill by the fortifications. Walk past the old monestaries and along the crestbof the hill to St. Vitus. A feast for the eyes!
When in Prague :). Definitely have to check out the Castle District while you're in Prague. Steep cobbled streets, wacky shops, and one of the best views in the city.
best Viewed from Charles Bridge. The Color combination of Castle district is what adds to overall picture of the place. it can definitely be a post card location
Well Worth an Afternoon Visit. Avoid the largest crowds and (the tour buses at least) and go there in mid-afternoon. Be sure to go to Golden Lane before she leaves.

The largest castle in Europe!. The Castle district is a must for tourists but there is just so much to see and to do there that one is not sure what to choose. The walk up is very scenic with streets lined with old-fashioned and charming buildings and tourist shops. Once you get to the top and at the castle, there are many places marked with numbers. We went to the tourist information where we presumed they sold tickets. They did not and we were sent off elsewhere to buy tickets. You have many options including what to see and whether with a tourist guide or not. We took the tourist guide but she was not very good repeating herself at least 3 - 4 times for each tidbit of information that she provided. I would suggest to skip the tourist guide and to take the basic package which already allowed a lot of visiting around in the cavernous complex and huge grounds. One thing not to miss is the Golden Lane which was included in our basic ticket. These are teensy tiny dwellings that were lived in until the last century. One of their most famous renter was Frank Kafka.

vast area, beautiful architecture. from private schools to government department buildings with the odd place for drinks and eating. just wander and you will be amazed, i'm sure there were ares we missed because there is so much.

So much history. There are different levels and costs of tickets. We suggest you opt for the most expensive ticket, it's not that much more, and you get to go into some really fascinating areas such as where the guards used to live along the wall which is now small, quality shops. You also get to travers the upper wall with the slits for crossbows and see the small torture museum.
Old elegance. Between the Castle and the river, is a whole area of beautiful buildings. Take your time and explore.

Amazing. This beautiful castle stands overlooking Prague and is a must to visit. The walk into the castle is worth seeing itself, guards immaculately dressed on either side. Beautiful buildings and amazing things to see in there.
Beautiful area.. Grand architecture below Prague's main castle. When en-route to the castle, it got us in the mood to enjoy the architecture of the main castle itself!

Gorgeous!!!. This is a must see! Be sure to have good walking shoes and a camera! The vistas from every single angle on the Charles Bridge are just stunning! The Charles Bridge is strictly a pedestrian bridge where you'll find vendors selling souvenirs, jewelry, musical CDs, and artists drawing caricatures. Prague Castle is a compound comprised of St. Vitas Cathedral, Lobkowicz Palace and Golden Lane. St. Vitas is so very beautiful. We did not enter Lobkowicz which is a museum. Outside Lobkowicz, we saw a changing of the guard and took pictures from the balcony. At the foot of Lobkowicz is a garden area which was lovely to walk through. There is a cafe inside Lobkowicz which has a pretty view from the terrace. We stepped in just to see the view that someone had written about. Golden Lane, to the back of the Castle is a street of very small charming homes circa 1500s. Home #22 was Kafka's residence for a short time. If you venture to the Lesser Quarter (Mala Strana) from here, be sure to visit the gorgeous St. Nicholas Church! Also, if you're looking for an excellent restaurant in The Lesser Quarter, I highly recommend Bar Bar! My husband had the risotto with mushrooms and I had duck with pea puree...one of our two best meals in our five nights in Prague. enjoy!
Great area. this is a large area in the area around Prague Castle. Very beautiful buildings. Nice to walk around. Food court and shops.
Lovely area . The area is so beautiful and filled with little restaurants everywhere around the castle. The views of Prague are stunning from here and the castle itself is astonishing!

Walk between the Castles. If you are getting there by tram ( number 22 ) get down one more station after the Prague Castle ( Prazky Hrad ) and walk lass that 1000 m from the station to the castle. You will see wonderful castles and painted buildings. Enjoy it.And the best view of the city is at the terrace in front of Prague Castle.
Beautiful and colourful place. This place is right coming down from the Castle . Many good restaurants and little coffee shops with a great view to the river Vltava .
good crystal shopping. have a irish coffe, cash only and watch the river boats going by, good crystal shopping, kafka museum interesting

family trip. been here quite a few times and never of sick of seeing its beauty. love walking across charles bridge and up to the castle (long walk, but goes by quickly as there is much to see) see places where movies were filmed. the bridge is lined with vendors selling little trinkets and things and we have purchased a few on our travels. you won't regret going here
short break Prague. The architecture in this area is outstanding you see old ninety thirties cars taking tourists around, and the views of Prague are very good.
Grandeur. A great discovery...just go strolling at your own pace. So much to see and read and learn. It is a must-do in Prague
Charming fairytale view. You can take a boat cruise which is about $14 per person which includes great views, a historical tour of the river and a free drink.

The whole area is worth a visit. The castle district is well worth a visit. In fact if you are visiting the castle and St Vitus cathederal then you just have to visit the castle district. Prague is rich in its history and having a good guide book is a must. There are also many tours to be had in this area and joining one is not a bad idea. Be warned it is packed in the summer but at the same time quite beautiful in the evening light. Lots of little bars and eateries just watch the prices before you go in. There are some reasonable priced venues and the food is whole sum and tasty for the most part.

Seat of Government, Palace & Cathedral Treasures & Museums. Hradčany in essence is the area around Castle Hill, Pražsky Hrad & the other historic buildings like Lobkowiczky Palác on the hill. The core of the district is the Castle complex & its series of courtyards & gardens. There are two sets of old steps stairs leading to & from Castle Hill ... coming down via old Zámecke schody (although there is over 200 steps) is much easier! The elevated location of Hradčany affords views across the Vltava River to the Old & New Towns of Prague.

Postcard Perfect!. This is kind of place one sees on a postcard. Every nook and corner is picture perfect. Beautiful buildings and architectural marvels every where. Antique shops, cafes, bars, bakeries etc. everywhere.

Must see area. Like most of Prague this us an area for walking with much to see. Wear comfortable shoes as there are steps and cobbled streets but it is worth the effort for the lovely views across the river. There are plenty of restaurants and bars but, while reasonably priced they are much more expensive than those across the river and off the Tourist route.
Take a tour. there are several guided tour that cost around 30 euros but they are the best way to see everything and meet new people.

Lovely place. Certainly a place to visit if you are coming to Prague, with its lovely landscaped grounds, beautiful buildings, a beautiful square in the middle of it, and a spectacular cathedral to boot, most impressive, though like a lot of places in Prague, it was overrun with tourists, so select a time when they are all having there breakfast!!
Best to see with a guide. You would miss too much of you don't use a guide. Lots of history to hear about that deals with the castle and the city. We saw this with a tour group. ..gate one travel.
Very quaint!. This is such a pretty area. Take the time to walk around as much as you can. Cute stores, restaurants and bars.

Pure culture with lovely architecture. Hradcany is a beautiful area in Prague. It feels really nostalgic and historical. I decided to go to this area through Malá Strana, a park on a hill with a lot of statues, a historic fortress and a great view over Prague. This made the experience better, because it took some effort to reach the goal. I simply loved the complete setting of the area; the architecture (great piece of mannerist architecture!), the cobblestones, the cathedral and the Golden Lane. Don't forget your camera! TIP1: It can be really crowded and you will see a lot of checklist-tourists and selfiesticks (its disturbing for me), if you dont want to see them, you can better go in the mornings. TIP2: Really nice to see; the changing of guard. 12 oçlock every day! For free
Be ready to get tired!. It's huge! But every inch of it is beautiful and even-thou you'll feel tired, you won't stop strolling around. The gardens, at fall, are a real treat.
Picture postcard. This is the stuff of postcards. Fantastic views from the castle. Take walking boots if possible - all the streets in Prague are cobbled!!
Beautiful and romantic. Huge castle comprising of different buildings. Quite steep walking track but worthwhile doing. The cathedral is a must.

Nostalgic Area. The castle district is breathtaking and beautiful. I could spend hours walking around this district taking wonderful photographs of the surrounding and beautiful buildings. The architecture is simply amazing and inspiring.

Gorgeous. The castle and old buildings are beautiful, and make for some gorgeous photos. Lovely to stroll through the alleys, over the cobble, but do keep your wits about you. There are plenty of people who prey on tourists that are not paying attention to their surroundings.

Beautiful old area. Spending a few hours just walking around the castle district is certainly one of the highlights of a visit to Prague. Once you get away from the castle itself it's actually possible to escape the crowds of tourists and really enjoy the atmosphere. Plenty of old buildings to admire and some decent views out over the city.

Wonderful area. It is a nice walk up to the castle past the beautiful architecture which reminds me a bit of Paris.
The castle and surrounding area are lovely and affords views over Prague.
Go early when it is not too busy.
Beutifull. What to say more, than it was realy beutifull experience see this nice Castke district from boat during Prague by night dinner cruise we join.

a historical place. The place is historical and there a nice old buildings, but you have to pay all over if you want to come inside and see anything proper.
Often there are a bounce of people so come early in the morning if you want to take nice photos.

Castle life. The entire walk is on cobblestone and we are surrounded by beautiful buildings. This was a part of our prague all in one tour. We covered everything by foot. Lots of shops restaurants etc in this area. Best to cover this in a tour.

The Walk to the Castle is fabulous, with cobblestone lined streets and shops.. The Walk to the Castle is fabulous, with cobblestone lined streets and shops. You will find antique shops, tourist shops, eateries and bakeries in the Castle District. It is a must walk for anyone traveling to Prague. We stayed in Mala Strana and really feel that it is the best area in Prague.

a lovely walk. We spent the day walking over charles bridge all the way up the hill to a brewery (Strahov Monastery) and walked back down to St. Vitus. We saw beautiful scenery and building, especially with the city behind us. Definitely recommend the walk.

The High Life. Great for pageantry, pomp and circumstance. The guards put on a good show including changing the guard at 12 (possibly other times too.) Crowds following their guides but you can detach yourself from the throng and listen to the excellent street musicians or just peer over the wall at the glorious sights of Prague.
A surprise. I had heard about the castle, but did not know the area around was so beautiful. Make sure you have some hours to spend here.
Stunning walk over bridge. Prague is great. Very busy in peak season in the city centre but worth it for the history and architecture.

Less party, more history. It seems Prague is visited mostly by partying European gap year kids, but the castle district offers a break from all that noise and is where the more seasoned travelers stay when they're in Prague.

This is a "Must See". Start your visit all the way at the top of the hill at the Abbey, don't get off the tram where everyone else does, go a few more stops to the top. Have a beer at the Abbey then start walking down to the castle area. When you reach the castle don't bother getting a ticket outside where the long lines are, go into the area where the church is, before going into the St Vidas Cathederal turn right and go into the ticket office on your right. Now you are in the entrance to the ticket office: if you want to purchase a ticket and a tour take the door to the right, if you only want to purchase a ticket then take the door to your left. If you don't get a tour guide then pay for the audoguide, otherwise you will have no idea what you are looking at. The B tour is your best bet, the A tour costs more but doesn't really give you much more.
Lovely area of the city. Lovely area of the old city and I enjoyed walking around the old cobbled streets with its very interesting buildings.

Steep walk but worth it!. The walk from the Charles Bridge up to the castle district is quite steep and cobble stones make it hard to walk on but if your motivated the only way is up! Not too many shops but some great restaurants on the way up. Be aware of Segways!

An amazing place, there is a little vineyard on the hill. We took a taxi up and met a local tour guide.. We started at the castle and worked our way around the grounds, stopped at a café near the vineyards. Our guide took us all the way to the bottom where we went for authentic lunch.

Castle District, Prague. For the place to stay, and enjoy better meals, the Castle district is a better choice. Most hotels are within walking distance to the Charles bridge, and excellent restaurants with attentive service nearby walking uphill. The Castle is a master piece of period detail, and well preserved by the friendly Czech people.
Amazing. Worth the trek for the view alone. So much to see! And, the views, Amazing! I enjoyed all of it. Not to be missed
Beautiful buildings. Fabulous views and all types of architecture. If you walk down to the old town be careful as it's very steep and all cobbles. Don't miss the changing of the guard every hour
Castle district!. I love castles, and you can see spectacular views from this district! It's nice to walk around, but also for sitting and takin it all in. I definitely recommend it.

Great area to explore . Based on a blog on the internet we decided to do our own walking tour of this area . It is quite easy to navigate with fantastic views of Praha across the river and in other directions . There is also some fascinating architecture in the architecture . I would suggest that this is another must do when visiting Praha .

Amazing views of the City from the Castle District. Take a Tram/Bus up to the Castle area but wander back down through the area into the city on foot. It's an easy walk down and you'll find lovely restaurants, shops and homes, Venture down the side streets to experience the local flavor.

Beautiful and interesting. The Castle District is another Prague attraction. You come there if you cross the Karl's Bridge and the interesting district of Mala strana with many shops, cafes and restaurants. It's always full of tourists. Then you climb to the Castle District with all its curiosities, historical palaces, museums and cathedral. I like to walk very much by the Zlatna ulicka (The little golden street) with its small and picturesque historical houses. From the terasses there is beautiful view on the river and of the town.

Great view. Great place to walk around to view the church and castle. The best part is the view of the city with the river and bridges. There are lots of artisans on the steps walking back down to the city.
One of the most beautiful places around the world. A number 1 must see place in Prague. Get a tour inside of the palaces to get the most of it and do not forget to visit the castle gardens.

Wander around outside of the castle area. We spent time wandering around the castle district outside of the castle. The views to the other side of Prague are amazing and it is so quiet and there are little no crowds the further away you get from Charles bridge and the castle. There are some beautiful little churches, and buildings just a block or 2 off the main street. Make sure to check out Strahovsky Monastery & Library. They make the beer on-site and have several cafes to choose from. Also, check out the library which is seen many times in BBC's The Musketeers.Also don't miss Kampa Island. As you are heading to the castle area to the left about 250 feet before the end of the bridge, there is a staircase that takes you down to it. Should you miss that staircase, there is another one as the end of the bridge. It is just a peaceful little place with big trees, cute little shops and cafes and some little huts to get food and drinks. A nice little sanctuary.I think the thing that amazed us the most is how quickly the castle district empties out at the end of the day. As the sun is setting, you see the mass exodus of the tour groups heading back across the bridge. It makes crossing the bridge and sitting in one of the cafes over there so peaceful!
Extraordinary Views. The Castle district has fabulous views over the old town and new town. The Castle District is large and includes many different 'must see' attractions.

Perfect area to stay when in Prague. Mala Strana and the Castle area are much more quiet and peaceful than the madness that is the Old Town. The streets are quaint and old with many good cafes and eateries. If looking for a place to stay in Prague 1, opt for this area.

Castle Square & Down the Castle Hill Sights!. Once you enter the castle square you are in the center of the Castle Quarter. As you walk through the courtyard, you are faced first by the imposing St. Vitus Cathedral and, as you proceed through the square and down the hill, other important buildings such as the Old Royal Palace, the Basilica of St. George and the Golden Lane. The passageway down the hill also offers views of Lower Prague and the Little Quarter and exits where the palace guards stand watch.

PLAN SOME TIME TO JUST SIT AND ENJOY. The castle and all the amazing structures on this massive property are a photographers paradise. Getting the sun light correct, there are amazing shots of the buildings, the panoramas of the city or if you time it right, the changing of the guard. Take the tram to the top and then wander back down through the vineyards. We really enjoyed wandering around taking it all in, then sitting down for a beer and some bbq pork, sitting on the small wall over looking the city. What a great way to spend the day

Surprised at how big this was, so much to see and do, views from here are amazing and it's free. I visited on a Sunday afternoon and it was teeming with tourists. The district is free to visit. You have to pay to see inside the castle. I enjoyed wondeing around. I was surprised at how big it was. There are lots of beautiful buildings, restaurants and shops.The views of Prague were fantastic. The gardens were peaceful and nice.You can get tram 22 or Metro Line A and get off at Malostranska or one of the hop on hop off buses.

Hike up and enjoy the views. Take time to stroll the Castle District and take in the gardens, many buildings the church then the park that is adjoining. There are lots of eateries and ships selling all kinds of glass and trinkets.
Great Tour. We had a guided tour from the top of the hill through the castle, village, vineyard, and down to Charles Bridge, and ending in the Old Town Square.
lots of history and beauty. but it gets so busy. try to go as early as you can to avoid the bus tours. Keep small coins (crowns) available to use the washrooms.
Historical district. Very nice historical district with huge amount of little shops. you can buy almost everything . totally recommend

Castle district is the heart of old Prague. No visit can be complete without a tour of this area. A guide, in my opinion, is essential. There can be a lit of walking but our bus dropped us off at the top and so the walk was downhill.
Great place. Loved this place. So many things to see here. It's a huge area. And finally the view from here is great. U can see the river and the city from here.
beautiful place. We went the second time to this area in Prag, there is a lot to see, its a very nice area.And a nice walk from old city as well

Enchanting Prague. I loved Prague! Every lane had something interesting to explore. Although the climb up the hill can be strenuous for those of us who have the tendency of huffing and puffing after a flight of stairs hahaha, it was still a wonderful experience. Getting back down was easy breezy! Had to put the breaks on as u really do feel like free falling. The walkways may seem narrow, so I was inclined to give ways to those who were at a faster pace. I always believe in being courteous. I almost forgot, lots of restaurants, cafes and shops. Had some lovely crepe at a small cafe!

What a view!. Around the Castle are some amazing things to see plus a lovely garden. There is a path down the hill at the back in of the Castle area. There are gardens and benches and great views all the way down.
Walking around the castle district. While harder than walking around the very flat old town, its easy to catch a tram to get you up the hill to make walking around the castle district easier.

Loved it, loved the surrounding area. This was a great place to visit. We went to the castle one day, but then kept returning to the surrounding streets throughout our trip, to frequent the cafes and shopping. It is well worth a visit. Just walking around is free (the Castle) but you have to pay to tour the inside... but if you don't want to do that, there is plenty of Castle and adjacent town streets to more than capture your attention. The cafes and shopping and people watching around this area is terrific. We had a memorable good time. I highly recommend.

Awesome tours, amazing history. We had a guided tour for this area and it was well worth it. The history we learned was so intriguing here. There's tons to see..even just in the external courtyards of the castle itself (we didn't even make it inside, ran out of time) There are amazing view of the city of prague from this area as well, I highly recommend bringing your camera :) Having a beer at the monk monastery.
Very picturesque. This is a must-do when visiting Prague. Well worth the hike up the hill. The buildings in the Castle District are superb and the views considerable.

Not just a walk in the park. It`s more like a walk back in time, in the Middle Ages. Maybe it`s better to start the walk from uphill (close to the Strahov Monastery) and go thorugh the castle courtyards, and then downwards towards Vltava.
Must see!. We walked up the (countless) steps to the Castle District, but so worth it when you get to the top and are able to take in the view over the city!
getting to the castle. Provides you a great view of the town. You can take the tram to get up to the castle and walk back through the back entrance.
Beautiful. The castle district is beautiful. Don't come to Prague and miss this! It's a step back in time and I highly recommend!
Not to be missed. If you are going to Prague you must visit this area. Old tiny cobbled streets, churches, cute shops...its all here.

Fantastic amount of history all within 10 minuets walk...... If you enjoy cobbled streets, great architecture, colourful builgings and a fantastic sense of European history! Then visit the Castle District. Would love to be there in the snow, very pretty I'll bet! We felt very safe, everyone was friendly and best seen on foot.

See comments for St Vitus Cathederal. This is where the film "Amadeus" shot due to it's intact city/state castle area with it's cobbled stoned streets and 16th century store fronts. Walk from the castled area to the historic Charles Bridge.
Again go super early or late.

Great day out. Amazing views. Incredible architechture.. What an amazing area. Spend a day or 3 just wondering around this area with so many different and beatiful buildings that will astonish you. The views of Prague from here are also phenomenal. GO HERE!!!We dod not pay to go into any of the "attractions" and I'm not you need to. You can spend a whole day just wondering about. The lines to a) get a ticket and b) to get to see it would mean you would need 3 days to get to everywhere. There is so much to see in the "free areas"
Take your time. Beautiful area. There is a lot to see, allow plenty of time for leisurely strolling and to take it all in. Many good restaurants.
Castle area. Overall the area is very interesting. Great views of the city. Visit the Loretto chapel where there is religious treasure.
Take public transportation. Take the public transporation and go see this area. It encompasses more than just the castle. Since the area is large, it does seem as crowded

Explore the shops and architecture. This side of town is fantastic. There are many museums and little streets to explore. Just walk over the bridge and you are there. Of course there are throngs of others who are there as well but just as with every place else, walk a few blocks in either direction and it is much better.
Soak it up. This is a lovely place, it is so well preserved and the cobbles, the buildings, the atmosphere, the bustling about. Loved it!

Best part of Prague. I took a tour of the area with a private guide, so I got a very good introduction to the history of Bohemia and Czech republic. I loved this area and recommend that you do not miss it.

"Must see" in Prague, but..... Everyone who comes to Prague walks over this bridge from one side of the river or the other one. Charles Bridhe is on of the "must see" targets. And this is the problem. You will have to thurst through the ceaseless crowd of turists during a day. So in fact you cannot enjoy the beauty of this bridge as well as the view over the Prague castle. Try to skip the rush hours during a day and go there later in the evening. You will be requited with that for sure. Then you will understand why this is one of the Prague's juwels.

Try not to rush. Luckily we had 10 days in Prague. This meant that we didn't have to rush around and try to cram everything in which must be a real temptation which is a shame as I think you will miss out on getting a real feel for the area and its history, however there is just so much to see. The area around the castle is so atmospheric. If you have time try to walk around and lose yourself for 20 minutes or so....

Very beautifully neighbourhood !. We like this area of Prague, all around the castle walking along these old streets, looking these differ styles of architecture. The church of Our Lady of Loretta and the museum with his treasury. It's easy and plentiful of cafes and boutiques...
great perch. walk the cobblestones to the castle, look over your past travels and future landmarks, sip wine or coffee while listening to a variety of musicians, admire the scenery

A highlight of our stay. There is so much to see, several hours being necessary to do it justice. Elegant and well maintained. an audio guide is available to the complex (including sections on St Vitus Cathedral). Advisable to read up about it before going in if you want to be flexible.visitors with mobility problems would do well to go around in a wheelchair.

Where's the castle?. The castle district has no castle, but still is considered the biggest castle in the world. Wonder how that works? Go find out for yourself...The castle district houses the Presidential palace as well as St. Vitus Cathedral, two very impressive structures while also being home to several other aristocratic palaces, the golden lane and some gardens. A short walk away is the Petrin hill and the Strahov Monastery on one side and Letna Park (great views of Vltava) on the other.

worth walking up the hill from the charles bridge.. A busy hive of activity. Shops and attractions.street musicians etc A good vibe to enjoy. There are vintage cars toride if you wish. Plenty of food and drink outlets.xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx☺

The Castle District is a must see in Prague.. The Castle District is an area that you need a couple of days to see. It is a fantastic site. There are many buildings and museums to see and a couple of hours is not enough. There are tours that cover the Castle Area in a couple of hours but these only scratch the surface of what is in the Castle Area.

Do your homework!. You get to this area either uphill on foot from the Malostranke area or downhill by taking the number 22 tram to Prazsky hrad. Others comment on the various ticketing options and you need to do your homework on this to see whats best for you. But most of it can be visited free of charge if you just want to soak-up the atmosphere. Yes - it is something of a tourist trap and the castle displays with the exception of St. Vitus Cathedral as all rather minimalist. The Golden Lane itself is something of a H&S nightmare when crowded. I have reviewed all the attractions individually - but the castle area and the adjacent gardens need to be visited if you've not been before. good luck!

Charming area full of photo opportunities. Plenty to see at every turn, the castle district is packed with charming buildings with elegant facades and quaint shop signs, intriguing alleys, vertiginous steps and a thousand photo opportunities. Plus some pretty good coffee shops and numerous opportunities to be parted with your spending money in an enjoyable way. Just go wandering and you'll find plenty to look at.
Views are brearhtaking. The castle district overlooking the rest if Prague is beautiful and the views are amazing. Buy a ticket to several attractions depending on your tastes and enjoy
Nice afternoon. We spent an afternoon visiting the castle quarter - it is lovely and the views from the restaurant up there are amazing - not to be missed!

Great views. We walked all over this region. It provided a lovely view of the city from up on the hill and it had many of the interesting buildings like the monastery and the castle as well as the governmental buildings with a changing of the guide ceremony.We really like walking through the lovely gardens too. Great place to get away from the crowds and enjoy the views of the city.

Lovely Prague . One of the most beautiful parts of town. Not just because of the castle but is an area pleasent worth exploring. There are gardens and parks, a it of the popular route is the Strahov monastery there are a few restaurants that offer not only good food but also a great view of the city. The walk down to lesser town is just fantastic.

Magnificient. Most beatiful part of Prague and the largest castle district in the world. So much to see here, for full exploration you will need at least 3 hrs and do not regret your money for full access on all attractions it's worth it!
Castle District. Take a walk, but wear some tennis shoes or comfortable non slipping shoes, because the cobble stone can be slick, and its up and down a hill.

Prague castle. Lovely to wander round on a nice sunny day and we were lucky enough to catch the changeing of the guard. Takes quite a few hours to go round properly but if just to see well worth a visit. Like everywhere else in Prague it can be very busy
500 steps. Walked up to the top of the tower. A real must. Calf muscles ached for days afterwards. But a splendid view.
Worth the visit. Best neighbourhood in Prague. There are a lot of things to do around and places to visit. The only downside is that is kind of dead at night.

Prague Castle. We stayed at the Best Western Royal Hotel which is walking distance to the castle. A few steps away is the Parliament which is housed in a former Baroque palace and its surrounding gardens offer a spectacular view of the royal palace on the hill above. The Parliament is open for visitors on weekends only.
Place of History. The Castle is very beautiful, the district with nice restaurants and historical places (like the German embassy or Charles Bridge).

lovely. beautiful.! love this city.
makes ship and car tours.! enjoy it and watch as much as it possible ;)
prague is awesome

Take the tram, fight the crowds. You have to. This is the seat of history and the views of the city are amazing. The multi-purpose ticket gets you into most, but not all, attractions. Get there early and choose carefully. The bus loads of tourists who think that they are the only ones there are crazy. You must take the 22 tram up. The hill is dramatic!

Architectural beauty. Great old buildings, good walking routes for sightseeing. It is better option to walk than taking a bus or tram. The narrow streets can get confusing, take a map along. You will not regret visiting Prague.

Only do this if you have plenty of time in the city. This is a reasonable walk from the Charles Bridge, up hill. Its a quieter part of town not as much to see but if you have a few days then its worth a stroll
Great views of Praha from Castle. This is a must see place but I would avoid weekends if possible as everybody is there. Beautifully preserved and enjoy the walk.
Worth a visit. Lovely area to walk around, lots of places to eat and drink and relax in,quite hilly in areas, definitely need good walking footwear

What a great area from which to view the City. Great sites to see and great for the sight of the City! On the way up the hill there are a variety of shops and cafes which are all very inviting,and the chocolates are great, but watch out for puppets everywhere!
Breath taking! . Worth a visit! The views are amazing and the historical architecture is fascinating! Worth a visit!!

Do not miss the Castle District. The Castle District is worth a visit if you are in Prague. Set aside at least half a day for this area as there are so many quaint cobbled streets to explore and the Castle is definitely a must visit.

Must do, take a walk from the Loreta and cerninsky palace to the caste and continue down to the river. Plan for at least half a day, take a taxi to the top or tram 22 and walk around the area before entering the castle, afterwards walk down to the river and discover the Mala Strana, avoid walking up, you will miss the nicest views over the city

Go, but be choosy on what you want to pay to see. Only parts of the castle are really interesting, and the crowds in summer are tremendous. The area surrounding the castle is interesting because of historical locations, excellent street musicians, and a lot of good places to eat.

A day at the Castle.. What an amazing day. Do take your time and take a stroll through the castle district. The local vendors selling some amazing food and I totally loved the potato dumplings and spicy sausage. Yumminess. Invest in buying a ticket to walked to the halls, because it does give you a glimpse into the past. Rich history.
Nice complex of buildings. Nice complex of buildings and gardens. Try to go early morning as it gets crowded. We saw the changing of the guard at 9:00. It is free if you don't go inside buildings.
Loved Praha. We had a great time visiting this area. The castle itself was wonderful and we enjoyed exploring the surroundings

Traditional food and snack to try. a very nice view from top of the hill. we can even walk to this place from Charles Bridge.
We went there on weekend, and there were lots of food And drink stalls to try

Great city views. Easy to get to using public transport, tram bus or Metro, but it is quite hilly and not so easy if you have mobility problems or can't walk medium to long distance. Lots to see in the castle area, whether you go in to the buildings or not, and some really good views over the city which make it worth it for that alone.

Not enough time to see everything. You could spend all day here. I would recommend planning a day and half. The ticket is valid for 2 days, you could get there the afternoon before. The church gets very crowded. Really is magnificient.

Different from the center of town. The castle district lies on the hill leading up to the Palace complex. Fewer shops but still interesting to visit. It is where you get the trams up to the complex as well as other old sites.
Easy to get lost. The streets are cobbled and there are lots of little cut throughs that aren't on the map so getting from one place to another is not easy.

Wort the Visit. Large complex with great views. Think fortress not palace. The Cathedral is one of the main attractions. The complex itself is free, entry fee into some buildings. Use public transportation to acces the complex - it is located on top of a steep hill. You can walk down to Lesser Quarter easily and stop for a bite along the way.

A wonderful site of Bohemia history. The castle site is a must on a visit to Prague. However, it is all about the buildings as there is very little detail inside. But that does not take anything away from the experience. The exhibition about the history of the castle is a must and needs time. If you want to see the changing of the guard ceremony it is advisable to check where it will take place. Guide books advise that it is at the front gate and the first courtyard. But during our visit it took place in the third courtyard. Despite these comments it was one of the highlights of our visit.

A Medieval Transformation. Imagine you are watching Game of Thrones, narrow cobblestone pathways, small and large churches, palace buildings, a large cathedral, a stone bridge with a natural deep moat, lush green gardens and beautiful flowers and trees and the view of a city with a thousand spires. This is exactly what the Hradcany is. Go there to see yourself. Take your time and explore around.

Beautiful preserved Castle. The Castle District is a beautiful area of Prague. It is dominated by the castle and the tour is really wonderful. But Kampa Park is also on this side of the river, with wonderful restaurants. It is a bustling area with shops, John Lennon's Wall and street fairs. Cross over the Charles Bridge to get yet another aspect of beautiful Prague.
All day visit. Buy the A ticket includes 7 attractions. Make sure you don't miss the changing of the guard at noon (its free). Plenty for all the family.

A must see in Prague.. For sure one of the best preserved heritage castle sites in Europe. Once again very well kept and a walk through which you can enjoy. One can walk down from the castle district and then cross the Charles bridge on foot as a good suggestion.

Our 3rd favorite place in Prague after the Market Square and Charles Bridge.. Take time to see if all if you can. We like the old historical street inside the castle best. The Cathedral is very nice as well.

Feeling like a medieval person.. As many places in Prague, we enjoyed an exquisite medieval feeling during our visit. The Castle is higher than the city itself so be prepared to climb quite a hill to reach the Castle. A bus is also available but I have no details about it. The view on old Prague is excellent from there. Yhe cateedral and the GOLD street are particularly interesting.

Fun area and great views. Cross the Charles Bridge and experience the 'other' side of Prague. Meander the area as if you lived there 500+ years ago and imagine what it may have been like. Lots of food and shops. Some could argue it's very touristy, however Prague is a small enough city that you'll always see other tourists. I like to travel off the beaten path and had no issues in any areas of Prague- don't be turned off by the volume of tourists.
hard walk but worth the effort. it was a very hot day and we found the walking we had to do hard work but worth the effort. the castle is very good and the change of the guard worth seeing

Magnificent views, changing of the guards.... Aside from the castle, its grounds and St. Vitus Cathedral, one must-see in this area is the changing of the guards; you should see it when you're here. Of course, the views at the top are magnificent. Just beware that there will be ample climbing/hiking involved before you reach the area.

The view alon is worth the climb. Start your day in Prague at the castle. The view of the city is incredible. There is not a whole lot to see inside the castle, the Swedes ransacked it and took everything in 1648, but St. Vitus Cathedral is worth the climb. You can also get there by public transportation if climbing steps is difficult for you. The cathedral took 500 years to build.

Must see. Another very interesting part of Budapest to visit. long queues at the funicular but about a ten minute walk up the hill. Discovered (too late) if you walk down along the river below the castle you can get an escalator and a light up to the castle. which were very quiet in comparison. Don't use the money change up here exchange rates are very poor. much better rates in the city.
More than just a castle. A myst to visit, can purchase tour or visit your self, worth being there for around midday to see the guard changing.Used the hop on hop of bus ticket to get here

Amazing views!. A must do! All day event going from top to bottom. Views, shopping, tourism, eating, drinking and just a casual walk back in time! I took over 300 photos in one afternoon so you imagine the sites along the way!

A lot to see, moderately expensive. Very beautiful experience. We took the B tour. The 2 churches, royal palace, gold lane and purchased the church tower. The gothic cathedral was worth the visit, st George cathedral and royal palace were ok, hog lane was worthless. The tower climb of the church was 150 cake, a littlecspendy but worth the view.

Beautiful buildings and a great view. One of the most beautiful sites of Prague. The top of the hill is covered with historical monuments. It also gives you an amazing view over the old city. The district can be reached on foot (don't wear high heels. The streets are made of cobble stones), but also by tram and bus.

A little of almost everything. The castle district has a little and in some cases a lot of everything in Prague. It has architecture from Medieval through modern times, an archbishop's palace (still used), monasteries, cathedrals, royal palaces, beautiful libraries, workers' homes and shops (Golden Lane), art museums, even a vineyard. And the views of Prague are fantastic. It's a must visit area of Prague but really requires probably a day by itself. This was our second visit to Prague and the Castle and we did not repeat anything in the two visits to this area.

Worth the climb. The castle is not easy to reach by foot and public transport but we found a way to do it and were happy we did. Complex requires ticket with several choices of sites within the walls. Can be very crowded and confusing. Tour groups often clog right-of-way and are clueless that there are other visitors trying to navigate the steps and narrow entries through or around them.
Amazing Views of Prague. Amazing part of town. I love the history in this town especially in the Castle District. Amazing views of the city from Prague Castle!

Lovely View of Prague City!. This is a spectacular visit! For those who like castles and churches, this place also offers that! However what fascinated me the most was the view of the city! It is fabulous! If you can walk, I recommend walking down the hill toward the city once you are done visiting the area and you will find many subtle beauties that gives you a head rush! :)
Castle District. The Castle District was a ton of fun to walk around and see the sights in. The atmosphere is simply the best! This is a MUST DO when visiting Prague

A must see on any visit to Prague. We would recommend purchasing the ticket which allows full access to the cathedral, access to a portion of the palace, and access to the Golden Lane. This gives you access to see portions of the castle district which you would not normally be able to see. The tickets are available at the ticket office just outside of the entrance to the cathedral. We spent a wonderful afternoon exploring the castle district.

So much to do so little time. Time just flies by whilst in the Castle District. A sore neck is almost inevitable as I spent so much time looking up at the architecture. A photographers dream place if you can cope with the crowds that can spoil your perfectly composed shot.

Spectacular. Take a god few hours to stroll around the castle area, so much to see, all well worth it, you can ak up the narrow street to the castle although it's easy by tram to the top and an easier walk back down passing a few shops and cafes or bars. The views are great on a clear day, the place is extremely busy. We were fortunate to see the changing of the guard. Not as good as some I've witnessed but worth watching.

For cultural immersion, walk here.... Dense, dense, dense with attractions, shops and gastronomic delights. Stroll down from the castle and soak up the atmosphere. We had a ton of fun just popping into little shops along the way down hill and perusing the wares, and talking to the shop attendants. Check out the Absynthe offerings and Absynthe related wares. Lots of fun. The young folks are super friendly and lots of fun to share stories with.
Beautifull part of the city. Definately a must-see. Especially because of the infrastructure, but also because of the view over the rest of Prague.
Best Castles in Europs. Every direction you look is a picture and a part of Czech history. It is almost overwhelming. Take notes or you'll never remember all you saw!
Spend a whole day to visit. This area needs a lot of time to visit. There are stunning views across Prague from the top. It gets very busy and crowds make it difficult to get around some areas.
Old area of town with great views.. Old area of town with tremendous views. Neat Hilton built in with an old castle. You can walk around on your own.

Live a fairytale. Walking this district gives you a sense of what it was like to lives in the middle ages, with the Prague Castle looming over the small and narrow cobbled stone streets. There are many different ways to walk up to the Castle we enjoyed the way up through the vineyard.

a big palace they name a castle. the place is called a castle but you only will see a palace and a cathedral as the old fortress castle is gone
prepare for a long walk and indulge in history with lots of ramifications

Reserve a full day for this visit. By the map I couldn't imagine how much I was about to see in this complex. If you have time it even worthy to reserve two days to really appreciate each corner of this complex. I had only one day, so it was quite intense.I didn't take a tour, but I rented a audio guide to visit the most important places of this vast castle complex.

Great historical site.. This castle and adjoining buildings is on top of a hill overlooking Prague. Some great views and fascinating buildings from a Cathedral to old Bishops Palace, a Royal Palace and further up the main street some great places to eat and drink. The tour bus stops here for 30 minutes but you will need longer so catch the tram up and walk down.

an amazing walk in castle district. castle district was a part of the walking tour we joined in Prague, we only got to see the outside and the view from the castle vantage point. it was an amazing sight. how i wish we had the time to go inside the buildings and the castle itself.

A Must See. An amazing array of Cathedrals, castles, museums, gardens with amazing views. It is not to be missed. I particularly loved the back street showing how the "little people" lived and worked and housing the display of weaponry, armour, and torture equipment.

Lovely, historic area with gorgeous views. This area of town is on an incline, so all visitors should be prepared for a hearty climb. The streets are lined with cobblestone, so comfortable shoes are a must in order to enjoy the experience. There are plenty of coffee shops on route to the castle, and vendors selling local snacks and ice-cream dot the landscape. There were lots of tourists when I visited, and Prague is pretty touristy, so large crowds should be expected. When we finally made it up to the castle, the reward was immense. The city of Prague lay at our feet, and made for amazing views. St. Vitus Cathedral, St. George Basilica, and the castle are all located within the same contingent area, so all can and should be visited on the same trip. I would highly recommend a visit for all lovers of historical places and baroque architecture.

Excellent castle, lots to see, spend a day or two. Well worth the 350k entry, quite a lot to see and do, so much that it takes two days if you do it right, good job the ticket is valid for two days. Buy a guide book or take the tour though. Check the changing of the guard ceremony out too.

Very crowded, but amazing view of Prague. As expected, this area is quite congested with tourists. Buying tickets to the castle tour is very easy at their office on-site and reasonably priced. The castle itself wasn't really all that impressive, but the Cathedral was amazing. The dining options are limited and crowded, and the service was not very friendly. I would highly suggest that you eat before entering the grounds

Walk into History. The Castle District is a great place to explore the Prague of the Past to the Present.If you decide to walk; allow plenty of time and know there is a good deal of uphill elevation. Side streets yield some of the more relaxing areas away from the tourist traffic.. The various buildings and streets are beautiful and worth the time and effort. We walked from Old Town across the Charles Bridge and then into the District up to the Castle and back.. Take your time and stop at a café for a little break and some refreshments.

Beautiful area for strolling, but go prepared for a hearty walk. We loved the Castle District--walked our way from Old Town to the Castle. However, it was very, very hot during our visit. Take plenty of water, because at times during the route refreshments were hard to find if you wanted to buy water or snacks. We are fairly fit (40 somethings with athletic teens and a preteen), and the walk up the hill on a hot, humid day was taxing (but certainly not impossible).Great views, beautiful architecture, nice views of the river.

Take the time - it is completely worth it.. We had Michael as our tour guide for the Castle portion of the tour. It costs 300 Crowns (which is equal to 12 US dollars) So, completely worth it. We started by the Old Town Square, across the river from the Castle. We took a walk across the bridge and then onto a tram (train if you will) up the hill to the Western Part of the Castle - This is a great idea, because you start from the 'back' of the castle and work your way forward, against the crowds, so VERY thought out. Michael had a very easy going style to his tour. Funny, but not in the way where it might seem to be rehearsed, but more so in a way where it was situational.We took a little break for coffee in the afternoon, and ended with the BEST view of the castle from the side facing the river, so you could see the entire Old town from there. Great historical insight - political insight as well (because it is still where the active president lives (not in the castle but on the grounds)) and also, where parliament is. After the tour he took time to talk to each of us, answered questions, and really made an effort to make us feel welcome. He spoke very openly and positively of the Czech people, and he really added to the entire experience of the tour and our time in the city.
A veritable architectural gem in Europe. Luckily, Prague was saved from the destruction of World War 2. This has allowed the preservation of wonderful architecture, especially in this area of Prague.

Incredible architecture, palaces and gardens.. Incredibly picturesque with amazing views across the whole of the city. Only spent one afternoon here but it's relatively small so you can happily wonder around the whole place in that time, although more time would have been preferable to linger around and really breathe it all in.

Great history. Again lots of history here. There was a beautiful garden that was fun to walk thru. Watched the changing of the guard. Only took about a min. If you don't get to see it you have not missed much.

It's worth climbing the hill to get up to the castle district, as you can stop and admire the view from various points.. The Castle District was beautiful, amazing buildings and steeped in history. Lots to see and do, with lovely wee coffee shops and restaurants dotted around too.
What a view!. We visited this area first with a City tour and then on our last full day walked back up to the Botanical Gardens for some incredible vistas of Prague.

Visit the church of St Nicholas if in this area.. The castle district is considered a must for visitors to Prague, but while there are beautiful views from the castle itself, and lots of souvenir shops on the steep hill leading up, we opted for the second priced option for tours which allowed us access to St Vitus cathedral, Golden Lane, and the castle. To be honest, I thought that our visit to St Nicholas church at the bottom of the hill, not far from Charles bridge on Malostranske Namesti ( Little quarter square ) was more impressive. There is a small entrance fee here, but it is very beautiful and according to the guidebooks, Mozart played the organ here a few days before he died in 1787.Very impressive, and amazing to think that it was like this several hundred years ago.

Must Visit. Must visit for absorbing the beauty of Prague. Lot of walking has to be done to see the Castle district but worth ever bit of it. St. Vitus Cathedral is beautiful and symbolises the spirituality and beauty of the castle district.
Beautiful. A beautiful area that is really magnificent and shows the true history of Prague. Recommend going as early as possible to beat the crowds.

Multiple Places to Visit in the Complex. This is a nice trip. We bought a ticket for 5 sites in the complex and enjoyed ourselves. If you have kids you might want to add the toy museum as well. We had lunch in a small cafe and it was good.

Stunning views of the city from the top!. This half of the city is really pretty with interesting architecture everywhere, windy cobbled streets and cafe's everywhere. It is more hilly than the other side of the river and climbing to the castle is hard work! The cathedral here is well worth a visit but tickets to enter are quite expensive although concession prices are available. The museum of suits of armour and weapons is also a very interesting visit!

Spectacular views - so beautiful!. The castle district was absolutely amazing - incredibly picturesque. We took a tram ride up to this area and wandered around - and then enjoyed lunch at a place under the bridge with panoramic views.
Super views from the top. The castle and area around provided great views of the city, some very decent restaurants and bars. The museums at the castle are a must see, as is the Baroque era Cathedral

Awesome place. The Castle district is one of most beautiful places in Prague. St Vitus cathedral is truly stunning and the royal gardens are nice place to take a walk and relax. Be sure to see the change of guards (at noon) and if you have time - visit the castle in the night time (open till 10 p.m. in summer). The lighting of the cathedral and view of the Prague at night is remarkable. Tip: do not buy the ticket - the entering part of cathedral is free (ticket is only if you want to visit the whole church) and arrive at exactly 5 p.m. for the Golden lane (after 5 it is free of charge and the shops are still open till about 5.30).

Castle district charms. I thought this was a castle with one family that owned it once. I was surprised to learn there are about 25 residences together with a cathedral and other churches that form this District. You need at least a day to walk and discover it all. Stop and have lunch at one of the many restaurants in the district. Don't miss the cathedral which dominates the site. The changing of the guard takes places daily with due pomp and trumpets playing.
Good views. Well worth the visit. Watch the changing of the guards at noon. Walk in the gardens. The cathedral is pretty.

More a group of palaces really. Hard to find a focus for the visit. Difficult to establish where one thing ends and another begins, and of course very crowded. By chance we found our way into the gardens below the ramparts, which were empty, peaceful, beautiful and delightful.

Beautiful architecture. Make up of numerous buildings of various architectural designs and styles the whole area has more of a feeling of a separate town. There are numerous palaces, religious buildings, statues, fountains, and other administrative buildings necessary to run a large castle complex. Don’t exhaust yourself struggling up the hill, simply take tram 22 up the hill and alight at Pohorelec. From there you can make your way down to the main castle complex, passing as you go numerous interesting buildings, shops and restaurants. Afterwards visiting the area you can take a more leisurely walk back down the hill.
Beautiful day trip. The Castle district is a beautiful part of Prague. You need to allow a least a full day to see it in detail but it was definitely worthwhile

Magical Prague. You really can't go wrong walking anywhere in central Prague! My advice would be to travel there in mid to late Spring . . . when all the trees begin to blossom and flowers bloom, and the city isn't overcrowded with summer tourists. Begin your first day in Prague at the upper end of Vaclavske Namesti (Wenceslas Square) at around 1 or 2 pm or so . . . make your way down from the horse statue near the front of Muzeum to Mustek square at the end of Vaclsvske Namesti, stopping at whatever shops or etc. that pique your interest. then continue straight down the narrowing street (not far off of Mustek you will see the Estates Theater (Stavovske Divadlo) where Mozart first presented his opera Don Giovani!!) . . . a beautiful theater .... Try to get tickets to see Don Giovani performed here ... there are often very interesting takes on this classic opera! Continue winding down the same street (I believe it is called Melantrichova at this point....but you should be able to easily follow the flow of foot traffic at this point), until you find yourself in the Old Town Square (Staromestke Namesti), looking up at the old Astronomical Clock (Orloj ... the prince who commissioned the building of this clock had the architect's eyes burned out of his head upon its completion, not wanting another like it to ever be built .... In a brilliant stroke of revenge, the architect/designer of the clock had one of his apprentices go deep into the clock and remove one tiny piece .... and for more than 300 years, nobody could figure out how to make the clock work!!). That church you see to your right, tucked behind a row of Baroque buildings, is called Tyn Chapel . . . poke your head inside and look up to your left . . . you will see a tiny window oddly looking over the main chapel area . . . that is the window of an apartment Franz Kafka lived in for a time! The famous Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe is buried in this church . . . for what reason? I have no idea! :) Wander the square as long as you like, but not later than the onset of dusk . . . you have more walking to do before then . . . Return to the old Astronomical clock and walk straight down Male Namesti (you will see a Hardrock Cafe on your right shortly after starting down this road . . . buy a T-shirt there . . . why not??) . . . continue down this road, which will curve to the left and become Karlova . . . take the first right to continue on Karlova . . . turn right on Husova for a few steps, then left again to continue on Karlova. There are too many interesting little shops and things to see along this road . . . so try to notice as much as you can as you walk along (note: most street musicians in Prague are amazingly talented.... almost always worth stopping and enjoying.... be sure to tip!!). You will pass a few churches on your way until you reach Krizovnicka (be careful crossing this street.... trams and cars stop for no one when they have the right of way in this town!). After you have crossed this street, turn around and notice the statues of each of the martyred apostles lining the rooftop (beautiful Baroque statues!). By now you will know what you have walked all this way to see . . . the Charles Bridge (Karluv Most) . . . If you have timed your walk correctly, you will have reached this most amazing of medieval bridges (originally constructed in the late 14th/early 15th centuries) . . . the Baroque statues that line the bridge and give it it's unique character, were added one by one, beginning in the early 1700s. From Karluv Most you will see Hradcany . . . the spectacular Prague Castle, brilliantly lit as dusk settles in to early evening, under a deep blue sky, with the last strains of light from the setting sun disappear over the horizon. This is how I first experienced Prague . . . It was late April, 1991, and I began my journey from a small house in Prague 4 into a city about which I knew not a thing . . . In my ethnocentric ignorance (as a typical American), I thought Prague would be a poverty stricken, dilapidated mess . . . instead I found an absolute gem, right in the heart of Europe! Continue across Karluv Most into Mala Strana and make your way up to the castle (Hradcany) . . . again . . . too much to see and experience for me to go into detail here . . . but make a point of going into the catacombs of Svaty Vitus (St. Vitus Cathedral) in the heart of the castle, and take a walk down Zlata Ulice (the Golden Way), where the diminutive alchemists once lived (note that Franz Kafka also lived for a time in a flat on this little street inside the castle!). I hope this lengthy entry helps somebody enjoy Prague that much more than they might otherwise have! By the way . . . I have returned to Prague multiple times since returning to the United States in 1995 . . . it is still every bit as magical as it ever was!

Nice for an afternoon walk. It's a nice district to walk around during the afternoon. I didn't feel the need to pay extra and go inside, so I just stood in the gardens and saw the castle from the outside. I don't regret it.
magical city. Stunning sights! Be prepared to walk and walk and never get bored. The sights are awesome. The best of Europe!
Sort of interesting. Not enough signage to know where you are going, so got lost quite frequently. Very spread out and tough to cover on a hot hot day.

You will learn the History of the city. you will walk thought historical buildings, and visit moseums. This is a good opportunity visiting Prague. I will sugegst to go there early in the morning to avoid quie.

History all around. This is so many things all at once it's hard to know where to start. The castle is the official residence of the President and has many formal functions. Like the rest of Prague, a lot of maintenance is on-going with scaffolding on many buildings but, somehow, this doesn't spoil anything and it's good to see that they are continually trying to improve the city. Magnificent historic buildings all around. Do take an official tour, you will learn so much more than by just wandering aimlessly. I lost count of how many bridal parties we saw, it's great to see the city being embraced by its' people. It's easy to see that Prague has been the capital city of several historic empires over the centuries, there's not a plain building in sight with everything done to please the eye. I had lunch at the open air restaurant in the square at the rear of St Vitus' Cathedral, sitting at a table under the tree. Perfect! From there it's a downhill walk with wonderful vistas and entertainments all the way down to the Lesser Town below. A great way to spend a day.

So much to see. So much to see! We visited on a hot day in July and got through most of it in one day. We didn't pay for the most expensive ticket and in hindsight it might have been worth paying for the audio guide but we didn;t think of that at the time. Great views from the top.
Thoroughly enjoyable time. What an amazing place. You will get to see some stunning views, impeccable gardens and very impressive buildings

Must visit. Must visit, even though it is crowded and the ticket counter is very slow. There are the main parts for less and all the buildings for more. We did the highlights. I was not really impressed with the castle part, I thought we missed something, but it was only a few rooms.

amazing :). The castle's architecture is wonderful. Prague is a "gothic city" and the castle adds gothic splendour to the city. The view from the castle grounds is amazing. You can truly see why it is called the city of a hundred spires :)

Large attractive area. Many interesting architectural buildings and interesting gardens. To see inside most of the building it is necessary to queue up for a ticket. Even a detailed map of the area costs about 5 CZK. Allow at least half a day to explore the area.

Amazing!. Of course this is the best thing in Prague. Castle is beautiful, has such fantastic things to see. I recommend getting circuit A ticket and for families it costs 700 CZK, that means about 26 eur, much less than in other European countries for a castle with such heritage. Once in, visit the St Vitus cathedral, which is to me the best thing in castle. Architecture is amazing, windows beautiful. St Jiri cathedral is nice as well, do not miss the Golden Lane, with beautiful houses, today furnished as those merchants lived there, for example, herbalist's home, then taylor's house, there's even a house that was used by Kafka. This must be one of best things in the Castle. You need at least 4-5 hours for this amazing complex and its gardens.In castle district there are Mostecka and Nerudova str, not to be missed, beautiful antique shops and cafes, nice architecture.

Sweaty in Summer. Climbed up in 35 degrees in August. Was probably a bad idea, should have gone with an Air Conditioned Uber/Taxi. Anyway it was well worth it, views are stunning. And make sure you pay and go up to the top of the Cathedral to see all Prague and how the clock mechanism work.

Steep(ed) in History & Culture!. I thought this rich part of the city had fewer tourists and better views. It can be tough walking but that only makes the coffee or beer breaks only better. Make sure you cross the bridge.
Steep but pretty. We didn't go in the castle as my kids were not interested but we did wander around the area and lower walls. Beautiful views of city. Busy in August!
Nice. We stayed at a hotel near here and found the area charming. However, it was too far away from the areas that had the action we liked. Would not stay in the area again.

I wish I had 2 days to visit this region of Prague. This whole area is so steeped in culture and tradition, its ridiculous!! You have to have an audio or a guide, if not a lot of the things you see look awesome, but lack true meaning, We bought a ticket to see just 4 of the 10 places of interest in this area for 250Kc. Absolute value for money, but even by limiting ourselves to 4, we were pushed for time. I feel it requires 2 visits, in order to see all 10 places of interest.

Favorite part of the city. This is a big area which requires a lot of walking. Central place is probably the world's largest castle with a great view of the city. You have to spend one day to explore everything. Definitely worth to be seen. Nearby restaurants are not the cheapest, so be careful.

Prague Castle id impressive. Whilst we didn't go inside the castle, you can look around and visit inside the walls, very impressive architecture and great views across Prague.Walking down from the Castle to downtown is well worth doing as their are plenty of interesting shops, antique shops and restaurants, its a pretty steep walk but worth it.

Come for the view, and then walk in some local history. One of Europes largest castle/palace complexes. In moderately poor condition, still being restored. The cathedral has enormous stained glass window by Mucha, as well as a baroque interior underneath a gothic exterior. The Lobkowitz palace down the hill has autograph manuscripts by the great composers.
Huge. A huge area to walk in, we got lost several times. Lots to see and lots to take pictures of. Great architecture and overview over the city.
Lots To See. Lots to take in with lots of interesting buildings. There are a lot of steps to negotiate in places so not much wheelchair access.

A must tourist attraction.. A must visit for any tourist. Attractive buildings and plenty of history. Great views of the river. Do go into the Castle and visit the Cathedral. If you are relatively good walker, continue down to Charles Bridge and onward into the Old Town Square.

Krasne miesta ale nezabudnite si zobrat turistickeho sprievodcu ( papieroveho alebo elektronickeho ). Co je krasne vidiet, Rudolfinum, stare meske ulice, socha Tomasa Garika Masaryka, Strachovsky klastor, Klastor Klarisiek, Petrinska vyhladna a samozrejme Chram sv Vita. Co nesmiete si zabudnut je turisticky sprievodca v papierovej alebo elektronickej forme. Bez toho je to na velku skodu. In english : What is beautiful to see, Rudolfinum, stare Meske street Tomasa Garik Masaryk statue, Strachovská Monastery, the Poor Clares, Petrin prospect, and of course Chram sv Vita.What should not you forget it is a tourist guide in paper or electronic form. Without this, it is the great shame.

Amazing Prague Views. Known as Hradcany in Czech, this is the district surrounding the Prague Castle & offers the shortest route to it.The main attraction is of course this largest castle in the world but a large part of the district consists of historical palaces,churches,monasteries,art galleries & museums.This atmospheric district is peaceful compared to the Old Town.Mala strana & provides amazing views of Prague city sitting from one of the lovely restaurants/cafes on the sidewalks.This lovely area has wondrous palaces such as Scwarzenberg & Sternburg ( Holds Art exhibitions), soothing Strahov monastery with its historical libraries,intriguing Loreto Square with replica of the Virgin Mary housed in Loreto House & Cernin palace.
Good views. Another one of Prague's many attractions. We spent a couple of hours here to make the most of this area. The church is very impressive.

Beautiful. Beautiful district of Prague. Very reminiscent of a fairytale scene. The views from the top are just stunning and you can see Prague laid out before you. Whilst here, we bought tickets for a classical concert in the oldest church in Prague - the music, soprano and setting were out of this world. The favourite part of my trip.

Cool, but to busy in August. Very nice sight. Go into the cathedral tower, that gives you one of the better views over prague. To many tourist groups, to noisy and blocking all the nice views. If the castle would limit this than the place would be a lot nicer. The best lemon lemonade of prague.
Good. This was the crowded place of Prague, But due to beauty of the place every one must go to this place.

Stunning view, amazing castle . The castle is beautiful and huge, it's followed by great gardens, from which you can take breathtaking panoramas. However it's quite far from the strict city center and there's no direct metro line to take you exactly there without having to walk a bit. Despite that it's extremely worth to go there. And did I mention there's a little vineyard nearby ?

Prague visit. We took a tour bus up and walked around for a while.
Nice story and lots of history. We stopped at a couple restaurants. One was inside an arcade and the second one was a fancy restaurant with great view of the city below.
Great picture taking opportunity
Must visit Castle distric!!. Great view point of looking over prague city. Beautiful Castle. you can buy a day pass. Take lot of pics from the top of the castle.

Castle with capital C. Prague Castle surely deserved capital C in own name. So big and great with so long history and so many things to see. Makes sure to purchse ticket for all " attractions " and make sure you have whole day for this Castle...you could alwys rest in so nice gardes just bellow main sq. and there is so much to be seing outside and inside. Castle painting gallery is so special too ! we love it !
It could be awesome. My sister was sad that there is no furniture inside the castle ;) Everything could be awsome if not a thousands people on the road.

Super !. We would have missed this place..luckily decided to go there and it was worth it if you visit prague..lots to see around here.the tram lines provide easy connection.make sure you get to know which stop is closest to each attraction

Stunning views. This is a must see if you are in Prague. The views from the Park are simply fantastic and the buildings around the castle are a photographers dream. If going to the Castle, best to do it early morning to beat the bus loads of tourists everywhere.

Better at night but great views in the day as well. While not a 'castle' in the sense you might expect (get a local to explain!) it's a great area to explore and the views across the city are simply stunning. A lot of steps to get up there and I'd recommend avoiding doing it in the middle of the day in Summer. Personally I think it's better at night (but do try to see the views in the day at some point if you can) and we caught a taxi up to there in the evening and walked down via Charles Bridge to the Old Town. It's a lovely walk in a stunning area.

Don't always believe what they say. This is one of those tourist sights/sites which does not quite live up to the tourist literature. Nothing wrong with it, although steep and narrow streets make access tedious and the legendary street of little houses is really not worth the effort of fighting through the mobs to have a look inside. There are nicer parts of

Be there at noon for the changing of the guard. The castle district is definitely not to be missed. If anything, the views of the rest of the city including Charles Bridge are worth the stair climb to the top. We were also there at noon to witness the changing of the guards and I would recommend being there at that time if you are unsure as to where to go.
