It is quite crowded in the morning, but there are only a few bottle-neck places and then the squares open up and you can spread out a bit. We didn't feel too claustrophobic.

Golden Lane makes it worth it. Be sure to visit Golden Lane as it reveals some wonderful history of those who have lived there in the past. It is preserved beautifully as the area that castle workers live in.
Worthwhile. Definitely worth a walk around, didn't realise Marie Antoinette was born here!!! Architecture is very akin to Bavarian - in fact I felt like I was in the set of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang!!

evening walk. we cross Karol Bridge in the evening and want for a walk around streets of the district. its very calm romatic and a bit misterious. a lot of magical small streets, stairs and small pubs and restaurants in every corner.
Great view. Offers a great view of Prague and if you time it right you get to see the changing of the guards. The golden Lane has shops and museums of all sorts of things

Well preserved and clean city. Well preserved and clean city. Awesome views over the city from the castle. Vibrant night life. Most locals in restaurants and shops were helpful and were able to speak English.

Impressive Castle Overlooking Prague Center. The castle sits atop a hill overlooking the city and river. It is a long hike uphill, so you might consider taking public transit (there is a tram stop across from the entry). Once inside, you have a variety of tour choices, and after, you can walk back down through the gardens.

Great views, and lots to see. This area contains all the castle buildings, which were unfortunately covered up for renovations when we were there. Still, this is a large area with lots to see, and great views around pretty much every corner.

lovelly suburb of Prague. stunning walk..this is a must for a great day out, the place is jammed packed full of stunning architecture .take your time and explore the place carefully, lots to see and many restaurants to stop off and have a bite to eat.
Completes your visit to Prague!. Castle district in Prague is basically an area full of castles and historic properties that are well-maintained. Home to Prague's noteworthy monuments.

Great Rail Journeys - Beijing to London. Loved Prague, only there for the day, need to go back & see more. Everything is within walking distance. The castle is great, with all the different building & the tradition.

Beautiful historical buildings and views, a must see area!. This whole area has plenty of gorgeous buildings and amazing views. Stunning architecture too. A walk through the Royal Gardens is recommended too, we learned a lot about trees! Shady areas were such a relief! Great views in all directions. Must see!

A must see . You can't go to Prague without the castle and the cathedral on your list. Wonderful to see and I recommend this attraction to everybody. Caztle and Cathedral in same spot. Very busy with tourists which is understandable.

Not as interesting as I had hoped. It is very pretty but quite empty, it's a shame there's not more in each room to give a better idea of how things were used. It's a nice view though and a pleasant walk.

Beautiful, but lack of information. The Castle of Prague is one of the greatest atractions in the city. It is of big historical importance and beauty. You must see it.However: the are few historical informations in the places to visit, specially in the state rooms. It would be necessary to pay for an audioguide, but it is more expensive than the ticket of entrance! 250 CZK for the Circuit B vs. 350 CZK for an audioguide. Comparing to other Castles (for an exemple, Cracow) or Palaces (for an exemple, Warsaw), it is far below the expectations in terms of informations and organization.
Prague history. Take tram #22 to the palace stop. The combo tours allow access to more than one venue. Don't miss the Royal Garden for its attractive view of local botanicals.

Worth seeing. Apart from the Old Town Square, this is the main place Prague is famous for and is worth seeing regardless the time of the year. Nice routes around the site. St. Vitus Cathedral is amazing and reminds me Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris. And Golden Lane is the cutest lane you've ever seen, with tiny hand made souvenirs shops and small houses/exhibitions showing how people lived back in those old times. Must see.

Worth the visit.. Simply beautiful. There are amazing buildings in every direction. The whole place is a work of art. The signage to get there from the Stare Mesto was so easy. At most intersections are great signs informing the direction of all major sites. The view of Hradcany from the Karluv Most (Charles Bridge) was spectacular. Inside it is easy to get confused about where to go, but look on the back of your ticket. There is a simple map that provides you with the layout and re-orient you. We suggest saving the III entrance for the peak heat as it is cool in the basement. We were able to recharge in the cool and dark space.
Wandering around Prague Castle area. A fascinating area well worth wandering around. Lot's of small bars and restaurants which are well worth a visit.

Nice walking route to include the Castle complex. If you like walking, there's a good circular route from Wenceslas Square past the Opera House, over the bridge, into the park to the funicular railway station that brings you up to the Petrin tower. You can also walk up the hill to the tower and stop at the restaurant on the way. The tower has 299 steps to the top, is a replica of the Eiffel tower, affords superb panoramic views across the whole city and will sway in the wind in even a light breeze so not good for people with a nervous disposition. It has restaurants and facilities at the bottom and another walk across the park will bring you to the beer making monks and further into the castle complex. All the signs are in Czech so use your smartphone satnav and/or the free maps. Whilst the castle area is spectacular, the queues and crowds in August were prohibitive, so we kept walking down to the Charles Bridge and back through the Jewish quarter to the old town Square. In the heat of summer, and on those cobblestones, lets just say your feet will tell you all about it that evening sipping an Urquell...
Lovely Streets. A really nice area to walk around in and explore. Lots to see and do and eat. It is different and equally as beautiful at night.
Great History in this District. We spent about 2 hours touring the Castle District. The Castles are so amazing and you should not miss this area.

Amazing architecture. Once you cross the bridge into the lovely part of the Old Town away from the Square (which is extremely underwhelming) you will be greeted with amazing buildings, architecture and views of Prague. Go into the Palace area which is vast with a beautiful Church.

Magical views and pretty gardens. We walked the hundreds of steps to the top to get to as many vantage points as we could for the views of this beautiful city w the red roofs and spires. Gardens were cool in the shade. We loved this area.
Too much for one day. Too much to see in just one day I thought, but tickets are valid for two days, so take it easy and arrange to visit on two days so you don't get overloaded.
A Must See in Prague. So much to see so make sure you give yourself plenty of time. Whether is is day or night, you will truly enjoy yourself.

Another part of Prague to avoid if you dislike crowds. This area is a bit less crowded than the Old Town Square, but if possible, has even more American ex-pats hustling tourists. Plus the cab fare to get here was outrageous, even in Crowns!
Beautiful. The area it self values a visit of few days. If you have ever questioned wether Kings garden has greener gras, I may tell you, it has.

A Must See. Allow a couple of hours here and plan on walking up and down hill a bit. Definitely have the camera and water. There are several attractions here but the signage leaves a bit to be desired.

Castle is not worth it. The castle is not worth visiting because despite its huge size, it only allows a small area for tourists to see. The entrance fee is not worth it. I would prefer to look at the castle from the river specially at sunset.

Views worth the steps! but could've done with some information.. After quite a steep hill and steps on a hot day we got to the top of the Castle District. Unfortunately the 'Castle' was getting renovated whilst we were there so did not get to see it in it's full state! The area was very busy, but to be expected in the middle of the high season, so maybe arrive earlier in the day to avoid some of the crowds. There were lots of buildings to see without paying (like us!) for a tour or tickets. The ticket system did seem a bit complicated with lots of different combinations and there were very big queues for the information desk. Be sure to walk the gardens, as this is where the best views were! What let it down was it could've done with some more information boards up and around explaining different places to you, as there were very few in any language and it would've made all the difference to know what we looking at!
Lovely clean city. lovely area well worth the walk. lots of interesting things to see in and around the castle area . A really beautiful clean area.

WALK IT. Walk the area! Great a great view back at the city and just enjoy the beauty of Prague. There is also an amazing Starbucks at the top of the hill that has an upper patio to sit and enjoy your coffee and pastry and just soak it all in

Allocate at least half a day. The castle district is undoubtedly one of the main sights of Prague.If you are with a car, I recommend to start the trip from the North, since you can easily park by the tram stop "Pražský hrad", on the street "U Prašného mostu" for a small fee. If on foot, I found the best way to go through the Charles Bridge, go up just straight ahead, and go up the stairs at the street "Radnické schody", close to Schwarzenberg Palace.All you need to do then is to slowly approach to east. Most of the museums and palaces inside are wonderful sights by themselves but take up a lot of time if visited. For a quick trip, I advise not to miss the St Vitus cathedral (in the middle of the castle), the Golden Lane (touristic, but still), the view points in the east over the city, and the lovely, romantic stair leading back down to the city.
Great views and interesting history. A great place to walk around and learn about the history of the city. If you don't want to walk up to it, take the tram.

great church to see. Very big area to cover in an hour so take 2-3 hours to spend there depends on what you liıke. My favourite was the church and the glasses insşde the church as well. This place is in every travel guide to visit so do it :)

beautiful. It is a very nice area, maybe the most beautiful for me, from here you can appreciate a great view of Prague and also have a walk in a garden, as well as going to the Golden lane and visit the amazing St Vitus Cathedral.

Number 22 Tram is essential.. Unless you are one of those people who love climbing in the midday heat, with sweat dripping and red faced.. I suggest you all to catch the Number 22. tram up the hill. Get off at the relevant spot and take in the cobbled streets, the view of Prague and the fantastic architecture. What made this whole experience better was knowing that as we were enjoying on the local ice creams and walking down, there were 100s of people walking up with agitated faces and grumbling conversations. Now, what could be better than that.. CATCH THE NO.22 TRAM!!! :D

Stunning views. Wonderful views across this stunning city make a visit essential, a stroll around is free but to see the interiors are not except for the first part of St Vitus Cathedral. A ride up on the number 22 tram is recommended you can then walk down via the steps or pathway.

Great view . I went on foot from Charles bridge. It a bit of a walk but the view is great. Went over the castle and the golden lane. Nice place if you're interested in history. I didn't take a guide. Golden lane is so crowded so hard to take any pictures. It's really small not a long street. The view from over the top is spectacular. You see the whole of Prague.

not to be missed when in Prague. The castle district is rather impressive - sitting above town one first has to get there - either 'climbing' up or by public transport or taxi. Take your time to walk along the entire district and be prepared, that you need an entry ticket for multiple attractions including the little golden street. When up there one also has a wonderful view over town and towards charles bridge.
Amazing history, for you to enjoy!. Amazing. Take your time and feel the history!If you can, I would recommend a private guide, it is worth the cost!

At night visit there be better. Actually here is the top of the Prague ,have a good view on site seeing
But in front of the castle had many building blocked ,difficult to have a whole view of
Besides , even you bring with Gopro and tripod ,also can't to take a good photo
I suggest to take a photo in old town rather

Gotta see but too crowded even at opening. We did the B option tour. No pressure to buy audio tour. One side says tickets and the other side says tickets with audio tour so choose the side of the ticket office to go to. We chose not to get the audio tour. The churches had no signs but the castle and the Golden Lane had plenty of detailed signs in English and other languages that explained what we saw in each room. If you want more history or details on the churches or the other buildings then get the audio tour. The castle was a bit confusing with poor directional signs but poke around in all directions including going up the stairs before you exit through the gift shop. We spent 90 min and might have spent longer if the weather wasn't so hot and crowds weren't so bad. But this was plenty to see everything, read the signs, and take a bunch of pictures.
Nice. You must see it if you are in Prague. This is unbelievable beautiful castle! with breathtaking view.

Lots of things to see at the top of the hill.. Unlike most of Europe, the "Castle" in Prague is really a collection buildings all together at the top of the hill overlooking the city. It is full of interesting sights like the Cathedral, museums and little lanes. Definitely worth a visit.

Extensive walking required. Another of the things that cant be missed in Prague is the castle complex. Choose the tram 22 to arrive in comfort here. We bought the B tour and a tourist guide in English. On hindsight choosing the Sandemans tour would have been better as the tourist guide was inferior in comparison to our free city tour guide of the day before.
Terrific spot to see Prague from above.. This is a terrific spot to get the whole view of Prague! There are so many gorgeous buildings and sites to be seen from here.

A must go destination.. In all the many year's i've been going to Prague this area still amazer's me ,i still find it as magical as when i saw it for the first time.I love to jump tram 22 up to the STRAHOV MONASTERY have a wander around this wonderful place,take in a meal or a beer in the monastery brewpub and then just lose myself in the castle area.THE GOLDEN MILE is superb to walk down ,lot's of restaurant's and tavern's ( AVOID PLACE'S WITH NO PRICE ON MENU'S ,THE MYSTIC CAFE IN PARTICULAR ,they can and will charge you what they want,so beware ).The site's are superb in the Castle District and area around here,ST VITUS CATHEDRAL,PALACE, to name but some of the delight's of this area,offering great view's of the city,this is most certainly a photogragher's dream so dont forget the snapper.There are all manner of shop's ,great to get some keep sake's.This is a must go destination in this wonderful city and one i will look forward to visiting again next year on holiday.

Golden Lane is the best bit.. Take the tram up the hill and get off above the castle - a much easier walk than up from the bottom. It's worth paying to get into the row of houses and shops built into the castle wall.
Hradcay tour. Highly recommend arranging for a private tour of book halls. Amazing collection of old and rare books.

A great morning's exploring. We had a lovely morning up here. We only did circuit B which gave us limited entry to the palaces but that was enough. Golden Lane was particularly good to see. The cafes are reasonable in the grounds as well. Lovely views over the rest of the city.

Walking tour from our hotel. Our hotel was at the Charles Bridge so it was nice to walk west and not cross the bridge for once. Mostly uphill walk and the castle complex has many, many museums in it, I liked the water tower which held a military museum.

Don't miss this.. You can buy a short time ticket or a long time ticket. We bought the short time ticket as it had everything in it we wanted to see : the St Vitus Cathedral, the big hall of the palace, St George church and the golden street. It took us about 3 hours to see everything and have a drink in between visits.

Best views of Prague. Centrepiece for a visit to the fairy tale city of Prague. Suggest you grab the tram up the hill and enjoy the sites at the top and on the way down. Enjoy panoramic views of this beautiful city and its river.  Don't miss Lobkowicz Palace (a somewhat hidden gem). Golden Lane is a fascinating journey into the past beautifully presented and preserved. Wander down through the winding streets of the Mala Strana and visit the John Lennon Peace Wall. Keep your eyes peeled for David Cherny's quirky and original sculptures .. always interesting and amusing.

Stunning architecture. Took the tram here as was very hot the day we visited, but accessible via many steps for the fit & active!! Was very interesting and plenty to see including the Cathedral. Didn't bother with tickets to go inside the castle as plenty to see outside but I'm sure worth the visit if you do.
Charming. Very charming part of Prague. Full of little independent shops, coffe stops and restaurants with traditional czech cousine.
Beautiful!. My favourite area of the city with gorgeous little restaurants tucked down little side streets and in glorious courtyards. Find Novy Svet on your travels!

Castle District - Take the 22 Line for a perfect start. The Castle District is a good way to see Prague from above - you get great views of the city from there. Walking up to the castle requires endurance and a level of stamina. You should definitely take the Tram there - catch the 22 LINE - it's easy. The castle itself is not like ones you see in England, it is more like a walled city but that does not take away its charm. Walk down in to Prague, just taking in the sights.
Nice area to walk and discover. Beautiful view over the city. It is nice to walk up here. I could be a lot of crowd so check the best time to go here. Nice castle and history.

Stunning!. We went here with our infant boy for a day, and sure it was fantastic!Strolling around and taking in the beautiful architecture and such.Many dining options, but be aware that the restaurants 'down hill' are not the best in town...
So much history. Superb views and so much to see. Hard to fit it all in within a couple of days that we had in Prague. We visited this area in June 2014.

Would be a shame to miss this.. Don't miss this. There is so much to see and do here. Separate ticket for "the Golden Mile" which I can't really recommend unless you want to shop. Pretty, but it's mostly shops. But plenty of palaces and cathedrals to see inside. Suggest a morning tour, then a coffee or lunch break in the square inside, then finish up with palaces.

Prague Hrad castle good trip. Lovely place needs a whole day to explore. Catch the 22 tram from the town as the hills a killer to get there. The tour is great as the guide can explain Czech history and the statues around the grounds. Changing of the guard was good.
Got it all in one section!. Stayed in this district and loved it! Busy, but quiet...LOADS to do and full of great restaurants!!!

A great experience of the Old Prague. With fantastic views and interesting exhibits which include bygone ways of life, this is a must to visit. Take in lunch at one of the great restaurants and make your visit a leisurely one to really enjoy this place

Unmissable. It is absolutely necessary to visit Hradcany if you're in Prague! Walk up the stairs along the remparts to reach the top where are located the Royal Palace and St Vitus church, both very beautiful landmarks.

A wonderful view of Prague with beautiful areas for walking and wandering.. The Prague Castle is not a tradition single large structure, but rather a collection of royal residences, churches and cathedrals. The main grounds are open for walking, but entry fees exist for many of the structures. The view of Prague from the castle grounds is spectacular.

Beautiful area!. The Castle area is beautiful. The gardens are well maintained and are very relaxing. There are some street vendors that make it interesting. Several places that are terrific for photos.

View from above. Requires a lot of walking and there isn't much to see really. I think the best part is the view of the lower district with its red roofs from the top. Worth a visit for that iconic view.

A wonderful area to visit. The District is on top of the hill. My best suggestion is to take tram #22 from anywhere in the lower part of town, get off at the Pražský hrad stop (Prague Castle), and follow the crowds through the area to the downhill walk. You'll end up near the Malostranská Metro stop, which is also a collection point for many tram lines. The entire transit system is VERY easy to use! This way you'll take the transit system up the hill, and be able to leisurely walk down the hill.When you first get off the tram, be sure to visit the gardens on the left hand side, especially the birds exhibit.While there are fees to enter some parts of the castle area, the church is free to enter.

Bring your walking shoes; museum highlights worth it. The ticket salesperson for the castle museums was impressively helpful and honest--he insisted we buy the smaller package of museum entries rather than the larger ones ("Who knows about these other places? Just do the key ones!"). The little golden alley was especially unique and interesting to see.

Fascinating area, lots to see. Loved all the fascinating buildings and cobbled alleys. Prices varied a great deal on refreshments. Make sure you choose places with prices in the menu otherwise you risk paying a lot, lot more.
must-do. Prague is beautifull, old & modern, attracting tourists from all over the world, of all ages, with all kind of interests. Chrles Bridge, and the Old Town are fabulous.

Immersive Visitor Experience. The tour around the castle was very interesting and the dungeons made you think how well behaved you'd want to be!!! There were some grisly torture items and lots of armour to see

Visit it early in the morning. Hradcany is a shut-in complex, and early in the morning is empty. Approached from the rear entrance of the castle (is open) - wide staircase leads to it. The castle is easily accessible by tram and metro Hradnchanska. The whole complex is very impressive, but the most beautiful is the Cathedral of St. Vitus. Magnificent Gothic building located in the third courtyard of the castle. Built on the site of a former rotunda from 929 year. The castle itself is like a city within a city. - Small streets, the cathedral, many courtyards and other smaller churches. Rear entrance of the castle reaches directly the Black Tower and the palace "Lobkowitz", continues in a small street, in countries where there are several courtyards and reaches the modest square in front of the Golden lane. The most famous street in Hradcany - that of craftsmen.

get ticket first!!. It is such a must do attraction but badly sign posted. We had queued for 20 mins to get into the cathedral before realizing we needed a ticket from a room tucked on the side in the first square you go into on the way in!! There are two types of ticket to buy both cover quite a few different areas, both very reasonably priced. Even the queue was a joke, if it wasnt for a woman coming out and saying that if you if wanted a ticket not the audio tour to go the front and get into the hall where there were three booths selling tickets and no queues at all, we would have waited a good 20 mins outside in a useless queue.How ever once in armed with ticket amazing, awe inspiring ,magnificent cathedral!!The organ we being played just so atmospheric. Golden lane very twee and mega crowed.

UPHILL AND WORTH IT. Delightful shops along the way as you continually climb up, up. There is a John Lennon Wall and a John Lennon Pub in the district- an homage to him. He is a hero to Czech youth-the peaceful activist--and students demonstrated against Communism in the "Velvet Revolution" of 1989 here. Complete with singer/guitar player doing Lennon songs loved it.

Absolutely Beautiful and Grand. This Castle is sooo big, sooo grand it is hard to conceive it's size. This castle is very well maintained and the gardens are beautiful. I took a tour first then went back and spent 3 hours taking in all of the surroundings with more than ample amounts of photo opportunities. There was enen a bride and groom there having fotos taken.

Fantastic area. We went on a walking tour which I would not recommend because it went too slowly. Just explore this area by yourself or use a tour which has an audio guide so they don't have to keep stopping.

Beautiful castle, review the ticket options before buying the combined ticket. The Prague Castle can be accessed by taken line 22 bus and walk up. It takes a bit of walk, but is well worth it.We bought the combined ticket within the castle district which covers around 9 sites. It would have been really helpful if the lady at the counter would have given us some suggestions on the sites to cover. Our first stop within the castle was the church. It is very historical and I would advice taking a guided tour if you want to know more about the history and the details. We hired the radio guide, which did not give justice. We also noticed that in the church there was an entrance were everyone was entering for free which was a bit disappointing. We then covered two other spots, another small chapel and the museum, both were less interesting. We spend around 3-4 hours, but if plan to see the other attractions, I would advice to spend the entire day there.My recommendations is to review all the ticket options and select the ticket with the attraction you are interested in. The combined ticket we purchased was very expensive.

So much to see. I bought an excellent value combined ticket to the main castle sites (see my review of St Vitus for comments about timing) & in addition visited 2 palaces & Starhov Monastery & there was still plenty to see.If you are o na tight budget, I also noticed lunch in the streets between the Castle & the Monastery seemed particularly cheap.

Great panoramic view. Interesting place and worth to be seen. The panoramic view from the top is really fantastic. If you are not in good shape though it is little bit hard to reach to the top by feet because there are a lot of stairs :)

The Distilled History of Prague. The buildings of the Castle District , and the many statues, trace the history of Bohemia as it was, Czechoslovakia as it briefly became , and the Czech Republic as it is. The statues of Keppler and Tycho Brahe both of whom worked in Prague testify to the seat of learning Rudolph II had established at Praha. The Strahov Monastery, burnt down in turn by the Swedish, French and Prussian armies then neglected by the Communists. The Royal Palace originally Romanesque, then Gothic, and finally Maria Theresa's Baroque additions, from the eastern window of which the second Defenestration of Prague ignited the Thirty Years war. On the way up the Second World War Memorial ( a tattered flag) seems to poignantly sum up the betrayal by the Allies seeking to avoid war

crowded large complex of buildings. Be prepared for lots of walking past the many buildings that make up the castle complex. We visited in July. It was more crowded than Disneyland, one tour group on top of another. You are likely to get more out of it if the galleries and music performances in the castle complex are your taste and you make time to go inside less visited places..

A definite "go back to place". History abounds, Prague is worth a visit. Take a tour of the castle you won,t regret this. You also get a fantastic view of the city, see all the sites from one vantage point.

oh well !. a bit of a let down. i mean there is really no castle if that is what you expect. while it is touted as one of the oldest castles in europe, you actually have much more recent buildings and a cathedral. and they all stand where the castle once stood. well !

Nice part of city. We toured this area by foot after leaving Prague castle and wondering downward along streets filled with shops, church's, and eating places. This is a nice alternative to the old City across the river and accessed this area by the 22 tram.
Well worth crossing the river. The Castle District is well worth visiting. Lots of restaurants and lovely little shops. Also you can get beautiful views of the city.

A District Rich With History. It's big and it's up on the hill. But it's the most rewarding stroll you could have in Prague, with beautiful buildings, cobblestone street, charming small cafes, and a view to the city ... it's really a treat to the eyes.

Worth the climb. We walked to the castle area which was a fairly steep climb but there are lots of cafes along the way to break your journey. As soon as we reached the top the changing of the guard ceremony took place so we stopped to watch that before visiting the cathedral and castle. There are lots of little shops and restaurants in the area and the views of the city from here is worth the walk.

Beautiful Castle Complex. This is a "must" place to visit if your in Prague, beautiful cathedral and church! It's not so much a castle as a fortified complex so there's plenty to see and do, we were there for about 4 hours on an unguided tour but you could easily spend much longer there! We didn't pay for a guide but got around fine with a little guide book. It was good value as well costing 350ck each for full access to everything available for 2 days (if you wanted it). If it's hot and you can't be bothered to walk up to it then I'd take the tram which are great value and plentiful.

Prague Castle. Make plenty of time for this - so much to see - steep walk up steps - or catch tram 22 to take you up most of the way or the road train from Wenceslas Square will drop you at Loreta Square - make sure you see changing of the guard at noon - view the castle back to front to avoid crowds - gets very busy.

Probably the biggest Castel. Prague castle is said to be biggest in world. The walk through the castle is a awesome experience. The city from top make you fall for it once again. The buildings in the castle is an perfect example of a great architecture. I liked its Gothic design. It is of course a must visit. You can spend all day long here.

feast for the eyes - and soul. Prague has more fine buildings than you can shake a stick at and the biggest concentration are in the Castle District. If one architectural style describes Prague's exuberance it's Baroque and it provides a dazzling arrangement of castles, palaces, churches, cathedrals and even stable blocks that dazzle and impress.Be prepared to share it with large crowds unless you go early in the morning or can visit in Spring.

Hire a guide or it's confusing. We didn't have a local guide for the castle, and we should have, as the history of the area is probably the most interesting thing about the castle. That, and the views over Prague. We had a guide later for the Old Town, and I realized how important it is to know the history of the town in order to appreciate all of the various groups that ruled this area over the centuries.

So much to see and do.. The area is so vast with impressive buildings - both the castle, the churches, shops, restaurants and a street with some small historic buildings. Here must be something for everyone. The view - when possible, is fantastic over the river and the city.
Loved this district. Lots of stairs up but definitely worth it. Spent a nice afternoon here admiring the view and looking at the castle and cathedral
A walk through history...... One of the prettiest and most historical neighborhoods you will ever have the pleasure of strolling through, amazing beautiful at night.

Hradcany, Prague. Great location at the top of a hill with cobblestone streets and touristic attractions. Great neighborhood, safe and calm at night. Access to trams and buses. 1/2 hour away to the airport. Lively and cheaper than the old and new towns.
A must visit.. A great place to see Prague. It is called the Castle area and there is no castlew there but you will like it.
Worth a half day. We paid for a Tour A ticket which gives you entry to most of the major attractions and spent a good 4 hours covering everything we wanted to see.

Not your average castle!. The Prague Castle has its own "district", and is huge. It includes a palace, currently used government offices, a 14th century cathedral that was not completed until 1929, other buildings, and tremendous views. Wear comfortable shoes!

amazing. Wow! It amazing huge! You need min all day to see all! One of the best place ever! Everybody should go there! Unhappy that you can pay for each entrance... even when you would like to walk by most popular street there.
But anyway 10/10

My fault for timing it badly. Never travel with me. It's not the fault of Prague, but wherever I go, there will always be a main attraction covered in scaffolding and the castle district in Prague didn't disappoint on this particular city break. The bits that weren't covered (as in plastered from top to toe) were great though and St Vitus cathedral is spectacular with stunning stained glass. You have to pay for everything up there, so we didn't do anything that required paying for on this occasion, but if we go back and the builders are not there, then we might.

Lot's to do and see .... There are several historical monuments & museums, good restaurants and cafes, concerts and performances and excellent views overlooking the river, Charles Bridge and the rest of Prague city. Plan to spend at least half a day here.

Walk around the castle. Buy the tickets to walk around the castle and do not miss the most important points, along with the changing of the guard that happens daily at 12. Enter the small houses that date back to the medieval era and see the armour's exhibition.
Largest castle complex in the world!. This place is a must to see! The cathedral is breathtaking, as well as the views from the castle! What a gem!

Beautiful hard getting around. It is hard to know where to start. Allow 2-4 hrs to see must. At the ticket office and they don't explain much and it has miss leading signs. But the place is amazingly beautiful! Worth spending enough time!

Beautiful area, allow time to wander. There are enough things to see to allow more time than just the castle area. Wander down (or up) the hill. Check out the gardens and all the embassies. Buy a to go lunch and sit in the Wallenstein Gardens to enjoy it with the locals.

Beautiful. This area is beautiful. I highly recommend taking a trip at night and seeing the castle lit up! Grab a beer at the monastery and maybe some dinner of Svičková and enjoy a nice walk in the city.

Very interesting, beautiful historic area. Worth spending at least half a day to explore the castle area. The castle gardens were my favorite part and probably the least crowded and most peaceful part of Prague.

Fantastic attraction, full of history. We had a guided tour of the area and then walked downhill from there to Charles bridge. Going with a tour is not enough. You need to come back to spend half a day there. Also the street performers are great and add to the atmosphere.

Tons to see and do. We opted to purchase the ticket to all of the attractions in the Castle district, including the cathedral, armory, and several museums. It was well worth it--something for everyone in our group, including who were more interested in visual splendor, military buffs, history nerds, and some who appreciated the picturesque.

Spend the day!. The entire castle district is full of ancient buildings so take a day out to go there and enjoy them. It can be walked but if you have difficulty walking then take a tour. You can see it all in less than a day but I would take a day out for it because everything else is on the other side of the river.
History and views. While our first visit to Prague, we where fortunate that our younger daughter had toured Europe about twenty years ago and recommended the Castle, we were not disappointed!

Beautiful!. The castle is the main attraction but the entire district is an amazing place to explore. The beautiful gardens leading up the hill and the view of Old Town and Petrin Hill make the climb up the hill worthwhile. You can take a bus but it's very interesting to walk up Neruda street to look into the shops and see the old buildings.

Lovely Area. The castle district is where the castle (big surprise), cathedral and other important buildings are. You can either walk up the steps (though it is a big taxing if you aren't fit) but worth it as about 3/4 of the way up is a cafe house where you can take beautiful pictures of Prague. You can also take a tram up that will bring you to the back side of the castle district. Worth it to spend the afternoon in this area. Though please note if you get the pass to get you into all of the buildings, it is does not include the Portrait Gallery - which is fine because it really isn't worth the extra 100 KC to get in as there are only 3 rooms of paintings.
Disappointing. I went to the castle day and night. Night was wonderful and serene. Day was a zoo. Everything is moldy, so I was forced to rush through.

Stunning. We stayed in the castle area so had the privlege of walking directly there. Word cannot adequately the breath taking beauty of the castle area. The plethora od old buildings, cobbled roads and stunning vista is almost too much to absorb. If you are there on a saturday, make sure you visit the gardens. They are free to the public. They are quiet, relaxing and instantly you feel happy. As stunning as this area it is lovely to have that sense of connecting with nature, albeit structured nature

Gives a real sense of Czech history.. The Prague Castle District gives you a real sense of the past power of the Czech / Bohemian rulers. Also what was the working of the castle when it was a center of power. A day can easily be spend here seeing everything that there is to offer.

Prague Castle is truly the most beautiful site, maybe in the world.. Prague castle might just be the most beautiful historical building I have ever laid eyes on. When you first approach it from the small square in the back your eyes are drawn to its extreme beauty, elaborate architecture and all that adorns the corners and peaks. We did not pay for the additional interior viewing, but just the free first section where the stained glass windows were in full view. I prefer the grandeur of the exterior, but it is all amazing.

Crammed full of history and power. A large complex full of palaces, churches and exhibitions. The exteriors (mostly) and a few of the buildings are free; otherwise you pay for individual entry but more economically you choose either the A or B bundle, which gives you groups of sites to visit. Some very large and very detailed explanations of Czech history which are fascinating. Allow a whole day for the visit.

Stained GLass windows , Knights and shopping. We went with the Grand Circle guide with individual hearing aids which really helped. It was crowded when we went with other tours but it was do able. We had lunch at the restaurant at the front which was very good.Bring change for the restroom.I bought a doll and minature horesman toy.
a lesson in history. Fantastic Place with old historical monuments. Use that e-guide to get the information as you go from one site to another. Rent this for a whole day. its worth it.

Others would apprciate this. Not so much a castle in the sense that I would understand but a walled village. Others would appreciate the time spent there exploring and the architecture is beautiful but not really for me. The highlight for us was the classical street performers. Too many guided tours.
Well worth a visit. Well worth a visit and catch tram 22 to take you to the top of the hill. Cafes inside with plenty to see, church, castles, museums, etc.
Find the Convent Store!. There is a little store around the corner from the castle that sells goods made by the local nuns. Absolutely a thousand times better than buying typical tourist stuff.
take hald a day to visit it. Magnific view of Prague . It is the largest castle in the world and i´ts Unesco world heritage . take the tram up to the Castle and walk back down when you're done.
Spring Visit with friends. Enjoyed the stroll round the Castle District. However, because of the location, found the cafes expensive compared to thre rest of Prague.

Free to explore without a ticket!. A lot of people don't realise that the castle grounds are completely free to roam about - it's only the big attractions you need a ticket for. And rambling through the place, which is basically an Old Town all of its own, throws up lots of interesting architecture and great photo opportunities (including a statue in a courtyard towards the lower end of the castle grounds that has a very shiny, ahem, appendage!). Approaching the castle from either end is very scenic.Bear in mind that the 'main entrance' is currently covered in scaffolding and is anything but photogenic.

Take a walk. The best way to do this is to take the 22 tram up to the castle (or two stops beyond) and then walk down the wall path. The views of the city are spectacular. Be sure to walk around the side streets at the base of the hill. They are lovely, and every bend in the road brings a new surprise. The area around the Lennon memorial is surprisingly quiet once you leave that immediate area.
Biggest Castle in Europe. A well preserved and well presented Castle. It is huge. You could wander it for hours. The crowning glory of arguably the most beautiful city in continental Europe.

Lovely district of castles and architecture. The castle district is absolutely wonderful, and there is so much to see in this complex, it's beautiful! This has to be a must see, there are so many different architecture areas here, its beautiful!
Worth the walk up. It is very nice up there. Great view of the city. We walked. There are other ways up if you are not able to walk.
Lovely area. A beautiful area and much quieter than places like the Old Town. However, prices much more expensive than other districts in the restaurants / cafes.

Gem in Prague. There are so much to see here. Fabulous Church which were build at 14th century. The view from the back side of the castle
to the entire Prague is just wonderful. You can take 1000 photos
and I don't think any bad shot. Love it!!
A lovely area. It's part of the must do places to visit when in Prague, we watched the changing of the guards which is at 12 noon each day, good to watch.

Lovely. As this is the biggest castle complex anywhere, make sure you have time to be there from 3 hours to half of a day. St. Vitus Chatedral is amazing, it is also amazing to see some crowns and defenestration window in the old castle but it was the Golden Lane which impressed me the most with its Medieval museum. There can one shoot with a crossbow, see armours, lances, swords, bows, normal castle clothes and torture instruments with amazing medieval music in the background. Not to forget amazing views from the castle on Prague and Schwarzenberg and Tuscan Palaces nearby. Also know that castle itself is not very spectacular in the interior but it is big and one-kind. Great for memories.

Do it with a tour guide. We did this with a paid guide from Sandeman Tours and were glad we didn't do it on our own. There's lots to see and understand, and you need someone to make sure you don't miss the unique features such as the special acoustic experience outside as well as the one in the church. You also want to try shooting a crossbow!

Excellent views. It's hard to try review each & every place we visited mainly as it is the whole package we enjoyed with the Castle District falling into that category. This is part of Prague & to enjoy the whole experience then yes it is well worth the visit, it does have some pretty spectacular views across the river of the old town.
Beautiful Castle. This is a must see while in Praha. The grounds are majestic and the castle is unbelieveable. It must be seen to be believed.

Pleasant two days in Prague.. An interesting site to visit for a day. If you have ANY mobility issues, I strongly suggest that you either use public transportation, taxi or car service which most hotels offer. Going either up to the Castle or returning back down to the city can be quite difficult. The Old Town and squares are pleasant places to spend a couple of hours; Prague has several great music venues, try and see at least one concert during your visit. For us, we were able to do what we wanted in 2 days.

Well worth the walk. We walked up to the Castle and enjoyed the changing views as we ascended. We did not pay entrance to any of the specific sites and also did not feel a need to. If u r really interested than maybe worth it. We were quite happy to wander around and enjoy the surroundings, There is a lot to see and some beautiful photos to be taken.
Beautiful. Just a beautiful castle which has spectacular views of the wonderful city of Prague from the top. Great area to just take in the beauty of the city.

Allow time to explore this area. The castle area is a brilliant way to spend a day. So much to see including the Toy museum, enjoy coffee and cake at the Lobkowicz Palace, visit St Vitus cathedral and just meander around the area.

Give yourself time. Make sure you put aside a few hours for this trip. There are many things to see. The castle, the cathedral, the Golden street. Take your time. Have a break in the cafe in Golden Street and then continue. Worth a visit.

Gorgeous Castle - a must to visit.. From the town looking up at this castle it was quite outstanding and quite breathtaking. In the evening when it is all lit up and most attractive. We walked round the castle after an early afternoon visit and left by the stairs, which did seem to go on forever, but the views we saw more than compensated for this.

Beautiful castle, even more beautiful views. The hike from Malostranske Namesti up to the top of Hradcany is not for the faint of heart! The 22 tram runs to the top for those not willing to make the trip. No matter how you reach the top, the view from Hradcany alone is worth experiencing. Visitors can easily spend an entire day in Hradcany visiting Prasky Hrad and all of its buildings.

amazing. the walk up to the castle is lovely,take time to have a look in some of the shops.the view over the city from the castle is absolutely spectacular!but beware it is very busy and crowded at times.
Worth doing. This whole area is lovely and there are so many different styles of architecture. Don't miss St. Vitus's Cathedral or the view of the city.
Impressive. Take the walk uphill and you will get a great view over the city.When you get to the castle you start to realize its greatness.

Hradcany very scenic and very crowded.. We left for the castle area mid afternoon, hoping to avoid the crowds. First, the trolley got stuck in a traffic jam, which wasted a lot of time, and the cathedral had such a long line (it was quite warm) we gave up on that. I never got near the castle. Perhaps the best solution is to go very early in the AM before the tour buses arrive. Still, the views over the city were gorgeous.
feel the history. you can feel the history of the astle and surrounding grounds and gardens when walking around this part of Prague. Fantastic and fab views.

Fascinating. Lots of interest in this very large area. We enjoyed the cathedral, the toy museum, Golden Lane and the gardens. It is well worth tacking the 297 steps of the Bell Tower for amazing view of the city

A Must See! Amazing to everyone, but history buffs dream! Allow 2-5 days.. I'll say first up i am very interested in history, and the history of this region. I went up to Hradcany District 3 days, but i really needed 5, and should of been there at 10am each day. And then I might have fitted it all in. I completely missed Loreta Monastery, didn't get to have a good wander around the streets of the district, and missed 2 of the 7 sights on my 2 Day Castle/Palace ticket. And i spent a good 3 days up there.My first day I'd left my camera behind, and was 1pm so (in hindsight wisely) decided to not enter any of the historical sights and have a good wander around and through all that makes up the Castle/Palace district - this allowed me to take lots of exterior shots on my camera so it was less of a priority on other visits. Then found nice pub with Prague Cider for rest (v happy), walked right up to top of mountain and got good view of Loreta etc, and found great vegan resturant way down.The other 2 days i bought a full 2 day ticket, however ran out of time and missed the Powder Tower (told didn't miss much) & Picture Gallery. My 2nd day i only saw 2 sights in 6 hours. Ended my 3rd day in St Vitus Catherdal...only 70mins until kicked out & needed another hour. If you are really into history allow at least 3/4 days, 5 if want to see the Monastery and have good wander. If not into history I'd still recommend 2 days, unless you hire a Segway and don't enter any sights. Highlight of my E. European trip so far (Vienna to come). Will leave detailed reviews of separate sights.

Must view. The castle district is an absolute delight! The view of the city from the castle, walking through the beautiful streets in the district itself, viewing the castle as well : unforgettable memories! Just have to be there!!

Authentic old Europe. The castle on the hill, dominates the Prague landscape. Take a bus or the trams and experience life of the ruling class for much of the 13th to 18th century. The castle is imposing, but the other smaller private palaces offer intimate looks at life for those who influenced life is eastern Europe for nearly a thousand years. I toured the Lebowitz Palace, which has been in the ownership of one family for much of the time that Prague was a seat of power. The family has collected paintings and treasures from much of the time and a walk through shows you family life for much of the period.
One of the sites to see in Prague. Very interesting from an historical perspective and also from an architectural one. Don't miss the changing of the guard if you can.

If In Prague - Come to the Castle. According to the Guiness Book of Records, this is the largest castle complex in the world. Quite believable. Courtyards, Palaces, Cathedral, Grand Halls, and several dozen other structures, encircled by massive walls and accessed on old style paving stones from days gone by. Lots of history, plenty of beauty, design and colouration - definitely a spot to add to your travels while in Prague. There is a fee for many interiors otherwise you can stroll around most of the grounds for free - but pay the fee and certainly enter some of the buildings.
So much to see. the castle and cathedral area has several squares, great views over Prague, coffee shops, museums and a lot of history. A must see.

It's an uphill experience!. The walk to the castle is a difficult one as it is a long hill with many steps..the view is fabulous but there are a lot of people everywhere and its congested wherever you go. You get to walk over any one of a number of bridges and it is nice to stand above the Danube and watch the boats
Beautiful Sights. Prague city is stunning and this area is the best for views of the whole city-well worth the trek up!
Stunning. Loved the castle so much to see and do and the views once you reach the top after climbing the many steps are truly amazing and worth the effort

Lovely area even if you're not paying into the attractions. The area around the castle and palace are absolutely lovely with great gardens and views across the city, we didn't pay to go into the exhibitions as we thought the price was quite steep but got some great pictures anyway

Very interesting. Once there you can decide which building you want to visit and buy the ticket accordingly. Some of them are not so necessary, for instance you can get to the s. Vitus cathedral all the same, just the entrance lane is different depending on what you pay you get nearer the glass windows or farther... Bear in mind that the farther you are the better pictures you take, so not always paying is better!
old and nice. nice walk in old times, but be ready - it is always crowded with a lot of tourists. it is nice to take a walk inside walls

Beautiful area. Largest castle in Europe, apparently. It was neat to go inside the complex - we visited in the evening, so we were not able to go inside the chapel, but apparently that is pretty neat, too.
a lot to experience. beautiful gardens, concerts in Lobkovits palace, very good and helpful tram 22 to go up the hill.I would have liked some statues and a bit more glamour.

Extensive and interesting location. We enjoyed the architecture and the views. The castle is alleged to be the second largest ancient castle in the world.There were some places which we could not enter without a ticket. I was informed that a ticket for ten euros would have permitted entry to four places but didn't buy the ticket. We had a drink (one black coffee and one small beer which cost 190 Cz. Kr. Very expensive! If you want to visit allow a few hours because it is very extensive.
Best view. do the climb, grab a drink on the way, and it is so worth it - the view is beautiful - if you want to see the red roofs - here is the place - best photos!!

Not what I expected. I expected a district full of castles. That is not what this is. It has a beautiful cathedral and is the site of where the current President resides. It's worth seeing and the cathedral is impressive, but we were there for an hour or so and called it good. I envisioned myself wanting to stay there all day.

Castle in snow. Although we had snow!!! the walk around the castle was magic, you feel history crashing down upon you. Prague is very much an "old" city to revere, and get the feeling of. we loved our stay!

Prague Castle. the Prague Castle is impressing - but, the most important thing there is the Cathedral of Wenzel, a giant Christian Church inside the castle, where it is reported the ambassadors of the Austrian Empire were thrown out og a window short before the outbreak of the 30 years long lasting war in 17th century.The Saint "Wazlaw" is the preferred saint of the Chechs, and he got a really impressing cahtedral!

A View to Remember. In this area there are some very good eateries and some beautiful buildings but the draw card is the old bastion wall, which is magnificent and beautiful in itself. Climb the bastion wall and the whole of old town Prague and it's beautiful river spread out before you.

Great walking area. We walked up to the Castle from the Metro stop in Lesser Town. It was a strenuous walk, but there were cute shops and cafes all along the street, so it didn't seem so bad. On the castle grounds, there is large square and park. A band was playing at one end of the square, and a street musician was at the other end. There are several cafes/restaurants at the castle, including a Starbucks with an incredible view of the whole city. One of the palaces is an art gallery.

Outstanding. Don't miss it. There's so much here to see, and it really deserves extended time. Despite the crowds and the conga lines of flag-following groups, it's great just to stroll around and soak up the atmosphere and the history.

You can have a very nice stroll around this area.. Very picturesque and beautiful. A view of the city can be scene from here. You can catch the changing of the guard at noon and tour the church in the court yard.

Beware the 'total' option ticket.. Unmissable especially the paintings gallery and Cathedral including climb up the tower. But beware, the supposed 'all inclusive ticket' I bought at the castle did NOT include the gallery or the tower!

Great way to spend a day. You could easily spend an entire day in the Castle District. There is so much to do and see. I would suggest taking it slow, there is a lot of history to take in. Start early and take a long lunch to really enjoy the area.
Gorgeous Panoramic view. Beautiful view of the Prague city can be seen from this place. Lovely atmosphere with good music played by people in street.

Quiet & peaceful Area. I like this area so much even I don't like the castle itself.. A lot of green spaces, gardens are everywhere in your way to the castle, I found the area is very peaceful & quiet.. Run from the hustle & bustle of Prague to this place.
So much to see. So many palaces, gardens, monuments and churches to see. You need a whole day here, another steep walk to the top.

Stepping back in Time. The best way to appreciate the Hradcany is to walk up Vlasska St from Mala Strana. This used to be the Italian Quarter and leads up to Strahov Monastery. The orchard from the monastery is still there and you get lovely views down to Prague and the castle. I was there in Spring when the trees had blossom on them. It is then just a short walk to the old city walls and the district known as Pohorelec. Some of the houses here are really old. From here you can walk straight towards the castle but it is worth taking a detour past the rococo Loreto to Novy Svet or New World.which is a picturesque street of houses built for workers at the castle in the 17th century. Tycho Brahe the famous astronomer lived in this street.There is so much to do do and see in this part of Prague. Recommendations to allow a whole day are absolutely correct. In fact in a whole day you can't possibly visit all the palaces. The guided tour of the castle is worth doing. I thought we spent too much time in St Vitus' Cathedral and would have preferred more time in the Royal Palace.There are some interesting things to see here. The Vladislav Hall is an enormous banqueting hall which was large enough to stage tournaments on horseback. When it is used for events to-day it takes 2 days to heat it! For students of European history one of the most interesting features is the window from which two Catholic governors were thrown out over the castle walls by Protestant nobleman in 1618 thus precipitating the 30 Years War. (Remarkably they survived!)The gardens on the terraces above Mala Strana are very beautiful but the ones on the moat side are more extensive and quite historic. No one should miss Golden Lane where various craftsmen have worked since the 16th century. Some of the cottages are furnished with period furniture.The changing of the guard occurs every hour but try and see it at midday as the whole band comes along then and sounds a fanfare from the Royal Palace balcony.

TIP: Go Early!. We were advised by many to go early morning arfter sunrise to walk on the bridge and it was spetacular. Only 30 people on the entire bridge and was able to take great pictures. Compare this too noon when there were over 3000 people on the bridge. So we went for our aerobic walk one morning and saw Prague with nobody in our pictures except the ones we wanted.
Worthwhile. The view of Prague is incredible from the castle district. There is lots to see and it is interesting. There is a good cafe in the area as well.
Fascinating. This was soo interesting - the cathedral, palace, Golden Lane and so much more! There's so much history to learn. It's amazing how old the complex is and it's still actively used today!

Don't miss this landmark. This is located on a hill overlooking the city with fantastic views. There is a great deal to see here in addition to the castle, including churches, palace, small historic lane of houses, as well as shops, etc.

Huge tour groups block the aisles. The Castle district is a must to visit but BUY A TRAM TICKET (Tram 22) that covers the ride both ways. About 50 Krowns. It's tough to find a ticket machine in the Castle area; the return ticket precludes that problem. Note: The operators of the Castle should ask ALL Tour Guides for a favor: Don't let your 50 people block the entire aisle in the palace for example. Not everyone wants to wait five minutes to get by while you talk about a single room in Italian or Chinese. In truth this is a problem in the Old City as well; they walk down a street, filling it wall to wall (roadway and both sidewalks) .... not allowing anyone to pass. If you are going in the opposite direction, the people in the group are very surly that you are walking through their mob. (I guess you are expected to get into a store and wait five minutes until they have moved away from this area??)

This is the reason to visit Prague!. Prague has the largest castle in Europe and just visiting the castle to see all of the attractions and the area around it will take you the best part of a day so enjoy!Top Tip 1: plan your visit - 15 minutes spent planning is well worth the investment. There is almost too much to do and you will miss out if jou go for the 'let's look and see approach'Top Tip 2: visit the Lobkowicz Collection - the collection included paintings, manuscripts, guns, china and all woven around the story of one noble family. Great audio guide is included in the admission price and narrated by William Lobkowicz himself.
Worth visiting. Following Charles bridge, I recommend to visit this spots in order to remind you of the city of Prague in the Middle ages.
Awesome city. We loved Prague. So much to see and do from people watching to beer and food on the square....spend at least three days here to see all there is

A huge complex of buildings. The complex is home to beautiful buildings, enormous squares, lovely gardens and the magnificent St Vitus Cathedral. Don't miss the changing of the guard on the hour and the wonderful views over the city.

Beautiful Views and and Lovely Cathedral. Loved the views from this spot as well as the wonderful old cathedral that has been restored. Fisherman's Bastion worth a visit. Nice outdoor dining spots around tool
The good St Vitus. Worth every step up the steep climb to see the beautiful stained glass windows in this church. This is a church to remember.

History and tourism well-matched. This area is very well-preserved and easily navigated. Yes it is "up the hill" but the transport is more than adequate and even the walking is nothing to shy away from. The gradient of the streets up from the River is quite sympathetic
Huge. This site needs at least 3 hour visit to do it justice, the best way is to take the number 22 tram to the castle and walk back down the area is full of squares historic house and museums
Winter. Worth the visit even with half meter snow covering the area. Just make sure you get appropriate shoes. :) There's a monk brewery nearby. Take a guide tour.

Great views and worth the walk. My husband and I visited in May 2015. We walked to the Castle District from across the river. The walk was lovely - lots of shops, interesting homes, beautiful scenery, restaurants, and outdoor cafes. This was one of our highlights of our trip. We would make sure to note to wear good walking shoes between cobblestone and and good incline shoes are a must.
Too much construction work, cars. This would be a great place, but there are too many cars and also the volume of construction work is too high.

Another must do in prague. We took a bus tour there the first day and went on our own the second day. Make sure we walk to to library past the castle. We didn't pay to go in. Just looking around and seeing the views were enough for us. We never did find the castle gardens. Perhaps that was somewhere you had to pay to reach
A Must See in Prague. We visited the Castle District on Segway's and on foot. Worth visiting both ways. Plan on spending a whole day in this area of Prague. There is so much to see and do.
Epic Architecture...Beautiful View. Epic Architecture and a relaxed atmosphere....great shops, art, restaurants, beer gardens...and fun to people watch....

Worth visiting. The castle complex in Prague is Europe's largest. It is right on top of a hill and requires one to walk up a hill. The climb is well worth it as the Castle area is very nice. I was disappointed with the Palace though. It could have been grander. The street with the armour etc. was very good.

Exceeded expectations. It is a complex of attractions that felt authentic and well preserved. Compared to some castle tours, I felt I could really imagine what it was like to live there instead of seeing a museum of fancy stuff!

Keep walking uphill. When you visit the Castle District, go see the Castle. But keep walking past the castle (West) as far up as you can go towards the edge of the Castle District. There you can overlook Lesser Quarter, Petrin Hill, and Old Town.
You'll find dining options up there that are less touristy as well.

beautiful view. Much to do in Hradcany- the cathedral is beautiful, and the smaller chapel within the fortifications is very peaceful. The castle is not too crowded and has great views of Prague. My kids have always like the Golden Lane as there is a corridor of armour on display
a must do. First time to prague in the 80's i skipped this. Castle and cathedral are well worth it. Great views of Prague. Lots to do on this side of the river.
Castle. Very quaint, enjoyed the fact that it was pedestrianized, made strolling around very relaxed. Cobbled roads/pavements everywhere, quite tiring on the fee.

It's amazing.. Everywhere you look in Prague is amazing, the buildings, the history, it's all around you. If you like this sort of thing then the castle district is one of many areas you'll be blown away with the beauty of.

Not to be missed. This huge Castle District looks over Prague and is a fascinating way to spend several hours. Do not miss St. Vitus Church and be sure to see the Klimt stained glass window there. Also worth a visit is the Golden Lane which includes cramped living quarters once used by the castle staff and now re-done in period style or refurbished as small shops. Once your visit to the castle area is done walk down the steps to visit St. Niklas church which is a baroque marvel as well as the lovely and peaceful Wallenstein Gardens.

you'll never know what you'll find. Well the famous Prague Castle is here, there are other things to explore around here though, but still have a look at everything because although a little run down you never know what you'll find
Nice mood. The Prague castle area is really a place where you can find your moment of peace and enjoy an amazing panorama...with price for to see anything in...

A really Big Castle. This castle is bound to blow your mind out. The castle has many amazing sights. As it houses a Cathedral and a Church with Gothic architecture all over it. Since the total time to build the entire castle spanned in decades, we can see the shift in the generations and how the modern architecture had evolved. All in all you will sure need minimum a day to finish and see the entire
DO NOT MISS. If you do not take a guided tour of The Prague Castle inside then you missed Prague. It is impressive and extensive- spend several hours with a GUIDE!!!

Absolutely Stunning. Loads to Like and Nothing to Dislike. The day we visited coincided with the one day of the year (May 17) that the state rooms within the castle are open to the public and entry is free (but you will be queueing for a minimum of 30 minutes. The Ticket for entry into the remainder of the castle and churches at CZK 350 is good value. Also the additional charge of CZK 150 to climb the 287 steps up church bell tower to get the stunning all round views of Prague is well worth it.
Great views. From the bridge you enter the Castle district, some nice restaurants along the way but be aware it's cobbled and very steep so those with disabilities should be aware

Beautiful walk!. Hradcany is just perfect place for a walk. Starting with royal gardens (open from May to October, I guess) with beautiful view to the castle church, then the beautiful view for all the city from the hill. Walking down you can end up on Charles Bridge...
A must see place when in Prague. A must see in Prague, full of history, very well preserved, today is the house of the president. You can really have an idea of the medieval era in Prague.

What a View, oh and there's a castle too.. Seriously, the views of Prague are what attracted us to this location. The cathedral was spectacular, but that was about it. The rest of the castle wasn't as interesting. We did the B tour route and felt that covered all the highlights. You'll get a ticket which is scanned at each section when you go through the turnstiles. They also ran out of audio guides, so we got stuck self touring. Probably another reason we didn't get as much out of it.
Touristy but worth the visit. Lots of tourist, obviously, and a steep walk if you come from Old town. But the view, gardens and buildings makes it worth it all.
What a blast. There are tons of little restaurants and shops to visit around the castle. Great for tourists who are looking for anything and everything. A definite must for everyone.
Nice view on Prague. I recommend to go on castle because you can have a nice view on Prague city and Charles bridge which is one of the top attractions.
Great Panorama Views. Make sure to take photos because you will get amazing panoramas of Prague from the castle district, a must while in Prague!

Great castle. The largest historical royal castle complex in the world, they say. And I believe it! Great castle, Go and experience it yourself!The castle area opens very early in the morning and the monuments 9 a.m and 10 a.mThe information centre opens at 9 a.m and when I´ll visit the castle next time I´ll be there already about 9 o´clock!Because the lines to the ticket office can be frustrating long.There are several options for different tours in the castle area and separate exhibitions. Prices vary from 70 Czech crowns (Powder tower) to 350 crowns (Circuit A and C)
Beautiful. The palace is so well kept the gardens are stunning and seeing the changing of the guard was the best experience. You have to see all of the palace so buy the tickets to go inside.
thoroughly enjoyable. Enjoyed a long stroll around the Castle District after visiting the interesting, beautiful displays inside the castle museum...well worth the visit...

Best view of Prague. Although this can be reached via the city's efficient trams, we cheated and hired a cab from our hotel. You are rewarded with a wonderful overlook of Prague and its river, the Vtlava (aka Moldau). Minstrel groups will remind you about the river, as Smetana's most famous tune is heard everywhere atop this hill. St. Vitus' Cathedral is not to be missed, and Art aficionados should definitely visit the museum within the Sternberg Palace. There within, the treasures include masterpieces by Reubens, Rembrandt and El Greco. Thumbs up!
Views to die for!. Worth making your way up to the castle to take in the superb panoramic views across the city. Also lots of little streets to explore and enjoy

Great Castle. The tram number 22 takes you to the royal garden and Castle (Pražský hrad is the tram stop) that saves you time and effort if you are travelling with infant or do not want to climb the stairs. We travelled with infant and were sceptical of steps. However, highly recommend the place, though it may be a bumpy ride on some spots. Also there is a narrow road left hand side of the stairs if you want to get down with buggy and avoid stairs. We took it and got down in 5 minutes.
Quite nice. The castle is quite nice I liked it a lot when we visited it there were some issues with the tickets so there was long queue

Gorgeous view. Very nice castle & cathedral area, perched high above the city on the Lesser town side. Beautiful view overlooking the river and old town and a very interesting history. Great area to wander and relax.

Go up and down.. When you are planning to walk into the castle district notice that the streets going up and down. The naberhood of the castle is full of souvenir shops with a lot of rubbish.Admire the place just at the entrance of the castle,wow !The castle is builded part by part, so again you will see a various pallet of architectoral types. Don't forget to visit the golden street.
its not just a castle. you must go there on the morning becouse its really crowded and i suggest you to take a all pass card becouse there are lots of things to do on the area

Very nice castle. Very nice site, it is possible to go in, but be aware that it takes at least 2 hours to see everything. Walking distance form Charles bridge, great panoramic scenery from the top. There's also a Starbucks for all of us, coffee lovers :)

Nice Castle. Very large grounds, much walking. Secret is to take transport up the hill, to save your legs and back, then walk back down the hill into old town. Washroom inside first courtyard but it's 50E. Changing of the guard is short and sweet, don't miss it. Great view from outside the castle.

very busy. It was a very interesting place to see, with a number of parts to it. It didn't help that it was very cold and heavy rain. There were a lot of organised tours so it was at times difficult to see the monuments.

Great value for money. The Castle complex is a must for travelers to Prague. For a small fee we got access to seven different areas and each was unique and fascinating. The views across the Old City are spectacular.The hot wine and apple struddle were pretty good as well

A must see. Superb buildings and architecture based in a supreme position overlooking the river and city. Watched the changing of the guard not quite London standards but interesting in its own right.

Indeed good. This location is formed of different buildings and, nothing makes you bored when visiting...Impressive buildings, the past, militarial, personal and, so on... Different than classical ones...

Castle District (Hradcany). This area is very big.. Its stunning with the castle and cathedral. This is also top attraction in Prague, so prepare yourself with crowd. Lot of tourist, so maybe you also must becareful with pickpockets?

Great views over Prague. The castle district is situated on a hill beside the river opposite the old town and is steeped in new and old history and has good examples of old building architecture. The changing of the guard at the Palace is worth seeing as it is similar to that at Buckingham Palace. It is easy to reach from the city by foot or local public transport and is included in various walking tours of the city. The views from here of the city are excellent so don't forget a camera.

castle and cathedral. The castle is not all that interesting as it still needs a lot of repair. You have to use your imagination. The Cathedral is huge and quite interesting. You can wander all over it, even into the upper regions and see films of coronations and other events. Some of the stained glass is exceptional and easier to see from the balconies. The gardens are extensive
Why you went to Prague!!. The castle district is fabulous, just make sure you buy a ticket for all the sites and set aside the best part of the day for your trip--stunning.

Wonderful area. We spent two and a half days in Prague, it was wonderful, we went up to the Castle District a couple of times to take in the sights and take pictures. We loved the walk up, although it was crowded with people most days, best time to go is in the morning.

A real Disney World.. It's hard to believe that the castle is real. The gardens are a real haven of peace and give a different perspective to the district than the hurly burly at the front of the castle. Really lovely. If you have trouble with long uphill walks on cobblestones, take the metro and then the tram (#22) up the hill about $2.00. Save your energy for the castle tour.

It's great, but on a hill!. This is my favorite area of Prague. It is a bit quieter, even in the mid afternoon, than on the other side of the bridge. Some nice restaurants are down by the water's edge that give some spectacular view of Charles Bridge. Make certain to wander under the bridge to your right to see the John Lennon Wall.

Tons of people on spring-summer weekends!. I don't know if it is better to arrive at 9am or 3pm but the queues are tremendous everywhere around 11am-2pm. Queue to get tickets and with the short ticket you get 4 places to visit and you will need to queue again for a long time to get in.Once in Cathedral St Vitus, the visit is nice but at the basilica once inside you can barely move so it is hard to enjoy the visit. Inside the castle is a bit cramped. In the Golden Alley you queue to punch your ticket, then queue at every little house-museum. You cannot have your own pace.So if you can, avoid weekends!

Very interesting castle with lots of different things to see and do. If you buy the most expensive ticket, you have access to all the opened sights, and I would say it's worth the money. Some of the sights are super busy, while others are often overlooked by people (and definitely tour groups, who rush through). I spent about two hours walking from sight to sight, and all of them were worth visiting. Of course people focus on the churches and the Golden Lane, but don't forget the palaces. They are a lot quieter.

Our favorite place in Prague. The castle, complete with the Old Royal Palace, St. Vitus Cathedral, and St. George's, were the highlight of our visit to Prague. Devote half a day here. We bought the reduced admission which enabled us to see all of the key attractions and was more than sufficient. I purchased the audio, which is helpful but overly long.

Great views of the city. We spent a lovely relaxing afternoon just wandering around the castle district - it was a lot less busy than the main city area and there were great views back over Prague. Definitely worth taking a couple hours to explore.
Prague. Castle and grounds are vast probably needs a full day to fully appreciate. Changing of the guard was quite a sight
Impressive. This is one of the most impressive castles there is to see and I believe the largest anywhere. Need a whole day to see it.

Great views. Slightly disappointed with the castle itself as there's not a huge amount to see inside but its not expensive and has great views over Prague. The walk up there was interesting. Stop on route and visit the Church of St Nicholas
Immense!. Be ready to walk! It is very impresive, very pretty and with plenty of history and details to admire. Easy access and would be able to enjoy to the full when weather is nice
