The views are worth the hike. Prague Castle is in itself an impressive piece of 14th century architecture that offers commanding views of Prague from its parapets. The narrow side streets surrounding the castle are filled with shops and restaurants housed in centuries old buildings - neither the shops or restaurants offer much in the way of quality goods or decent food - they are geared towards the naive traveler.

Beautiful architecture. A must see for anyone who visits Prague. Also, a bit of trivia, these are the largest castle grounds in the world and span over numerous churches, a cathedral and the actual castle.

The biggest think in Prague. Amazing place for whole day - even one day could be not enough - so many attractions, museums, streets. You do not have to pay to be in this district, but some museums and chapels requires tickets. It could be more information displayed on some buildings saying what is it. By the way - do not miss the place, try Czech hot dogs - parka v rohliku and beer. Prices very reasonable for Euro countries.

The Exquisite Prague Pastles. The Castle District is something worth seeing. In fact we went back a second time just in case we missed something. This is a very steep climb and it is best to get a No. 22 Tram and get off at Pohorelec which is at the top of the hill and then you can work yor way down through the castles.
Great view of Prague. A very nice view of the entire land scape of city from this place. City looks like a post card. Great view not to be forgotten at all
take a stroll. We had nice memorable strolls around the Castle District - get off the beaten bath and walk around - find the John Lennon memorial and enjoy the Wall.
Blew me away!. Stunning place with gorgeous views.They do need better signage however. We got the A pass and it was worth it.
Fab. The bridge is very decorative with all the statues lining the bridge. It get very busy from 11am - 4pm

huge historic heights. Remember to visit this superb area i Prague. There are endless qualityes form wich I will mention a few:There is in Prague a way of bringing historical buildings from many centuries successfull together. This succedes also in the castle district, where a broad spectrum of the ceunturies historic buildings are represented. In the cathedral you will be able to se glasspaintings from the very beginnig as well as paintings from 20th century ( Mucha is also represented). Wow.Don´t forget the golden street, which shows exhibitions of the use of the small and charming houses i different periods.This is only to mention a few things to see - but don´t forget to enjoy the wiev over the city of Prague - especially i april it is surrounded bye the the tiny green leaves af the trees and the pink flowers of the cherry trees.

This is a wonderful place to linger. The Castle District is the highest architectural point of Prague. Take time to walk amongst all the wonderful buildings and see how the Czechs lived for centuries.

Simply famtastic. I loved the dofferent architecture that has been recruited and created in different eras. But the stories behind the buildings of the people living in them were just as fascinating and it is something to truly admire. There is simply nothing it's equal back where I come from and I was very appreciative of the work that had been done.
Not just a castle the Cathedral is a must. There is so much to see. It's not just a castle, the cathedral and the St Georges church are spectacular. The changing of the guard at 12 is worth a look.

Most important part of Prague. You got old town first on the list, Charles Bridge second on the list because of the proximity and you need to cross them to be in Castle.But Castle is the most amazing part of the city. One day is no where good enough for visiting Castle. There are a few cathedrals of which St Vitus cathedral is the most amazing Cathedral I have been too. You got Royal Palace, you will find all the rooms which you search for a dream Palace. There is golden lane where you can see witches home, Soldiers den and some other important places. You will stand a nude statue and have a constant look at the most touched part of his body. you will walk to place where you get the amazing view of the city with Red Building Tops making the best background view for your photo shoot.if you are buying tickets like I did, Please utilize it to the fullest and don't get carried away by the large number of tourists :)

Largest Castle in Europe. With the title you now know to give yourself at least a couple hours if you can read fast and jog along. It is a steep climb with plenty of shops to stop in along the way and small restaurants to fortify yourself if need be. Golden lane was especially interesting with all the back stories it included, perfect if you enjoy history. Just watch the doorways, they were not tall way back then.We paid for the B tour and it was the perfect amount of time and history. This tip came recommended by a local and we were happier for it.

Amazing area of Prague!. This entire area of Hradcany is just amazing! It is absolutely stunning! There is so many different eras of buildings, yet it all fits perfectly. The architecture in this area is phenomenal at a minimum! When you are walking through this area, your head is on a swivel as no matter where you look there is an 'wow' moment. On top of the amazing buildings, streets and history, there are tons of shops, restaurants and cafes in which to visit. We stayed in Prague for 2 and a half months, and after seeing just about all of prague and it's areas, we still think this area is the best overall! Not much more to say about it other than 5 stars! Please go see this area, it is a must!

Castle Hill. It was wet and windy when we visited, but there is so much to see. We will be returning to have a proper look in some of the many palaces.Great views of Prague Had an excellent hot chocolate in oneof the palaces
Massive area to see. Amazing structures and different building types, beautiful. Lots of cafes and places to eat. Easy to get to by 22 tram.

Postcard views no matter where you look. The Castle District is a great day of exploring - the property was built up and added onto for hundreds of years - great exhibits detail this amazing place. The architecture is stunning.

Perfect for stroll. The walk up to the castle is truly rewarding as the sights are beautiful and great for photos. Aprt from that there are lots of cafes and restaurants around to explore making it even more fun and once you reach the castle, the view of the entire city layout just calms you down and pays you well for all the walking and climbing. Prepare yourself with comfortable shoes before you embark on this trail but for the views it is well worth it.
What a view. This is an amazing spot nearby the castle. If you go there in nice weather it is a great view of the city. Allways a good place to visit.
Must see in Prague. The Castle district is very well maintained and the view of the Cathedral is breathtaking.You can go up through one of the entrance free of charge and enjoy the view on the city!
Nothing to shout about. The castle district is pleasant to walk around in but it is nothing too special for me I'm afraid. Although it is a must visit whenever you are in Prague.

Beautiful to wander.... The Castle District is a beautiful area, one with little cafes, shops, and beautiful buildings around. Make sure to stop at the castle. There are beautiful views of the city from here. History is so rich!
Loved the conservation. Great place to walk about and explore, both the church, the castle and the Golden Lane. Good walk up the hill to the castle and very good information all around the area.

best view of Prague. if you are going to Prague, you MUST go up to the castle. To look over the city from this spot is breathtaking and a site to see. the Castle is gorgeous and the church gives you chills from its beauty.

into the mists of centuries. lasting impression of majestic beauty palaces! particularly memorable Martinický palace, monastery, Plague Column with a statue of the Virgin Mary. Prepare comfortable shoes as the walk will have many.

Just walk it!. Bring some water and a snack and take in as much as you want. A guide or guidebook would be handy. We went off the main street and found a cafe that had only Czech writing on the menu - the soup was so scrumptous we ordered a second helping to the staff's great amusement. And then the chocolate layered cake was omg! Name: U Zlateho Pstrosa at Karmelitska 20. And so reasonably priced.

prague castle. I'm so amazed with views of old town from prague castle...we had a chance to see the changing of guards it was really awesome..the most exciting experience i had in prague castle garden there is a platform the you will a echoes of your voice quit mysterious but highly recommended to try it..
Interesting and beautiful. So much to see and learn! A must see attraction in Prague, for sure. The view is amazing and the History is so rich.

guided tour. we took an afternoon guided walking tour of the castle district. So much to see and so many stories. The changing of the guides is a sight to see if your timing is right. Thankfully a bus took us up to the top of the hill so our walk was all down hill. Beautiful views of Prague.

Looks just like a castle from childhood fairytales! . Imagine a Disney castle that you remembered from childhood stories, but in real life! First time I saw the castle, I was in awe -- it looks so beautiful and majestic. Walking around the inside takes time it's huge. We enjoyed hot wine on our way out, so good!

Stunning castle and surroundings. My partner and I went in April 2014 and the castle district is stunning. The buildings are so grand and stunning.
We went all around the castle area and in all the buildings around it.
Their is a Christmas shop there that sells beautiful Christmas decorations, a must buy if your there.

Beautiful sites, incredible history. This is one of the must-see sites in Prague. We walked up from the Charles Bridge through Mala Strana. It was quite a hike, but really beautiful. It was already somewhat crowded when we arrived around 9 am, but we didn't have to wait too long to buy tickets or to enter any of the buildings on site. There are several different things to see inside the complex, and you can buy different ticket packages depending on what you'd like to see. We paid to go inside St. Vitus, the Old Royal Palace, St. George's Basilica, the Golden Lane, and the Daliborka Tower. St. Vitus was amazing and almost overwhelming in its history and decoration. The Old Royal Palace has a grand feasting room and then some much smaller rooms to the side - it was not what I expected a palace to be, but quite a bit of it is closed to the public. I was blown away by St. George's Basilica - it's not very spectacular (especially if you've just been inside St. Vitus), but it has an ancient, Old-World charm that is just fascinating. The Golden Lane was very fun to explore - it's comprised of a row of apartments, and each one is decorated to portray the lives of former residents (both real, like Franz Kafka, and fictional). The final stop for our trip to the complex was the Daliborka Tower - it had medieval restraints and torture devices on display, so if that's your cup of tea then be sure to check it out.

Lose yourself in the cobblestone streets.. Walk through the historical area and take in the surroundings. Lovely parks and old buildings with small surprises down laneways. Nice cafes and restaurants for great meals.

The castle complex is a must. We thought it was just the castle, but there is so much more to see and walk around. So many different buildings and areas to wander around and go in. Much can be done for free, but if you want to go into various places, eg Golden Lane, Basilica, far end of the cathedral, the palace itself, you need to purchase a ticket which lasts for two days. You really need a minimum of a half day to see it all, and ideally the majority of a full day.

Ver picturesqe great photos. This was well worth the wLk to see all of this, it is a World Heritage site an when you seit for real it's even better. This is a must if you go to Prague, and there are some wonderl views to be had. Wear good walking shoes, it's all cobbled. We walked up the steps, areal killer but there is an easier way up past some lovely cafes servin good coffee. Great experience..
A lot to see. We spent almost a day here.There is a lot to see: St. Vitus Cathedral, Golden Lane, Rosenberg palace...
Beautiful and rich with history. Definitely worth a visit. There is so much to see, just walking around is a wonderful experience. St. Vitus Cathedral is a must!

Photography, photography, but doesn't feel like a castle at all!. The castle itself is just not that interesting. You really can't go into any of the buildings except the church (as best I could tell and I took a guided tour). Also, it doesn't look like a castle at all by most people's estimations. Just more like a prettier version of most of the buildings in Prague. So I think how much you'll like it will depend on your expectations. (I actually had another group of tourists standing three feet from the gate ask me where the castle was! They were positive this couldn't possibly be the thing called the "castle.") With that said, I have been to this area multiple times, because it provides a fabulous view of the city! The stairway down the back is lovely. The rooftop views are quite nice. I've seen couples doing wedding photos there. It is a long way up from the old town. Take the tram (line 22 goes up). Or a taxi (10 Euros in my experience). I went up multiple times at different times of day just to catch the light and do photography. I recommend a taxi (if you're traveling alone) if you're going really early or late (sunrise or sunset) because it's pretty desolate then.

Amazing Trek, Amazing Views. You can't go past this incredible experience! Seeing this on our walking tour at night and again during the day, you get to see Prague in all its historic and modern glory. Have some comfortable shoes to explore all the surroundings

Walk to the crossroads of Europe. Now for pedestrians only, the Stone Bridge is rightly world famous. Once the only crossing point of the Vltava river making it essential allowing trade routes across Europe, it is now a noisy mixture of towering majestic religious sculptures and modern traders of 'tat! A lovely way to end a tour of the castle. Walk down from The Golden Lane and follow the crowds! Views of the city from here are spectacular and, of course, it's free!!

The castle and gardens are amazing. Go and see the castle enjoy the walk around the gardens and the district again lots of little places to visit nearly every building has a statue or decorated facade all very old

Prague castle. The largest castle in Europe. Quite a trek to get to, use the tram or you could get a taxi. Be sure to use the yellow cars with taxi sign and ask about the price. From the old square to the castle was 300 Krona, about £8. We arrived from Berlin by train and got a taxi to hotel which was 5 minutes walk and was charged 15 euro (lesson learnt). The castle is massive and we spent 5 hours there and still didn't see it all. You can get different tickets. We got circuit A which covers everything and was about £10 each. Great value.

Tour the Castle. he castle itself is magnificent, but inside is spectacular. The St. Vitus church is simple amazing as are the courtyards. The St. George basillica is also wonderful but Golden Lane with its quaint houses, (#22 was used by Franz Kafka) and superb knights armour exhibition were all highlights. And there is more. Highly recommended.

Nostalgic and beautiful. If you are visiting Prague you will probably go over the Charles Bridge. Basically it is a bridge around 300-400 metres long with beautiful statues, stunning views and array of street artists and musicians. If these things normally bore you, they still will here, but if you like to gaze upon stunning sculptures from years gone by in scenic surroundings you'll be glad you went. We went in March and it was comfortably busy, but I bet that it becomes a bit unbearable at busier times of the year.

Central European Architecture at it's best. Covers several important buildings within it's walls - above Prague on the opposite bank of the Vltava from the main city.Czech kings and Presidents had their inauguration ceremonies here, a magnificent cathedral and interesting museums. Golden Lane in the 24 little houses of the former royal guards has interesting craft and book shops, with some of the houses previously lived in by well known figures such as Kafka
Peaceful - even when busy. The crowds are in the Castle grounds, but just outside there are some lovely streets selling reasonably priced and good quality food. Find a bench, rest and enjoy.

Great. When you are in Prague take the time (at least 4 or 5 hours) to visit this area, the cathedral, the houses and so on. It gives you an understanding of the importance of Prague in the history of Europe.

Well worth a visit. The district is full of historic buildings and you can easily walk around for hours. Next to the castle there is also the Cathedral and there is a restaurant if you feel hungry or thirsty, off course the prizes are a little higher but the view while eating or drinking is worth the prize

Great!.. Impressive views. astonishing master works of the architecture.
A majestic walking that you can never miss when visiting Prague.

Monitized to the point of annoyance. There are many beautiful, intricate and stunning castles in Europe and while the Cast District in Prague certain fits all of those descriptors it is also one of the most poorly run and heavily monetized. I don't mind paying to see parts of the castle, quite the contrary, I enjoy knowing that my funds will help preserve history for others to see. What is frustrating is when you have to buy multiple, rather expensive tickets, to see everything within the same complex. For example, some of the castle is available on one ticket, other parts of the castle and the cathedral on another. And if you want to climb the tower? Well a third ticket is now in your future. The view from the top of the tower is lovely, but I would suggest the tower atop the hill next to the monastery instead as it gives you a higher, more unobstructed view of the city. While beautiful there are better castles in Europe to see and nice places in Prague to visit.
Good place to walk around. the Castle District is a good place to walk around once you have finished seeing the Cathedral.. explore the by-lanes of the Hradcany.

Beautiful and lots to see. great for the history buffs. your ticket lasts for two days so you can take it in slowly if you like. there is a TON to see so it can take a while. March is considered the off season and it was packed, can't imagine what is it like during the summer. A lot of things don't have any signs about what they are so the audio tour may have been the way to go.

Lovely, especially in the spring sundhine. We expected throngs of tourists but were pleasantly surprised to find it just pleasantly humming, no crowds at all. The view is excellent, second only to that from the park/woodland just east of the Strahov Monastery. The sun was warm and we basked in both it and the beautiful architecture. We meandered towards the monastery and found something worth photographing at every turn, some interesting shops and restaurants and had a lovely afternoon, allow time, meander and just soak up the atmosphere!
Magical area.. The castle grounds are unlike any place I have ever visited before. There is a mix of old and new, modern and classical - and you can feel the history of the area underneath your feet.
My favorite place!. Calm and small streets, nice new, tasty coffee, palace Loretta, old Prague spirit! And not too many people!

Lots and lots to see here. this is a must see. Go at 12 noon to see the changing of the guards. So neat. Go inside the Castle walls to see so many things, St. Vitus, old prison, the Golden Lane where Frank Kratz lived once, older chapels, soooo much to see...

breath of the past. this place is astounding. as you walk through, you will learn a lot and see some beautiful things. again, as I would say about many sights in Prague, you should also make an effort to see the outside at night. Inside will be closed but it's still worth an extra trip. In summer they hold a fancy classical music event there every year, called "klasika pod hvězdami" - oh my, that's worth buying tickets for way ahead of time (they sell out early). It's an amazing combination of the castle scene and classical music.
Awesome walk. You feel like you are back in those days. A total walk to the past. The view from the castle is unique, try to go there on the afternoon and i guarantee you will see an amazing sunset

What a climb!. The castle area is well worth visiting and is kept is very good condition. Cobbles everywhere! definitely worth investing in good walking shoes. The buildings have the most beautiful decorations, most of which are high up so it begs the question, who would ordinarily see them. Nevertheless they are well worth looking at.
Make sure to have this on you list. Make sure to see this place. You definitely can feel the history in the air and the view you can see from there is great. Cross your finger to not get a foggy day.
lot of history. As you walk across the bridge you can feel the history. It is a busy bridge but a lot to see. It would be good if you visit it as part of a trip with a guide to explain.

many buildings to see. it takes about 1.5 hour to visit the entire site and it is worthwhile.One place that is less known and that we feel needs to be seen is the toy museum. Its very large and rich collection of toys is very interesting.

Very interesting place. Lots to see and do here but if you are expecting a castle like you see in the UK you will be disappointed. The complex is huge, containing a cathedral, a little basilica and several palaces. There is also Golden Lane which I found the most interesting of all as it showed the homes (rooms) of the servants as they were in the Middle Ages. A couple of nice cafés here too, to rest in between visits. You can easily spend over half a day here and the views from the top are great too.

Sense the History. Wander around the large open square, walk through the Castle grounds and soak up the historical atmosphere. Watch the 'changing of the Guard', but be careful of pick-pockets, while you watch the ceremony!visit the surrounding cafes, one of which is near the top of the street - can't remember the name. we sat in a lovely courtyard out the back, and soaked up the sun. Try the local pancakes(crepes), with cheese and spinach/ham, but beware, they're huge, but delicious. Share if you have a small appetite at lunchtime.
Couldn't make the castle. Unfortunately we didn't make the castle due to tired legs as it was quite a trek uphill to get there.
Must do for Prague Castle. Great area but that main attraction is the Prague Castle, which is awesome. Nice area to just wander around
A day well spent. This visit requires the whole day as there is so much to see and enjoy right from the ride to the castle on the tram.

A lot to see and do. Make sure you have at least one day at your disposal to visit at ease the Castle District as, according to the Guinness Book of World Records, Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle complex in the world - http://web.archive.org/web/20060721043205/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/content_pages/record.asp?recordid=50103 (I did not even know that).Start with the 12 o`clock changing of the guards at the castle`s main entrance and then proceed to discover its second and third courtyards. Make sure not to miss a visit inside St.Vitus´s Cathedral, St. George Basilica, the world-famous Golden Lane and the Royal Gardens. The towers are not a too spectacular site unless you are interested in the Castle Guard`s history (Mihulka Tower) or torture instruments (Daliborka Tower). Then go and visit the Royal Garden with its magnificent palace called Belvedere and the Singing Fountain in front of it. Last but not the least take a walk into the most quiet corner of the Castle District, the Novy Svet street (or The New World - narrow street with small houses where the owners used to put house signs above the door to identify their houses, which you can still see there), and make sure to get to Loreta on the hour to hear the famous chime of the bells in the tower.

Hradcany Prague.. Excellent place to visit practically a must. The Castle Quarters so good to see and The Guards on duty outside two of them. They keep so serious and people smile beam make faces and photograph. We were so luck to see the change of the Guards and a Guard March exit the Castle with their Rifles and march in harmony. Outside the Castle quarters are two people dressed up as a Jester and a King. They have a Seat and a Big heart so people can sit and have 4 photos taken with these actors and if anything you shall crack up laughing as they get you to do the various poses. On exiting the Castle to the left you will be blown away with the fantastic panoramic view of Prague. Don't forget the camera. There is also a man there with vintage cars of which you can hire for 50 euro . This entails him taking you to see all the sights and attractions of Prague where they stop so photographs may be taken. great quick way to get around. I say this not that I took the car as I prefer to walk. But if one decided to walk down to the Charles bridge from the Castle quarters there are many steps to go down and may not be suitable for everyone. A taxi, Bus . The funicular is there to use also to go up the inclined plane of the hill to the castle. Great system for everyone to access Castle quarters. You can drink some nice soft drinks or hot wine a favourite of people to warm them in the winter autumn visiting months. On reaching the bottom of the steps down there are little cafes on the right hand side of the steps the first one as in nearest was run by a family. simple local foods hot and cold available. Very quaint place. lovely little rooms and quirky things to snap shot. Enjoy this visit . I sure did.

A must to do. The Castle District includes Prague Castle which is almost a misnomer as it's a series of historic and majestic buildings within the castle precinct. They are all very interesting and visitors should allow time to see as many as possible. Unless you have limited time or are physically restricted do yourself a favour and commence your trip on foot from Old Town Square then over the Charles Bridge and explore the fascinating streets and lanes as you walk to the Castle. Howard - Sydney, Australia

Fulfilling experience!. The Castle is a must see in Prague and even though not all of the exhibitions are great, there are many nice and interesting things to see while visiting there. It is a great part of the history of Prague and the Czech Republic in general, so it is definitely worth your time while in Prague. Keep in mind that you will need some hours to explore it so go on a day that you have plenty of time!

Very impressive. Fantastic area- I would recommend a tour to take in all the details, we went with discover Prague tours which were great value. Took the Tram up the hill and walked down after. Changing of the guard is hilarious!
Only if you have extra time. Beautiful buildings but they're not a rarity in this city. The castle is the draw.Save this are for extra time if you have any.

Prague Discovery free tours.. Used the above tour company,free tour of the city took 2.5 hrs,all districts covered,Jewish Quarter,Squares,Bridges,Cathedral,etc.Diana was our guide,very informative and witty.The second tour was of the castle area,again,very informative,lovely city views,changing of the guard etc.

You must walk this. Walk the streets, wander up the hill to the castle. It's a steep and long climb, but worth it both for the view and to see the castle and St. Vitus Cathedral. Look for the joke rubber manequin with arm outstretched to brush against the ankles of the unwary. A great fun.

Beautiful. A beautiful area, full of life and culture. I loved every minute of being in this city. This area is full of street artists, all lovely, friendly people. The shops in this area are a mix of tourist and traditional craft. Lovely.

Beautiful view!. Great place, must in prague!
A little far away but worth to visit. Also prepare to be there a whole day alot to see there. The best view at prague from the castle. Recomended!!
a pretty district. It has some quaint shops and bars which offer good value for money it does get busy but its worth seeing
Go and walk it all through. This is the kind of places where you would like to get lost. Walk and walk, see the architecture, imagine and enjoy the view from the top!!

Awesome. You definitely feel like you're in Europe if you go to this area. The narrow, cobblestoned streets and charming restaurants are so enjoyable. We didn't bother buying tickets to see additional sights as we found spending a few hours ticket free we'd still seen a good amount of Czech culture.

Beautiful area. What a nice area of Prague! We spent a full day up here and bought a 'long visit' ticket + a ticket for the grand tower of the cathedral. Take your own food and drink if you can. The prices up here a really too much The whole place is really well kept. The palace guard are immaculate and deserve a mention. Their museum is well worth a visit (Item 7 on your ticket) Its not obvious, but it is to the left of the cathedral entrance, beyond the toy shop.

Worth it for the views. Went on an organised tour but if I was doing it again I would just jump the 22 tram and go independently. We Did not gain much access to the interiors of buildings and access in the cathedetal was quite limited. There are plenty of eating and drinking places and i imagine this is a popular location in summer where you could sit on a terrace with a drink and enjoy a great vista of the city

Walking Back in Time. We lazily took the bus to the castle as we didn't want to walk UP the hill! The views at the top is spectacular! There are guards at the entry point at the top. We went into the Church but found that you can only stand just pass the entrance as you have to pay to go further into the church. It's a beautiful church.On the way down, we visited the ornamental glass gift shop and watched the wine glasses being etched with various designs.We then tried to walk into Golden Lane but found that you had to pay to see this too. As we were only in Prague for a few days, we had decided to see all the free things first! Next we visited the Toy Shop but didn't stay long as we found that this didn't really interest us as much. There is a bronze statue of a naked male in a plinth outside the shop. It is said to be lucky if you rub his private part! Obviously this is now the shinnest part of the statue! We went into the palace museum cafe for a drink and something to eat! The food and drink is good but you do pay a little more; as we found when we pass a smaller cafe on the way down! However, as the cafe is all part of the palace museum, they also had a gift shop to wander round and also some interesting pictures!You can take some great photos at the top!The walk down is not too steep and there are some souvenir stalls on the at down.Don't miss this experience if you have the time!

Loved it!. Fantastically preserved, built over many centuries, the Palace (and St Vitus Cathedral above it) is the heart of the Czech Republic - there are ancient galleries, art collections, a rows of artisanal shops (not overpriced), changing of the guard, great views over the red-tiled roofs capes/

Buy an 'A' ticket and book a guided tour. The guided tour takes you around the old castle rooms and the cathedral. It is very informative and then you can re-visit these places again in your own time either on the same day or the following day. You also get entrance into many other buildings in the castle complex which are worth seeing. Also, go to the bottom of the hill for spectacular views of the city.
Some Castle!. A stunning area, not so much a castle as a small town, had lunch on the terrace at Lobkowicz Palace, great food and stunning views over the city.

enjoyable walk. Had a great morning walking around. The cathedral is especially amazing and although you do not have to pay to walk inside to truly enjoy it you needed to walk around the whole building inside. The only problem we had were the toilets . I had assumed that by paying we would have access to toilets but the only ones we found needed money and we had no small change and nor could we get some.so top tip if you think you might need a visit to a little room bring some small coins with you . Would have given this )5stars if we had found toilets easily

Great place for a walk. It is a great place for a walk. There are amazing views from the top of the hill. Some great photo opportunity. Many small restaurants to stop in and shops to visit. Great narrow street and colour buildings. A must visit when in Prague.

chocolate. Walked over the Charles Bridge and up to the Castle. It was lovely and very pleasant to walk about. Only thing is they charge you entrance and the want to charge you the same amount for audio. Think is a bit unfair but guide told us it all depends who is in the government at the time. Went to a lovely cafe that sold beautiful coffee and the nicest hot choc I have ever tasted. Highly recommended. I even purchased it to bring home
wonderful. the history is fantastic the church and watching the guard changing the guys at the windows playing their instruments the outfits the guards wear were lovely
Do not miss this. If your visiting Prague you must go to the Castle district, walk up or take a bus what ever the view is breath taking and then you have the church the castle and so much more.

Amazing views from above. The view of the entire city from the top of the castle is excellent. You can see just about all tne landmarks . Your hotel can help with discounted tours and if you have more than one day, you can spread out your visit. It's alot of walking, some of it gently inclined streets. There are approx 270? Steps to the top of the cathedral, but if you want spectacular views of all the gorgeous spires, cathedrals and domes, do it. Lots of touristy shops for mementos, mostly boutique stores. Use cash - most stores give small discounts for cash rather than credit cards.
One of the best castles. Definitely worth to visit. Spend at least half day. The complex is huge and many interesting spot. I visited it twice, and was still amazed
Walk and learn. Great area for stretching your legs and admiring the architecture.Plenty of cafes, toilets and buskers to choose from and some absorbing exhibits if you choose to see them.
Place for those who like history and architecture. We nice place with many historical buildings from various centuries. We really enjoy it. All quite close in walking distance, accessible.

Hidden gem. A hidden gem as most visitors dont go here! Trams takes you to the bottom.....then its a good walk up! St V's is stunning inside, a real surprise. Great walk around the grounds and a different view of Prague. Couple of nice cafes for lunch. We walked back all the way to the cafe Savoy for great cake!

Medieval. This area was nice with the many small streets. It seemed like there was a beautiful church on every corner. The Cafe's were plentiful and the desserts were great. My husband loved the coffee.

Prague Delight & History. The castle area is a tour of Prague's history. Take the Circuit A ticket which gives admission to the majority of the buildings on the castle site. The ticket is valid for 2 days but you can only enter each building once. Pay extra to climb the Great South Tower for spectacular views of Prague. Well worth the climb up the steep,spiral staircase. If you want to take photographs in the inside areas where this is allowed you need to buy a permit costing 50 CKR. To get to the castle area it's an up hill walk from the Charles Bridge. Allow plenty of time to see everything. In fact if you walk from the town centre then I'd allow at least 5 hours to get the real benefits of the area.

Take your tine. A great way to dive in to Bohemian history. The castle district iscquite large, so its best not to rush yourself. Take your time and enjoy a refreshing drink while in the area. Lots of different locations to explore. Some - or even many - might prove to be difficult if handicapped.

Huge castle complex. A very big complex of architectures, probably the biggest castle I have visited so far. The view from the top of the castle church is very good, you can see all the famous landmarks from there. Also, the area around the castle is all full of interesting boutique stores and nice restaurants.

Worth the climb!. Lovely even on a cloudy February day. We bought tour A which includes everything and ticket is valid for 2 days which you need as too much walking and too much to see on one day. The climb to the top of the Cathedral tower (about 270 steps) is worth it for the view. Bought lovely wooden gifts in a shop called Manufaktura on the way up ( but dotted all over the city too) which are very reasonably priced and made in the Czech Republic. Would have liked to have tried their beer shampoo and shower gels but too big for hand luggage liquid allowance unfortunately! Starbucks near castle expensive it is better value in the cafes down the hill! Tip - public toilets need 10 Kr coin and usually no change given so go prepared with change.
high on a hill. a great view from the castle. star bucks at the site by the castle. have a chat with the loan protester against European integration, what a great character
Impressive Castle. Lots to see at the castle...we enjoyed the changing of the guard ceremony....the cathedral is in the same area..the glass windows are stunning
A must see for anyone. so much to see from the old palace to the cathedral to the stunning Golden Lane - so much history, so much beauty
Go up there and explore. You need your walking shoes on but this area is worth all the effort of getting there and discovering the castle and other interesting buildings etc
A must see...... Its full of attractions...Must wear comfortable shoes streets are cobbled stones and can be quite steep at some places..
Long walk. Must see but prepare for long walking day and also pay in to castle to get full benifit of all the castle
Must see attraction. Dont miss it it has many things to see . Dont forget to watch at 1200 noon the change of guard. Also visit the gold lane

Best time to visit: winter. The Hradcany is a must visiting prague. Therefore you are never alone up here. But if you really want to get a feeling of the place, come here in winter, early spring or late autuum. In summer because of too many visitors you want be able to see enough.The "small" ticket, which you get at one of the information centers, is enough. You will be able to visit the most important places: St Vitus Cathedral, the Royal Palace, St.George´s Basilika and the Golden Lane.The Audio Guide is unfortunatly not giving a lot of general information but tells a lot of details, on architecture and design but little on history and a only few stories around the place. For example I did not know, who St Nepomuk was but learned everything about his silver sakropharg in the cathdral. Where the silver was found, who paid it an why it was placed there.  By the way: Catholics see John of Nepomuk as a martyr to the cause of defending the Seal of the Confessional, romantic nationalists regard him as a Czech martyr to imperial interference, and most historians present him as a victim of a late version of the inveterate investiture controversy between secular rulers and the Catholic hierarchy. He was imprisoned, tortured and thrown into the river on command of the King Wenzel IV. (see the place on Karl´s Bridge). He is THE national hero.

Prague's history. A whole day at the Castle was just enough but there were still areas we missed. The cathedral stained glass windows were spectacular. There were not too many tourists which meant no queues or crowds. The Czech goulash was delicious whilst enjoying the view of the city.

Best of Prague to discover. This is the medieval part of the city that worth to be discovered.You have indeed the castle on the top but also very nice streets and monuments to discover. Good restaurants are all around. Don't miss to get a beer at U krale Brabantseho to come back to the middle age

The Castle and surroundings, worth the walk. Not only the Castle, St. Vittus Cathedral, the Golden Alley and the immediate surroundings of the Castle are well worth the visit and the view, but all the surroundings further up and around, (the Gardens if not in Winter) are worth the visit. A good tip is when you get down from the castle, everyone takes the stairs, but almost no one takes the little trail that goes next to the stairs, but through the vineyards. This is less crowded and a wonderful way down without the crowds... Simply take the alternative to the left of the stairs as you come down, and voila!

Must see in Prague. The Castle District is different from anything we ever seen in Europe, the Catedral inside the complex is wonderful and the city views are beautiful! Tickets are valid for two days so you can explore all the attractions. They charge 50cz for taking pictures, I do not think this is nice assuming it is a touristic area. Access is easy from the city center.

A unique tour. at the north side of the castle hill there is a street named Novi Svet. start your tour with it and climb on the hill from Chernin palace, explore the main street and then enter the castle and see all its attractions.

Plenty to see for free. Everything it's cracked up to be - but wrap up warm. Just strolling the open areas is wonderful and there are plenty of "hidden" things to see beyond the core tourist ones. You can go to the cathedral entrance without paying and various shops etc enable you to peek into other buildings.

Great view of the city!. We went on a walking tour around the castle district which I would highly recommend as there is so much history to be told and learned about Prague. Such a great city, and small enough to take advantage of the walking tours. Very beautiful, the castle district is well worth looking around. Once at the top the scenic views of Prague are so pretty. You can see for miles! Good picture opportunity!!

Dusk is good time to go. Just before darkness come, Castle and surroundings looks magical, guards are changing,illuminations goes on,not too many people, in short, great time to go and watch City of Thousand Spears bellow.

One of the best View of Prague/ Great Please to visit. Is located in the top of a montain. Is a nice walk up hill, but you will not feel it, because there are a lot of restaurants, stores, San Nicolas Church is in the way, there are a small parks with street food. The Castle provide you a tours, which I recomend because in less time you can see and learn form Praga History.

Lots of quirky shops, pushy sellers outside inviting you in.... The fact that we got lost walking around this area, allowed us to see lots of these little pedestrian streets.Very pretty.The buildings around are "mix and match"; some really nice, and some beyond repair.We saw lots of funny/ quirky ( sometimes on the edge of vulgarity) shops ...quite a few ladies outside their shops tried to sell us drinks to take away/ food etc.The architecture and feel of the place is quite nice apart from these interruptions.

Castle. Fantastic - loads of history, but a long walk up (208 steps), so if mobility is an issue - get a taxi. IThe Castle os free to walk around but you need to pay to go inside. The views from the Castle are stunning - an absolute must!
Must See, Very Charming. We took a taxi up to the Castle and walked down to the Bridge. We enjoyed the shops and the tea rooms. Great views of the city
Amaaaazziinnnggg. Wonderful wonderful wonderful. Beautiful buildings all around . Great scenic beauty and what a place to have a walk... its out of this world...
Nice walk. we wandered round on foot for a few hours through this area and it was lovely.Felt very safe, this was during the day.
fab. Once again the buildings are amazing there is so much history we could have stayed all day. the veiws down over the City are great even in winter

gotta take a look. nothing i can add to previous reviews, the buildings are stunning you must have a look turn it into a day have a meal ( not mytsic cafe/pizzerie unless you want to be ripped off) the area is very romantic at night with a drink in you : )
Labyrinth. Walking up is nice and you believe it is easy to find the way back. But once you have lost the direction it is not easy to get same way back; nevertheless enjoyable.
stunning. again stunning part of the city so much to see, TIP go up Petrin Hill and get the best view of Prague before walking back through the castle and over the bridge

A must do, but I wasn't impressed. This is a castle that I think is better to look at from the outside than the inside. We did the walk up, along the main staircase that everyone takes. We did it with a stroller, and it wasn't difficult, but it wasn't fun. Once inside the only thing we went into was the Golden Lane (which has free entry after 5pm). There are some great views of the city from the castle. Apparently there are great gardens, but in winter it was so cold all we wanted to do was get to somewhere warm.

A real testiment to Czech Architecture. The castle is stunning with incredible architecture however I would not recommend paying to look around the cathedral. You can enter the cathedral and get an essence for what it is like for free but if you wish to tour it costs. The castle is at the top of a very steep hill but I would recommend walking it if you can as there are some lovely quaint shops along the way.

Amazing area. This is an amazing area of Prague and the sheer size of the castle and associated buildings is incredible. There's a great ceremony at 12AM for the changing of the guards which is worth witnessing. You could spend hours in this area alone and there are marvellous views over Prague. It is an upward walk but not too strenuous.

Great European Castle. Great Castle is a must-see in Prague. I recomend the extended trip, to see almost all the places. Still there are some that you will go through suprisingly quick, but the whole experience is fantastic, and gothic cathedral is breathtaking. Wawel castle in Krakow is a longer and more historical trip, but Hradcany has their own unique beauty.Also Golden Street is soo overated.

Hallmark of Prague. Prague Castle and Charles Bridge are the two symbols of this city. If you're coming from Mala Strana (Lesser Quarter) to the south, the Castle sits atop the hill in Hradcany and is only accessible via a flight of stairs on Zamecke Schody that vears off of Thunovska near St.Nicolas Church in Malostranske namesti (the main town square in the Lesser Quarter). Using google maps to find these streets will prove helpful if you're planning your own walking tour like we did. If you're coming from the north, the entrance is easier to find, but most visitors come from the south via Old Town into the Lesser Quarter before climbing up to the Castle, which makes the first route a more likely option. Prague Castle is actually a complex (the largest ancient castle in the world) housing the St.Vitus Cathedral, St.George Basilica, the Old Royal Palace (home of the Czech President), and various gardens, so don't expect a stereotypical castle with wooden torches and hidden passages, just merely a set of walls containing a bunch of buildings. Still worth a visit nonetheless, even if solely for a great view of the city below. The grounds are free and open until 11 pm, but the individual buildings are closed starting at 4 pm.Another note: Tram 22 to Prazsky Hrad or Metro Line A (green) to Malostranske followed by a short walk up the hill are the 2 easiest ways to arrive in this district.

The largest castle complex in the world!. The castle complex stands magnificently on the hillside overlooking the city of Prague and it is definitely worth seeing as there are so many different parts to it. There are a wide variety of architectural styles including Renaissance, Baroque and Roman as well as the Gothic masterpiece of St. Vitus Cathedral. The Vladislav Hall is a huge hall over 60 metres long with an impressive rib-vaulted ceiling and you can imagine the coronations, banquets which have taken place over the years. It was even used for jousting tournaments and there is a 'riders staircase' with nine shallow steps so the Knights could ride into the hall ready for their tournament. There are panoramic views across Prague as you walk down the Golden Lane which dates from the 15th Century and has a beautiful, olden world quaintness about it.

Amazing views, worth the trek. Its a walk to the top but you can see the whole city whilst up there. We didnt pay to go in anywhere just walked round the different court yards and grounds. There isnt a castle as such like we know back in the UK but some amazing buildings and views, definately made our trip special.

Great views but crowded. This is an interesting place to visit and probably a must see. However be prepared for huge crowds. Despite it being freezing it did not put off the tourists so it was almost impossible to move. Tour groups everywhere.

Nice place with bogeyman. Great place to see. Interesting sights, perfect view of Prague but little bit overcrowded. It is also recommended to visitors to avoid encounters with current Castle's master. He is real bogeyman.

Great walking district with views over Prague. Prague Castle is a must-see on any journey to Prague. Not only the 15-16th century government building, but St. Vitus Cathedral, at the top of the promontory. From the top, an exquisite panorama of Prague opens up for viewing enjoyment. Walking down the slopes of the castle, there are any number of charming cobbled streets where one can get lost, splendid architecture, and small shops and bars along the way.Two half days should be allotted to appreciate the sights in this district. Best to take a taxi to the Castle and walk down, unless one wants the exercise. From the Charles Bridge to the top of the Castle takes about 20-30 minutes of steady walking.

The Climb is Worth It. The Castle District has something for everyone. There is the Castle and St. Vitus Cathedral and a wide array of shops, cafes and snack shops. We visited the District several times during our stay. There is a climb to get to the castle but the view of the city and the Cathedral are worth it.

Well worth a visit. Watched the changing of the Guards before spending a few hours looking round the castle, buildings beautiful. Cold when we where there so a loverly drink of hot chocolate to warm us up. Plenty of places to eat or get a drink there, we went on the hop on hop off bus and walked back. There is a charge of 375 kronas per person for what they say is full admission to all the buildings, however a couple of buildings we still needed to buy other tickets. 100 kronas is approximately £3.

Stunning!. The stairs are all part of it...we climbed them, and got to the top at 12.45, got some hot wine(it was cold) well we wait to see the guard change at 13.00 which was really cool, then wondered a bit more to see the stunning cathedral! Highly Reccomend this...it was grat!
Must visit. You can take the tram or the bus up to the castle and then enjoy the nice walk down to the town square. Or if you are fit, go for it an do the walk up to the castle

Prepare yourself for half day visit. I really like this part of Prague. It is up on a hill, so it is better to use tram if you are older or if you can not walk so much. The view is wonderful. If you want to visit it properly, you have to prepare yourself for half day visit. I recommend you to visit- St.Vitus Cathedral, Golden Street, Prague Castle, Lobkowicz Palace, St.George Church,... There is a ticket office where you can buy tickets for several or for all attractions. Also, there are a lot of shops, restaurants and bars on the way down to Charles bridge.

Prague Castle. Prague Castle is certainly well worth a visit and the walk up the steep street to the castle is well worth the climb and anyway the street itself is interesting with its many shops and bars. The castle and the cathedral are beautiful and there is also an old street to visit within the castle grounds showing how the homes and shops etc. used to be in bygone years. I have not yet been inside the castle but maybe next visit! At night Prague Castle is lit up and it is awesome; it looks beautiful and magical.

Breathtaking. I completely fell in love with the castle area of Prague. We visited on a snowy day and it was like a fairy tale. The buildings,Golden Lane and the views are staggering. It needs a couple of days to explore properly as there are lots of little alleyways to turn down and there's a lot of walking involved,but I'd love to have the chance to do it again.

Just stunning when peaceful!. We took a trip out to see the monastery. I wasn’t convinced this was the day out for me but went for it anyway. Luckily there’s a train that takes you up the hill so the mammoth climb can be avoided. Once up there you will find Prague’s version of the Eiffel Tower, lovely landscapes, spectacular scenery The Castle and splendid views over Prague, it’s certainly a trip not to miss out on. The monastery and vineyard are excellent. There is a brewery in the monastery where you can order food in lovely surroundings and buy their very own un-pasteurised beer. It changed daily dependant on what was brewed. I did notice a table full of American young travellers (who were far too loud and screechy and everything was oh so fingers down a chalk board-ingly ‘awesome’- oh God!!!! Must everything be ruined, it’s a monastery, why send a me a herd of loud Americans? Why? why?????) Anyway (anyway’s?) They all chose pints of un-pasteurised beer (which is really neat). I couldn’t help thinking that in the USA beer is often advertised as triple filtered. I felt a warm glow of satisfaction knowing that most of that gang would wake next morning with the screaming ab dabs and nothing, nothing would be awesome anymore. So yes, go there (unless of course your name is Tyler or Brad and everything is awesome) and enjoy the spectacular scenery and food and drink and general ambience and the peace and quiet. It’s beautiful.

Disappointing.. Inside the buildings there is nothing. No fine rooms with beautiful furniture, paintings, gilded mirrors - nothing at all! Waste of money. Don't bother buying tickets to go in. Just look at the buildings and the view over Prague but be warned it is windy up there and therefore very very cold if you visit in winter time. Brrrr!!!

Incredible views of all of Prague.. First, pay attention to the architectural details in every building! Stop and take photos of these amazing masterpieces. Everything has amazing and ornate details that should not be missed. Sure, there are Segway tours, and local shops and touristy restaurants (overpriced) but the view from here is simply breathtaking! Walk up to the Loreta and just enjoy the sights!
Changing of the Guards. We loved watching the changing of the guards. The show at noon was great. The whole area was very pleasant to stroll around.
Great view of a beautiful city. If you have the time visit the castle on the hill. Great view from up there and a well preserved bit of Prague history.
Excellent. Really enjoyed exploring the castle area and watching the changing of the guards. Which happens at 12 midday. Some lovely museums and interesting stories and places to eat.

Raw beauty. On a bitter day in December day we visited Hradcany, with freezing rain and snow, temp -5 to -8. Walking swiftly from Petrin Hill we enjoyed the streetscape en route with such beautiful architecture, historical buildings and lovely paved streets, with lots of attractive little shops and restaurants. We visited the Church of Our Lady Victorious on the way, dating back to the 16th century run by the Carmelite order, which houses the famous Infant Child of Prague - well worth seeing. Prague castle, seat of the Czech president, is an interesting collection of buildings including the amazing gothic St Vitus Cathedral, dating back to 1300s. Some glorious classical music could be heard from one or two of the churches. There are several palaces to see including Lobkowicz Palace, whose museum holds some Beethoven and Mozart manuscripts. The changing of the guard took place while we were there, but it was quite a simple small event. As we later made our way down the hill towards Charles Bridge with its Baroque statues standing proud, snow was falling and the twinkling lights of the city created a magical unforgettable scene. Would recommend spending a full day, maybe have a guided tour to see all the sights at the Castle.
ENORMOUS. The area of the castle is so wide and large that it takes at least one day to visit it!! We didn't but we enjoyed the view from the castle above the city of Prague. It was a great moment!!
great views. Went up on the tram.great views from the castle and fab buildings.Also a lovely walk back.Lovely church to look around but had to pay to go in which i do not like.

Nicely strung out. After walking around the Old Market square, it was a pleasant change to find a string of business, although primarily aimed at the tourist, offering a wider variety of products & services whilst ambling up to the Castle. What I particularly liked was their individuality [with the exception of 'highstreet chain'.Be prepared for a stiff neck and collisions with other pedestrians as there is plenty to cast your eyes over up above.

Wonderful. One of the nicest place in Prague, it feels like being in a city into the city. Full of bars, cafés and pubs it is great by night as it is by day. The view you get from the Castle is awesome!

What a wonderful piece of history. You could spend half a day walking th cobbled streets of th castle district. The beautiful gardens, castle and surrounds and the wonderful view across Prague make for some excellent sightseeing. Great restaurants and some real history in the area are worth taking a guide or a tour.

A must visit location. There is so much to see at this location with a wealth of buildings and the beautiful cathedral. We did the walking tour with a guide and timed it so that we could see the changing of the guard at 12 noon. You could spend all day here and not see it all. Also great views of the city of spires from here.

Get there Early. Words cannot do justice to the history that is on show here. Take the 22 tram and climb up to the castle and cathedral - we missed the cathedral (it was the New Year Day's service) so will be back. The castle is beautiful, the views of the city stunning and the history breathtaking. It is a tour best done slowly to take in the enormity of the place - magnificent.

Impressive. The Castle district is well worth visiting, but give yourself time because there is so much to see! Our visit included a lunch-time concert in Lubkowicz Palace, and a brilliant wander around the hugely impressive cathedral.

Gigantic. Huge complex of historical buildings, lots of things to see. Spend several hours to sightsee everything. Nice walk from petrin hill,not so far from there.St. Vitus Cathedral is also in walkable distance.

LIke a Fairy Tale!. The castle and its environs are very beautiful This town was not bombed by Hitler, so when you walk through the streets and alleys you are walking on the same cobblestones that Smetena and Mozart walked on. Beautiful architecture.

Loaded with History and quite a sight to see.. We visited with a local guide (very affordable), and she brought the history of the Castle District alive. The Cathedral is absolutely a sight to see up close and personal. Worth the time. Take the tram to the castle and then walk down through lesser town to the Charles river bridge. Great sights.

Fab, get a guide and watch the changing of the guard. Again as I have mentioned in other reviews Ross is the best guide ever and he will show you around and enhance you tour with his wealth of information, he took us at the exact time the changing of the guard took place, he showed us the most magnificent views.

there isn't actually a castle. Basically there is the castle grounds with cool aspects such as golden lane and all the medieval displays however there isn't an actual castle to look around. Maybe because we're English and we have actual castles that we were disappointed.

A must visit. If one has never been to Prague before, a tour of the castle area is a must. There is much history tied to this relatively small area. For the hiker, it can be reached on foot from the Old Town square. My wife and I had a guided tour with an exceptional local guide, Helena. The St. Vitus Cathedral is part of this complex. In four visits to Prague, I have had this tour four times. It is different each time.

Brilliant place. We've just visited this place is amazing and beautiful. We did it as a part of free walking tour. The castle demands a revisit for maybe a few hours. At sunny day the views over the city are wonderful. Greeting from Prague.

Amazing view. We hired a vintage car and went up to the castle to see the changing of the guard, then walked up to the viewing tower through some woodland, went up to the top of the tower and then got th cable car down. Nothing in Prague is expensive so just do envy thing you can.

Get fit. Visited the castle as part of an all day walking tour of the city. A dusting of snow fell during our day which made the city look very pretty. The castle demands a revisit for maybe a half day on it's own to see more. On a clear day the views over the city are wonderful.

A snooty cafe owner.... On way back from castle, on man street, we stoppd in a cute little french cafe; ordered 2 cappuccinos and one slice of cake; owner told us "one slice of cake, only one fork" . We chuckled:) Then watched him tell customers that 2 people couldn't sit at a table for 4! He had only 2 tables that sat 2! Somehow he left us alone even though we were sitting at table for 4!! It was a riot as people just up and left! Hospitality run amok....... in Prague.

Three Hour tour!. We did the Tour B option in the early afternoon and just got thru it before the 1600 closure! Visited between the Christmas and New Years, and there were lots of people, but very little delays. Each location on the tour was good, many people disregarded the no photo signs!
Amazing views from hilltop.. Well worth the walk up - stunning views over Prague & the river. Worth taking a good guide book - the castle is more of a district, rather than just one building!

Fairy tale castle. The tram unwinded over the hill, giving us pretty views of the city until all of our attention was drawn towards the medieval castle district. The castle looks staright out of a fairy tale. Read more : http://julie-kanvinde10.blogspot.co.uk/2014/09/prague-tales-discovering-dark.html

Impressive historical castle. The castle was well preserved and maintained in excellent condition. The area is clean and well sign posted. The view of the Old Town from the castle is impressive. The only downside is the lack of free toilet like everywhere else in Prague.

Yeah it was alright. It's was okay, same as every other castle slash church in Europe, kept the missus happy atleast, just watch out for those sneaky fuucking Asian shop keepers, shorted me missus 1000 koruna in the mini mart after buying a bottle of water for 65, fuucking thief, took some strong words and some yelling to get the correct change back, most everyone one else is nice and honest, so good overall. Beers pretty good too,Chee blokes

A beautiful castle. You can't leave Prague without visiting the castle but it will take you at least 4 hours for the... short visit. A combined ticket gives you enough flexibility to visit all the important sites.

Overwhelming area. The top entrance can be easily reached by number 22 tram then it is just a short walk down hill. The buildings are very impressive. We purchased a ticket for the tour.Maybe just to walk around & look inside the huge Cathedral at stained glass windows & the exterior of various buildings would be enough unless you have a full day in this area.Cafes for snacks. The interior of houses along the narrow Golden Lane were interesting ,like a museum. I recommend a visit/ tour of Lobkowicz Palace further down the hill but you need to purchase a separate entrance ticket. & after walking for 4 hours allow enough time before closing. If approaching this area from below you would reach this palace first.However, a well graded walk down with more amazing views over the city & also several restaurants.

What a place!!!. Totally love it. This district looks amazing!!! Lot of things to see and explore, youneed at least one day to see all the beautyof this place. And the viev for the city wow.... Need to see itwith your own eyes
Big Place. 1400 rooms, something like that, weird soviet era statues, food, church was amazing, lots of walking around

Great to walk around. But if you do queue up and get a ticket there is much more to do! There is plenty so see walking around and you can get in the door of the Cathedral and see how big it is. The Castle District has old churches palaces and the servant quarters great views out over the city and lots and lots of visitors. We bought the ticket which allows for one entrance over two days. So we were able to come back on the Second morning and finish off some of the ticketed attractions. Even so the crowds were up early and there were still queues. Perhaps not so long. What we did enjoy about coming back in the morning was that the light was different and much easier to get photos of the City. The walk from the off town across the river and then up the steep hill is part of the experience so make the effort.

Stunning buildings and churches. We are not generally into churches but the buildings are just stunning especially set off against a brilliant blue background. We took advantage of a free walking tour which ended at the Castle complex. Lennon wall is close, beautiful buildings,quite steep but ok if taken slowly. Castle complex impressive and you can watch the changing of the guards. Finishing at St Vitus church which is stunning especially when you realise how old it is! Obviously because it is running up to Christmas lovely trees and decorations. Plus the guards had lovely winter coats. Breathtaking.
We Came Back Again and Again.. You can't see this area in one short visit. You have to return 3 or more times to take it all in and to appreciate it.
Great! Go there!. Loved the golden lane! The dislike was too many people again. I liked the st.Vitas catedral second best.

be there at 1200 for the changing of the guard. There are several uphill or up steps walks to the castle. If you are there for 1200 (be there early as it gets crowded and you need to get to the front of the crowd!), musicians stand in windows whilst the changing of the guard happens. Then wander about the castle area - lots to see and do, museums, beautiful architecture, cafes and restaurants, and take a different walk, or a tram back down the hill

Been there thousands of times and keep coming back. Growing up in Prague, coming by the Castle from the Petrin Hill or up the hill negotiating the steep Castle steps or better yet up the Nerudova street was something we did often. In the past twenty years, when we could finally return and visit Prague again, we never miss the opportunity to climb the hill up to the castle. We have done it in the spring, summer, fall and winter and can't get enough off the ever changing views of the city. We do not go on the tours, but stop in the Cathedral, catch a concert in the Basilica and stop in the Lobkowitz Palace for a bite to eat and of course the view.The changing off the Castle Guards at noon was something we never saw in Prague before. On our last visit our timing was perfect and we lined up with a lot of other people for a perfect view of the elaborate ceremony.
Well maintained castle area, a must see. Absolutely beautiful and well maintained area. As with the rest of the Prague, the only thing to say is that go see during the week. In weekend to crowded.
Wow! What a beautiful castle and church!. My wife and I along with several friends enjoyed our visit here. The castle district is quite large with lots to see. The tour guide was most interesting.

Great view!. The vivew from Castle district on Prague iz amazing, no meter if you visit Castle district by night or day. You can see one amazing church, traditional Czeh guards, and visit few museums there...

Wonderful. For a decent price you get to see the St. Vitus cathedral, the castle, Zlatna ulička (the Golden street), the St. George's church and the gallery. The cathedral is wonderful and imposing. The castle with its main hall is great and worth the visit. I especially loved the St. George's church. It is a small church in romanesque style. The Zlatna ulička is a lovely, small street with souvenir shops and small displays of everyday life in the middle ages. The view from Hradčani is amazing.
great experience. It is very impressive area. You must see this area when you're in Prague. It has also great view from the top of the hill.

Take the time to do the full tour.. It was worth the walk to get up to the top of the hill as it was very cold and we warmed up. So much to see when we got there that we paid extra to do the full tour instead of just the short tour.

Count Prague's 100 spires. Prague, a city of 100 spires and what better place to check them, count them if not from an elevated point. The views of the city from here are stunning, very many photo points too. Amongst the Royal route, the castle district seems to be tucked away and forgotten by time. Conveniently not forgotten by tourists though. The place seems to be teeming but doesn't give you the crowded feel. Ensure you taste the hot wine from the many stalls avail through out. Based on the advice of fellow TA contributors, we didn't buy tickets for the tour and I think the decision was sound and the advice good. You can either take a bus from the city center to the top of the hill (forgot the no, was informed by our hotel staff) and walk down or vice versa or walk both ways (which may be a bit cumbersome for the elderly and challenged). We followed the offline TA map for various attractions in this part of the city and honestly didn't miss much coz the map also gives a brief intro of the place. We witnessed the Guard changing ceremony at 13:00 at the palace gates, nothing royal but was good. Not sure if this is an hourly thing or once a day. If possible, try to time your visit to the top of the hill by 13:00 to catch this event.In all, would suggest to include Hradcany into your itinerary.

Prague castles. Beautiful, must see and spend time here! Go to the oldest castle district away from the rest of the hustle bustle. The oldest castle has a gorgeous view of Prague and the river. Dvorak is buried here, you can visit his tomb.
Lovely castle complex. Lovely walk through a castle complex with interesting buildings, with great histories; while beautiful Prague is always in the background.
visit early in the morning. majestic w+alk around and feel th royaltythe w+all around castle is decorative you may sit on the stairs and feel the romance

Well worth the trip out. I would advise getting a taxi or some other form of transport upto the monastery and castle district if you are staying down in the old town district - it's a fair walk back downwards and even tougher if you walk all the way up! But well worth it lots to see and the architecture is fantastic...
Worth the walk up the hill. Massive, wonderful Bohemia! Beautiful views over the town below. Don't forget John Lennon's wall on the way up.

Truly amazing!. This place dominates Prague from wherever you are (you won't believe the number of photos I have of it!). And once you get there it doesn't disappoint - the history is amazing and presented very well.The 'long' tour gives access to the 'Story of Prague Castle' exhibition which is really worth spending some time at. Changing of the guards at Midday - get there early for a decent view.Gold Lane - a real highlight and so different to the grand courtyards and cathedral.St Vitus Cathedral - stunning.And the rest of the district around the castle just felt really nice, relaxed and cool - not what you would expect from such a major attraction.The guidebook suggests getting there just before 9. We made it for about 10 but because it was winter it wasn't too busy - but if you are going in the summer be prepared for crowds.

The worst of tourist traps. Be prepared for a steep climb. Then when you arrive, be prepared for misinformation and rudeness at every turn. Start with the information/ticket office. There is a maze of combination tickets to the numerous individual sights up there, but absolutely no signage or brochure which explains it. Instead, you get to wait behind a line of customers only allowed an explanation and negotiation of the maze when they get to the one person selling tickets. They even have the gaul to charge you for a simple map of the grounds. In our case, we only wanted to see St Vitus cathedral. "Oh that's free, you don't need a ticket." Great. We find the cathedral and discover that we are restricted to a penned area at the very back of the church. To see the aisles and the alter you need a ticket! Then we thought we'd check out the shops on the Golden Road, which we enjoyed on our last visit several years ago. Well now you need a ticket. "But it will be free in half an hour at 4:00" We offer to buy a ticket. "No, it's too late to buy tickets." We sip coffee for half an hour. We go in and what was once a row of unique specialty stores is now a row of the same cheap garbage as 90% of the Christmas Market booths. We'd had enough, so we followed the exit sign behind long row of tourists down a very narrow covered stairway. At the exit gate, a hostile thug yelled at everyone to go back, they were locking the gate! Back we went to a gate marked "No Exit" to finally get our. Kafka's work suddenly became abundantly clear. I'm a Prague resident now, but I will never go anywhere near this place again. For a city full of wonderfully friendly and helpful people, I am sadly discovering that rudeness and poor customer service are the hallmark of the cities museums. Stick to the restaurants, shops, and free attractions and you'll see a whole different Prague.

Castle District. A lot of tacky souvenir shops, a few quaint restaurants. The Castle district is directly at ground level of the Prague castle.Not really much to see but is a great place to sit outside and have a beer in the summer.

Great place to spend evening. You can just start from Charles bridge and take this route towards Prague castle, and you will see amazing lights, shops, and great atmosphere. We walked all the way till castle, taking a small staircase route from district, was nice.
Excellent. The castle area was absolutely great and the history was amazing. It was so lovely to walk around seeing the different architecture and listening about the castle.

Allow plenty of time for the visit!. Reachable by tram, you have to pay even to take pictures in addition to the entrance fees! We did feel they are doing a masterful job in investing that money into the property though. No trip to Prague would be complete without stopping here!

Castle District. Lots of stairs to get to the top, but when you reach it you won't be disappointed. The aerial view is amazing, and if your into photography you can take some wonderful shots.Their is a Starbucks at the top, so you can get a drink.Their are also guards at the top by the castle which change at different times of the day, a few churches, architecture is amazing.Worth a visit.

Great fortification.. I did not visit the castle but did walk round the grounds. Great view from up here of old, new and part of lesser town. Some very eye pleasing gothic/enaissance/ baroque architecture. Love the cafe shops and restaurant close by.
Our Travels. To view most of this you'll have to walk up very steep roads and some are made of bricks. If your fit you will enjoy and appreciate the views.

Take Time and Absorb. There is so much to see and do, our favourite was walking around admiring the exterior of buildings. No where else is the architecture so beautiful, stunning and in perfect condition. Lots of places to eat and drink, some pricey, some not but definitely the place to stop for a hot wine or cold beer and people watch as well. Perfect for the panorama mode on your camera.

Great day out. You will need to spend a whole day this side of Charles bridge. First visit the Church of Our Lady of Victory to see the Infant Jesus of Prague statue. The John Lennon wall is very close by. Take in the views from the tower of St Nicholas Church before ascending the hill to the castle. You can wall around the castle grounds free of charge but it is good value for money at £11 to pay for entrance to 7 of the main attractions including St Vitus's cathedral. There is something for all the family at the castle. Finish off the day by walking further up the hill to The Lorretta ( a monastery £4 entrance fee) You need a lot of stamina as Hradcany is on the side of a hill, the views are great.
Nice walk through Hradcany. Great as always, in spite of hoards of people; found a lovely cafe with great cakes and hot chocolate.

Good afternoon visit. We took the tram to the top of the hill and spent the afternoon walking around the Castle District. While we were there, the St. Vitus Cathedral was closed, so we did not opt to spend the money (250-350 czk) on the tours inside of the castle. I would recommend the walk from the Castle down to and across Charles Bridge (just follow the crowd!).

Amazing historical gem.. A must see in Prague! Pay to tour all the areas. Audio guides really help to enhance the experience. We went to the classical concert as well which was in the Lubkowicz Palace. The music in this beautiful venue was truly an audio and visual memory of a lifetime!

Huge Historical Complex. The family loved all the museums and palaces and seeing the Bohemian crown jewels. Great photo ops all around. The weapons museum was a favorite with all the cool swords and guns and torture devices.
Wonderful, one of the best castles in Europe.. so well preserved and filled with interesting sites, views and insights on the castles history overtime. A must

A whole town on the hill. Not your typical castle, but a collection of courtyards, the cathedral with a Mucha painted glass window. See the changing of the guard on the hour, toy museum, the Golden Lane, cafes. Well worth a few hours of your time, and on a good day, the views are great.
