part of the Prague Historical Reserve. Hradčany is a part of Prague adjacent to Prague Castle (the main sight of the Prague Castle and of the whole of Prague is the St.Vitus Cathedral). Hradčany consists of the Schwarzenberg Palace (Renaissance style), the Tuscany Palace (originally Early Baroque building), the Archiepiscopal Palace (Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo), the Martinicz Palace (Renaissance), the Šternberk Palace (Baroque, Rococo), the St.John Nepomuk Church (Baroque), the Hradčany Town Hall (Renaissance), the Černín Palace (Early Baroque-Rococo), the Loretto (the copy of the building in italian Ancona +Baroque), the Strahov Monastery (Romanesque-Classical), the St.Roch Church (Renaissance), the Our Lady Church (now is in Baroque style), and the other buildings.

Putting Prague and the Czech Republic in Perspective. I knew little of Prague or the Czech Republic before this visit but did not expect the affluence and grandeur that I experienced at Hradcany. Well worth a visit to marvel at the size of the grounds and the magnificent cathedral.

Tour with Prague Sightseeing Tours. Great sights, lots of interesting history. Find a guide for the full experience. Some of the best views of Prague can be up at the Castle, though I think some of the best shots I got were from across the river at night up at the castle. Amazing lighting. Worth the ticket for sure. Restroom are pay all around here, and this is a tourist trap with lots of shops with crap. Try the Hot Wine if nothing else. Grog will warm you up on a cold day too.
Breathtaking and a must to see!. This is a must see in Prague. Very impressive how good is maintained and still functional. A true piece of history!

Simply beautiful. The castle complex is simply breathtaking, it is amazing that such structures existed from way back. It is important to separate a tour of the castle for other tours as I can assure you that there is so much to see.
A definetely visit. If you go to Prague you should defintely spend at least 2 hours to see the whole of the castle. Its worth every minute of it

Oustanding View. The view of this castle was nothing more than beautiful. You are able to see the bridges and the lake. The view of the city was magnificent. The city is huge and worth the visit. I would recommend wearing flats because the hike is very steep.
Lots to see. Give yourself plenty of time up here. We didn't and rushed through. There is a lot to see and you can spend several hours here. Have lunch up top and enjoy the view.

Incredible. No more words to describe this than incredible. Worth paying for a guide as there is so much you need to know about the surroundings and history of an incredible place. Much more than a castle.

Great viewpoint over the city. The cathedral is amazing & trees plenty more to see within the castle complex - we spent around 4 hours looking around. If you're up for it, the 289 steps up to the top of west tower gives great views.

Magnificent. I'm sure every travel will visit the castle but make sure you do a tour of all the spots and I suggest buying the audio as the place is huge with a lot of history. You won't know what you are seeing without either a guide or the audio. Plan on spending about 3 hours

Lots of Walking. My husband and I walked all over the castle district just enjoying the shops, cafes and of course the walk up to the castle. We took some side streets that were out of the tourist area and enjoyed the architecture that makes this city so unique.

A lot to see, and a lot to pay.. Worth the visit, and its very big with lots of separate buildings and churches to see. Big queues for tickets and no information until you get to the front. Expensive £50 if you want to go in everything.Unless you are into history, save your money and walk around the outside for free there is lots to see. Its quite a walk up the cobbled streets to get there but worth the walk and you see more. There are Taxis and tours etc. Changing of the guard gets very busy. Cathedral is good inside and costs nothing to just go in the door and look without going past the ticket barrier.Beware hoards of group tours.
wonderful. Take your time to wander round the castle district there is so much to see, and the views are amazing. Definitely worth a visit when in Prague.

Wonderful medieval neighborhood. Steep and narrow streets lead up to the castle complex. I got tickets at the information office at the entrance, past the front gates where the change of guard happens. If you are not that interested in the historical details of the place and architecture and just want to have a peak at the buildings, go inside and just have a look before passing through the till. We bought the five building package and I think it was really worth mainly for the cathedral which is amazing. If you want more details, it is worth it to get the guided tour headphones. There are several cafes along the way and we also found the hollow pastries (trdelnik), freshly made at the end of right wing of the castle. A beautiful way to explore Prague and spend the day.
Prague castle. Prague castle and surrounding areas is so stunning, really beautiful. Lso the Loretta is really lovely, well worth a visit, allow about three hours to enjoy it.

Worth the walk! . Although it is quite steep, it's definitely worth the walk just for the views alone. The castle was brilliant, we got to see the changing of the guard and there was so much to see. The attractions were well priced as well

A view of the world!. Located in the hills above Prague is Prague Castle. Absolutely beautiful grounds and very easy to find your own special place to sit or even stretch out. Quite a hike up, so if you are not ready for the trek, jump on one of the many trams that will make the trip easier.

Romantic trip to the history. You can take a walk through the Karl´s bridge and then continue to the Hradčany district. It is full of shops and restaurants and of course of tourists. The view of the town from the castle is amazing and also do not forget to visit St. Vitus Cathedral.
Huge Castle. Castle district is a beautiful are with a huge castle and an amazing park with white peacocks. Walk through this district was amazing.

Wonderful compound.. We liked the walk up to the castle and did not find it difficult - my husband is 65 and in so-so shape. The cathedral is amazing. I have been in 100's of cathedrals and this is one of the most magnificent ones I have seen.

Much to take in -- reserve 1/2-1 day!. We did it right-- took the tram to the "side entrance" at the top of the hill and walked in. We bought a combo ticket which included the 280+ walk up the narrow stone staircase to the top. Suggest starting at the "top" and working your way down to the lower entrance and walking back into town.

Captivating. This area of Prague is quaint, with all its charming buildings cobbled street's, chocolate shops, gingerbread shops, church's, museum's bars and restaurants, we loved this part of Prague.

not to be missed. Here you need at least a day. Make sure you are able to do a lot of stairs. The southern tower, 287 steps (up and again down) is worth it. Such a beautiful view over the city. The castle itself is amazin, the cathedral too. So don't miss it.

Rosenberg Palace, former home of noble ladies. Near the end of our time at the Prague Castle complex, we visited the Rosenberg Palace, a former home to noblewomen without families. I was hoping that the exhibits would tell more about the palace's former use, but there wasn't much about that. Instead, there was a lot of the usual things you would see in a Baroque palace: a stunning ceiling mural, ancient wooden doors with impressive iron and brass locks and hinges, some beautiful 18th century furniture. My favorite part exhibit here was of plaster casts of gargoyles from St. Vitus Cathedral. I am endlessly fascinated by the grotesque nature of gargoyles, and it was very cool to see these close up.

Beautiful view of the city. Take a cab to the top of the hill then walk down it much easier that way. The castle is amazing and they have preserved the support buildings around the castle too which are just as interesting.
The biggest Castle. Prague´s Castle is considered the biggest in the world. It´s deffenetly worth a day, at least, to visit.

Totally worth the hike - several facinating structures and views.. Take the 22 tram from the bridge to save some hiking.Alot of history among the buildings: leadership, defenestration, moats, river views.Then take the tram back down to the "Lesser Quarte" which has many charms of its own.Sit by the river at Kamp Park. Cross a bridge to the little river islands.

Grandeur with beauty. Without lining up in any queue you can descend from the top of the hill, first through the picturesque old city to Strahov monastery, then through magnificent squares and splendid buildings of the Hradcany Castle, to enjoy the view of Prague along the Danube to walk back up again through magnificently laid out gardens. On a fine day no better experience.
The Castle Did Not Disapoint. We enjoyed our 3hour tour of the castle and felt it was worth every minute. It's history of Prague you don't want to miss.
Interesting views, architecture. beautiful and interesting views from the observation deck. Prague as the palm.many tourists - it's hard to come take a pictureworth taking a walk here

Must see. For starters, great views of the city. The Saint Vitus cathedral and other buildings are worth the better part of a day to explore.The changing of the guard ceremony was very entertaining as well.

CASTLE TOUR ETC. PRAGUE AND GUIDE MICHAELA FROM BEST TOUR. This e-mail was sent to our fantastic guide from Grand City Tour of Prague including an interesting and pleasant Castle-tour.Dear Michaela,I am pleasedto tell you that our tour on 4th November was so fantastic because youwere our guide. You were doing your outmost to make us enjoy the tour and you suceeded. First we were received down town in a very sweet andnice way. I am sure that all five of us felt very welcomed. When you gave us the history of Prague, you really proved to us that your knowledge was very impressing. The information was given in a very fluent English so we all could understand. We also enjoyed our stay atthe Castle-area. First of all it was a great pleasure to listen to your guiding, but I even enjoyed our lunch and chatting more. Luckily you choose goulash from the menu with a wonderful bottle of white wine. The goulash was very delicious and tasted very good. This was myvery first time to have goulash for lunch. I felt that our lunch couldhave lasted longer, but understood that we had to proceed to The Astronomical Clock.To see The Astronomical Clock was also fantastic. This was the last tourist spot on our trip.I want to thank you very much for being so friendly and helpful also when you understood we were looking for a place to buy crystal. Both Jan and I did shopping to our families and they were very happy when they received our gifts.As last, I just want to tell you that we had a fantastic day thanks tothe excellent job you did. Your were very sweet, friendly, professional, helpful, interesting and entertaining. I am sure that I will join you on another tour next time in Prague and will recommend your tours to others. 16th November 2014. Arne Magne Tjåland

Must see. This is a great place to visit. Wear comfortable shoes as the cobblestones can be tiresome. It will take almost half a day to see all so come prepared. Lots of nice bars & cafes to rest between sightseeing. Prague Castle & Cathedral are the highlights,

Beautiful Views and Great People!. The Castle District is worth the trek for the views of the city alone. But, don't miss all the sites there to enjoy! Museums, palaces, the castle, cathedrals and so much more. Take tram 22 two stops past Hrad Prasky stop and enjoy a nice downhill stroll to the district instead of climbing all those steps. Plan a visit after lunch to avoid the worst of the crowds. Get up there!
A must see. Lots to do and see around castle don't miss the changing of the guard at noon. Golden lane is worth seeing. Coffee average price, cheaper than the old town cafes
hansel and gretal. very hilly and tough on th legs but amazing to go to. Reminded me of Hansel and Gretal fairy tale,well worth going to see

Good place to learn some history. This place is taking time, book 2-3 hours take with you some snacks and enjoy castle. Food was very expensive therefore I recommended to take some snacks. My favourite part was golden line and cathedral.

Do a walking Tour. We took a Sandemans tour for this area as there was a large group of us. The Castle and all surrounding buildings were stunning. We covered all the main sights with a guide who was very knowledgeable and thoroughly entertaining.

Its a district not a thing. This is an area of differing buildings and historic sites, some free, some for a fee. Counters for tickets can be busy, have a look about and you will find others that toursits just don't spot. Lots to see and you will need at least half a day to do any kind of justice. Great views of the City, but an alternative view is available from the 'Metronome' statue.

very typical of Prague. it is wothwhile seeing but expect a long queue for tickets if you visit it in August. The cathedral is great, the Golden Street is fascinating and less market-oriented than I expected

The Walk back from the Castle. Walking from the Castle you see the well preserved buildings which feature emblems over the doors showing their original purpose. This is a steep walk on cobblestones so you will need solid sensible shoes (whether you are walking up or down) but there is beauty where ever you look so the effort is very worthwhile.

Amazing view for all city. Hradcany is rilly adorable district. Once again I need to admit thatis super crowded place, but Prauge isa city which never fall asleep and in all season is full of turist. But the view from there is worth to go through this.

Nice area to visit but a bit of a tourist trap.... We walked all the way from the Old Time Square, we did not use the funicular; it was nice walking up and we enjoyed the view of the city. We stayed up there few hours. Beware that this area is a tourist trap, they were selling bottle of water for $6.... The other thing that was a bit disappointing is that we needed to pay to go on the Golden Lane and we could not easily find the place where they sale tickets and to be honest I was not convince that I wanted to pay to walk on a, although unique, commercial street.... It is unfortunate that they make this a bit of a tourist trap....

Well preserved complex. We walked from our hotel, the Salvator, through old town across Charles Bridge and up the hill to the Castle. Despite being November it was a lovely suny day so the view was amazing. If you have been to Prague you will go back if not you have a pleasure in store.

Disappointed. The city, the district, each attraction are all BEAUTIFUL! However, I was totally disappointed by the HORRENDOUS customer service. In most places I visited, which includes Tourist Information offices, shops, restaurants, night clubs, markets, street stalls, MOST people (not all of course) "serving"/"helping" customers/tourists were EXTREMELY rude. I would think it twice before coming back to Prague/Czech Rep.

Had a nice time. The line for the tickets by the entrance was about half hours long. it finally started moving when everyone ran to the changing of the guards (nothing special)Only later did we find another 30 ticket counters all the way in the complex on the right hand side...How hard would it be to put a sign: "more ticket counters up ahead"
perfect setting. a lovely part of Lesser Town. lots of little shops and bars/cafes, beautiful churches and stunning architecture. the hill top walk is worth it for the views of Prague.

GREAT. It is worth visiting it and you will never forget the view from there-almost whole Prague. I will go there again to stay longer and enjoy the athmosphere of ancient Prague:)Awesome:)Maybe one of the best castles in Europe!!!!

Historic. We visited the Castle and the Cathedral,it was free but you can pay to see more. We were at the Castle for the hourly Changing of the Guard. Don't expect the likes of Horse Guards Parade in London. This is very low key, only 2 guards change, but it is a nice little ceremony. The entire area is very large and the gardens must be wonderful in Summer. Unless you are very fit take a taxi or tram up to the Castle area and walk down.

Must Visit. We went with a tour and returned the following day for an in depth visit. Be sure to pick up an audio guide. One will do for two people. Also, if you are over 65, be sure to have ID to secure reduced rates. The buildings and grounds are amazing. Give yourself a half day (at least), and if possible have lunch on the terrace of the Lobkowicz Palace. The view overlooking Prague is lovely
Historical gem. The castle is a must see in Prague but the rest of the area is a very interesting walk as well. Hard to take everything in within a single visit.

Take the whole day. There is just so much to see you might just need the whole day. Take the tram 22 to the stop after everyone else gets off for the castle and walk down from there. It is a better approach to the castle (thanks to a local resident for telling us this).
great tour. I was there with guide Nina and it was very informative and nice tour. There are a lot of historical facts about Castle district. It is home of head of state. I can recommended.

Give it the time it needs. Its really huge and the distances to travel should not be underestimated. Its hard to turn a corner and not see something different and buildings which in their own rite would warrant a visit to many a city.
Amazing views. You have to walk up the hill but it's all worth it. Take your time and enjoy the walk. The castle is beautiful and the view amazing.

Now this is what I call a CASTLE!. Simply breathtaking from any angle. Two trams from Revolution Square will get you there easily. A number 22 and a number 5 or you could opt to walk from the Old Town Square over the Charles Bridge and up the hill (I recommend the trams as they're easy to catch, frequent and cheap. The trip is definitely worth it and also a must see for any visit to Prague.

You must visit. The castle is located on a high can be reached on foot.The view is more than wonderful, where you can see the city of Prague and enjoy one of the cafes to sit. There are a number of shrines which are essential for you to visit and enjoy the performances of some musicians in this area.

Allow at least 4 hours. You don't need to spend any money to enjoy a visit to this area. There is much to see and the views over Prague are breathtaking. If you are not very fit you can take the No22 tram up to the castle. the complex includes a number of palaces, a fantastic cathedral, a monastery, a micro brewery with restaurant and much more. We had lunch in the brewery situated in the monastery and very nice it was too. You can pay to have full access to the cathedral but it is free to enter part of it and you can see most of what is to be seen from there.

Impressive!. We took the tram from the city center (number 5, I think), got off not too far away, and enjoyed a 10-minute stroll through a residential section and then a grand park with gardens and greenhouses and other lovely buildings.The castle grounds themselves are stately but too popular. We enjoyed a band concert, climbed the tower (fee required but worth it) and were lucky to get into St. Vitus late in the afternoon.Makes a great day out.

Very romantic!. I travel a lot, but the sight of the golden city of Prague from Prague Castle always impress me! I like to come back here. I recommend you go through, except sights, the castle in the evening when it gets dark and a wonderful view of the lighted Prague and combine it with dinner in the Lion Court, where is possible sitting in one place where you can see the lighted St. Vitus Cathedral (the glassed place-in terrace). For romantics, it's an unforgettable experience.

Great buildings, extraordinary stained glass windows. Spent an afternoon in the Castle. It's a good walk up hill to the Castle, along interesting streets and at the top we enjoyed a well earned beer on the terrace of an attractive café (not Starbucks - they don't pay tax).There are two main options for your stay in the castle: visit fewer or more of the buildings. We chose the reduced option and visited the Cathedral first. There is virtually no printed material in the building to help you understand what you are seeing. So take a detailed guide book or pay for the audio guide. Alas we had neither. As you would expect it's a fine building, but the stained glass windows are extraordinarily beautiful. There's not much more help in the Old Royal Palace but there's more in the simple and very beautiful Basilica. The main thing is: use a good guide book or the audio guide.
A pleasant walk. The castle grounds are beautiful. Lots of shops and restaurants here, too! Allow at least a half a day to explore.

A great walk. Prague castle district is the immediate area around Prague castle, the famous landmark in the city. It really pays off to wander around in the streets that are outside the castle area because the whole area has such a unity of style and history. There are many buildings and museums to visit, but if you only do the 'outside' tour - just walking the streets - it already takes half a day.

BREATHTAKING. If you go to Prague, this is a must see visitor attraction. The sheer scale of the cathedral is amazing and the interior is out of this world. The Presidential Palace is here too. Take time to go to the observation tower (via the funicular railway) and the Czech Senate gardens too - you won't be disappointed.

No Ticket No Problem. I walked the castle district and did not have enough time to grab a ticket to venture inside. However, my favorite pictures are from the castle grounds, Prague was not destroyed like other great cities as far as youc an see is the most amazing architecture. FANTASTIC.

A must see. Allow 3-4 hours to do this area justice, especially if you buy the entry passes to view the insides of the buildings. I didn't have the time to visit the insides but just walking around on our own was a treat and provided lots to see and enjoy.

Great views a very special place. Fabulous day out, lots to see and enjoy. The buildings are terrific especially the cathedral. You will need at least 4 hours as a minimum but you can buy a ticket which you can use for 2 days.

Great Views of Prague. I stumbled upon the Prague Castle after strolling along Karluv Most (Charles Bridge) from Old Town Square. It was very early on a Sunday morning and I'd avoided the usual crowds that assemble there. The complex is vast and open and has breathtaking views of the city. It was a peaceful place that morning, and I was able to sit, people watch and admire my surroundings as well as reflect on my wonderful time in Prague. One of my favorite experiences in Prague!

Wonderful experience. We visited the Prague Castle area in Sep, 2014. We did have a negative experience when buying our tickets--the lines were long and moved very slowly--and the lady who waited upon us had a bad attitude. However, once we had the tickets, we had a great day. Although you can wander the grounds of the Castle for free, we bought the tickets so we could see all of St Vitus, St George's Basilica and the Golden Lane.I have seen many churches in Europe, but St Vitus must rank in the top 5. Despite being crowded, we were able to enjoy the entire church. St George's Basilica is a small church, well worth seeing.Despite all of my research before our vacation, I was not aware of all the Golden Lane had to offer. It is filled with old weapons, torture equipment and armor and helmets. Not just a few, but hundreds of various shapes and designs. This was a highlight for me.We also saw the changing of the guard---but due to the crowds, it was hard to see everything.Overall, a wonderful experience--do not miss it, it is one of the major highlights in Prague and well worth the price of the tickets

Beautiful buildings. The castle district is fun to walk. There are a myriad of shops and restaurants with plenty of outdoor seating and the whole feel of the place gives an air of romance. Just be aware that it is crowded most of the time and most of the items in the shops are cheaper on the other side of the Charles Bridge!
Dissapointment. I expected a real castle not something quite resembling a town. There are a lot of tourists. It's only worth going here for the views of Prague.

A huge complex of buildings. The Hradcany castle district is made up of a huge complex of buildings. Among these are St Vitus' cathedral, several churches, the Royal Palace, the Belvedere or summer palace and many other places, including the famous narrow street of shops and houses called Golden Lane. It's an area that is not to be missed on a visit to Prague. If you want to get away from crowds of tourists, seek out the gardens around the Belvedere, from which there are some lovely views looking out across the city.
Soak it up. History History History and The Magic of a Castle, just let your imagination run away with itself, but don't watch Dracula before your visit. Just soak up the atmosphere

Walk around. Lots of places to see and to just seat and relax!
Just lose yourself and enjoy the views.
It is worth it

Beautiful sight. Amazing buildings with so much decorations. Well maintained. A wonderful view of the city. A great city with numerous attractions. Everyone must visit Prague. It is as wonderful as Rome.

If you're a tourist, you should come visit.. I myself took a ticket which covered all available areas (I think there are up to 10-11 locations covered by the ticket) and was good for 2 days. There is plenty to see and do here so it's nice to spread it out over 2 days (and with small children it almost becomes needed). If you take the time to look thorugh it properly yo^'ll learn quite a bit about Prague's history. You need to buy a photo permit if you want to take pictures in most of the buildings. I didn't realize this until after we had already bought tickets and had visited a few of the buildings. Pity it wasn't offered by the cashier. Tip... The toy museum isn't included in the main ticket but well worth the visit (especially with children). The lobkowicz palace isn't included either but not really worth the time (unless you're big into someone else's family history).

Visit and stroll around in the first instance.. Well worth the visit but having paid top price for our ticket we found that we did not get into everywhere and would probably have rather just selected a couple of those not included on the main ticket rather than just being able to walk around those that were.

Beautiful Architecture at Castle & Cathedral.. We went up to the castle using the Hop on Hop Off Bus Tour. This was well worth it as the castle is high above the city. the view of Prague is fantastic from the castle.There are a few small restaurants and bars selling hot mulled wine and to add to the atmosphere there was a band playing traditional music. We'll worth the visit.

Fabulous Views. The whole castle complex is interesting and beautiful. I would recommend tram up and walking down past the vineyard. There is so much history here, fascinating! The views on the way down are also incredible. Try to see the changing of the guard (and the band).

Unique even if you have seen it all. Many people compare it to a doll house, to a jewel box, none does it justice... it is simply beautiful, not more not less. Few places managed to carry their spirit across times - good and bad - as this part of Prague has. Every corner you turn manages to surprise, and every step allows you to say again, and again, how beautiful the place is... and it is.

Good day out. We bought the A circuit ticket for cz700 (family of 3) which included entry to several key attractions including St Vitus Cathedral (awesome and fantastically ornate, probably impossible to finance and build today), the Golden lane, Rosenberg palace, St Jiri Basilica plus the most interesting Prague story (section 2). This is an impressive and substantial development and well popular with tourists so arrive reasonably early - opens at 9am

Excellent architecture. This is where you get the real feel of Bohemia. Fabulous architecture. The cathedral is the central focus, however, I enjoyed the changing of the guards at mid day. The frescos on some of the basilicas were amazing, but the general buzz and atmosphere was fabulous. Good panoramic views.

Another Must See.... I read that the Prague Castle is such a national treasure that every Czech has to visit it at least once in their lives and know some basic information as to its history...I believe that. It's fantastic. I particularly like the fact that there's a post office on the castle grounds so you can buy some postcards and mail them out right at the site! Normally any postcards I mail are seldom sent from the city they depict. This was an added bonus!

Worth a day. Most people stay in the Old Town, but you have to go to the Castle District and spend some time. It's worth half a day, or a whole day if you have it to spare. Beautiful buildings. We walked the whole way from the Charles Bridge and it was a nice walk and got a little exercise after eating all the wonderful food in Prague!

Visit the castle, but also the neighborhood around it. The castle is a must-see. There are many different types of tickets you can buy, and the ticket is good for two days so you don't have to try to take it all in at once. I appreciated that, for sure. Having said that, I have no idea why they charge to visit the Golden Lane, since it's filled with touristy shops. It's cute, yes, but I was turned off by the fact that you had to purchase entry (part of a cumulative ticket). We paid extra for the gardens, which was worth it as they were beautiful. However, I don't think I would do that in the winter. A place that not very many people seem to have seen are the Royal Gardens outside of the castle, in the Hradcany neighborhood. Very peaceful and not crowded at all. The Hradcany neighborhood itself is worth a wander around as well. Interesting homes abound, and it allows you to see what a real neighborhood is like, away from the touristy areas.

Varied, fascinating - and with wonderful gardens. A must-see. Don't miss the wonderful gardens - Chotkova to the east, then the Palace Gardens, the small Bastion gardens near the west entrance, and the glorious gardens below the castle (best entrance seems very unlikely: from near the Cathedral, take the stairs under a canopy mounted on small metak bulls). Well worth paying the extra amount to go down through the terraced gardens to the bottom of the hill.

Interesting area. The walk up the hill is well worth the effort. Great little bars and restaurants and a nice view of Prague from the top. Did not see all the interiors but the surrounds were full of history.
Super. Great place to discover the history of Prague. Take tram 12 to Funicular get on top of Petrin Tower and get a birds eye view of castle district. Also great view from atop the clock tower.
History. go earlier (opens at 9 AM) to avoid the tour groups and guides. The cathedral is very beautiful and the audio guides were very helpful.

So much to do. Fantastic views over the city from the walls. Exploring fully took days. The ticketing is slightly confusing. You can book combined tickets for an inclusive price but some museums have to be booked separately. The staff are friendly and will help when asked nicely, but you sense that they get fed up of having to explain it over and over again. The changing of the guard is fun - the brass group playing from the windows are worth looking out for.
Fun to explore. We opted to just explore the area without buying a ticket. You can see a lot of the grounds just from walking around and it's a very scenic area with a nice overlook of Prague.

Not much of a castle. Perhaps our tour guide chose the wrong things to show us but this building was certainly not a castle. It actually didn't look like any palace that I had previously seen. I felt that the rulers of Prague must have been the poor relations if this was the best they could afford. I was disappointed.

The largest castle complex in Europe. We went on a guided walking tour of this complex and it was very interesting. the complex consists of several palaces and churches and is said to be the largest castle complex in Europe. Well worth seeing.
Amazing. A must see, cathedral, palaces grounds. Very busy with tourist as is most of the old city but you just need to look up or past them to see all the wonderful buildings and sights.
Concert in the castle. I think they have them every day, mid day classical concerts in Prague Castle. Oh boy, it was wonderful, a viola and a piano playing, Beethoven and Mozart
nice view. i have visited Castle district in June 2014, i liked the ambiance of the castle. i liekd old building and history

Take time to see this. We took a tram up but it was still a lot of walking uphill. Bring comfortable shoes. To properly see the Castle quarter, I would recommend spending an entire day here or at least half a day. There is a lot to see. We took a walking tour to the Castle quarter which was good but after reading the reviews on TripAdvisor, I feel we missed out on a few things, which is disappointing. Views are breathtaking.

Historical Prague. Fantastic historical buildings with something for everyone. The changing of the guards is well worth seeing at 12.00 noon. Visit the Castle gardens to get away from the crowds. Views over the city are fantastic. Comfortable shoes very important.
Must be seen. The whole of the castle area is stunning, Must visits include St Vitus Cathedral, St Georges Basilica and Golden Lane with its quaint. The surrounding gardens are beautiful.

Great way to spend a day. The Castle is a great way to spend half or even a full day the purchase of a ticket will give you access to the St. Vitus Cathedral, two Palaces and my favorite Golden Lane, where you can peak into the small dwellings that the staff used to inhabit.

Fascinating. Well named as castle district, as this is far from the stereotype castle. It is a huge collection of palaces and associated buildings, St Vitus cathedral, all within fortifications. Try to see the changing of the palace guard.

Wonderful architecture and view of the city below. We did a walk , boat and tram tour ending at the castle . It was fabulous and anyone visiting prague should do this guided trip .The castle is indescribable , it has to be seen to believe on hiw beautiful it is .We strolled back down the hill to Charles bridge taking in the wonderful views and atmosphere of prague , otherwise a 22 tram takes you back .

So much history. Never thought the 1800's would sound soooo new but after visiting places dating back so far in time, it sounds like yesterday. The Castle was interesting and certainly a nice place to visit along with Strahov Monastery and St. Vitus.
wow. spent the day exploring the tiny streets and ancient buildings. Loved it. Plenty to see and do as well as ample places to stop and eat

Castle. The Prague Castle is a mixture of styles form different canturies, The castle is dominated by St Vitus cathedral but also visit the palaces form 17th-18th-19th centuries in the district. It is disappointing that you have to pay entrance fee to Zlata ulica.

Spectacular Views. The view from the castle is amazing over the river and the city. Well worth the effort to walk up the long steps to the castle entrance.
It's very busy but worth the effort.

Prague is perfectly wonderful. visiting this section of town was incredible. The monastery and the streets filled with lovely sites and sounds made out visit here perfect. I highly recommend a visit to this area, and if you want serious peace and quite, then you should stay in this section of town.

Lobcowicz Castle in Prague Castle District a MUST. In the midst of Castle area, Lobcowicz is a small "castle" tucked on a side street -- go in, pay your admission and pick up the included audio guide. This was the most interesting sight seeing we did in two week vacation. The audio guide was riveting. It was rich from a historical and art perspective. In addition, the cafe served great food, including a perfect hamburger.

Beautiful castle area. A beautiful castle area must to visit in Prague. When you go to the top of the castle area, you can see the whole view of the beautiful Prague. You can also enjoy a cup of coffee at Starbucks in the castile area.

Gorgeous and breathtaking. Amazing spot, you can't miss it if you are in prague. I walked it up there from the old town square across Charles bridge. Everything in the castle and all the cathedrals are definitely worth the visit. Go early since there are guided tours you can be part of it and doesn't cost much .

Unbelievably Busy. Fabulous views of the city from up there, but unless you go at dawn you will be sharing the complex with literally thousands of other people. Far too congested up there and very poor signage!Admire the castle from afar....
A must for any visit to Prague. Loads to see here - with the castle and cathedral - and the quaint streets round about - well worth crossing the river for

Don't miss the changing of the guards. The whole castle area is very interest but don't miss the changing of the guards. I've seen this ceremony in several countries and this has the most pomp of any I've seen. The gardens and grounds are beautiful and there are lots of street musicians and entertainers around. It's a must see when you visit Prague.

Seen Better. After the walk up the hill the castle district could be better. It is definitely worth a visit to see the guards change on the hour, and the cathedral. However, this isn't the best in Europe.

A"must See" in Prague. You can't visit Prague without spending time in the Castle District, home to the Czech White House, St. Vitus Cathedral, numerous castles & museums, and an epic panoramic view of the rest of Prague from the castle heights. There are a number of ways to access the area, including walking, but be aware that it is a daunting hike up the hill from the Charles Bridge to the top. Plan on spending several hours here, and time your visit to see the changing of the guard. It happens hourly, with a special ceremony at 12 noon. It's popular, so get there early to stake out a good spot. Warning: individual tickets aren't sold to a number of attractions, such as Golden Lane, and must be purchased as a package.

Enjoyed it. Enjoyed the changing of the Guards and seeing the Brides waiting to get married there. I noticed how patient the Security Guards moved the people to make way for the Guards to pass through.

Beautiful area. There are a lot of thing to see like the old historic beautiful building, like Church and Palace. when you slowly walk up or down the hill you will see the beautiful view of the city for free. Many people visit the castle but the area is very big so not very crowded
Amazing after dark.. Wonderfully romantic place to stroll around, especially at night when the hordes of tourists are away.

Very nice castle. Lots to see, many various ticket types you can purchase to see different parts. Changing of guards worth seeing.Views are amazing from the castle.Recommend this - well worth a visit! Best to get tram up there though and walk down, as lot of steps!
A must see!. Seeing all the castles and learning more of the history was fascinating! The views were priceless! There is a lot of walking and all well worth it!

Open Air Museum. The area on the hill around the castle is unbelievably full of history and things to see and do.Palace, museums, gardens, restaurants, shops people to watch, breweries, just the lot.Make sure you do all the gardens and walks around and under the place, including some terraced gardens that wind up the hill to the palace.Prague is spectacular
Fantastic. Too much to tell. Beautiful courtyards and vistas of the city. Watch for the Changing of the Guard hourly. See the church with flying buttresses.

Astounding Views and Amazing History. High above Prague you look down on the lovely red roofs of the city and the Charles Bridge - take a taxi up there and walk down enjoying the sights of the historic town.
Wonderful but overcrowded. Must see, though during daytime it's just too crowded. If you want to enjoy it you better go in the night.

Storybook Perfect. Hradcany is how I imagined Prague would be. It sits on a huge mass of land (70k sq.m.?) and houses several structures including the impressive St. Vitus Cathedral. We went at around 9 am and there were already a lot of tour groups within the castle grounds. However, given the vast area, it's still possible to find pockets of peace and quiet I chanced upon a garden off the entrance near the guard house, which had flowers in full bloom and a space where several falcons were being tended. Opposite the said garden was a small cafe below a souvenir shop which carried high end Czech art pieces.I suggest walking around the area to bask in the signifcance of the castle and its surroundings.
High point. Don't miss this good viewing point even if the weather is a bit dismal. A Starbucks was noted there but was closed!

Skip Old Town, visit the Castle District. With fewer crowds and hawkers you can walk thru this area and get a real feel for Prague and it's history. Enjoy the Palace and the square. Take a walk around the perimeter looking out at the Bridges below as well as the "old town". The museums, gardens and views make this a special place
A Nice Visit. We had a tour guide take us on a tour of the Palace grounds. I liked it and really liked seeing the Golden Lane which is where business men sold their wares.

A day is not enough. If you think that you can go by with an afternoon of sightseeing, you are quite wrong. A day is not enough to see all the magical and unbelievably beautiful things that the Hill can offer. Enjoy the views and buildings, and take a stroll back in time.

Great place to tour. We booked a tour through Sandemann's Tours. Unlike the typical Sandemann tour - this one is not free, although I think you're basically just paying more or less for entrance to the castle. Guide was excellent.

a must in Czechia. even if this place is so crowded by tourists, it is just amazing. I suggesting an alternative route, take the tram 22 and get out at Pohorelec station, walk down towards the castle and turn left around the Czernin Palais. Explore the Lorata chruch and the pitoresque quarter new World (Novy Svet), which is lke a tiny village in Prague. Than go to the Hradcanke namesti, on the corner to the Jan nepomucky church there is a house, where in te Amadeus movie Mozart was living.Than go to the ramparts and enjoy the breattaking view of Prague, capital of Czechia

Worth a visit (individual or with a guide). We went as part of our organised tour (Collette Worldwide) and had an excellent local guide.This made it a very informative experience. The arrival and issue of tickets was efficient. The views over Prague are worth seeing from this old part of the city. The main ticketed attractions were very busy, but it was certainly worth seeing them, especially the Cathedral (separate review). Having spent time here I would then recommend walking back down to the Old town area over the Charles Bridge.

One of the must-see places in Prague. You kind of have to go there. And yes it's crowded. You can get tickets to visit some of the places (the most interesting one is the cathedral). As you'll be on a hill you have a beautiful panorama on the city. If you don't want to do the visits, the buildings are still nice from the outside.

Great views of historic Prague. Visited this spot twice during our three days - the first time was in the morning and very cloudy so we returned a second time when the sun returned. The buildings are worth the walk up from the Charles Bridge although it was also fun taking the 22 Tram.

Impressive architecture. If you've never been to Prague before the scale and opulence of the architecture is something of a surprise. It's also quite a climb if you are walking up from Charles Bridge. Anyone with a disability will definitely need a taxi. There is a small café in the castle gardens where you can put back on the weight you have just lost.
Amazing. Plan on spending a good amount of time touring the castle and grounds. There is so much to see. Don't miss it!

Dont do it as a tour - go solo. The guided tours and the overpriced entrance fees for the castle are not worth the money (average £12.0) .So much better off getting a local tram up the hill and explore the castle grounds and gardens yourself. Spectacular views over the often ignored Lower Ton and across the River Vltava into the Old and New Town, it is a must to walk the old castle staircase back down from your visit.

Lovely area, intriguing history but hardly a 'castle'. We went first with Tomas from city sightseeing tours bus. He was great with the history. The castle is mostly palace and very little is left from the 'castle-building' age- so don't expect massive walls, turrets, ramparts and such. We were also lucky enough to come across a food and wine show the following day in the palace grounds. The cathedral is a fascinating story, Wenceslas sainthood etc. Mucha contributing a stained glass window, and a neo-gothic rose window, just above a frieze containing a few guys in suit and tie.
Pleasent place. Very nice vew from the Castle. Try to get there early, before thousends of local school boys and girles as well as tourists will come.
Must see. there is a lot to see but a worthwhile visit. Take the walk up the hill,to get there it's good for you and you'll need it after all that Czech food.m

Lots to see and do, especially on a rainy day. Had one really rainy, miserable day in Prague. What to do? Buy the 350CZK general admission ticket for the Castle District. You get to see all of St. Vitus, Golden Lane, St. George's Basilica, Black and Powder Towers, Rosenberg Palace, etc. Great way to dodge the drops and see history. Stop for a warmed wine or a cappuccino. Not so busy either. Spring for a 50CZK photo licence. Well worth it. Spent 5 hours taking my time and enjoying every minute of it.
Beautiful Area Steeped in History. We really enjoyed our tour of the castle. Amazing sites and stories. There were two tour packages, we took the cheaper of the two and felt we saw plenty.
A definite must. Take a guided tour to truly understand the history of this beautiful and fascinating castle area. Buildings, gardens, moats and a lot more.

An area to visit. When visiting Prague you must spend a few hours walking around in the Castle area. We had a local, english speaking guide, and that gave us a very good picture of Prague, the Caslte area, history and the culture.
Get a tram. This is reputedly the largest castle in Europe . Has a lot of interesting sites and a great view of Prague .
So much history !!. The whole area is fascinating and well worth visiting. So many ornate buildings and the views are wonderful.
A must see. There are few cities in the world with the age old charm of Prague, and you can't come to Prague without visiting the Prague Castle and St. Vitus Cathedral.
A must. This is a must when visiting Prague and the beauty of it is something to experience. I started my walk around by starting at this point and just taking in all the sites around me.

beautiful. very beautiful, we were spend around 6 hours there, worth to go! and you can see the whole city up there.
just too many tourist group....

World Heritage. Largest castle complex in Europe, probably the world, with museums, churches, restaurants, and spectacular views over the city. We particularly liked the Golden Lane, with tiny artisan terraced houses.
Get your own tour guide. Used tours by locals . com and this is the way to go rather than wonder around alone or in groups of .

A tip for you.... Take the 22 tram to pohorelec stop...do not get off before this stop...this way you will be walking downhill rather than vice versa. Also, the gardens are spectacular...most of them are free but the"Lower gardens" cost us 50 K each ($2.50 for seniors). There were quite a few stairs going down and it took about 30-45 mins but we ran into only 4 other people. My only thought was tour groups do not have the time nor ability and most people do not "stumble" upon the gardens. They were large, beautifully manicured and on 5 levels...the highlight of our trip to the castle. I am not a garden lover, but did find these to be more impressive than the changing of the guard ceremony.

Prague Castle: Views, Culture, History, and Hiking. Prague Castle (and specifically the district around it) provides travelers with a fantastic hiking experience on cobblestone, dirt, and trails. We also visited the gardens for 80 Koruna (maybe 4 USD, 3 Euros) and thought the views were fantastic. Although we did not make it inside the castle (it closes early around 5:30 PM) it did not matter. The walk was around 1-2 kilometers round trip, but is well worth the time. There are also some fun cafes within the castle walls to enjoy and break up the trip...however, make sure you take tons of pictures of the castle first!

Wear your walking shoes. This was a stone's throw from our hotel, although up a lot of gradual, broad stairs. We were there not during a peak time, but the crowds built over the day. You have the option to pay for shorter or longer tours of the buildings, take the longer as you will want to see everything. We really recommend beginning with the Castle Story tour as you will go down to the original foundations of the castle and see the complete history of its life and people who inhabited it. The St Vitus Cathedral and Vitus Treasury are other attractions that we enjoyed. The treasures are quite astounding as to workmanship and priceless values of the artifacts. The Golden Lane was not so interesting and was just a vendor's opportunity to get you to buy souvenirs. There are a few places in to buy ice cream, drinks and food in the courtyards. Lots of cobblestones so need to wear your good walking shoes. We didn't get to explore the castle gardens but they are supposed to be very beautiful.

An amazing place to walk about. It's an amazing place to walk about ,people watch, browse the souvenir shops or simply sit at a cafe' and enjoy doing nothing just experiencing the fairy tale land of Praha.
amazing castle. Castle, residence of president and catherdal gives you a great impression, well maintained and magnificent buildings.Golden street is overated.Worth climbing to get there

Interesting old and new. "Castle" doesn't mean the same thing in Prague as we imagine. It is not a single building, although the main building is spectacular. It is a series of many fascinating buildings. It was interesting to watch the changing of the guard at the front of the castle. It is a must for anyone visiting Prague.
A Must Visit. It gets really busy so the earlier you start your visit the better. Pay the extra for one of the castle guides and get a real idea of the history, it's well worth it!
So much history. Traveled back in time as we toured the castle...the buildings are amazing and in such good shape and we could imagine what it was like so many centuries ago.
Not to be missed. The castle district of Prague is jammed with cultural attractions, art and other tourists. The city's major museums are nearby as well as convenient cafes for coffee and cake.

Run through it if you can! unforgetable. I hired a local company to run while I was on vacation: Biko Adventures and we ran through this area. It was the best idea ever! Lovely coffee places, great photo-shooting and as you go up toward the castle, you will find even a vegan restaurant! Walk safe in the morning and even at night!

Grab your walking shoes. You should definitely be prepared for a day of walking up and down hills and stairs in this part of Prague but it is beautiful. You can take a taxi or a bus to this area but you do not feel the full effect of the district without walking the small side roads leading to the castle.

Seems more like a village than a castle!. The castle seems more like a small village than what I usually think of as a castle but it's a great visit with great views of Prague, not to mention some beautiful buildings. The walk up is a little steep but you can take a bus so don't be out off.

Interesting. We enjoyed an early morning tour of Hradcany Castle District. We were afforded the opportunity to get a close up view of the changing of the guard. It was very nice to compare the changing of the guard to the changing of the guard in Arlington Cemetry in Virginia. Even though it was very different, we enjoyed watching the performance. it was also nice to visit the area at night to see how the light shines.

Just amazing!. Beautiful city up in the hill overlooking the city centre of Prague, it is difficult to understand that this is called a Castle because there is much more than a Castle up there. The cathedral is amazing, and all the little streets have such a charm!. Dont forget to buy the ticket as you go in so that you can visit the Gold Alley and the Cathedral!. Not to miss!

Take a guide. First of all, the Castle is not a Castle as you generally imagine from childhood. It's some historical monuments close each other. I liked a lot the two churches and the Old Royal Palace. Very interesting to visit, especially with a guide that explains you the main characteristics. If I hadn't, I wouldn't have appreciated the Castle as I did. Strongly recommended.

VARIED PALACE GROUNDS. Beautiful palace and beautiful view. Very interesting and well done exhibit on the history of the castle itself. Don't try to walk up and when you walk down, keep to the left down the slowly descending ramps.

Begin at the top and walk down. Its important to begin your walk from the right end.Take the tram all the way up and walk down because all the ticket booths are placed their. Its a very impressive place and i'm glad that i'we seen it but that's it.

Its a hike. Being from mountainous regions will serve you in the climb up cobblestone streets past the gaunlet of kitsch shops to reach the castle grounds. But it is all worthwhile as the grounds themselves are a real treat and it is easy to step back in time and get a sense of how royalty lived. There were a couple dead end streets, especially the one with the ancient minature store fronts. There the hordes of pic snappers didn't mind blocking the view and imposing their need for a photo on your need to walk by. You may want to have a map and be clear how you will get out of the grounds as there are indeed only a few ways in and out and many ways you would expect to get out have locked gates. The view the city from the top is marvelous.
Best View of the city. The castle, cathedral and palace are all in the same location with a fantastic view of the city. Easily accessible and places to rest once in the courtyard.

A good morning. This is a truly beautiful way to spend a morning. My partner and I walked around the free areas of the castle in bright sunshine taking in some fantastic views. The climb was steep up the hill but being young folks it wasn't too tiring. It was extremely busy but that doesn't bother us. It had great views over the city and there are plenty of places to eat and drink.You can't visit Prague and not come here.

Audioguide was great.. We got the A ticket, though the B ticket would be enough. We walked around yesterday without the audioguide or ticket access. It's worth the ticket and the audioguide. You get a great deal more from the experience. The Cathedral is brilliant. While you can see a gear deal of it without the ticketed access, the extra things you see and the information you get with the audioguide throughout is brilliant and well worth it.The old Church is a highlight, in it's unpolished and ancient condition. The grounds are impressive. Main improvements would be better signposting for the audioguide (you need to be paying attention to make sure you don't miss things and to find things), more small cafes (for drinks) and toilets better signposted. A great deal of walking if you are not an active person, but if you are even reasonably fit you will be more than fine.We went early and still had large crowds. The bus loads of asian and german tourists are extremely inconsiderate, but if you stand aside for a couple of minutes they tend to move on quite quickly.

Beautiful. Loved the castle complex, which included St Vitus cathedral, the caslte, Silver lane and many more buildings. If you have walking difficulties there were not many places to sit on way round.

Walk in the sunshine.. Got a good day to walk around the Castle and it's grounds which are beautifully kept.
Lots of history here.

Without a guide we found it to be a letdown. If there is a tour with a good review, I would recommend taking it. Without a guide, there is very little information posted so not very much to be gained for someone who is unaware of a lot of the history. The cathedral was beautiful but you could see the majority of it without paying for entrance. The Royal Palace was largely unfurnished so there was little to do in there without a guide. I thought Golden Lane was quite a ripoff - it's interesting to look at I guess, but I resent paying to enter a street that is just full of shops. All in all, I would recommend just walking around outside or paying for a guide. We only spent about 25 minutes walking through everything. The views are beautiful though - and free!

Beautiful!. The Castle District is so very clean, green, and peaceful. It is easily accessible, with trams regularly plying to and fro. Walking in the area is a delight and the weather during our visit was quite pleasant too. An experience, no one must ever miss...

Take the tour!. You don't need to pay for the more expensive A ticket. Just take the B ticket for the highlights - the cathedral, the old church, golden road, etc. The cathedral is amazing. Gothic. Reminiscent window of Notre Dame in Paris. The old church is really lovely, non-renovated. The Golden road with all the tiny old houses is really unusual. Very crowded so go first thing and do your best to avoid all the tours!

Over-rated!!. Too many people, toilets difficult to find and a long tram ride! I know that Hradcany holds significant historical and cultural value for, not just Prague, but for the entire Czech nation but it wasn't the highlight of our Prague visit.Pros: Birthplace of a nation, great views, elaborate architecture. Cons: Too many people, not enough toilets (that are well signposted) and a long, hot tram ride!!I'd much rather spend my time wandering the back streets of Mala Strana or Stare Mesto or taking in another string quartet. Perhaps for us a little over-rated!!

Castle District. An area of beauty. We were in a group and used a guide who used 'whispers' i.e. earphones programmed into the guide's microphone. A lot of information to take in but better to go around on your own and discover for yourself. Its the biggest Gothic complex and worth seeing in full. The cathedral is amazing and the Golden Lane is worth a visit though you have to pay in. The views of the town from the top are a photographers dream and looking down towards Charles Bridge is beautiful. (But as in most large cities and crowded areas, beware of pickpockets and safeguard your belongings.)
Wow-stunning. Get a guide to show you round in what is an amazing trip.Cant describe how beautiful it was.See the Guard changing which can become very crowded.
Must Visit. Peacefull place. Lots of history. Terrific views to all city. The castle is located on the Hill.So view is WAW !!!Must see
Pleasent walk. Walking down from the castle there are 2ways to walk down. One to charles bridge and the other to tube station. Whichever you take you can enjoy the view.
Amazing. Lovely grounds beautiful views and wonderful art. The private Lichtenstein residence has a private collection that includes original written copies of Beethoven work

Beautiful Area. This is a nice area. We did the "B" ticket which allowed us to go into the Cathedral, Palace and the Golden Lane. It took us about 3 hours to get through everything. This is the largest gothic complex in the world and its well worth the visit. The Cathedral wasn't completed until the 1900s and that is why its not a 5 start review.

wonder away the beaten track. was given a tour by a friendly local into what's called THE NEW WORLD....lots of narow streets near the wooded area full of quaint little houses and restaurants frequented by the locals rather then tourist

Castle district is worth going to. If you are not afraid of walking, this is the place to walk around and enjoy some local food, The only thing in Prague, to us, was the walk around in the Castle District. We took a train up but walked all the way back to the old town square. The cobblestone streets are fun and if you have small kids, you can also stop by in local parks for play time.

Nice to see it. All district is very beautiful, mainly the buildings. There is also a lot of pubs, bars and restaurants all around. Near the castle you may visit for a fee the golden street which is traditional tight street with several touristic shops. Not far away from the castle you may visit also a park with a view tower.
Lots to see and do. You can spend a long time here visiting the cathedral and museums and parliament buildings. Plenty of places to eat and drink or relax.

Imposing historic place. No wonder Unesco included it in its patrimony, the Castle District is full of towers, buildings, gardens, statues and above all, the St Vitus Cathedral. What I don't like about it is the ticketing they are having for it. They ask for a separate ticket for about any building in there. You even need a ticket in order to walk on the Golden Lane. You can buy a combination ticket, but I didn't find one that covers everything, so most likely you will need to buy more than one combination ticket in order to get everything. Each building has a number written at the entry that you can also find on the map behind the ticket, but there aren't directions to guide you to that. You can walk a little in St Vitus for free, but the complete tour requires a ticket. There is a free garden at the entry of the Castle District, but there are others that require a ticket.There is a changing guards parade that you can watch if you want. The combination ticket is available for two days, but the place is big and can get awfully crowded so expect to use those two days if you want to thoroughly visit the buildings. Otherwise, it is better to choose just a couple of buildings and then have a short walk on the free garden before leaving if you don't want to spend too much time in there (or you are not willing to come back the following day). The Castle District is located somewhere up the hill so, if you want to walk there (as I did), there are a lot of stairs. You may want to consider that before thinking about going up and down more than one time (I did that for three times or so and it is tiring).

Fantastic Castle with great views. This area is well worth a visit with great views over the city of Prague. The size of the complex was breathtaking and the buildings were beautiful. The changing of the guards on the hour was a bonus to watch. We walked back down through the area to the Town Square. It was a pleasant walk through cobble stone streets and over Charles Bridge. A great morning's site's seeing- well worth it, but try to do it with a guide who can give you all the history etc. on your own I would imagine you could be overwhelmed by it all.
A lot of historic sites.. A lot of history, an you can easily spend parts of a day here. Also Nice if you want to have a long walk.

Wonderful place to spend whole day. Nice place, but quite epensive. Unless you decide to pay extra money for audioquide, you should make sure that you took your giudebook or antyhing else, tkat will make you albe to read anything about places you paid to visit...

Must Visit. Its doesn't have a castle per se, instead the area is considered a castle district and it is the biggest in the world. It has many areas in it for you to explore, including the Vitus cathedral. Take the tram 22 (stop called Pražský hrad) - variant 1. Then leave the Castle through the Old Castle Stairs to metro station Malostranská.
Castle Visit. Good visit, a chance to look at various buildings and visit the "golden lane" where you can see the smallest house and smallest rooms!

Half a day trip. A place not to miss. We went to this area twice on our visit to Prague. The castle area is a lovely area, that you must see. The area consists of the castle/ cathedral/ towers and lovely gardens. Along with narrow streets/square, shops, restaurants etc. The view from castle hill is lovely day or night. You can exit the castle area by the 100 steps or a slope behind the gardens. If you use all your energy up there are plenty of take away food stalls to store your energy up again.

Unforgettable. Definitely one of the must-see parts of the city. On the top of the Small Town (mala strana) the Castle offers tons of history and you can enjoy it with an organized tour or on your own with an audioguide that will explain you any details of the place. Since the castle is still used, if some institutional events are ongoing, you might be not able to visit some of its parts.
That's why people go to Prague.. There is nothing you can see more. Hradcany, all Mala Strana and of course Karol's bridge. Any season, any time of the day - it is always worth to visit.

Amazing castle and park. The castle complex is amazing! It's very big and if you want to learn something about it, visit the museums, galleries and churches inside the complex. The park is also very nice from where you have a great view on the whole city.

Loved it all !. Loved it all ! WATCH THE CHANGING OF THE GUARD FROM BEHIND THE ROPE ! Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !Loved it all !
beautiful view of the medieval buildings. be sure to see, great buildings.Just look at the building awakens in you a sense of power.old time have a strange power

Excellent. Well I'm sure no one is going to go to Prague and miss out this area. Get your ticket and take in everything you can. Get up there early before the crowds and I mean early and I do mean crowds. Some nice views across the city. The atmosphere was wonderful early morning. St Vitus Cathedral is a beauty with wonderful stained glass. History everywhere and wonderful photographic opportunities. The ticket is well worth the price. Only negative I found was being asked to pay extra to photograph an imitation crown. I refused to pay.
Wow!. A beautiful castle that takes your breath away when you first set eyes upon it. The church of St Vitrius (think i’ve spelled that correctly) is mind blowing
A great day out.. Lots to see here. The castle district is free but then the individual sites have charges for which you buy a group ticket. One of the 3 must-do/see places in Prague.

Very pretty. Wear walking shoes is my biggest tip! When walking round the castle DONT buy a ticket to walk inside the church - you can go inside without a ticket, you can take pictures and enjoy the place but you can't walk down the nave end - big deal - save yourself a few bob!It's very hilly but this will give you fantastic views across Prague.I suggest you get a tram to the castle and walk round and down rather than start at the bottom and walk up, much easier on the feet!Very pretty area and worth a visit but not on top of my list to go back to.

Spectacular Historic Castle and Church. This venue is a must for any visitor to Prague. Best and cheapest way to visit is to take the Metro to HRADCANSKY STATION. Follow the signs on a short walk to the beautiful castle gardens. Stroll through these spectacular gardens to the back entrance to the castle. Once inside, if you see a flag atop the building, it means the President is in his offices. The castle grounds are huge, with many buildings dating back to the 15th century and some much further back in history, entry to St. Vitus cathedral is free, and it is often jammed with tourists. Quite fabulous, inside and out. Don't miss golden street on the Castle's outer wall, to see the tiny homes occupied by the poorer residents. Allow several hours to visit inside the castle walls, and more in the historic squares and lookouts over Prague outside its walls. Take a grand downhill stroll from the Castle to Mala Strana, with it's many embassies, the Lenon Memorial Wall, and end up at Charles Bridge. A great way to spend a day in Prague.Peter and GayeVictoria, B.C., Canada

An important day's Visit. We bought a ticket covering the 8 main "attractions" within the Castle District. Each building or set of buildings has amazing history. There are jewels, and wonderful medieval rooms. The art gallery had a very interesting collection of paintings. While a pain to go in and out of (crowded and tiny), the Golden Lane offers a glimpse into the workers lives. The multiple palaces are neat (especially to Americans like us, who don't have castles back home).Older visitors, or individuals with physical challenges may struggle getting up to the complex, and around and in and out of the buildings. We took the tram up, then walked. We found a wonderful cafe that overlooked Prague (up in one of the buildings), so there are alternatives to the mediocre snack/sandwiches at the stands (just take time to look and find them).Give yourself most of a day - it's worth it.
Shopping. Lots of shops and restaurants in the area. St Nichols church is worth visiting. Be careful when crossing the roads, the trams are very fast and the roads are very busy.

Hilly!. Be prepared to walk upwards for a long time to get to the castle. Otherwise, lots of souvenir shops and different palaces near the Prague castle area.Of course, you should visit the castle if you are here.I liked the cathedral the most.

It Is Well-Worth A Visit When You Are In Prague!. Ranking 3rd or 4th on my personal Prague's Sightseeing List, the Castle is a nice place for inhaling better quality air, taking pictures and resting/calming yourself. It offers nice views, 1 naked statue, where many girls will take a picture of themselves (hehehe) with a big smile, a museum and a nice cafeteria that can provide you with some nice coffee and memorable views.
Wonderful Views. Panoramic views of the city can be seem from the castle area. You can spend a whole day going through all of the different buildings of the complex. Very interesting.
Good views. Climbing the stairs to the castle is tiring but it has a reward: you will have some beautiful views to the old town. Again, you will have to put up with thousands of tourists.

Beautiful, Two-Day Minimum. Buy tickets for the whole palace, they are good for 2 consecutive days and you will need 2 days to see everything. Don't waste time on changing of the guard, get into outside areas early in the day to beat the crowds, then head into one of the galleries.

Free to enter and great in the evenings. I love walking around old towns and old castles - the Hradcany is no exception and it's free but if you want to avoid the crowds go before or after opening hours - much less people and great light for photography
don't miss. The whole castle area is one of the best places to visit in Prague. It is quite beautiful and interesting. We took the one hour tour aand it was well worth it. Don't miss.

you haven't been to prague if you haven't seen the castle district. Best picture spot! Gives great views of the city as well. Historic buildings, cathedrals and galleries give it a nice touch. Best for budget travellers, like it is said, the best things In life come for free! Oh and people with strollers and pushchairs might have a problem carrying them up this steep hill, so be prepared!
A challenge. Of course another must see - cathedral, palace, garden etc. However, very crowded even in the afternoon. Coffee shops are overpriced and of inferior quality. Too many gift shops.

Essential visit. The climb to the main gates is manageable but for the old, young or infirm, the tram trip up is probably wise. Nonetheless whatever way of getting up to them, the Castle grounds are an essential visit for visitors to Prague. We explored the intriguing Golden Lane, impressive but crowded St Vitus, calming St George's Basilica and the Old Royal Palace (i.e. the reduced circuit which provided ample access for a half-day visit). The beautiful gardens and views provided an opportunity to recover. Although some parts of the district are crowded, most of the spaces accommodate the crowds. Wear good shoes and be careful not to slip on the stairs going back down into town. Changing of the guards a little underwhelming.
BEAUTIFUL. Simple beautiful to see and explore! We watched the changing of the guard and walked around the Palace gardens!

Energising walk up to the castle. This is not how you would expect a castle to look. There are no turrets etc, and it is more like a government block of buildings. It is however adjacent to the beautiful cathedral and you have great panoramic views of the city.
Wonderful architecture. Nice, loved every single details. Few coffee houses in the area, ther could more. Very croudy, but still beautiful and loved it.
Take in a Concert. We had dinner and took in a concert that evening at the Castle. IT is GOREGOUS! a must see. They have vineyards and beautiful views. YOU will love it.

Half a day needed. There is a lot to explore in Prague's castle district and it can easily take the best part of a day. To save on walking get tram 22 to Pražský hrad stop, then after your visit you can walk down the steep castle steps to the metro at Malostranská. There is a lot of walking involved, especially if you climb the 280 steps in St Vitus Cathedral Tower. The castle complex is open 9am-4pm. There are lots of free areas to wander and fabulous views across Prague from the castle's prominent hill top location. To fully explore the area you will need to buy a 5 part ticket which lets you into extra parts of the Cathedral, Royal Palace, Chapel, Powder Tower & Golden Lane. Tickets A.B & C cost either 350Kč or 250Kč, depending on how many parts you want to see.

A bucket-load of charms and secrets in this treasure-troved neighbourhood. To appreciate fully the charms and secrets of this fabulous neighbourhood, take this path. generally, pilgrims to Prague first pay homage to Prague Castle, but those in the know and savvy with the 'local -goodies', recommend the neighbourhood behind the castle, as it is a treasure-trove of monumental palaces and towering churches interspersed with souvenir shops,eateries and excellent cafes. We walked along the main artery of the district finding winding passages, narrow stairways and walled streets veering off to the left and right. The tram stop, (Pohorelec), is an excellent place to start,as we alighted from the tram, watched over by the imposing statues of astronomers.  Up next is Strahov Monastery with amazing murals and friezes. The libraries a treat visually for bibliotechs like my femme, but i rather fancied the gorgeous ceiling frescoes. It was time to feed the ravenous stomachs, so we grazed at Klasterni Pivovar Strahov, where we sampled some lovely grub with a dark, heady brew of ale. Exit, and stage a left fork past the Emperor's ambassador's pile and onto the magnificent Loreto, the most amazing religious building in Prague. Its a baroque fantasy. But then, is there any other? Its has eye-popping treasures and a macabre style. On and on we trooped, dizzy with our finds. "Onto the castle!!", said my passionate femme with resolute imperiousness to her intonation. Palaces by the bucket-load followed.... Sternberg, Tuscan, Martinic, the Archbishops and Swanzenberg with the best Renaissance facade, now a military museum. Now it was my turn to claim visiting imperiousness. We split here. I to the museum, she to the Archbishop'. What a fabulous district.

Breathtaking, Emotional Experience. This was my highlight in Prague. Do what Rick Steves says, and enter the grounds promptly at 9:00am. This is slightly before all the big tour groups come in, so you can have your first taste of a crowdless Prague, and take GREAT pictures. We didn't even buy a ticket for anything because we chose to attend the cathedral's mass (for free)--again, less crowds and great unobstructed pictures afterwards. I felt like I was dancing around in a Disney movie; don't miss the Castle district! We went out the back entrance and down the steps to the tram stop....on our way down was our favorite lookout point over Prague!

Amazing - an absolute must see!!!. It is an amazing place and you should visit, it's pretty hard to miss once you make it in Prague. Look from a distance and then get in up close and walk around and around from very angle, a truly magnificent collection of buildings and palaces.
Sandemans Castle Tour by Hugo Barcia (in Spanish). The most amazing and knowledgeable guide! Hugo has a degree in History and is passionate about it and Prague. Highly recommended.

Certainly Worth the Climb. Start over hill up to the Eiffel Tower miniature, and I recommend the funicular to get there. Then cross over the hill to the backside (top of the hill) to go and see everything that is up there. And at that point you are mainly going back down the hill. Everything is quite interesting, but if you try to see everything it will take all day. If you only have time for one tour, I'd see St Vitus. Or just walk around everything on the outside. Be sure and go to one of the restaurants up on the hill for a drink or lunch, and an enjoyable view of Old Town.

The Two Main Art Museums are Splendid. This whole area is beautiful from the cathedral to the museums. Make sure you visit the picture gallery and the two museums across from the West Gate. Visit the gardens of the museums and grab a coffee for some break time. Wonderful place i will visit again.

nice way up and amazing ending :). Castle district is located on one of hills in Prague. Really beautiful and climatic place. During way up you will find a lot of interesting small shops, restaurants and cafes. And when you reach the final point you will enjoy amazing views cuz you can see whole city from there not mentioned about great castles which leads you there.

Top most attraction in Praha. Take the No 22 tram to the Castle. Do not get off at the stop which says Hradcany but get off at the next stop this is where the entire tram almost emptys out. This is the closest stop to the castle. Keep at least 3 hours for the Castle district. Walk from the front down all the way to the Charles bridge.Do not forget to visit the golden lane it is a really interesting alley with quaint small houses including Kafkas house.
Great views and gardens. Go to the castle and see everything and see the views over Prague. Gardens are really splendid this is a place for any age to enjoy
