Quite a climb up!. So beautiful - spent ages wandering around and so worth the climb up from Charles Bridge. Some good restaurants.

My Favourite Part of Prague. This was our second time here in two years and we have decided that while the old town is wonderful the castle district is divine. This time we stayed 2 nights in the old town and two nights in the castle district. When we return we will stay in the castle district and further explore the lovely gardens, the quaint streets and the fine dining establishments. As the sun goes down the throngs of tourists seem to return to the old town which is part of the castle district magic. Do try rooftop dining in this area to enjoy the lit up buildings close and far.

Old Prague at its best. High on a hill overlooking Prague is the Castle and the nearby St. Vitus Church with its spires and gothic architecture. The view from this hill back toeard the many bridges spanning the river is just amazing.

Magical at night. I know it seems crazy, as you can't go inside at night, but this area is absolutely wonderful, safe, and uncrowded (but not deserted) to wander around at night. The buildings are dramatic (especially lighted St. Vitus) and the area offers great views of the city. Instead of walking up the hill, ride Tram 22 to the top. Arrive at dusk and stay until after dark. Then walk down the hill and stop in whatever cozy little place or cafe you like for a late dinner or drinkies. Pure magic! (We also visited during the day and paid to enter several of the buildings -- totally great -- but my favorite was at night.)

Above and below.. Lots of guidebooks tell you to come in via the main gate and up the steep steps. There is a lovely cafe near the top with grat views over the city. I would also suggest you try coming in via the park district after visiting Petrin Tower. Above the castle grounds are some lovely streets with quirky shops, restaurants and churches to visit.
Castle. A beautiful place to visit and learn of the history. Nice architecture and wonderful scenery. The weather was very nice. Not to hot.

Sunglasses Handover. Really loved the changing of the Guard. On our day they did a ceremonial handover of the sunglasses. Pity the soldiers couldn't have afforded a set each. Check the stained glass windows in St Vitus cathedral. Some are by A Mucha Illustrator of iconic French bar posters.The faces are the giveaway.

Interesting castle area. Beautiful castle with interesting history. Make sure to bring a lot a good tourist guide because otherwise you will miss all the detail.Tip: take the tram to the top and walk down the stairs. No need to get sweaty :)
So much to do around the Castle. St. Vitus Cathedral, Lubkowicz Palace Museum, Strahov Monastery, Loreta, all the little windy streets. Go for the day at least!

Don't Miss the Castle District. We entered the district by crossing a bridge over a moat. Be sure to go all the way to the Giant's Gate Entrance. The changing of the guard occurs here & enthusiastic street musicians were playing across the street. The area is filled with historical buildings so it would be wise to study some information on it before you go otherwise they will just be buildings. There is a large viewing area outside the main entrance that overlooks the hillside of Prague. The American Flag flies over the American consulate, but the view can be foggy. Celebrate if it is a clear day.
magnifique. the houses in this area around the castle is just lovely and very european, most are foreign consulates, the spires are sporadic, very beautiful place

Worth it.. Its a steep climb to the castle district but well worth it. The castle itself is like a small town in its own right with streets and churches and a cathedral which are all beautiful. Some stunning views are a bonus as well and the surrounding area has some lovely restaurants..
Nice area. It´s a very interesting area to walk around, as it´s quite different from the city centre. I liked the architecture and also the views.
Poor Prague. Wonderful buildings, but crowds, crowds, crowds. Walk 2 minutes off the main roads, and you will enjoy the area as much, if not more,

Required. Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful.
Nothing like this in Australia.
The opulence is amazing but not over the top like some places.
by segway and bicycle. spend 2 hours and walk the grounds... great photos of prague, small wine vineyard, changing of the guard (they wear armani)
Great area!. Such a beautiful area. Buy the ticket that includes all the attractions to get the most out of your time in the Castle district.
Huge complex. This castle has beautiful views of the city. It is a huge area with multiple courtyards. Changing of the guard occurs every hour.
Get a guide. So much to see! I recommend getting a guide so you don't miss some of the sights, like the little living quarters and shops that were built up against the inner walls.

Interesting!. I highly recommend going to this side of the river. It was actually the only experience I enjoyed in Prague.This is a great location! Loved the Castle District and is lovely for a stroll to take in some great Prague views. I recommend going up the hill by tram and then walk down through the Palace Gardens which are on the left side of the castle and is worth it. It is beautiful. Don't forget to go to the Golden Lane - it is so interesting! Kafka lived in one of these little houses.This area is a tourist trap, so all the cafe's are expensive but I found it much nicer here than the other side of the river, as it seems less crowded and dirty with groups of drunk people and beggars.
Magnificent. If you are interested in photography, history, art, architecture and all related topics, this is the place to be. If you are not, simply enjoy the view of city from above.

Changing of the Guard at Noon Very good. While it is a hike to get to the castle it is worth the trip. Get there by 11:30n to see the changing of the Guard. The fee for the castle is not bad, and i recommend the audio so that you can follow what you are seeing.

Give yourself enough time to just wander around. Fortunately, we were staying in Lesser town, so we were steps away from the Castle District. Yes there are typical tourist stores along the way, but they are within historic buildings, so they don’t stand out. Avoid the mini marts as they are overpriced. There are a couple ways to get up to the castle, so we walked up the hill, and took the stairs on the other side down (which was nice as we walked past an apartment that Alfons Mucha had stayed at). There is also a way to walk along the old moat (which is now dry). It was interesting as saw the small area where there used to keep bears (which was given as a presidential gift). There are great views from the top, and a lot of quaint little side streets along the way. The castle and the cathedral at the top are beautiful so give yourself plenty of time to see everything and just wander around!

Out of a Boris Karloff Film. Stained from centuries of accumulated dirt, the panorama is unique in its spookiness and history. Food services are limited and a rip-off. Audio guide rental is bureaucratic and content below par. Stick with the great views.
many attractions in one area. You can wander around and see some sites. But it is well worth it to pay for the entrance fee to visit more of it, especially St. Vitus Cathedral and Golden lane.

Lots of walking. This is a must see, but be prepared to walk uphill to get there. Once you are there, plan on spending at least 1/2 day to walk around and admire the grounds. A good view of the city and the river. We went on a walking tour and it was a lot of walking, so wear comfortable shoes.

Fantastic Location!. This is a great location to visit for a stroll and take in some great views. It does get very busy in the daytime but there is plenty of space for everyone. You can get a tram 22 up there to save walking up the hill if you prefer and then walk back down. If you walk up, I would say walk up via the St Nicholas Church way, up the stairs and back down the other side which is a nice walk. Don't forget the Palace Gardens as well which are on the left side of the castle as you walk back down.

Well spent time.... really worthy. When U are in Prague you need to go there, is really amazing. You'll enjoying climbing through the street which leeds you there. And when you will finally reach the point you planned you will admire the beautiful compleks of palaces, and the view for whole city. We spend there almost whole day. And we were totally satisfied. One of the most beautiful city in Europ.

Enjoy an evening stroll here when it's calmer. Most of the tour groups, hawkers and associated tourist industry paraphernalia are all here during the day, but after 18:00 it's all free of charge and large crowds and you can stroll through the far less crowded cobbled streets, alleys and squares of the Castle District and enjoy spectacular views (especially at sunset) over the city below. It's then much calmer than the Charles Bridge and Old Town Square and makes for a really memorable visit. The streets around the castle also have lots of small restaurants and bars which again are much less manic than across the river.
Wonderful. We went on a guided tour, wanted to have more time to explore the interior of the castle and just stroll around. Beautiful.

Very nice but...a bit boring.. It's a castle. Actually it's more of a medieval district. If you travel a lot to Europe you may have seen many places like this (only the Czech one is much larger).If you are in Prague - go visit this place, but don't give it more than a couple of hours. We didn't like the fact that almost every building required a fee for entrance. It gave us a feeling of a tourist's trap.Near the bottom of the slope there's a place selling cold drinks with royal chocolate. We recommend the ice coffee with royal chocolate. Here is a well known tip that we think worth a repost: most people do a big mistake and get off tram no. 22 at Pražský hrad. If you do that, you need to walk up a very steep incline. Don't do that. Keep on with the tram and get off at Pohořelec.

Castle complex is amazing. Pretty large so wear good footwear.
I just love the gardens,the castle area gets really crowded in summer so if you can,go in the morning or off season.

CAN'T MISS THIS. This complex of palace, cathedral, church, shops and even a prison is full of a long and rich history dating back centuries. The views are spectacular, looking down at the river and the old city. What I can't understand is why, with this amazing heritage, they have allowed a Starbucks to be the first thing that greets you as you turn the corner of Nerudova St and go up the hill to the castle. This needs to go!! as it completely destroys the ambiance of the area.

nice and relaxing. such a lovely place to just relax and people watch. Could get there easily by tram. I visited the Carmelite Church of Our Lady Victorious to see the Infant de Prague and had a look around the museum there.
The Heart of Czech History. You have to see it and feel it. The most important place in the Central Europe, medieval capital of the world.

Beautiful and rich in history. Try to go when it's not too crowded. There are a lot of uneven cobblestones so ditch the pretty shoes and wear some sensible, comfortable walking shoes.The history of the area is amazing as are the views and the stories. The monastery is still functional although there are fewer than two dozen monks still there. The castle area has many things which will appeal to all ages.Allow plenty of time to visit the castle and the gardens.

Worthwhile. This is a must see if you are in Prague and you should make time for the castle, the beautiful church and spend some time in the gardens.Recommend early in the day before all the tourists.

Beautiful and quaint. The castle district offers great view of the city and the wonderful rooftops of famous buildings, especially at night when the city lights up. St. Vitus Cathedral has many beautiful stained-glass windows which includes one done by the famous Czech artist Alfons Mucha. This district also has many quaint alleys
Great view to the city. This area takes you back in history. Excellent public transport all over the city can take you there.A real day trip to walk around but recommended.

The Castle Quarter is the heart of Medieval Prague.. The Castle District of Prague is filled with palaces, churches and even a castle. There is so much to see do not even try to see it all in one day. The most important part is St. Vitus Cathedral, the Westminster Abbey of the Czech people. Be sure to see the Castle and Golden Lane. Be on the lookout for the Castle Hill Orchestra busking in Castle Square. Also, there are great views of the city from multiple places on the hill.

Not so impressive "castle". This is not really a castle- I mean there is no fortification just a group of buildings the one next to the other and maybe a few towers (I saw just one). What really worths in the castle is the view, which is great. Also in the castle district you can see (with the same ticket) the St. Vitus cathedral (which you shouldnt miss), the golden lane (very nice) and a variety of museums. Have in mind that there are different entrances to get in the castle. We took the metro, stopped to malostranska, climbed some stairs and then got in the castle- but it was a little confusing and we didnt know from which side to go and start our visit. It is much better to take the tram22 - you will avoid the steps and you wont be confused because the route is easier from that side.

Love it but why is there a Starbucks. The Castle District is beautiful. We walked up there from our hotel 3 times. The Slovakia President was visiting so there was a lot of security but we could still explore. There really isn't a castle. The tower is the St. Vitus Cathedral which is very nice in itself.

Amazing views. The walk up to the castle is long and up a rather steep hill, but it is well worth it! The views of the city are totally fantastic! You have the opportunity of so many different views each as good as the one before!

History, Shopping, and Everything in Between. The changing of the guard, an activist and a wedding couple getting professional photos taken added drama to the castle with it's gorgeous grounds and spectacular views. Wandering by the church and through streets less traveled helped us feel like our experience was unique and special.

gorgeous. the castle is well worth the visit,but go early if you want to enjoy it in relative peace. then walk down the hill toward the bridge. picture perfect streets, grab a beer on a terrace and enjoy the scenery

Impressive!!. Was lucky to visit this castle and it was totally worth. Best to take a guided tour for half a day of Prague city that way you are well oriented and then slowly you can explore on your own and digest the beauty and culture of this city. Great photos to take from other side of Charles river at night. The church is so prominently visible with distinct lighting at night. Perhaps also worth taking a evening cruise on the Charles river.

Long and rewarding family day. We took the family ticket with 7 attractions and even our youngest 4 year old took the full walk until closing time. Family means real full family going beyond 2 kids. That's awesome. The place is magnificent and there's lot to see for adults, teenagers and small ones. Also the view to city is beautiful. Be prepared with cash as no place takes card. Info location has ATM so that helps and saved us.

Lots to see and do. Great outlook of the city. Plenty of history and culture. Many old cobbled streets and a variety of dwellings. Great photo opportunities. Easily spend a few hours visiting the sights here alone, without venturing too far.

Impressively and magnificently beautiful.. The Castle District (Hradcany) comprising of the Prague Castle complex, the various streets and lanes surrounding the castle and leading down to the Little Quarter (Mala Strana), is in my opinion overwhelmingly beautiful. And overwhelming in a wonderful way. It's true that the Prague Castle complex is one of the largest castle complexes in the world, though at the same time the various palaces and buildings in the castle complex are beautifully well-maintained. St. Vitus Cathedral is indeed grand and massive, though impressively beautiful at the same time, with a great historical significance (the country's patron saint, St. Wenceslas, is buried in the cathedral).The various streets and lanes surrounding the castle are quite beautiful and charming, and a few side streets and lanes near the Presidential Palace are quite quaint and charming. And when you walk to the area near the Strahov Monastery you're rewarded with wonderful views of St. Vitus Cathedral and the Prague Castle complex, along with stunning views of the Little Quarter, and the Old Town out in the distance. From the area near the Strahov Monastery you can then walk down to Nerudova Street, which leads you into the beautiful area of the Little Quarter.Because this district is so impressively beautiful and historically significant, you'll have many, many people visiting this area. Since I had a total of 9 days in Prague, I was able to visit the Castle District twice. The first time I hired a local guide, who walked me through not only the Castle Complex, but my guide also treated me to a few of the side streets and lanes near the Presidential Palace, and I found these side streets to be very charming. I feel I would not have found these various side streets and lanes on my own, I felt hiring a local guide to walk me around the Castle Complex and the Castle District was absolutely worthwhile. On the second time I visited the Castle complex and Castle District I was able to take my time in visiting the Cathedral and other spots at the Castle complex.I felt the first time I visited the Castle District I got so much out of visiting the district with a local guide. I feel hiring a good local guide makes a huge difference in visiting the Castle District. And I felt once I learned the significance of the Castle District, and the important points of interests of the Castle District from the local guide I hired, I was able to visit some of those same points of interests in more detail on my second visit to the Castle District.Whether you visit the Castle District with a local guide, whether you explore the Castle District on your own, or (as in my case) you do both, the bottom line is your visit to the Castle District, your time in the Castle District, will be an absolutely wonderful and memorable experience.

WOW. During my tour of the Castle District I was blown away by the history and the monumental efforts of the Czech Republic's citizens in protecting, telling and preserving their history. It is truly an amazing destination.

Castles and palaces galore. Prague Castle is a district not a single building. It is the hill top and the many palaces, some still in use as state offices, and ancillary buildings. Many of the palaces and their gardens are open to the public for a fee. Many have gothic origins and all have a baroque facade.
Beautiful views of city. Views from the area are great and loads to see at the top. Makes a good morning trip. Castle is one of a kind

Huge and imposing. To visit deeply the Castle, one of the ancient and biggest in the world still "inhabitated", you should spend a couple of days (and the entrance tickets for the castle are therefore valid for two days). There are lot of attraction to visit, each of them worthy to be seen:St Vitus Cathedral, The Gold street, the ancient castle, the st. vitus treasury, etc etcOn top of this take your time to have a walk in the nice royal gardens and on the charming streets that bring you down to Mala Strana.Each hour you will also have the opportunity to see the guard change, especially at 12:00 when you can also see the flags show.
Impressive architecture and views. Large open courtyards containing preserved churches, palaces and museums can be explored for free but there is a fee to enter the palaces and museums.
Amazing. Feast for the senses, would definitely recommend taking some time to stroll around. We took ourselves on a self-guided tour, I think that we missed a lot not taking a tour group though.

Beautiful Castle. I would recommend taking a walking tour up to the castle, because otherwise you will not learn the true history of the castle. Andrea from New Sandemans does a tour for 10 euros, and it is informative, fun and meaningful!

Fabulous place to discover while in Prague. So much to see. The highlights were St. Vitas Cathedral, The Old Royal Palace,Basilica of St. George And the Royal Gardens. If you have time check out the Golden Lane and the prison. It can take you most of a day if you take your time.
Beautiful. Beautiful area, so much to do and see. So many great photo opportunities. So much history. Highly recommend
So beautiful. Just like the rest of Prague, thie Castle district is really nice, tidy, clean and ... wherever you look: BEAUTIFUL... take the time to walk that area.

Near our hotel. Our hotel was in this area. It is quieter than "down the hill" but you can still find good places to eat and drink up here. The Library is well worth a visit as is the tiny brewery. The only negative for me was a pub called "The Black Bull" - right opposite the "Loreta Hotel" - We were made to feel unwelcome and to be honest, if you are expecting a friendly welcome and polite staff , don't go here !!

Great castle. An essential place to visit in Prague. It is really great and I thing thah Golden lane and St. Vitus cathedral are the best part of the whole castle but there are still many other very interesting places in the Hradcany.
Ole PowerShot headquarter. It is a historical place centre of many top important decesion was forged. IT. Prague was spy centre during cold war, and this castle is one of simbols of that time.

Spend the day and take it all in. The Prague Castle and the district that surrounds it is worthy of a full day of exploration. Their are some really cool cobblestone and narrow streets outside the castle, especially the one with a steep incline heading back down into town. Wander the streets and meet local merchants. Take it all in. This was a great stop on our European tour.
Stunning architecture. Stunning architecture, St Vitas Cathedral's beautiful stained glass windows, and the views overlooking Prague are fantastic!

Grand!. We had to do a really quick t6our of the castle district a we had to catch our flight to Amsterdam in the afternoon. Of the many attractions, we chose St. Vitus Cathedral, the Prague Castle, St. George Church and the yellow road. We really enjoyed St. Vitus Cathedral, its grandeur and beautiful interiors and exterior. The Prague Castle was a disappointment as there were a lot fo areas not open to the public due to some renovations going on. Unlike other castles we saw in Europe, this was a let-down. The church of St. George, the Dragon-slayer, was also a disappointment becasue it was not so well-preserved. I didn't like the yellow road because it was too commercialized for my taste but I do understand that some people like to shop around. I would probably visit again and spend more time at St. Vitus.

Prepare to spend a day. Large area where main attractions are of course Prague Castle and St.Vitus Cathedral and both are great. Views from Castle Hill are amazing overlooking beautiful Prague and if you are in decent shape with good shoes, then you can walk up there. Public transportation works great too and (legal) taxis in Prague are cheap

Patrimony and more. St. Vitus was the star attraction. The café just by the entrance was decent. The shops within the castle area were most surprisingly free of trash. We bought Christmas decorations and other presents, much to our surprise

Golden Lane. When visiting here look out for Golden lane which is slightly off the usual tourist route. Best way to visit is to take 17 tram to top of hill then walk through royal gardens to the cathedral.The castle is really the cathedral surrounded by houses of many styles sdo you won't see battlements or crenelations. Hundreds of visitors so you may need to queue for cathedral..

Too much commercialized. I just do not like reconstruction of old building. Yes, they need to maintain it but moden bandage job is tastless. Way too crowded even in early June. Too much commercialism.

Dont miss out. From the old town you can walk over the Karluv bridge and continue too the Castlr district on foot. It´s a nice walk and a lot to see on the way! Lot´s of cafeés and bars on the way. The castle area is free to walk around in, but you have to pay entrance fee to some of the closed areas. Still worth coming here even if you dont choose to enter.

Paid for an informative Yellow T-Shirt guided tour. Happy to pay for some extra explanation in English... Easy to do on your own too. Be aware that you need stable walking shoes as this place can be tough on your feet, and definitely have a good map, as it is easy to get muddled on your location.

A day at the castle.. The castle is a great place to spend the day. We've been there twice in the past year. First on our own and again in May with the in-laws. In both cases we arrived in the western square/gate in the mid morning. For the first visit, the lovely bride and I walked up from the hotel near the bridge. For the second time with the in-laws, we took the tram. The walk up is a bit steep so the tram is a good idea. If you time it right, you can see the changing of the guard. Try to watch from the small inner square. You'll see the band playing from the windows. We suggest buying the 4 site pass - Circuit B. That includes St. Vitus Cathedral, Old Royal Palace, St. George's Basilica, Golden Lane with Daliborka Tower. That seemed to work well for us. About half way through we ended up having lunch at the little cafe on the north side. It's fine and reasonably priced. We finished around 4:00 which was just enough time to walk back to our hotel (Pod Vezi) for a nap before dinner. Definitely worth a visit.

Amazing area. We did circuit B at a cost of approximately 10euro each and we saw everything we wanted to see. Golden lane is excellent and the cathedral is very impressive. A beer in this area will cost 4euro, extremely expensive.

Vast complex. Be aware you will have to pay to see a lot of the inside of the cathedral except what can be seen from the very back. Lots of interesting buildings, changing of the guard and a great view overlooking the city. You can either take the subway about half-way up or walk up a fairly lengthy set of stairs from the Lesser Quarter.

Lovely area, beautiful grounds. The castle area can be reached by several tram lines and is worth taking the tram as it is a pretty big climb otherwise. I think it was the #20 tram that went closest, but check with your hotel to be sure. There is still a small climb, but on an even grade (no steps). Also some steps to ascend to various areas in the Catle, but pretty easy and not a strain.

Don't miss this part of Prague!. So much to see and take in! Highly recommend hiring a local guide. Prague Walker - excellent guide (Jana). Refreshment expensive at the top of the hill - pack your own water.

Up on the Hill. It's a hard walk up the hill but the rewards are there for the intrepid. Beautiful architecture and of the course, the. Castle. Why not take a tour or horse carriage ride to avoid the walk. Must see area whichever way you get there.

A must !!!. When there do take a small castle trip which cost 10,87 eur and includes catedral, Vladislav hall, Golden lane and st. Goerge. This will give you an amazing perspective over this beautifull part of the city. This is just amazing!!!
Amazing. Excellent, a must in Prague. one of the most beautiful cathedrals in the world, sense of stepping into medieval time, perfect views...Highly recommended!

Much Better than Touristy Old Town. There are quite a few things to see in the Castle District, including the castle itself. Given the huge number of tourists in Old Town, the Castle was surprisingly uncrowded and very interesting. St. Vitus Cathedral is inside the castle and is huge. Actually, the castle itself is enormous and well worth seeing. About fifty meters from the castle entrance is the national art gallery, which has a nice collection. There were maybe four other people aside from us in the gallery. A little ways from the castle is the Loreto church, which has a replica of "St Mary's House" on its grounds and a nice display of religious "treasure." You can also tour the Strahov Monastery and art gallery. The monastery makes and sells its own beer. There's also Novy Svet (New Street) of very picturesque houses. All of these places were practically deserted compared to the tourist throngs in Old Town.
Excelent. The castle is very nice, but unfortunately are restrictions for visit (like no pictures in some areas). Staff there is on the edge of rudeness. Anyway is a must when you visit Prague.

A beautiful historical district with great views. It's worth a visit just to spend some time in Castle Square (but the Castle is the main attraction). There's so much in this district besides the castle and the city within a city. This is where you can take in the beautiful view of Lesser Town, Old Town, and Petrin Hill. There are also many different styles of architecture all around the district. People seem to miss all of this as they're rushing to the castle. Take time to see the surrounding palaces and monuments before you take on the huge crowds at the entrance. The visit to the Castle is just the icing on the cake. I wouldn't have missed that for the world.

Hradcany Castle. There was a slight climb up the front entrance to the Hradcany Castle and two beautiful vistas on both sides of the walkway. We followed a very large crowd into the castle and it was jam packed the entire way and therefore hard to approach any particular room and view it easily. It was very difficult to hear the guide describe anything. This was midweek an off season so I cannot imagine what it would be like in the summer with tourists from every country. I found the rooms interesting but not particularly spectacular that I could even remember anything that stood out.nI felt for a castle it was one of the least interesting points of all Cz.
Good exercise. Nice area to walk, rather touristy, but lots of beautiful views and great photography chances. Walk around the hill to the mini Eiffel Tower!

Beautiful view. I didn't bother to go inside the castles and its museums, but the view is nice. You can see Prague from above and while there, you might really understand better the whole city and it's present day (just make sure to do some research on the place before going there!)
Great. Plenty of great shops, restaurants and places to stop for coffee, wandered around the area for ages, we had plenty of time so not rushed, well worth the effort.

Easy to spend 3-4 hrs here. Easily in this place you can spend 3-4 hrs.There are a lot of attractions that can be seen.My own favorite is the "classic road" where there are a lot of "classic" shops in that small road.

Spectacular architecture. The walk all the way upto the castle is full of shops and on arriving at the castle you can see the changing of the guard prior to actually entering the castle grounds which is an experience in itself and a trip that mustn't be missed

Organised tour. We travelled on a nice day but it was a public holiday, so the area was crowded. We did not see inside the Castle or St Vitus. We had an excellent guide whose English was remarkably good.

Great views, if you are able to walk, don't take the train!. Walk up, stop off and have drink then take in the view then walk down. The crowds can be avoided if you don't wait till the afternoon and e view is really good. The orchards are lovely to walk through.

Very nice point of view to Prague. Very nice point of view to Prague and the old town. The history of the castle stretches back to the year 870 with the construction of its first walled building, the Church of the Virgin Mary. The Basilica of Saint George and the Basilica of St. Vitus were founded under the reign of Vratislav and his son St. Wenceslas in the first half of the 10th century.The first convent in Bohemia was founded in the castle, next to the church of St. George. A Romanesque palace was erected here during the 12th century. In the 14th century, under the reign of Charles IV the royal palace was rebuilt in Gothic style and the castle fortifications were strengthened. In place of rotunda and basilica of St. Vitus began building of a vast Gothic church, that have been completed almost six centuries later.During the Hussite Wars and the following decades, the castle was not inhabited. In 1485, King Ladislaus II Jagello began to rebuild the castle. The massive Vladislav Hall (built by Benedikt Rejt) was added to the Royal Palace. New defence towers were also built on the north side of the castle.A large fire in 1541 destroyed large parts of the castle. Under the Habsburgs, some new buildings in renaissance style were added. Ferdinand I built Belvedere as a summer palace for his wife Anne. Rudolph II used Prague Castle as his main residence. He founded the northern wing of the palace, with the Spanish Hall, where his precious art collections were exhibited.The Second Prague defenestration in 1618 began the Bohemian Revolt. During the subsequent wars, the Castle was damaged and dilapidated. Many works from the collection of Rudolph II were looted by Swedes in 1648, in the Battle of Prague (1648) which was the final act of the Thirty Years' War.The last major rebuilding of the castle was carried out by Empress Maria Theresa in the second half of the 18th century. Following his abdication in 1848, and the succession of his nephew, Franz Joseph, to the throne, the former emperor, Ferdinand I, made Prague Castle his home.In 1918, the castle became the seat of the president of the new Czechoslovak Republic.

Take a tram. The crowds were overwhelming! Our hotel gave us directions to the tram and that was the best advice.
While I was not overly impressed by the castle grounds and building it was worth going to as it is one of the top attractions in Prague

Spend a day here if you're a museum buff. To be blunt, don't pay admission if you're only looking to see the architecture and the scope of the castle. You can enter enough of the common grounds and gardens to save the money and stroll at your lesiure. If you love history and museums however, spring for the full pass and spend the whole day exploring the buildings and trying to understand the significance of the people and rules of the area and their profound and understated impact on history.

Beautiful area of Prague. The castle district is well worth a visit, even if you decide not to go into the overpriced and busy places within it. The whole area is beautifully built and designed and on a sunny day it is worth taking several hours to walk around.
Must see. Beautiful district with lots of magnificent well preserved buildings and a breathtaking view of the city and the river.

The view!. Despite freezing cold weather we ventured up to the Prague Castle to see the underwhelming changing of the guard, and bought a ticket which gave us access to The Old Palace, Basilica of St George, St Vitus's Cathedral and the Golden Lane. These sites were worth seeing, especially the Golden Lane with its glassed exhibits of how things were in medievel times, and the quaint little touristy shops. The best aspect of this site however is the view of Prague spread out below. A little stroll outside the official site bought us to the U Lubuti restaurant. This old world, wood panelled gem offers great service and real czech food in abundant servings at very reasonable prices. The search for a delicious, melt in the mouth beef goulash was finally over.

Gorgeous site to visit when in Prague. Loved the cathedral and all the little houses in the castle neighborhood. Great place to visit. A good approach is to get transportation to the castle and walk back down to Charles bridge.

Great Views. We didn't pay to go into the palace, but we did walk around the grounds. It was beautifully maintained, and the views from the top were gorgeous. It is a bit of a walk though, so make sure you've worn good shoes and area reasonably fit.Bathrooms were not free, so make sure you have a Euro or two on hand in case nature calls.

Rather special. The only down side we encountered in the castle district was, just after someone said to be careful of the rough cobblestones, I tripped on a rough patch, base over apex and hobbled the rest of the day. Apart from this, it was a great visit. The castle and cathedral are impressive and I've become one of the "when you've seen one castle/cathedral, you've seen them all" brigade. The changing of the guard is as impressive as that in Monaco, neither being anything to write home about. The view from the lookout is panoramic and impressive. The trams are an excellent means of accessing the heights, the area is definitely not for those with limited mobility. The previously monastic brewery makes and sells some very good beers,this is just near the white church with two towers visible from the bridge. A visit here could quite easily cover multiple days to view all areas. It is essential to be aware that you are at the mercy of the weather in between each site so a hat, sunscreen or maybe umbrella are suggested. You could wander this very large district and not spend a crown if you didn't want to and still have a great visit. The view is, again, rather special but...watch your step.
beatiful. The castle district is lovely with lots of things to see although we had a wheelchair with us and Prague is not very wheelchair friendly .
Beautiful location, great attention to detail. In Prague, the attention to detail is amazing, and the Castle is a must see. One of the most beautiful places I've ever visited
Incredible!. This is not only where you will find a lot of attractions (castle, cathedral, etc.) but will also have a breathtaking view of the city.

Centrepiece of Prague!. A must do as this is the place to see the city from above and is a delight in itself with its old buildings and wonderful cathedral. Try and avoid Sundays and bank holidays or get there very early.
Wonderful like most of Prague. you are going to walk in Prague and walking here is a must. It offers interesting architecture in the grafitto style and well preserved palaces and other buildings.

Breath-taking. The entire area is expansive, with lots to see and take in. Great historical buildings, quaint alleyways and streets, wonderful gardens.
Wear comfy shoes and save up a good chunk of time for this!
Step back in time. The city of old, there is so much to see and do here the views are wonderful you overlook the old town and the river. There are concerts every day in the church.

Haven't walked so much in ages ... and enjoyed every minute of it. What a super district, so much to see. We were lucky to have enough time to go back the next day. Maybe next time I'll stay in a hotel in this area.

Overall truly magnificent.. Our entire day up there was the best of the trip. We started from high above and then descending slowly to the square, the castle, admiring the sweeping views, the imposing monument, the quiet of this old residence of the city rulers. A day to remember.

Very large castle complex. The castle complex is very big. You must see St. Vitus Cathedral. I didn't see the whole thing. I was burnt out after about 6 hours. See the major parts that are labeled with roman numerals when purchasing your ticket.
Go at dusk.. If it's a stroll you want, miss the crowds and head up the hill at dusk. Far more photo opportunities and some streets etc are accessible without tickets!

Spectacular. Beautiful grounds and buildings with gorgeous view of Prague from the district with lots of restaurants with the same beautiful view and cobblestone street and shops. The huge Cathedral was VERY impressive. Definitely worth spending at least half a day or more.

Loads to see and do. We book a tour with the getyourguide and we took a tram from Mala strana, and the guide took us around this area. She also took us to the monastery, where you can have a panoramic vue from Prague, and where the monks produce their own beer. We also saw the changing of the guards and finished on the beautiful gardens. great afternoon out.

must be seen. It's a spot that cannot be missed in a touristic trip, but it's also not that interesting. The royal palace is not very impressive. Also the other buildings that can be visited are not, except for maybe the cathedral. It can be extremely crowded here over the weekend. The golden street is worthwhile to visit. Small old homes that nowadays mostly host small shops. For a great view, go up into the South tower of the cathedral.

Disney wonderland. Set high on a hill overlooking the city and the river this is the place to visit first and get the real feel of Prague. We went there twice, once on a guided tour and the next day which was my wife's birthday on our own. Have lunch at the restaurant half way down the path that cuts through the vin yard and try some of the local wine . The food is lovely and a reasonable price and the view of the city is fabulous , and wear a pair of comfortable shoes for the cobble stones !

Would be excellent if only there was more explanation. Lots of buildings in the castle complex but very little explanation on site of what you can go into and what you will see ... the information office is really just for ticket sales and explaining what buildings are covered by what offers ... not what you will get to experience once inside. BTW over 65s can get discounts. Some sites are free to enter one Saturday each month - usually the 1st Saturday - when it can be very crowded to get anywhere. Sundays can be good day as crowds less- but check about Cathedral closure for services.
Great. When one speaks of K&K empire, usually means Wien or Budapest, but Prague and Hradcany can make you feel the history. the castle, the church, name it..It is Golden city for a reason.

Huge Hailstones. Lovely area with so much to see. We went through and round but did not pay for entry to any of the exhibits. You can walk through the entrance to the exit to the cathedral for nothing and the view was spectacular, especially as the light was so bright preceding a hail storm! Huge hailstones!

Don't just go to the castle!. I'd really recommend getting tram 22 into this area to wander around the castle then down into the rest of the castle district. There are some lovely bars and restaurants to while away the hours in. The gardens around the castle are beautiful and well worth a stroll.
Lovely walk up and views. This is a really lovely walk, with good views and pretty gardens. It does get pretty crowded but it is worth the walk up the hill.

Fantastic History.. The castle grounds are really well kept. The signposting could be better. Especially as far as the ticketsales points are concerned. We lost at least 30-45 minutes by standing in the wrong (and right) queues.

Prague Cadtle...pay attention to all the reviews. Since we are in Prague for 3 weeks I decided to ignore the advise of Trip Advisor travelers and purchase the 350 krona ticket. Not the best idea: the powder tower was just a display of military uniforms; the Story of a Prague was mostly text; the old Castle was big empty rooms with the exception of a small bookshelf over a doorway with beautifully bound tax records and even the Rosenberg palace was a bit dry. The Golden Lane was a bunch of tacky gift shops that was actually a ticketed site! However, St. Vitus was wonderful and the ticket allows you to see much more than just the free part. The gardens are free and lovely as is the noontime changing of the guard and the views. So, listen to the travelers and save your money.The Toy Museum is an extra charge but there is no sign about tickets at the bottom of the 3 flight you have to walk up before you find out.Also...take the 22 tram to the Cadtle and walk down.

Great views & more spectacular buildings.. After crossing the Charles bridge, a climb up the hill past some interesting shops & cafes' brings you to the castle. Free to go in for a look around, including the superb cathedral, the view over Prague is fantastic.

Special area to visit. Unfortunately we came too late for wandering also the gardens which I remembered from our previous visit, and also could no more climb to the top of the tower for the great panorama it offers, but we could still get an impression of the amazing architecture and the amazing views of the other parts across the river. It's definitely a must for any first time visitor and recommended also for those who visited before.
A must see!. Definitely a must see. We didn't buy any tickets just walked around and took a lot of photos. The place has an amazing view of the city. Don't miss it! We really enjoyed it.

Make sure they're open!. We struggled up to the Castle two days in a row to find that access was denied because there was a summit conference in some of the buildings. Nowhere do they warn you until you get there and they have tiny signs saying they might do this at any time. On the third day, all the hoards that hadn't been able to get in for two days descended upon the place, making it very unpleasant to see anything. Best seen from a distance, perferably at night from the Charles Bridge.

Worth walking around and exploring. Castle is usually the focal point of the visit to castle district, but the areas near the castle are fairly nice to explore and walk around. The food and souvenir prices are not the best, but the narrow streets and views are good.

Go there - easy to buy tickets and get audio guide. Lots of see - the church, the castle the very window where the defenestration of Prague took place ; great views and some inspiring buildings. Well worth the climb up the hill to it.

Worth several visits. Try to visit the castle area on different times of the day to get new impressions each time: morning, afternoon, evenings... Also, use different streets on the way up and down! Since Prague offers a multitude of concert opportunities, why not choose one in a unique setting? St. George Basilica at the small square east of the larger cathedral is a good choice.
Beautiful!. This area of Prague is so beautiful. You can see most of it from Prague Castle. It's a wonderful area to explore and see a lot of street performers and entertainers. It's a MUST SEE!!!
Nice place to explore. We didn't pay to go into anything but had a pleasant time wandering around and enjoying the sights. The gardens are nice also.

Well worth a visit. Forget the tour and take tram 22 to the main gate (it passes many of the main sites). We in our 70's climbed the tower and the view was spectacular. Guards and changing of the guard was fun. Because of the narrow space it is fun to see the various ways people try to get pictures of St Vitus.We attended a wonderful concert at St Georges Basilica.
nice walking. I enjoyed everything I did in Prague including this one. I like to know about different things, and through this walking, I learned a lot about different architectural style in Europe.

A MUST. Castle District (Hradcany), is a must for tourists because of the many attractions and the fantastic views od the town.The Castle itself, the Presidential Palace, St. Vitus Cathedral, the Golden Street of the alchemists, the Archbishop's Palace are all there. Have in mind that there are a lot of stairs, but the second time we've been there, the bus left us at the other entrance of the Castle.
A must see!. Although we didn't go in, you really should visit the castle! Go over the Charles bridge to get there and you get amazing views of the city!Definitely worth the walk :)

My favourite area in Prague!. Lovely area with lots of green around, great views from the hill on the accross-the-river Old Town and with such a smooth atmosphere you cannot miss it! Head yourself to Letna Park as well...

Prague Castle. The view is great, the history is wonderful, the series of buildings to look at are great. We had a wonderful time. We took the hill up and we took the stairs up, the only way to get there is to go up. Loved the Golden Lane, and all of the different parts of the castle district. Be sure to take the extended tour.

A must do. This is such a prominant feature in Prague visitors must go here. Though I think it is prettier from a distance, it is well worth the trip to walk through. I walked here from the Metronome and it was a very pleasant walk through a park.

Beautiful. The views over Prague are lovely. The changing of the guard picturesque. The architecture unspoiled. No bullet holes like in Budapest. And nice beer to be enjoyed while overlooking the city.

Great place. Having the Old Town and Castle so close, this place is just brilliant tourist attraction. It has a lot of beautiful places to offer; just take your camera, comfortable shoes and give it a go! If you feel tired after few hours of walking, just pop in into one of the Czech restaurants. The prices there are lower compared to the UK ones.

It is worth to go. It is worth to go, is magical, nostalgic like the movies we watch.   The entire route to get there pretty well. It has so much to see it will take long. Especially the collection of old armor, helmets knights and their weapons are really fantastic. Huge museum that pay a decent amount to get into, you will definitely amaze you but will bore you with endless hours necessarily need to see it all.

Pretty place to wander. You don't need to buy tickets really - the cathedral is pretty inside but you can get in for free to see the stained glass. The castle is pretty dull inside - not much to look at apart from big empty room (big enough for jousting tournaments). I guess the Golden Lane was worth a look but again you can get the feel of the place just as well by wandering around. Pretty gardens - bring a picnic as the food at the cafés is pretty standard.

The most beautiful church I've ever been to. The most beautiful church I've ever been to. Do not miss this cathedral. It is the most beautiful one I have ever been in: fantastic sight with beautiful windows, amazing ceilings and is really light.
cute and cozy. The area leading up to Prague Castle is cute with small cafes and stores. Cafes have outdoor seating and it is fun to do people watching

Lots To See and Do. This is an opportunity to see lots of historical sights and there is always something to do. You will be afforded wonderful views of the city. Tours are available for you. The are lots of shops that you can look in. You have to do this if you go to Prague.

Night time view. We went up here twice during our visit and would definitely recommend taking a walk round here in the dark as the cathedral is spectacularly illuminated and the view across the city at night is quite special.

Great views. The view is great as well as the history of Prague located mostly in this area.
If you are not lazy, walk up to the castle or down from it... Don't miss the cafe's and shops on the way.
An evening stroll. We were staying at a nearby hotel and each evening after dinner took a leisurely stroll into the Castle courtyards and around the Cathedral

Lots of things to do and great views!. The whole castle district was lovely and offered an amazing view of the city and a variety of places to see and eat/ drink. We opted for the short visit pass which gives you access to the Old Palace, St Vitus Cathedral and Golden Lane for about CZK 250. St Vitus Cathedral was magnificent, really worth the visit, while Golden Lane is lovely representation of old houses/ stores in the district.I was a bit disappointed as the exhibits were not clearly labelled and so was impossible to understand what was going on. I would recommend trying to get on the guided tour for only CZK 100 extra.

Great place just to walk around.. I liked just about everything. It was a hot sunny day [ yes it was March ] and the views from up there were fabulous. Lots of eating places, plus wherever you go it all seems to lead back down again onto the famous bridge.

Not Wheelchair Friendly. Great place with lots of history. Practically all the history of Prague is within its walls. Unfortunately it is not wheelchair friendly as the ground is very uneven and the wheels kept getting stuck in the ruts.
Step back in history. This is not a flowery castle but rather a small walled town with cathedral, restaurants, squares and royal rooms and history

There is a lot to see, the changing of the guard at 12-00pm, the Loreto treasures. The view of the city from Star bucks coffee shop is amazing, there are some funny acts to watch we saw a man on stilts playing a violin, there a plenty of places to eat there but be careful as they charged you for the almonds on the plate and for the bread.
Castle experience. We enjoyed our time here, the architecture, history and panoramic views added to make this memorable. We were mesmerized with the changing of the guards.

Tram 22 "Pick pocket express". Beware of the pick pocketing on Tram 22! I consider myself a savey traveller visiting Prague for the third time and 30 visits to Europe. These men are crafty but fortunately I grabbed them and screamed loud with getting my items handed over by their hand! Our hotel conceriege confirmed this issue. Love Prague but beware!

Pretty good. We enjoyed walking around the complex and checking out the views of the city from the hill this is on. The cathedral is breathtaking but you have to pay to go further than the front of it. I think this is a must if you are in the city but personally I was slightly bored by the time we left.

changing the guard. went to the castle area on part of our walking tour, saw the changing of the guard, this happens every hour worth seeing. the cathedral within the castle is utterly beautiful and should be visited if possible. Stained glass windows are stunning.

Worth a morning or afternoon of your time. Lots to see - the cathedral, the 'palaces', golden lane etc. Very pretty, really interesting, a few watering holes to keep your strength up. A place you could return to.
A must see.
Changing of the Guard. we visited on the sunday morning in time for the 12 noon changing of the guard and enjoyed the experience whilst bathing in the glorious sunshine
Nice visit. Visiting Prague is not possible to Forget to visit the Castle. It is a nice walk, specially on a sunny day

Talk about Castles in the sky!. We actually walked from our hotel on Hybernska to the castle complex for which you need a certain level of fitness, but you can get a lift in an intriguing 'old' car made for the purpose of transporting a number of people up the steep cobbled hill. There is so much to see and admire here, but also plenty of crowds, so try and time your visit early. We took the 'small' ticket due to lack of time, but rather regret that we didn't buy the 'large' ticket which includes all the great buildings and churches.

Worth the walk or take a number 22 Tram. From the city, the castle has a prominent position on the hillside.It may be a walk up to it,but well worth it if you do.Alternatively,take a 22 tram from Starometska to the castle.

Where else?. How many places in the world can you wander an old Castle? Well, perhaps many throughout Europe, etc. But each one is unique and resplendent in it's own history. As is the Castle District in Prague. We enjoyed just strolling & viewing whatever took our fancy. Golden Lane was particularly interesting, a row of little (tiny!) houses that some of the craftsmen/women of the day inhabited, both as little shops during the day and and as their homes at night. Give you a glimpse into their very primitive lifestyles. Nice collection of armor and swords and even some tools of torture, if you're into that kind of thing! It's a nice day of strolling through history. Lots to see. Nice restaurant / refreshment places to sit when you're tired. As in most of Europe, take coins for the toilette! The grounds and the gardens are lovely, as is the view!

A place full of history! . This place holds a variety of different buildings that include a castle, a cathedral, dungeons, a vast variety of religious pieces of art crafted in gold and gems, etc. since this is more like a Middle age citadel you need at least half day to visit it.

Lots of various style buildings. Nice area lovely walks lots of various places and buildings to see also a lovely park and gardens to walk around. sometimes they have an owl display where you can have your picture taken with owls. Also the summerhouse is a lovely building
AMAZING. In Prague, everything is awesome. When I go to the Hradcany I move into the world of fairy tales is an amazing place where very happy to be back.

Disjointed yet excellent. Lots to see with great views...a little irritating that choosing the 'long' tour ticket over the 'short' tour ticket still leaves a few attractions requiring payment to enter. Couldn't see any way to pay for everything and the cafe prices are steeper than the castle steps...but experience is worth it

A great day in Castle District. The Castle indeed is a must see in Prague, but once you're there, the whole Castle District (Hradcany) worth a one day visit. My recommendation for a pleasant walking tour would be:Take tram no.22 to Kralovsky letohradek station (one stop before Prazsky hrad), enter the Royal Garden's gate opposite to the tram station and follow this itinerary: Royal Summer Palace (where the building ends: very special view of Prague and the Castle!), walk through the Garden toward its main entrance, turn left, visit the Castle (just walking around is for free), St. Vitus Cathedral and exit the Castle building complex on the front exit at Hradcanske namesti (Renaissance palaces!). Continue on Loretanska street, turn left to reach Loreta church (admire it from outside or get a ticket and visit the place). After a short walk on Cerninska street you turn right and continue on the romantic Novy Svet (New World) street. The Kanovnicka street will lead you back to Hradcanske namesti Square.One of the most pitoresque stairs of Prague, Radnicke schody (Town Hall Stairs, near Restaurant Ve Stari Radnici, Loretanska 1) will take you to Nerudova street (In this steep street you can find many restaurants, souvenir shops, embassies, but what’s most remarkable about this street are the house signs and the people that lived in that houses. Why house signs? The house numbers were introduced in Prague in 1770. Before that the houses were recognized by their signs and Nerudova street has a vast collection of them: no. 49, 43, 41, 34, 32, 12, 6)At the end of Nerudova street is Church of St. Nicholas (Malostranske namesti Square) and after a 3 minute walk you find yourself on the Charles Bridge! Admire the statues, the view, and stop for a while to listen the street (bridge?) musicians playing genuine Dixiland made in Prague...(Estimated total length of this tour: 5 km)

Greatest views of Praha.. The Castle district offers some of the best view of Prague. The garden is also a great attraction to visit. The castle is great being in a different architecture then other castle in Europe.
Beautiful. Long walk up to castle, but plenty of places to stop and have a drink or some lunch... When you get to the top the views are spectacular

Amazing access. Pay for the ticket and there is heaps of stuff you can see. If you take your time, you could be here all day. Walking around the castle was really interesting. I had quite low expectations of this attraction and was pleasantly surprised. Tip - take coins for the toilets!

Visiting the Castle. We stayed near the Charles bridge on the Castle side and we were within an 8-10 minute walk from the castle. Our visit to the castle was interesting but of everything we did during our 6 days in Prague, if I had to eliminate anything due to time constraints, I would now delete our visit to the castle. It was extremely busy and took a great deal of time. There were many large group tours going on in the castle area and this always reduces the amount of enjoyment we experience. My wife and I both agreed after our self directed tour, that we would not recommend this to anyone unless they were really into castles.

Gorgeous Views. Was in Prague a week before Christmas. Went up to the Castle twice in the 3 days i was in town. Spectacular views from just the stairs alone. I went up all the way to the top of the tower (for a fee of course) but i must admit that it was worth it. Views from the top were just as amazing. The church next to the castle was absolutely beautiful. We just stood in the middle and admired the detail. The church does have an entrance fee should you wish to walk around.

Great look out spot. A lovely area to wander around, with some stunning views over Prague. We recommend getting a hot chocolate in the restaurant opposite the castle gates and sitting out on their terrace, which was warm and sheltered even in a cold January wind!

View of Hradcany Castle is incredible!. The view of Hradcany Castle complex from across the Vltava River is stunning & like something out of a fairytale! See it during day & during evening when it's all lit up! Magical indeed!
Enjoyed the changing of the guards. The castle district was interesting and enjoyed the changing of the guards upon entry and again in the court yard.

Makes Prague so special. Castletown was my favorite part of this city. It's so full of history, and we were surprised to see it wasn't so crowded. We used a guide, which I recommend, as it can all get overwhelming. Don't go to Prague without seeing these castles. You'll feel like you're in a movie, and it is totally worth it.

A must do. Here you get beautiful views of sea of red roofs. Make sure to bring you bring good and comfortable walking shoes, there is a lot to conquer and lot to see, it's great getting lost here, you can be your own guide

Showplace of Prague. You need at least half a day to see everything. There are museums, churches and Golden Lane, a street with small houses with exhibits of life in medieval times, knights and armor.You can even try crossbow shooting. Just be aware that this street gets very crowded in the afternoon, so best seen first thing in the morning.St Vitus Cathedral was built in 3 separate sections but looks contiguous from the outside.Gorgeous stained glass windows.St. George Basilica very simple but oldest church in area.

Loved Prague. Not many people will get to find out about the Musial fountain I can recommend it. The night I went it was Michael Jackson. I have also seen the one in Dubai a couple of times but it is not as good but it is also free.

Great views.. We took the steps up to the castle, and there are lots of them, but it's well worth it as the vistas along the route are stunning. It's an easy district to get to and is well served by trams and metro links.

Enormous grounds & buildings. When you stand on the old town square, you can see all these buildings on top of the hill. Once you go there, there is a lot to see outside and inside. The buildings are enormous. You can come down the hill through the vinyard or enjoy a drink or snack in the restaurant that you can find in the middle of the vinyard.

Lovely area. The trip up to the castle via tram 22 was a pleasant journey, passing through some residential areas, but once adjacent to the castle the area is a lovely was to spend a couple of hours, Nice bars, restaurants and views.

Beautiful area not to be missed. This is such a beautiful area. It's a short walk and great exercise to see some amazing views of the city. Once you get to the top you can really appreciate how big the castle is. There are several restaurants that offer dining with great views. There are also some viewing platforms. You can really appreciate how beautiful the city is from this area. Make sure you plan a trip up. You will be glad you did.

Wonderful Area. This is a large expansive place full of many great sites. It is home to the Prague castle, St. Vitus cathedral, and museums. It is also a great place for views of the city from above. Worth the time to see.

Impressive but plan your trip. An enormous complex which offers a cathedral, castle, homes etc and well worth the day you really need to devote to it. There is a very good restaurant (with balcony) on site for lunch. The only minus was that in the art gallery we were discussing a painting when we were told that no noise/talking was allowed! My advice - give this a miss especially if you have children with you

Vast expanse of Prague Castle. The Castle is enormous, this will take half a day to visit either on foot or by tram. There are several museums, cathedral, parliamentary buildings, palace guards. Very impressive!

worth a view. fabulous castle complex; very large area to cover so pace yourself. Tram 20 takes you to monastery area. Venicular takes you to the observatory and then you have quite a steep walk down. sensible walking shoes a must!

Very scenic. We had a crisp, sunny day after a night's stay in the area which made for great photos of the castle and bastion. We had shops and cafes near our hotel and came upon very friendly locals. You can catch the Hop-On Hop-Off bus at stop 13 just down the street from the Hilton and tour the entire city after browsing the town.
Many Steps to Castle. Worth the long walk up the stairs (apparently there is another approach to the castle) but we enjoyed the views en route. Another must see when in Prague

Great day out. We went up to the castle one day and bought the short tour ticket. This gave us quite a few hours wandering around the complex and then visiting various buildings within it. We ended up buying the extra ticket to go up the tower and although there are rather a lot of steps the view you get from the top is fantastic. Our favourite bit was actually the row of old houses that they have converted into a mixture of shops and museums. The armoury on the second floor was particularly good.We also watched the changing of the guard and as others have said it is perhaps less impressive than other ones I have seen, notably Buckingham palace, but is worth watching.
Lovely historic area. Lovely to just amble along the cobbled streets, explore the castle precincts, full of atmosphere and charm.

Lovely part of the city. Once you cross Charles bridge, you enter the castle district. This really is a nice place to visit or to stay whilst in Prague. There are some lovely shops, restaurants and bars. Its also not quite as busy as the old town so you can get a bit more space and peace depending where you go. Once past the castle you can continue waling up the road until you get to Petrin Tower
Go There!. wonderful place to wander around and get a real feel for Praha--its people parks, special buildings, etc.
great place. A must on any trip to Prague. the castle and cathedral are absolutely magnificent. also the walk up to the castle from the old square is also a great treat

Great. Since the castle is on a hill you can see an amazing view to whole Prague from Hradcany. It is really nice to walk around the park and the whole Hradcany becuase it is really magnificent to se all architecture.

Much more than the Prague Castle. In Castle District the most known attraction is the Prague Castle, no one argues about that. But it's far from the truth that it's the only one in that part of the city. In the square facing the Castle entrance there are at least three other palaces that hold very interesting exhibitions (from Baroque to Renaissance) and lovely architecture. All them are worth a visit.

Favorite parts of Prague Castle and excellent lunch. We were confused at first because Prague Castle is actually a complex of various monuments. St. Vitus is the largest and most impressive. The original castle (as in the battlement walls) has been converted into the Palace over time. So go on the tour of the Palace to see the remaining castle. We also enjoyed Golden Lane because there is a section with a fascinating display of medieval armor, torture chamber and weapons. This section is kinda hidden, look upstairs across from the cafe. The wooden craft shops are also charming. And the walk uphill to the view is outstanding. After a long walk and tour we had an excellent late lunch at U Labuti. Its located at Hradcanske namEsti 11 about 1 block down from the changing of the guard. After some heavy Czech meals, the salads were extremely fresh and delicious. Together with some excellent soup and Czech wine it was an excellent meal that recharged us for the long walk back.

Habsburgian but well dimensioned. The Burg reminds obviously of Vienna, the imperial K.u.K. capital. We liked the well-dimensioned proportions which stylistically are much in line with Vienna but under a more sympathetic and site-adequate scale.

Castle Hill walk. After an excellent lunch at the Little Quarter Square, we walked up the hill to Prague Castle where a most amazing view of the city awaits you. We walked around the Castle Square and Courtyards and visited St. Vitus Cathedral where an Alphonse Mucha (of Art Noveau fame) magnificent stained glass window sprakles in all its glory. We exited through the side and crossed the Deer Moat which led us to a park trail that runs across from the Castle grounds to the Metronome (another landmark in the Prague skyline which used to hold a statue of Stalin and has since been replaced). There is a marvelous view of the castle complex as you walk away with a stunning vistas of the cathedral and castle if you venture out this less traveled exit.The sun was going down and we stopped at various points just to gaze at the city in the golden glow of the setting sun. There were very few tourists, mostly residents walking their dogs or taking a leisurely stroll before heading home. The light, the views, the distance from the tourist mobs that seemed to hound us wherever we went made this moment my favorite time in Prague. It was the perfect ending to a wonderful stay in Prague!
Beautiful. This definitely has to be part of your trip to Prague!Its beautiful,full of history! We did this as part of an all day tour so learnt a lot about the history and its significance.

Great views after long walk. So the Castle is on the "other side" of Prague and its all up a very steep hill. The walk is worth the view if you want some nice pictures of Prague but seeing a Starbucks when you reach the top is abit dissapointing! The Castle and govenment buildings are all nice and interesting to see (however to actually go in and see them you must pay) Then you must walk back down.If you are into sightseeing though ofcourse it is well worth the walk up!

A Must See. A great view of the city from this hill top castle. Take the #22 trolley to get there and walk back down. It will save a lot of wear and tear on your body. If you start off early enough in the day you can take in the lessor quarter the same day. Don't miss the cathedral.
family weekend trip. we don't plan out our days, we just go and start walking around. we ran into the district on our first night in prague and it was beautiful.

Get there for the changing of the guard. We arrived there just before the changing of the guard at 12 noon and is a great traditional spectacle. Afterwards have a look around the Cathedral and castle grounds. Very impressive

Excellent castle - not terribly bad climb.. Outside is nice - Church is nice. Inside tour doesn't cover much. So hang out in the square. Gift shop is good - check out the tour interiors there in the books.

Good place to spend a day. The castle district is just that - not only the castle but other sites as well including St. Vitus. Wonderful to wander and view the buildings, the panorama over the city and be entertained by "buskers". Buskers are not your street variety buskers but very accomplished classical musicians.

Great place to see. Our guide was Bianca and she had a wealth of historical knowledge - I don't think we missed a corner of this place and she didn't rush us - it was a take your time and enjoy approach. I would recommend this tour to anyone - just looking for the yellow umbrellas in the Old Town Square.

Beautiful and interesting. Along with the usual things to see in this area - the castle and the gardens we took our guides recommendation and went to the museum at the entrance to the palace and saw a fabulous exhibit of glass.

Plenty to see and explore. So much to see beyond the obvious where the crowds were. We bought an entrance ticket for a lot of the attractions (not all attractions are included in this ticket) including the cathedral.We also explored the area that was further from the main hub of attractions. The crowds disappeared and we found some of interesting places to explore that were a short walk from the castle and cathedral. Don't know if it is normally crowded here but it was the weekend and there was a special event with the crown jewels going on.There was so much to see that we returned the next day which was a weekday and the crowds had dissipated. We had taken the bus up to the castle since we knew we could be doing a lot of walking later that day. At the end of the day we took a major street downward from the castle towards the old town section of the city that is worth taking. Lots of shops and things to see along the way.
Beautiful location. Always the perfect spot to expore...the gardens are exquisite and the castle a must see.Fun to watch the changing of the guard, just the entire atmosphere is lovely.

Worth buying a 'Grand Tour' ticket. The castle area is well worth a visit and contains many sites of cultural and historical interest. Many hours can be spent in the area which, whilst busy, does not have the volume of crowds that can be found in the city itself.

My favorite...but be careful to get tickets that include everything you want.. This is a "working" castle, with guards 24/7. Be sure to see the changing of the guard. The complex is LARGE, so be sure you are ready to walk. The views of the city are spectacular.A few drawbacks: We were with a small tour group, and had the ticket with four of the areas included. We knew we were going to stay longer, because we wanted to go to the treasury, and spend more time in the little shops. We learned that once you exit the area where the small shops are, you cannot walk back up there without getting another ticket!! Which required going back to the ticket office nearly half way back to the entrance! Poor customer relations. I have money that I want to spend in those little shops and you won;t let me walk back the 40 yards uphill to look in all of them again...really? So, if you are with a group and you want to stay longer then they do, do not exit out of the narrow lane of shops to meet them down at the statue of the young boy (a popular place for a tour guide to say to meet at the end of the tour), or you will have to get a new ticket to get back to those cute little shops! Also the treasury requires a separate ticket.Also, there are nice cafes to eat in for lunch or a snack, whichever your preference. There are ice cream bars, desserts, sodas water, chips and such in the cafe by the statue of the young boy, There is a very nice gift shop there as well. When departing, the exit straight down from the castle is quite steep and has MANY small long steps. i wish we had not gone this way...but we did not know where we would exit if we took the garden route, which is over the the right of the lookout when you exit. ENJOY all!

Several days worth of sites here. The buildings are all magnificent, but we spent most of our time exploring the royal gardens. The trees all have markers with information written in Czech and English and there is an amazing display of different varieties.

Prague -The Castle. This is a large area --impossible to see in a day. It was built over centuries-and yes, the Hapsburg s had their hand in this too. It includes the Cathedral, a magnificent garden and multi buildings. there is also the Changing of the Guard ceremony at intervals throughout te day.It is a little removed from the City Center, but relatively easy to get to by city buses.Even though, I saw it in the rain, I loved it.I saw this for only a partial day, so definitely did not see everything, but what I did see makes me want to return to see all of it.

So Beautiful. This wonderful area provides great vistas of the whole city of Prague and includes the Castle as well as Castletown. The buildings are so lovely and the area is very historical. Make sure to take a look at Franz Kafka's tiny house. We found using a guide was very helpful. We used a company called Prague Extra and highly recommend their services.

Inspiring. The castle retains its historical feel and ambience. Had a tour guide explain the history of the city while exploring - a must! Spent a wonderful hour listening to wonderful classical music - a pianist accompanied by violinst. Just amazing.
Of interest to historians.. Guides are available but I find medieval history a bit convoluted but this is an interesting place to visit.

Surprisingly good!. I live in Budapest, so I am a bit jaded. I have seen many medieval villages in Italy. Sometimes I think, "Ho, hum, another caste, another cathedral." Not so. The Basilica was spectacular, and the stained glass was like nothing I have seen elsewhere. The whole area and especially the little shops on Golden Lane are wonderful. Don't miss it.

Cozy. The castle district is huge so plan at least a good part of your day here. Even though it's so huge, it's still very cozy and romantic with small alleys, cobble stones and little shops, including a Christmas shop with beautiful ornaments for the Christmas tree. On your way up the steps to the castle, there's a "hole in the wall" where you can try a real Prague delicacy which looks like a cylinder that they then smear chocolate in. Very yummy! There are several options for entrance tickets, depending on how much you wanna see. We took the basic one, which gives access to the cathedral, the castle and "golden circle", which shows how life in Prague was in medieval times. You also have an amazing view from the Castle district so it's well worth a trip just for the panoramic views, if you don't wanna spend money on going inside the castle area.
Well worth a visit. This castle is well worth a visit. We got the cheaper ticket and took half a day. The best place was Golden Alley which was like Diagon Alley from Harry Potter.

Need plenty energy. this really needs a whole day to appreciate it all. try and time visit for midday changing of guards as this is the more ceremonial change, if very busy in cathedral etc you do feel like your pushed round like cattle a tad......you cant have a pee for free anywhere..this is pretty true for most of Prague in popular areas...we found shopping centres and bars were though

great place to visit. excellent views of the city, very romantic. we went through the park, I strongly suggest that. very nice park to walk through. it was october and the leaves were green, yellow and red, very beatiful
