Disappointing. This is not a castle! The area contains an old castle wall, a palace, presidential homes and buildings but no castle. It isn't even especially attractive. The best thing about it is the cathedral and the view. Although sadly the "new" buildings were built in front of the cathedral so you can't even see that easily!
Gorgeous area. As of so many place in lovely Prague this is a do not miss area. The views, the castle, the grounds and St. Vitus Cathedral are beyond beautiful. What a city!

Not to be missed. We joined a walking tour on route to the Castle district and did not regret it on our last day in Prague. A local resident guide (ex-pat Australian Kate) led our group and provided an enthralling description and tour of the district including the Changing of the Guard. A great afternoon.

A true castle. A fantastic place with all the lanes and other parts of a true castle. St. Vitus was amazing. An awesome church though the inside not particularly attractive. Much better was the Church of St. Paul and Peter at Vyshrad.

Historic stroll. Spent our last day in Prague on castle hill. Tied up a lot of history from our last 2 weeks touring Budapest, Vienna & Prague. Once again took Rick Steves advise and purchased the "lite" ticket which gave access to 4 of the major sites and it was a perfect overview. I would recommend Lobcowicz palace in addition as it was a very intimate tour and tops as far as museums and insight into court life

A must see. We walked up the hill (a very steep incline) and enjoyed a view overlooking the city from the top. Wonderful place to take pictures. If you must, you can visit a Starbucks at the top. We walked around the area but there were no tours, unfortunately. You can use Google though to learn more about the castle and cathedral, as we did. Going down we visited a place that makes crepes and the rolled donuts...excellent and much less expensive than some of the fancier touristy restaurants. Then we watched the sun set from the Charles Bridge...perfect for taking photos of the silhouetted castle.

Do it!. Time it so you get to see changing of the guard. We went with a tour guide (1/2 day walking tour) which provided excellent commentary. You are picked up from your hotel, bused to Hdracany Castle which you tour then walk downhill, past Lennon's Wall, over Charles Bridge, river cruise with excellent vantage point of Charles Bridge finishing with late lunch in an underground restaurant.

A Fun Stroll. This is a grand walk downhill from the castle. It is very touristy but still lots of fun with many clever shops and cafe's. It is a dandy place to round up your souvenirs for the kids back home.

The Castle Proper. Trip Advisor wanted me to write a review about the District, but I can only comment on the Castle area itself, which was astonishingly beautiful and quite large. If you go on a tour in the fall, remember that once you are on top of the hill it can be quite windy and cold, so dress warmly. Our group got dropped off up there, and we thought we would be in a bus most of time so didn't dress warmly enough. We about froze, but warmed up on hot cider when our bus got us back down to town.

Castle District. Lots of shopping and restaurants to choose from. Best to do your shopping off the beaten path. Also too many people working you to eat at their restaurant. And watch out for the men trying to exchange your money for Czech money.
Packed with tourists. Again, it is a tourist attraction and difficult to get around. The restaurants are not bad, but many are quite expensive. Otherwise it is charming and worth going.
Beautiful. This area is beautiful. I loved the little shops and cafés. The area is very clean and very scenic. this area should not be missed. You can get beautiful views over the city.

Was expecting more. The Castle is beautiful from afar and adds to the landscape of the city. We had a private tour guide and he certainly knew what he was doing when we took a bus to the Monastery and started from there. This meant that we walked DOWN to the Castle rather than up. If you are planning on walking to the castle from the Charles Bridge, it is a long uphill climb. The outside of the castle is beautiful and I was happy to have a guide to bring the history of the city to life for us. It was very busy and honestly, we didn't see much of the inside of the castle at all, very disappointing. The Golden Lane area was very interesting but again very crowded. It took us a long time to exit as there is only one narrow doorway through which the crowd of people have to go through one at a time. I personally enjoyed the Jewish Quarter and Old Town more.

Where to begin? Brilliant!. Where do you begin? The sheer size of this place makes you forget you’re walking through a castle. Visible from almost anywhere in Prague, it sure is a sight to behold and enjoy whilst you can. We never did a tour of it as walking through was enough for us, but in hindsight I was we had. It’s also SO busy with tourists, if you have little ones, make sure they’re attached! The palace gardens are also very nice to talk a little walk through on a nice day and if you like tree’s, you’re in for a treat. If you’re in Prague, check out the castle, you can’t miss it.

Great view over the city and good to see anyhow. Take the time to come up here either by walking or public transport. We had a guide tell us about the history of the area, but even without you can still have a nice experience up here. Views are really good from up here as well.

Go with a guide to the Castle area. Unless you are familiar with this part of Prague, and I. Order to fully appreciate the area, it's buildings and the history, I would recommend you went with a guide able to explain to you the complex history behind many of the castles, palaces, churches and buildings in general that surround this area. The history is fascinating, and a guide will certainly enhance your visit to the area. If you have trouble with walking take a taxi ride up there from the town, you can come down the same way or by the vaniccula.

Welcome to Prague (Dobre Den). Walking through Old town, over Charles Bridge, then off through Mala Strana, going up the Hill/climbing the steps etc.This is a tourist paradise; so much to see, so much to admire, bazaar, lots of coffee shops and lots of restaurants on the way.So if you want to quench your thirst, want something to eat or want to buy a momento, icon or souvenir then you are in the right place.The only snag though is the cobblestone; better to wear trainers or comfy shoe

Pragues nr 1. together with the town square the castle district makes the trip to Prague special and different from other big cities. The compact area and all the lovelly buildings make it really unique. But it is allways packed with people.

Cobbled streets. My son lives in this most attractive area of PragueEvery street is an architectural pleasure...with lovely bars and shops to go to. The stroll down from this area is delightful but save some energy for walk back up if you are staying in this area!!!!

Beautiful view over Prague.. View over Prague. Walk up Nerudova Street and enjoy atmosphere.
You can find Prague Castle and St. Vitus Cathedral in there.

Lots of crowds. Interesting but brace yourself for a city of tourists. The walk from the old town to the castle is nice. The steps to the castle are steep but my 78 yr old mother had no problem with the hike.

A city within a city!!. The Castle District is huge! Allow plenty of time if you are trying to locate a particular place!! We enjoyed walking around just looking at everything!! We went on a week day & it was crowded, but pleasant enough. We heard from others that it was so crowded on the week-end they could barely move so they left.

Impressive!. We took the hop on, hop off bus to this district. Unfortunately, we only had 40 minutes, in the rain, to tour the area. It wasn't nearly enough. This is a half or full day tour. The cathedral of St. Vitus is here, along with the castle and all of the surrounding buildings. Wear your walking shoes and be prepared for long lines.

Where's the Castle. Went looking for the Castle only to discover its not really a castle as we understand. The center of the Castle precinct is a Cathedral and is surrounded by various buildings built over the centuries. We walked over from the old town via the steps and were welcomed by the views from the top. Although is isn't really a castle there is a lot of history linked to the cathedral and the surrounding palaces and churches. Well worth the visit, take time to read the information or listen to the guide if you take the tour. There is no fee to enter the precinct, however you need to pay if you enter any of the buildings.Changing of the guard is worth watching, not quite the sharpness of the guard at Buckingham Palace however very entertaining and colourful. Be early to get a good viewing spot as it is a popular event - 12:00 each day.

Breathtaking. Once the initial charm of Prague has sunk in - take a trip to the Castle District and be even more amazed. Breathtaking views!Recommend taking the tram or bus up the hill but walk back down via the steps to finish an outstanding visit

A piece of history. Toured the castle precinct with a private guide which gave a good insight into the history of Prague over the centuries. worth the expense as one gains so much more understanding into the history of the Czech nation.
Excellent tour guide.. We had Bianca an excellent tour guide for Prague. We had a 4 hour tour and covered all the major sites in Prague.
A long day. You will not believe the size of this castle. A city by itself. You can spend hours if not days touring the grounds and buildings

Spread out your tours. The Castle is more of an area rather than an actual castle. And it is HUGE! You could easily spend two days here going through all of the different exhibits. We spent over three hours looking at just the castle history. I would recommend doing multiple tours but you might want to spread it out over a couple of days as it can be a bit overwhelming.

Impressive complex. I only had time for the "short tour" but have to say this is not the most impressive castle ( I liked Cesky Krumlov's better), but in its entirity, combined wiht the cathedral, and gardens this is an impressive complex, which took a good 3 hours to explore.It is not necessary to climb up the hill as mentioned in some other reviews. The #22 tram takes you all the way there.

The heart of Prag. The whole compound can be done on foot, takes half a day with the full entrance ticket: Lobkowicz Palace was our highlight with the paintings of B Canaletto and Brueghel, St Vitus Gothic Cathedral ,Golden Alley with Kafkas room and the Jewells of the crownroom.

All Inclusive Tour. The tour mentioned above bussed us to the castle. This place is huge and amazing between the old church and palace. The walk down the satirway to Old town is great and the walk over the Charles bridge is great also. Straight from the Charles bridge leads you to the old town square. What a delightful place.

Prague Castle - historic and beautiful. Sitting up on the mountain, regal and beautiful, Prague Castle is a beautiful part of the history and soul of Prague. It is lovely to visit and I highly recommend it to you.
Wow - but -. Amazing and surprising that so much has remained to be seen and appreciated. A LOT of tours and crowds in the morning =not as bad in the afternoon

great views of the city. the image that immediately comes in kind when thinking of Prague is that of those red roofed buildings. This spectacle of the city is visible from atop the Prague castle. The cathedral inside the castle complex is quite enormous. The emotionless and undeterred guards are a fun to watch.

Spend some time there to enjoy & learn. We bought the 350 Kc ticket and did about half of the sights before our energy ran out. Do the Golden Lane at some time in the middle of your visit as it's a fun part of the visit and you don't want to slight it due to fatigue.
Excellent. Lots of walking and exceptional views to be got from here. Watch the changing of the guards.They also have concerts here and they are really good.

Lovely place to wander. We wandered around the streets of the castle district which is yet another fairly tale like place lots of little cobbled streets with amazing glimpses of beautiful buildings. We found the souvenir shops to be a little more expensive on this side of the bridge but nothing that will break the bank. Again people were friendly helpful & not pushy .

Be prepared to walk. The castle district begins after a climb of several flights of stairs, unfortunately there is no other way up so do bring a pair of sturdy walking shoes. About half way there is an entrance to St. Wenceslas vineyard. They offer fermented grape juice which is extremely delicious! Certainly a must try. You can walk through the vineyard for rest of the way or continue through the stairs. The entrance is marked with a guard post, whose guards are trained not to move no matter how much you try. Once inside you will directly encounter Lobkowicz Palace or you can go on towards Prague Castle & St Vitus Cathedral which is located right next to it. Go for the castle first, as entrance to the inner chapel's of the cathedral is included in the castle admission fee.

Excellent. Loved everything about this area. Lots of great shops and restaurants. Lovely atmosphere - even when it's raining! Not to be missed. Suggest accessing this area via the Old Town Square, Charles Bridge, and then over the bridge. Great evening walk.

Do not miss atmosphere. A bit off the mainstream of the Prague central but provides a sense of the life of the city and pleasant uncrowded appreciation of the environment and culture. Small shops, gardens, military processions fill the surroundings.
Great History. Loved the architecture and the variation. A great concentration of history. Loved the art and the fact that I could get so close to it.

Excellent tour. This tour was in a brochure at the hotel and it was worth the money around £40 for 2. The reception organised it and we were picked up at the hotel, transported to Wencleslas Square were the tour began and finished. The guide was good and the sights were great as was the weather that day. The castle area is lovely the information and recent history was good.
Love!. Fabulous part of town to wander around! Lots of cute gift shops and different places to look at. We found some great, cheap souvenirs here!

Mostly free and plenty to see. Make your way from either Charles bridge or nearby road bridge. Either way you will find yourself climbing a steep stairway.The gardens on the south side , closest to the river, are lovely and have been mainly restored.There are plenty of places to sit and picnic or take in the views across to the old and new towns.Inside the complex you will find the cathedral which is chargeable but free if you just want to look at the immediate inside area. When leaving via steps towards Charles bridge end there are some lovely coffee shops which are a lot cheaper than in the town and great for a break before visiting St Nicholas church.
Beautiful gardens.. The gardens are beautiful peaceful and well worth a visit. Take time to wonder around and enjoy not only the gardens but beautiful views.
Beautiful!. Pay attention to the free guide tours going around the district, is a great way to know the history from this awesome place!

Heart of Prague. I absolutely loved it - wandering around the Castle is like a time travel. Definitely a must-see. Don't forget about the gardens and wear some good shoes, because seeing everything requires a lot walking.

Busy. You need to spend a full day here to see everything. We caught the changing of the guard which occurs every hr. The architecture is beautiful on all the buildings. We walked back down the hill though didn't attempt to walk up to the castle. There are plenty of cafes, restaurant's and shops in this area though expensive. Its an enjoyable walk around this beautiful area.

Make sure you visit but don't buy the ticket immediately. The castle district is mainly free to visit, but if you want to go inside the buildings then you will need a ticket. However all of the buildings allow non ticket holders to go inside a bit. There you can decide if it's actually worth going inside. If you have been to other historic palaces then you may find this one slightly disappointing so buying the ticket may not be worth it and with many of the buildings, the ticket does not offer significantly enough over what you can see for free to justify it.One must visit inside the castle district is the Golden Lane - especially the free to visit weaponry museum located at the entrance to the lane. You will find some very interesting and creative weaponry there and this place was certainly the highlight of my visit to the castle area.
Beautiful. I loved this place. My hotel was located here and the view was fantastic. One can see entire city from this place. It has good restaurants.

magical. If you enjoy something different from your trip then visit the castle at noon each day to see the changing of the guards.The buildings are beautiful and the scenery from the top of castle hill is fantastic.

A magnificent Edifice. Excellent view of the great castle. Magnificent Cathedral and great view of Changing of the Guards. Who would not visit Prague without paying a visit here. I could not visit this in 1973 because of government restrictions.
Amazing. Would definitely reccomend to visit. Spare some time, but prepare for numerous atractions through the whole old town
Could easily spend a whole day here. So much to see! We were on a walking tour which was helpful, it's great place for photos since it's high on a hill and you can see the city of Prague.
Do the castle tour. I did a paid tour around the castle and it was more than worth it. You get all the story background with a very very nice walk, Also the view from upthere is truly amazing

The view. In the downtown you can pay for going upstair the tower to have a panoramic view of the city. Well, here in the Castle district you can have one for free and accessible for wheelchairs (beside the characteristic rock made floor).

Stunning...but beware of pickpockets!. It's free to stroll around the castle area which is great as you can pick and choose which parts you want to pay to visit. The views are stunning and so are the stained glass windows in the cathedral. However my experience was somewhat marred by the fact that I caught a pickpocket trying to open my bag while lining up for the toilets! She pretended to be pushing in to the line and as she pushed she was actually opening my bag. Luckily I cottoned on and slapped her hand away before she took off but this could have ended rather badly. The toilet attendant was looking as this happened and did nothing (She may not have realised what was going on) but this did make me a bit suspicious.
prague. Spend the day in the castle district. There is lots of small shops and restaurants. Food is not to expensive. You can get there by tram and there is lots to do, see and taste.

Beautiful. If you live castles. Visit this district. You need a good walking shoes to explore this big complex. It has buildings thats amazingly designed. Cafes and starbucks inside the castle. Watch the change of guards every hour. Its fascinating.
Make time for this. Stare Mesto gets all the press, but it is worth walking around in this part of the city. It's quaint and it provides easy access to the Castle itself and the St. Vitus Cathedral.
The costs. It was too expensive. You have to pay for nearly everything, but it is very interesting and beautiful.
A lot to see. The cathedral was simply mindblowing. The rest of the castle beautiful. We took the audio guides, and it was worth it.

Plan to spend the whole day!. The Prague castle is amazing in every way. So much history everywhere you look. Pay the extra amount (around $2 per person) and get an English guide if you do not speak Czech. Your castle ticket will get you in to the different areas two times, so plan to spend the whole day. You could easily spend hours just in St. Vitus Cathedral. Definitely spend time on the Golden Road, see the castle gardens, and enjoy an amazing view of Prague from the castle wall. Incredibly beautiful and very romantic. Also, at 12:00 you can see the changing of the guard at the gate.

Definitely walk around. Great to stroll through. Lots of different things to see and visit. Go back late at night and the grounds are open till 12am. Really great to see the area not crowded and lit up.

Great area particularly the golden mile. Must visit area of Prague. Particularly loved the Golden Mile (which is now a paid attraction) which shows the old streets, houses and shops of centuries past. Full of tourists which makes moving difficult in such a narrow space but still a must see area.

First time into the park. I have been to this area 3 times, and I walked into the Castle, just to walk out to get to the park with the Palace. I had never been there before. It was raining all day, and there was a food festival going on. (A very wet one!)
Interesting and beautiful. The buildings were very interesting to go in and so beautiful. Don't miss the toy museum! It was excellent and fun! Well worth the price of admission!

Easy to pass a day here. The whole area around and including the castle has a nice feel, the castle itself is well worth visiting (short tour takes a couple of hours) then there are the gardens, shopping streets, restaurants etc. all of which add to the atmosphere

A good high point to view Prague.. You can visit the Castle by either tram or the metro. There is also a steep walk up from the shops over Charles Bridge. - Getting off the metro also involves the same climb. The is lots to see in the Castle District and you can quite easy spend several hours there.

Don't Fear the Crowd. Be brave to hike and walk uphill but worth it when you reach the destination, do the stroll as fun walk, always give yourself a rest, shop, look and perhaps grab your favorite flavor of ice cream - it's the essence of travel- don't fear the crowd but instead realized that fear makes strangers of people who should be friends...

A lot has changed in 20 years!. Having visited this area 20 years ago - when there was free access to everything, we found it a bit confining now with lots of lines of people and lots of areas roped off inside St Vitus. It's still worth going to see and the walk back down is very picturesque.
High & Dry. A lot of history, statues and things to see. Don't walk in the golden street, seems to be too pricy for nothing. It's a long walk but worth the while if you like the view on the city :)

Fun Castle district. Take my advice. Shuttle or taxi up and walk down (unless you're a billy goat :D ) There's a restaurant at the very top that has a million dollar view of Prague. At least have a beer there but the food is good too. Standard tourist shops. Save your money for the market in town for souvenirs.

Attractions within a compound. The castle district/area is a huge compound uphill with several attractions all within walking distance of each other. Not including the gardens, there are at least 10 attractions (buildings) and there are often temporary art exhibits too. There are some amazing historical monuments, some trying too hard, some too touristy and some just less interesting. It really half great, half OK. To visit here or anywhere in Prague in summer, you must really have the patience and energy to deal with the crowds followed by the usually super rude-curt front line staff in ticket offices, restaurants,shops etc. There is so much to see here that it feels almost exhausting, I would suggest doing it in 2 days but that means you'll have to climb uphill twice (perched on the top). Within almost each attraction, there is a café or restaurant so you wouldn't need to leave the area for lunch. We did trudge downhill a bit out of the compound thinking it would be better, not much difference really. Like the rest of Prague, you are bombarded with souvenir stores or anything that could be sold to a tourist. It's Day 6 of our 14 day trip in Prague and I am quite sick of the rudeness and curtness. It's the worse in Europe I've encountered (and I travelled widely in France, been to Spain, Italy, Greece, Vienna, London). Most people do not speak English

Nice area and castle. We live in Prague and like to go there for a walk or to see any of the interesting exhibitions that are held in the Prague Castle. The castle is the very important historical place for our country, it was the seat of the Czech rulers. You can see permanent exhibition about the castle history " The Story of the Prague Castle" in the Old Royal Palace". I would also suggest to take a walk in the Royal garden and go to the Belvedere - the summer villa of queen Anna.

Beautiful architecture. The whole grounds were beautiful and well kept. the buildings were lovely to look around and we took and well needed stop in a cafe in the grounds and enjoyed a cool drink and something to eat sat in the shade of the parasols.
Changing of the guard-Great!. Love the castle area....watching changing of theguard very interesting. I have no dislikes to report.

Amazing Views. The castle itself is lovely, I first visited this at night with my partner as the hotel we were staying at recommended to see it at night plus it was less crowded, stunning views over Prague a must see. We visited it in the day time too where it was flogged with tourists but in the Castle it was beautiful.

Nice area - but not exactly a "castle". Not the typical castle I would think of, but I really enjoyed the castle district! You should definitely try and find a beer garden while on this side of the river! Check out the cathedral!

a good walk. this is a trip for a walker with a good pair of shoes and a camara!! if i remember rightly there is a john lennon wall and a lock bridge if like me you have placed a lock in every place you travel.

Takes you back in time. A great deal of attractions with a fantastic view .Walk over Charles Bridge and up the steep hill to the castle at the top for a stunning view of the city. The changing of the guard is well worth seeing too. Make sure you go early before the great unwashed arrive in their tour buses and befor I gets too hot.

Best part of Prague!. This is the best attraction in Prague, bar none. We gave ourselves three hours to go through with a private guide and it still wasn't enough; we wanted to go back again and stay longer, but it just didn't work out. The complex is absolutely huge, so make sure you allot plenty of time for this magnificent complex.

It.... makes you feel you traveled back in time. We liked the Golden lane and again I was surprised we needed the ticket to enter the street. It was not the case 20 years ago when my father took me there,

Worth the trip. OK, you have to walk up the hill but once there it is unbelievable. There are several tour options available. I was rushed as we weren't in Prague for long, but I would go back and just spend the day here and have a tour of the entire grounds.

a bit touristy. good walking tour around the Castle Hill area and the church. The newer parts look very disneyland as I think they are meant to be but if you stick to the older stuff its well worth the visit.

more beautiful architecture, cobblestones galore!. we wandered around the castle and went up into the the structure but did not pay to enter the inner buildings. It was well worthwhile, nonetheless. Views of the city are fabulous.

Great place, great views. A great deal of the attractions can be visited free of charge - if you want to see the old royal palace etc., you have to buy a ticket, but you can even visit St Vitus (yes, you can see only a limited portion of it, but nevertheless). The gardens are a real delight to visit. Food/ drink is of course rather expensive, so if you're on a budget, go elsewhere for that.

Fantastic. We visited the Monastery, Castle and Cathedral. It was the highlight of our visit to Prague. We also saw the gardens before we went up the hill. All worth it. We too tram 22 from Old Town to the area which was crowded but an interesting experience.

Hradcany has heaps to see. The whole area around the castle abounds with history and interesting eating houses. Visited as many palaces and museums as possible (forgot names), two minutes from the castle. Again, the Prague card comes in handy and the military museum is amazing. Still has cold war feel but the historical aspects of the area are great.

Top attraction at the top of the city, great views and architecture. Walk over Charles Bridge and up the steep hill to the castle at the top for a stunning view of the city.
The changing of the guard is well worth seeing too.
Make sure you go early before the great unwashed arrive in their tour buses and befor I gets too hot.

Not your usual castle. This complex was amazing!! Not your usual castle with turrets and motes. This is quite a conglomeration of buildings with an interesting story. We were lucky enough to witness the "Changing of the Guards", which they take very seriously. Reminded me of Buckingham Palace, only a slightly smaller scale. It is definitely worth exploring.

Have to see the inside and the outside of the Castle to appreciate it as a whole.. The Castle audio recording was helpful. We did the recommended short tour and found it was enough. We walked around the neighborhood and surrounding area rest of the day on our own.

The Castle. It is everything that the guide books say it is, so take the time to visit. See the gardens and walk the long stairway down to Lesser Town. The best entrance is behind, not where nearly everyone starts out.

Don't miss the changing of the guards. The whole casle district is very interesting and it takes some time to see everything.Changing of the guards at 12:00 every day is very impressive.Rent an audio guide -it helps a lot.
This was very interesting. Our guide took us around this district and shared the history and the struggles the Czech people have had. Very interesting

Absolutely magnificent!. You have to be dedicated to hike the 300 some stairs to get here, but it's so worth it! (I guess you could take a taxi if you're lazy.) The architecture and size of the buildings in this area is just extraordinary. On the day we were there, a couple was getting married in one of the fairy-tale castles.

Get your walking in!. You get plenty of exercise walking the many stairs around here. On a hot sunny day, like the one we experienced would drench you while doing it too. Castle district is very interesting with beautiful architecture, fancy gardens, beer pubs, many souvenir stores and uniformed guards who walk to their positions where they stay put for hours without any movement. Again, if you get a tour guide or get closer to a group who is using one, you hear very interesting anecdotes. One needs time to explore the area, little by little.

Must see stop when in Prague!. We loved this area and went 3 times during our stay. There are many things to see and do. We enjoyed the Castle tour, Lobkowicz Palace, St. Vitus Cathedral as well as St. George's Basilica. We also enjoyed walking through the gardens and walking behind the castle area and stopping for ice cream. Be sure to watch the changing of the guards at noon as the ceremony is very special.

Not to be missed. You need at least four hours to do this justice, and every part is different. The old church of St Vitus is magnificent, and you must see a concert in the old circular church at the end of the Castle complex.
Fantastic views. Very nice views from the top of the castle. Seeped in history and tradition, its quite a calm and tranquil place even with the hordes of tourists around!

Can't miss. No one should miss this this Castle if you are in Prague. In Prague this is the most visited castle. Although I would not term it as huge, it is a venue that you must visit. There are beautiful chandeliers, fairylike stories to be told about Kings, Queens, Princesses etc. Its like living in a fairy tale book. So please go there and take lots of photos. You can take photos from the outside anyway.

Hradcany - Lots to see in the Castle District. Hradcany, also referred to as the 'Castle District' is one of the ten listed old districts of Prague. It is located just beyond Mala Strana - 'Lesser Quarter' and is the location of Prague Castle and other impressive attractions that you can spend a couple of days visiting during a holiday to Prague. Like Mala Strana, there are many quaint alleyways and passage streets that make this a nice area to simply spend time. However, its the major attractions set this area apart from other districts in the city. Obviously, Prague Castle is the main feature in the area. Here you can visit a handful of interesting attractions, including the Old Royal Palace, Golden Lane, Rosenberg Palace. Within the castle grounds you can also visit St. Vitus Cathedral, This Gothic masterpiece is the biggest and most important church in the country and one of our favourites of this architectural style in all of Europe. Other very good attractions in the Hradcany District include the Strahov Monastery, Loreta Monastery and Treasury and Schwarzenberg Palace amongst others. Predictably, cafes, restaurants and souvenir shops a plenty can be found in this area as well. Hardcany, having an elevated position over the city, affords some very pleasant viewpoints as well. We much enjoy those found at the Strahov Monastery as well as those seen from Prague Castle, particularly the walkway leading to the eastern gate. Overall, we enjoy spending time visiting the attractions of Hradcany District. While we prefer Mala Strana a bit more personally, this is a highly recommendable area of Prague to spend time during visits to the city.

Impressive!. The sheer scale of this area is hard to imagine. The castle, cathedral and surrounding buildings are on a grand scale. Can be a little crowded but this does not detract too much from the sightseeing. Need some space then visit the lovely gardens below the castle that have fine views across the city.

Stunning Views. The spectacular view from this highest part of Prague is well worth the climb. You will have a panoramic view of the city with its many red roofed houses and bridges - makes you want to stay longer just looking at the landscape. Very beautiful indeed!

Great day. From the cathedral to the historical exhibits, the galleries and Golden Lane, the castle was a wonderful and long day out. We got the all inclusive senior pass for the castle area which was a bargain at about $10 each for all entrance fees. Most impressive for us was St. Vitus Cathedral.

39 Steps, try 299. Beautiful vieews across the city, amazing achitecture of a bohemian, baroque style that blows your mind. The detail on every building is stunning, you could spend hours just looking at the houses in this beautiful area of the town..

You need lots of time, so much to see. I believe this is the larges castle grounds in the world. there are so many buildings most of which are terrific museums and galleries now. Make sure you leave enough time to see as much as possible.

wonderful sights. there are several sights within this small area. St vitus cathedral, castle, monastery. You need to be fit to climb up and down though- climbing up the cobblestoned streets is not easy

Beautiful Views!. The Palace is another location one cannot miss when in Prague. It is situated at the highest point of the city and offers amazing views of the city below, in itself making the trip worthwhile. The Castle itself was interesting, but not as elaborate or ornate as I had imagined it would be. The walk around the area is really the best part or the visit because you get an incredible panorama or the landscape, the river, and the whole city.When making your way down on foot, beware, it's a steep incline and my sister fell quite badly. So watch your feet, because the cobbles are often uneven or missing(!!)

Thought I was in Vienna. What is great about the castle district is that you could never imagine how well all this building are maintained and still intact. You can really enjoy all the different styles. I sometimes thought I was in Vienna.Go watch at the Matthias Gate for the changing of the watch. This happens every hour. If you go around noon there is more than 2 guards changing you will see a small army parading and there is even a small band there. Must SeeIf you like to visit Golden Alley, wait till after 5 in the afternoon. After this entrance is free, be aware there will be plenty of tourists in this side of the castle district.

So Much to See In One Spot. We did an evening tour of the Castle district before dinner. Our tour guide was very personable and gave great descriptions of each of the buildings we passed. There are small winding streets, beautiful old palaces, the huge castle and tremendously impressive cathedral. Its a fantastic neighborhood with gorgeous views.

Totally worth the entry fee !!. We went up the castle district by Tram.The Castle complex comprises of 4 main parts - St Vitus Cathedral, Old Palace, Basilica of St. George and Golden Lane.St Vitus Cathedral is the MOST gorgeous church that we have ever seen, has Gothic architecture and is the largest & most important Cathedral in the country.It houses the tombs of many Roman Emperors and Bohemion kings.The old palace is a castle where the Bohemian Crown jewels are kept and where the kings held their courts.St. George's basilica is the oldest surviving Church building in Czech Republic dated 920 AD. It has a Gothic Style chapel and holds the tombs of several Saints. The Abess of this Church had the right to crown the Bohemian Queens consort.The Golden Lane is an olden lane dating from the 15th century and has an old world charm to it. It contains 11 historical houses, inside which period scenes have been created to show the life of the artisans who lived there.The upper levels of the houses are connected and have a display of medieval armory and textiles.There was a torture chamber, house & workshop of an alchemist, goldsmith, army man, etc.

Fascinating array of winding streets and small squares. From across the river the castle district looks a bit underwhelming with the main building looking more like a government office than a Castle or Royal Palace but is well worth the effort to visit with buildings and architecture on a par with the famed old town.Walk across Charles Bridge but rather than just hike straight up to the castle lose yourself in the side streets and just keep heading upwards. Truly one of those times when the journey is more fun than the end location.

An enjoyable area. With the Cathedral, museum, government buildings, this is a very interesting place. We spent the biggest part of an entire day there. We had lunch in the Lobkowicz Palace Cafe. We also saw the changing of the guard, toured the Cathedral and Museum.

Great views from the castle on the hill. Prague Castle is a site not to be missed on a visit to Prague. I suggest taking a guided tour so that you can get some history to go with the historical buildings you will visit. The area is quite hilly, so be sure to have on good walking shoes. It is all cobblestone streets on uneven surfaces, so use caution. You most likely will see wedding couples having their pictures made when in this area, because evidently lots of couples come to Prague to get married and only have a photographer with them to take pictures to show family back home. You can take some great photos of the old town from this hillside location. Be sure you go on a clear day!
Amazing area. With the Castle of Hracany and St Vitus as the center points you can explore a amazing area of history

"A village, not a castle"~Empress Maria Teresa. This place is a conglomerate of many different types of buildings. You can explore for hours and keep finding hidden gems. Walk through the castle itself as well as the surrounding gardens. Also, try the chocolate muffin in the cafe by St. Vitus Cathedral. Yum!!!

Don't miss the Golden Lane!. Did you remember those little towns with many pastel colored tiny houses, with glass windows full of folk art, candies, and dried flowers that we saw on the fairy tale books or in our dreams? Like that is the Prague Castle Golden Lane, don't miss to visit the place, enjoy every detail, and buy an antique, a wooden toy or a dancing puppet.

Great location to stay. I stayed in this area on my visit to Prague, and I felt it was a perfect location. Close to the castle and all of the attractions on this side of the river, and a great place to come back to after a night out on the other side of the river, without all of the noise and disruption that hardcore partiers can cause if you stay in the busy district.Climbing to the highest area of Hradcany can provide great views over Prague, and fantastic photos featuring Charles Bridge.
St. George´s basilica -castle.. Opera performance (From Smetana - Brahms) excellent! The singer (sopran) the best you can imagine (I even compare with performances in the Met).

Fantastic preservasion. Loved all monuments included in my short visit ticket. Golden Lane is the most picturesque place in the whole complex of the Castle. Poping in and out of the tiny houses is great fun!

Great views over the city. Take the tram to the back of the castle and avoid the steep climb then take one of the steep paths back down to the lesser district. Don't just spend time inside the castle walls, explore the streets around the castle as well.
castle view is awesome. castle view is awesome along with M1 bar and bombay bar... party all night with lots of people and food joints open all nioght

very nice. Well this is a very nice place to wander arround. I visited the interior of most (accesible) building and they are nice but the outside is even better and FREE. I suggest to mostly walk around during the early evening since it"s less crowded then.

Amazing. I made a review of Saint Vitus cathedral that is inside the Castle.- All in the Castle is amazing from the Powder tower to the colorful tiny houses.- It will take a good amount of time to visit (and enjoy) it.- As in the case of the Cathedral the 22 tram takes you from downtown to the very doors of the Castle.-
Simply beautiful. We went later in the day and found it a bit less crowded. Be prepared to hike back down to the "lesser town" after you tour castle area.
Favorite area. This was a great area to visit. It is a MUST SEE area when visiting Prague. There are cute little shops & a great view of the city.

plenty to see. We bought a ticket to see all of the Castle District attractions and spent a very pleasant morning there (Palace, Basilica of St George, Picture galery, Golden Lane, Powder Tower, St. Vitus's cathedral, Rosenberg Palace - cost 350Kc (about $18 - half this for seniors in June 2013) good for two days. We didn't see it all before heading off for lunch and were too busy seeing other things (lots to see in Prague) next day to go back. Highly recomended.

Let time take you away!. We were very lucky to see several brides walking in the Castle district, which seems to be a tradition here. I suppose it is because the roads and buildings make it a very relaxing and peaceful place. I really enjoyed soaking in the atmosphere and the fantastic city views.

Beautiful Area of Prague. We walked all around the castle district starting at Lohorec tram stop all the way down the hill to the castle and to the Charles Bridge. Be sure to hit the rocking horse toy shop. It is on the right side of the road from Lohorec to the Castle. Surprisingly there were few tourists until we go to the actual castle.

Worth the hike.. I visited this area twice during my 5 night stay in Prague. My first visit was at about 9pm on a warm summers evening. There were very few people around and The St Vitus Cathederal was bathed in sunlight making for great photographic opportunities. A couple of days later the Palace Guard put on a free display in freezing cold weather and I bought a 300kr ticket that gave access to most but not all buildings in this area. The powder room holds an interesting collection of uniforms, history and arms belonging to the Palace Guard and would keep kids amused, there is also a collection of armour in the Golden Lane area which is pretty but busy.To do this area justice you need a day, but if on a tight budget or pushed for time a free stroll round is equally as pleasant. The area is surrounded by some pleasant restaurants and bars, the better ones being further up the hill. For a small additional charge there is nearby toy museum full of Barbie Dolls. Beware of the cafe in this vicinity as refreshments are expensive as it is a tourist trap and I was short changed.
Majestic Castle. We enjoyed the Changing of the Guard along with hundreds of others. There are many gates and courtyards to visit including the Cathedral in the centre.
Beautiful. Fantastic views, well worth the walk up. Pay for the ticket to get in St Vitus, you only see a small amount for free from the door & the other churches & pay areas are well worth while
Castle district. An amazing little city in itself lots to see and amazing views across the city, unlike the traditional British castles

Superb Buildings. Rain, rain, rain, rain. What can I say. The weather spoiled this excursion. The gargoyles poured water which just added to the wetness. We walked down the 101 steps. We intended going back on Monday, but Prague was closed. We could not get out. What we were able to see was lovely.

Tour....... Booked the Tour - walking from the Castle downhill after being collected by our bus, then to our Boat on the River, up to the Bridge, all main aspects pointed out by amazing informative guides, a brilliant day......................

Great place to visit. Really nice place, just as large as it seems. Beautiful, clean, fantastic architecture, history... The only downside for us was the fact that they charge to get into some parts and pickpockets were highly visible, so just watch your stuff, but it should nto take away from your enjoyment of the whole site.

Fascinating castle and surrounds. We loved the experience of visiting the Castle and its surroundings. The views of Prague from the top were spectacular. One can buy a ticket which includes parts of the castle and St Vitus cathedral, both of which are well worth visiting. The art gallery and Treasury are separate tickets. I found the Treasure truly fascinating - wonderful treasures belonging to past royalty and the Churches.Priceless jewels, reliquaries, monstrances and religious vestments. The St Vitus Cathedral has a wealth of history to discover and the stained glass windows are incredibly beautiful. At 12 noon one can see the changing of the Guards at the Palace Gate which is really fascinating. The area has pleasant gardens and outdoor restaurants. The area is a must, when visiting Prague.
Must see location. This district has the best views over Prague, good gardens and impressive buildings. Make a day of it taking the tram up, then go down through the gardens.
Nice walk to the Prague Castle. When we went to Prague Castle, we walked to it which was a good idea going through this neighbourhood. It is full of pretty small restaurants and shops.
Requires lots of time. What a fantastic area.Be prepared to spend a few hours having a good look.Picture gallery interesting plus the old royle castle.

Hire a guide!. We really enjoyed the castle and the castle district, but you should know that there is very little narrative in English. We certainly enjoyed the place, but would have enjoyed it more with some narrative on the importance of what we were viewing. Only the castle itself has narrative in English--and although it is interesting, it was a little bland. We tried to hire a guide when we bought our ticket, but one wasn't available for over an hour. In hindsight, I would have gone on the castle tour with a guide that we met in the square (Keith... from California... wears a green shirt). I think I would have enjoyed it even more with his type of narrative giving lots of interesting facts.Also, be aware that the castle is really a castle (not a palace). It isn't really much to look at inside, but the views from the balconies are worth going in for. St. Vitus Cathedral is gorgeous--worth a visit (again... with a guide). We also went to St. George's Basilica. This was interesting, and we knew that there must some importance, but without any narrative in English we really didn't appreciate what we were looking at until after we had left. Again--you really could use a tour guide. When you arrive, you can buy either a short tour ticket or a long tour ticket. We did the short tour, and I was happy with that. We spend 3-4 hours just doing the short tour, and I was pretty tired of walking by that point. I'm not sure we would have gotten our money's worth of the long tour.

Amazing views interesting history. This has got one of the best views of Prague. It is pretty steep walk so we took Tram no 22 from city centre and it took about 20 minutes to get there. It has lot of old historically famous buildings and monuments and pretty gardens. There are lot if people visiting this so give yourself about 3-4 hours to see and visit everything.

Great place. The district is fabulous and worth visiting, but it's crowded (what a shame). But the visitors have good reason for going there. If you go to Charles bridge, you get a nice view of the whole district.

Lovely day. I spent a whole day wandering the grounds and the streets...it's very beautiful and offers the best view - in my opinion - of Prague. If you walk. Expect a tiring hike up the hill. Otherwise you can take the tram. Lots of great things to see and some nice restaurants too.
Great place. We didn't do the whole tour but still we spent more than 3 hours there and it was great. Don't miss the cathedral and the Golden Lane.

Lovely area. I really enjoyed wandering around this area. There are some amazing buildings and corners to visit. We visited late afternoon so there wasnt too many people walking around. Take your time to wander and explore. And it offers the best views of Prague.
Attractive Castle and District. I went to see the Castle with it's old architecture and surrounding buildings beautifully decorated.There are lots of hidden sites to see there also.

A core area of interst in prague. a core area of interest in prague, the most important and one of the oldest churches of prague, the old royal palace, the lobkowicz palace and museum, the national gallery are here. the Loreto sacred place is nearby.

Culture, history and art.. Allow a full day here as there is so much to do. The castle, beautiful gardens and art galleries. Leave time to wander slowly back down to the city centre on foot if you can as it takes you through some amazing scenery and places such as Golden Lane.

Must see most of all. Changing of the guard at 12 noon is a must see at the palace.
see the band play from the castle windows.Make your way back down through the castle`s beautiful gardens

Area of contrasts. We spent the best part of a day here, lots of grand buildings and the magnificent cathedral, but we loved the little houses on Golden Lane, such a contrast. A fun way of getting there from the Old Town Square is the little tourist train.

Amazing complex. Many important monuments are very close together, packed. The most beautiful is the cathedral with splendid glass panels. It was finished in 1929 , 4 centuries after they started to build it.
a must see. The castle complex was fascinating. great architecture and a look into historic Prague. great views of the city.
Walking the streets is a definite work out!. Take a day to walk up to the castle and enjoy the surrounding areas. It is different from the Old Town and the views from on high are spendid.
Unique. The atmosphere makes you think that you are in a fairytale or in an old movie.There are so many steps, but they are worth it.

Huge complex with diverse things. We started our morning here on a Prague tour. Glad the bus took us to the top of the hill. Then we only had to walk down after seeing the castle grounds.There are many wonderful buildings on the grounds including St Vitas cathedral which was really good. Would recommend a guide book or live guide to fully understand all that is here. Allow enough time to walk through it.Good photo ops and views from the castle.

Beautiful place. The castle grounds we're beautiful and the st virus cathedral is gorgeous. I did go on a tour or into the cathedral, but it was lovely to walk around the grounds and we had a drink on the terrace near the Marilyn Monroe exhibition which was lovely and a drink and snack in a cafe next to the toy museum which was also very pleasant. I don't find the place very 'castle like' its more like a town with a moisture of very old buildings from different eras surrounding a cathedral. However it is a beautiful place and the history as why the stale is all so different I'm sure is fascinating (I probably would have found this out on a tour) the changing of the guard was great to watch! Very pomp! The walk down to mala strana (lesser town) was lovely too!

Spend the morning or afternoon here. Take the 22 tram to the top and walk through the whole Castle District. There is so much to see. The is the area where we walked the streets, the castle grounds which were beautiful, went into the St. Vitus Cathedral (there is a fee to go all the way in), saw the changing of the guards with trumpets, there are shops, café’s, and pubs (not overwhelming so) that made the day worthwhile even though it rained quite a bit.

A Must See. It is obvious that this is one of the top destinations when visiting Prague and should not be missed. The focal point of this area is the beautiful St. Vitus cathedral with its stained glass windows, not to be missed. Visit also the Royal Gardens as a nice get away from the tourists in the square.
Castle?/Palace?. Whatever you call it, it's a really great view of the city with a flavor of the medieval era in which it thrived.

total enjoyment!. Total enjoyment! That is really worth a visit! There are a lot of beautiful buildings, most of them hotels, churches, pubs, and I must assure you that the castle district is one of the liveliest and prettiest places in Prague! Highly recommend it!
dont miss out at night. All the action of bars restaurants etc !! pretty and classy, enjoy the views and some of clubs are awesome, open till late !

Takes you back. I really enjoyed the preservation of this tight knit area. Many things to see and plenty of tourist information centers. I purchased the "short visit" card but sort of wished I had purchased the long visit as I wanted to see more when I was done. I have included in my review, a picture of the price list for the attractions and tour cards. I purchased the 50 koruna photo pass and at no point was I asked to show it when taking pictures inside the buildings. I think it's a safe bet to buy it as that is only about $2.50 to not have to sneak photos.

So much to look at and take in. Take your time wandering around the castle district and take it all in. Very busy so get there early or late afternoon, the bus tours pour in here. Beautiful architecture, heaps of history, beautiful gardens with amazing view. Don't rush through here.

Well worth the climb. Make sure that you reserve at least half a day for a visit to this magnificent castle. Two wonderful churches and plenty of other things to explore. Very nice cafe on the terrace when the weather is kind. Quite reasonably priced for what is on offer.

A wonderful area in Prague. The castle area is superb for tourists in that there is a lot to see in a small area. There are nice little restaurants and bars around and numerous routes to walk, including being able to walk through small vineyards. The views across Prague from the top are spectacular - so remember to take your camera! A must for all visitors to the city.

Views fantastic but very crowded!. Walk up to here is not for the unfit. Views are amazing. Changing of the guards ok. Don't forget your 10kr for the loo. Staff on these are awful aggressive. We arrived at 10am and it was already crowded bought a pass for 5 places. The small houses on the golden street worth a visit and probably what we enjoyed the most. Watch out for Chinese and Japanese camera MAD TOURISTS!!
Castle. Did the city bus tour and stopped here for 40 minutes - wonderful views and could happily have gone back for another day out.

Not enough time!. There just isn't enough time to get even the basics of the historical power of the castle district. So much to see, to learn, to study to truly appreciate how much history exists there.

Lived here for 6 months, it was lovely.. You'll come for the castle and it's well worth visiting. I wouldn't recommend eating/drinking in the area as you'll pay tourist prices, unless you're willing to go down the backstreets following and elusive "gambrinus" sign.
Awesome view of the city. Loved the view of the city, the change of the gaurds and the castle..took most of my pictures in this area.

Very impressive buildings. The Castle is very impressive, though you cannot go in to most of it, as it is used for government offices. Go there by tram, or use the hop on hop off bus - both drop you off very close to one of the entrances. En route to the castle, do not neglect to wander through the gardens to the left before you enter the castle. Entry is free, but there is a charge for a few areas. If you can visit to be there at 12 noon, you will see the change of the guard with much trumpet blowing and marching - well worth timing to coincide with this. You must go inside the cathedral while you are here, if only to admire the stained glass windows.
Beautiful. Great location, looking down onto the city of Prague. Large impressive building with the Cathedral behind. Worth seeing the changing of the guard
Loved it. Beautiful area to visit with all of its grandeur and history. We found it to be very clean despite all of the tourists

All who wander are not lost. Narrow cobbled streets winding up and around, secret gardens, ancient houses, a tavern or restaurant at every corner, what's not to like? You could measure distances in Prague like this: how many beers or beer gardens to such and such attraction? Take your time to just wander around this part of town. Less crowds, lots of parks and gardens, plenty of opportunities to stop and have a refreshing drink or snack.My favorite part of Prague.

A couple of other sights to see. Once you have explored the castle and cathedral I thoroughly recommend visiting the Loreta and Strahov manasteries. The church within the former has a breathtaking interior and the Strahov has a brewery; essential after all that kulture!!

Tickets, Tickets, Tickets. Quite a shock to discover that entrance to the Cathedral nave requires a ticket. First time for everything.Indeed most of the Castle complex requires a ticket.Still all its worth paying 150Czech crowns for the 287 steps of the South Tower for the views.

wonderful. Absolutely stunning castle, changing of the guard and the views from the cathederal, unfortunately whilst waiting for our bus myself and my wife saw a naked young female walk past with two camera men, my wife had the camera !!

Breathtaking views. Definitely my favourite part of visiting Prague. Besides all the buildings that make up an entire architectural complex, the views are breathtaking. You can see entire city of red roofs fromt here :) It might be a long walk, so take a map of trams and use one to get right there, on the hill, its possible.

Lovely day. A must for all visitors
Make sure you do the 12 noon changing of the guard
The gardens are nice and its a lovely walk round to or from Petrin hill

Still lots to do for free.... After a gorgeous but exhausting walk up the hill we arrived at the Castle. The view across Prague is stunning once you reach the top. You have to buy tickets to see the attractions, it is 250K for everything, Given all the different sites there are to see, it isn't that this is crazy expensive, it's more that is would take at least a full day (if not two) to see everything included in the ticket and if you haven't got that much time, it seems a waste. Even if you don't buy tickets to any of the attractions, it is still stunningly beautiful and worth just wandering around, taking in all the architecture.

Frozen in time. My walk started from the Royal Garden, going to the Prague Castle, St. Vitus Cathedral, Golden Lane, among others. This is easily one of the most scenic and most interesting places in Prague. I particularly love the Golden Lane, especially the models of old houses / shops during the old times. St. Vitus Cathedral is just jaw-dropping in scale and beauty. It is a long uphill climb up, but the view and the sights are very rewarding. A must-visit.

Nations pride and business machine. History, beauty and impressive architecture is among the very best in all world. -The art gallery is a gem not to be missed.The more the shame of complex and exspensive tickets system.-To have to pay to walk a street! This should be a symbol of independence annd democracy, not markets economics.

Art from every period.. The castle plateau contains an extraordinary medieval cathedral, a Romanesque church, several places, and government offices. There is also an old street called the Golden Lane in English. You have to pay to walk on it, and it is part of the shorter and longer tickets. Don't bother. I will repeat a comment I made under the Cathedral. Tickets are good for two days, and entrance is by electronic tickets with bar codes. The fees can be quite high, but they only let you in once. If you have visited the cathedral on one day, and want to go back the next, you can't do it without buying another ticket.

Amazing. Take the tram to the entrance it is quite a walk up hill. You need all day for this visit. There are several palaces and the church plus the Golden Lanes to see. Did not like paying for a long or a short visit too restricting. Cafe's were good.
Biggest castle in the world. Build in the 9th century. Has St. Vitus Cathedral in the complex. The castle has the offices of the President of the country.
typical historical buildings. very historical buildings. safe and nice neighborhood. nice architectural buildings to see. nice hustle bustle place to hang out and walk around

Beautiful. We got a tram up the hill to see this area and I am glad we did. This was a beautiful place with such pretty gardens and fountains and then the castle and surrounding buildings. The drinks and cafes here are very expensive as its a typical trap so its worth maybe taking a drink and a sandwich with you and enjoy them in the gardens.
Lovely church. Not much to see here, the golden mile was a disappointment. The church was nice especially as you see it's architectural progression through the years.

Made for Kings. We did an organized tour of this whole area that was very good. It was about a 90 minute tour that was offered by the City Tour company. Very informative. We stayed about 2 hours longer just exploring other things not covered in the tour, We had lunch in the courtyard café. But beware, they only take cash. I was surprised by how many tourist things did not take a credit card in Prague.

Impressive. The Prague Castle is immense and impressive filled with historical buildings and a lot of Czech history. Unless you are on a tour, there is significant walking required to get to and through the grounds...I suggest you climb the hill to enter and exit the other end via the stairs. Although claimed to be the biggest castle in the world, I would like to see it compared to the Nugyen Dynasty Castle in Hue, Vietnam, which dwarfs the Prague Castle with its grounds more than a mile and a half on a side!

Excelling views. We took tram 22 and went to the back of the castle and walked in that way. The guards were changing so that was a treat. The gardens are beautifully kept and the buildings are superb. We had both been in the castle and cathedral before so just walked down through the gardens and the steps to the bottom of the hill. Well worth it.

lovely views. we walked up to the castle a number 22 tram goes up but we read that it tends to attract the odd pickpocket.....the walk wasnt to exhausting....the views from the castle were lovely looking over prague. lots of nice bars within the castle district where you could watch the world go by.

Bring your walking shoes!. Not easy to reach if you don't come with a tour bus or car, but once you're there, breathtaking views and enough to keep you busy for even more than one day. And make sure you get to the castle at 10 mins to the hour to get a good spot for the hourly changing of the guard (and a major change at noon). Concerts at 1 PM daily as well. Lots goin' on!

A gentle approach through gardens and trees to the castle. Fabulous area with much to see and to do. Approaching it can be a climb up steep street or many, many stairs. Or, do as we did and walk gently up through the Letense Gardens. There are routes from river level from the Stefaniuv and Cuchuv Bridges - the latter connects directly (and quickly) via Parizska to the Town Square.

Must not be miossed. This is an old city in itself. The history of the castle is fascinating. Too much to explain here in a brief review but take a good guide book to Prague like the DK Eyewitness guidebook and you will easily spend a whole day in the castle.Don't miss the Golden Lane.
very interesting historical site. The Castle district is the richest historical place in the entire Prague area. Takes an entire day to see the most of the places.
Prague. We loved our visit here. The St. Vitus Cathedral and the Palace were wonderful. We walked all over the area and then walked back down to the Charles Bridge. This was a great value!

city break. Did this with a guide. Well worth paying as so much more information. Take the 22 tram to save the hike to the top. Changing of the guard ceremony well worth waiting to see. Walk back down and take in all the views
Dont miss Golden Lane. There is almost too mmuch to see in the Castle District - but all of it is good. However, the best and most interesting is Golden Lane - do not miss it.

Very packed, but worth seeing. Presidential residence. Old buildings undestirbuted by WWII. Was visited by 2 prior Popes. Better to go with tour guide so that you understand what its all about. Great view from area right outside back gate.
Beautiful view of Prague. If you visit Czech the must see is the castle not for itself but you shouldn't miss the view of whole Prague from castle wall.
Prague castle. After crossing the historic Chalres Bridge you walk up the trek to Prague Castle. There is a changing of the guard, and excellent hilltop views for picture taking of red roofs.

Beautiful to walk in.. This is a beautiful district to walk in, with lovely gardens, palaces and churches.
Do not miss the Royal gardens near the St. Vitus cathedral and the Belvedere building (and singing fountain), as they are simply stunning.

The "castle" didn't fit my idea of a true castle.. I know I was supposed to love the castle in Prague, but to me it's highly overrated. Yes, the area is big and dominates the city, but it's really more a series of palaces, churches, etc, than a castle. It felt a bit dead to me -- or maybe because it was springtime, and a bit on the cold side.

Fascinating. a lot of interesting buildings. Take your time to visit them. Admire the gargoils of S:t Vitus Cathedral. Of the galleries do not miss Sternberk Palac wit some marvellous paintings.
I strongly recommend you to have your lunch at Lobkowitcz Palace and sit in the terrace and enjoy the view of Prague

Great views. My wife and I did the castle tour straight after our free walking tour. We had a group of 6 which gave a more intimate feel and allowed the guide to explain things in more detail. This tour is definitely more tiring than the free walk, however the views and gardens at the top are great. The lasted around 2 hours, including the tram ride to the top of the castle district (included in the ticket price of 250 Czk)

The walk up is worth it. Great views over the city of Prague, although it is deceivingly high up so have comfy shoes on and plan a wee stop on route to replenish your strength. The bus and train tour trips do travel up here which may be an easier way to travel up at least.
far too busy. I liked the area but it was so busy all the time that it wasn't really a restful visit. Just too crowded for my taste.

The castle is one of the best parts of Prague!. The castle is like a medieval video game scene - really a great experience. The views over the city are fantastic. This part of the Prague experience is a must!
Impressive castle.. It was pleasant to walk around the confines of the castle, but we didn't have time to go inside. We would go inside next time, but be prepared to pay to view the different parts.

Some free, some not. This is not a traditional medieval castle, more like a palace, which it of course is. The Czech seem to have found a nice balance, give tourists some things for free and make them pay for some other areas of the palace.And the small cafe on the steps leading to the palace, pop in and have something. It's not the cheapest in Prague but you really don't pay for the coffee/tea/beer/whatever, you pay for the view of the city. And there you get what you pay for.
Rich in history. Again, I would suggest a tour guide, as it would not have been nearly as interesting without knowing history and details of much of what we were seeing.
Did the short tour. How could you go to Prague and not go to the Castle?! Worth the price of admission. Make sure you also goto the Lobkowizc Museum before leaving.

Huge castle complex, nice views, paid attractions overrated. The castle complex is huge. The surrounding regions offer excellent views over Prague.From the castle, try walking down Nerudova street towards Charles bridge. The cobbled stone street offers fantastic ambience of lovely buildings, interesting shops and nice restaurants.In case you have 30 mns extra, it is probably worth walking down the street Nový Svět / Černínská, It has some pretty houses with a lot of history.

Spend some good quality time here. The region around the castle, the building and the amazing streets with their stories are a just do. And as you get to red sit down and enjoy the view. Some amazing views from different locations. Make sure you have a guide or a good guide book which tells you what the buildings and streets housed and signify.
Prague Castle. We visited the area on a bright, sunny day which does make a difference. Lots to see and do. Worth the walk back to town. We took the hop on hop off mini-bus to get to the castle area.

Nice walk and beautiful place. If you find yourelf in Prague and have two, three hours to spend i would recommend walk to castle district, which gives a great view to old dame - Prague. Many of the places can be visited without extra payment, it is very tidy, nice, offers restaurants, caffes, post office, souvenir shops. A lot of stairs to get there but worth every step. Also free wi-fi in some places, prices of food and beverages a bit higher which is understandable. In my opinion top three must see things in Prague.

So Many Grand Palaces. Apart from having the "Castle" itself the area has numerous Palaces,churches,gardens etc. most of which can be visited as well as observed from the outside in their splendour.Having visited the castle the previous day but not having time to appreciate the whole Castle District .We approached from the "Old Castle steps" through the castle area exiting at the front of the Castle into Castle Square which is surrounded by grandiose palaces . The Archbishops Palace , Scharzenberg Palace,Sternberg Palace,Martinic Palace and Toskansky Palace.The large area has a tranquility about it after the hustle and bustle of the castle courtyards.Further on theres the Strahov Monastery,The Loreto ,the Cernin Palace which is huge and houses the Ministry of Foreign affairs which is apt as down the hill into Mala Strana are many foreign embassies.A small cafe at the side of the Schwarzenberg Palace boasts a magnificent terrace area with views of the city and Petrin park etc.As it was covered in snow when we were there, we warmed ourselves inside although a little pricey ,it serves the best Hot chocolate we've ever tasted(my wife had the White chocolate version ,which she said tasted like rich warm custard)

beautiful at the top!. Well worth the hike to the top to see the city set out below and not to be missed -the vista is breathtaking and really demonstrates the vast range of architecture and beauty of this old city

Amazing views- even just to stroll by and not enter the castles. We visited the Lobcowicz, St. Vitus, and watched the guards. This area brings so many fascinating sites together-which even by just strolling through can give you a sense of Wow! I'm here! Yes filled with tourists yet no one accosting you on hard sells, or unlicensed vendors- very refreshing! The changing of the guard is worth seeing and impressive, yet do not worry if you miss it.
Prague Castle. Must see. Not easy to get to on foot unless very fit & mobile. Need at least half a day to doit justice. Quality
fantastic. everywhere is spotless. lots to see and experience, but go for the audio tours if you want plenty of info as not many written descriptions in english
Amazing. Full of history. Great architecture. Wonderful cafesloved itConsWas packed with tourists and we were almost trampled

Charming area. Charming area again like most of Prague full of beautiful buildings very quaint, cobble streets, nice places for eating & drinking . Everywhere is very walkable in Prague very compact city.

Castle district is lovely, the castle itself is not so lovely. This page refers to the general area surrounding the castle and NOT the castle itself - it's a huge site, biggest in the world, so has multiple areas.I've reviewed the castle itself in another review - in a nutshell, it looks pretty but is almost entirely devoid of interest inside - so check that out for more details.However, we thoroughly enjoyed walking around the streets near the castle, looking back over the rest of Prague etc. and spent a nice morning exploring. I'm reviewing a cute little cafe we found (Kaficko) in another review too, near Charles bridge area but off the beaten track and not packed with tourists.The whole castle district would do better if they stopped the endless parade of tourist shops from exploding out onto the street but if you ignore them and look at the buildings, exploring down side streets etc. you'll have a nice time.Just be warned, the castle itself is pretty bad! :)

Like visiting a fairy tale. I had an image of what it would like like in my head, and as we walked off the Charles Bridge toward the Hradcany, it lived up to every expectation. The view from the bridge up to the castle and cathedral is amazing. We walked around before catching a tram up to the top. Tram 22, it was really easy, with our 24 hour metro passes. Walking around the Hradcany, you have an amazing view of the city, along with the chance to see the Royal Guards, the Palace and St. Vitus Cathedral. If you want to see the cute and quaint Golden Lane, you need to purchase a Hradcany tour ticket, which will grant you access to a lot more museums and houses in the area. Didn't do the tour, but wish we had had the time. It was truly beautiful.

Biggest Prague attraction. The castle is a must see when you visit Prague. I especially loved the Cathedral, such beautiful works of art to be found inside! The castle area also offers a large number of viewpoints over the city.

fairy tale old caste stronghold. This place is magical and after a trek up hill to the cathedral and the area around it you will come to feel as though you just been sucked into a book of fables... great ancient buildings, enormous cathedral, great museums and nice vista over the city belos

Watch Your money on Tram 22. We went here on a Sunday morning taking a very crowded tram no 22 packed in like sardines and my partner had all his local money taken from his pocket. Were informed at the hotel this Tram is renown for Pick Pockets.Could take a day to see everything in the Castle and the views over the town are superb. Also found an excellent un-crowded up market coffee shop/restaurant in a museum opposite the tourist shop at the furtherest point of the castle walls with stunning views from its balcony. Arrive early to see it all as packed by lunch time.

More than just the castle. The tourists generally stop at the castle gates and while the castle is a masterpiece in it's own right, Hradcany is the district around the castle. For me, the best way to experience the area is to catch the number 22 tram from Malostranska to up behind the castle at the stop called 'Hradcany'. This will allow you to walk down through the cobbled square where you get you're first view of St Vitus' Cathedral. Lots of gas lit winding streets and alleyways which hide fantastic little hotels, restaurants and pubs. Follow that with a walk through the castle down towards the old castle steps.
Just the castle. In practice, to see in this area which is important there is the castle and the area surrounding it. But that is more than enough. The landscape is nothing short of gorgeous.
Huge. Oldest castle in europe the entire expanse is massive. Also the largest once you reach it you can walk through the different buildings forever

get there early. Try to arrive early before the day trippers. We went in winter and its was still buisy with various tour groups and groups of tenage school children on day trips. An amazing place, the oldest castle in euprope. However if you are looking for a castle with old walls etc this is a castle of a number of influental bulidings.
Castle Tour. Lots of free walking tours of the area and if you are going to the Castle however I would pay for a tour - well worth it to understand the history, and architecture.

So Big. There is so much to see, it does take a day bu the time you walk there and back, but the walk across the bridge is so entertaining! People and pilgrims from all over. The shops on the way to the castle sell everything, I found some great garnet after I shopped prices.
Beautiful area. Hradcany is a beautiful, fascinating area to walk around in Prague. Spectacular views and definitely worth visiting.

Beautiful and vast.. We didn't get to go into the grounds of the castle as the old president was handing over the town to the new president and there was another of security, but it was an unexpected bonus to our visit to witness the ceremony.
great. a bit of a walk up but the stairs are not to bad. worth it once you are up there and there is places to eat and drink

Well worth a visit - spectacular views over the city. This is a complex of many buildings overlooking the city. The view itself is worth climbing the hill for.
