There are two tickets you can buy - a long visit or a short visit. These entitle you to go into all or some of the buildings (both include the cathedral - well worth a visit). The ticket is valid over two days, so you can take your time and return if you wish.

Gold gold gold. OK so its not real for the most part but the gold adornments and crosses look spectacualr against the clear blue winter sky and the castle does what it was built to do -enjoy a commanding view dominating Prague. A nice Cathedral with some lovely stained glass and a fearsome colection of gargoyles.There is a lot to see if you are up for the full day ticket but we chose the shorter half day which let us into the attractions we wanted. Do nto miss the gold street an incredible bit of the 17th century still intact with the houses combined with workshops for jewelers and other artisans looking like something out of a fairy tale. Lots of opportunities for photos but I suspect too busy for comfort peak season. Take the 22 Tram from Staremesto on Narodni -just beyond Wenceslaus square which saves a serious climb

Not much inside the Castle. They sell a short tour and a long tour ticket for the castle [really a conglomeration of buildings and palace]. We opted for the short tour. Not much inside the four buildings [incl 1 church] and if not bothered or pushed for time you can access the complex for free and not miss much! The area in general is quite nice and a change of pace from the old town.

Stunning architecture and views. This district is just as beautiful as the old town. The architecture on display and the cathedral amaze. The position from the front of the castle afford expansive views of the city

Great Castle. The Castle district is full of interesting things to do. From the extremely beautiful St. Vithus Cathedral to the Golden Lane and its tiny houses. This is a must see in Prague and you'll feel like wanting to walk around the district all day long.
great veiws. long walk up but amazing views of the city when you are up there..some great buildings with fantastic archieture...

Pure magic. Don't buy the (overpriced) tickets to visit all the attractions--the inside of the cathedral is not worth it, the picture gallery has very little to interest the artistically inclined (even the Rubens is of mediocre quality), the Golden Lane is so overcrowded you cannot see a thing. Only the banqueting hall is worth paying for. BUT walking around is more than enough to imbibe the splendour and atmosphere of the place. We were lucky to see it more than once but we had the good fortune of seeing it at night under the snow with very, very few people around--quite extraordinary.

stunning scenery. High up by the castle give excellent views all around of prague and well worth a visit. Steep to climb but if you take your time even the hard of wa;lking can manage it. Beware if icy though as the paths can be trecherous for walking

Amazing district!. This castle and the surrounding area is simply stunning. The whole area is very well maintained, this is especially considering that this area is about 1000 years old. Many places on the inside, but also a fantastic place to get a view of Prague. If you want to take in the whole package, one should add a full day. This is a must when you go to Praha!

go as a tourist. definitely go there..walk around the alleys and look in the shops, I check out the tickets, but really I don't see the point in going into the cites as I think the entire area is worth walking around and actually the sites are very so-so comparing to other "museums and castles" around europe...definitely go check out the buildings and stuff or take a tour...but just to pay to go in and look might not be that worthwhile..
Lovely Walks. We stayed near here and enjoyed many walks around the area. It is sso interesting and the architecture is breathtaking!
Pricey. Lovely to walk around but entry into everything except shops and restaurants incurs a charge. You can stroll around but can't access anything without paying
The symbol of Prague. We spent many hours there in sightseeing, drinking hot wine and enjoying the view. You should plan not to miss the changing of the Guard there.

Best part of city. We travelled a little further out on the tram to this area where the real people live and go, it was fantastic and very made us realise what a great place we were in, we took lots of photos much to the amusement of locals in the supermarket checking out all the cool stuff.

A romantic walk in history. The buildings are really beautiful. Exceptional architecture but the tour inside the palace was a let down. I expected to see a fully furnished palace like in Istambul or Cairo. Only the treasurey has valuable artifacts and is outside the palace ticket price. But the grounds are lovely and worth the time spent as you feel you are in old Europe.

So much to see. The Castle District in my opinion begins at the Charles bridge and the beginning of the trek up towards the castle. Make sure to pay attention to everything that's left and right, there is tons of history. There are various parks, the whole complex on the hill. There is a funicular to get you up, maybe take that one up and walk down or vice versa. And set aside at least one full day for the adventure.

Great views and busy park. worth visiting this beautiful area of the city. walk straight over the beautiful bridge from old town over the river and sample the beautiful architecture. if you have time walk through to the top of the park on the west side of the river, or take the hillside train. the view looking back over the city is great. you can even go up a replica Eiffle Tower structure to get your head in the clouds. a good afternoon out.
Arrive early. Lots to see and lots of walking but very worthwhile. There is a quiet little restaurant on the castle grounds when you need a break.

Great views and history. I wish that I had more than 2 days in Prague and could have explored Castle District more thoroughly. This area was very lovely and had some interesting history throughout the district. Would recommend a few hours adventuring around the area.

Wish we had more time. We left this until the last day and boy, did we regret not going sooner! This castle district is a gem located above Prague city. Stunning views, heavy history and so much to ohhh and ahhh at as you walk around. If you love taking holiday snaps then take your camera fully charged because there are so many photo ops here. An easy tram ride will take you to the top and then a great downhill walk to the bottom and you're at the tram again.

Stroll the lane ways and shops. Take a walk and discover the many little shops and small restaurant and cafes located below the shadow of the Prague Castle. Beautiful Puppets and gifts can be located far cheaper than at the old town square in Prague. We had our best lunch in Prague at one of the small restaurants located going up the hill towards the Castle - best Pasta Carbonara ever !!

Wide variety of architectural styles. Huge complex of varied buildings. Golden lane has some interesting tiny shops. Worth going on a tour to get some information about the history of all the different bits.

Nice area to stay. We stayed in this area and it was just great. A bit out of the center, which meant it was nice and quiet. We enjoyed our daily walks to the other side of the river, however, there was public transport around the corner as well. In the area itself is also plenty to do and there are a few nice restaurants too.

Lovely to wander around. Whilst we didn't go right up into the castle, we came across the bridge and wandered up the streets and saw the castle from the outside. Lots of little shops and restaurants and nice to take your time and browse. It is uphill, but not too strenuous if pace yourself.

Gorgeous. It's truly spectacular and a must-do if you are in Prague. Gothic, beautiful and full of history, we would recommend a visit to everyone. Make sure to leave yourself a few hours to explore; this is not just a photo op, it's worth your time!.

A city all in itself. There much to see here, the beautiful gothic cathederal is stunning. You're high up on a hill so you may want to get a bus or tram here. Being high up, the views over the river and the city are brilliant. From here if you head on down towards Charles Bridge you come across St Nicholas Church, the John Lennon bridge and the lover's bridge, all of which are worth seeing.
History plus. Fanatstic photot opportunities exist here and it is fascinating to walk around in this historic grandeur.

walks in the park. We enjoyed walking in the park here just over the bridge and seeing all the local people and their dogs having fun! a little normality amongst all the Christmas visitors! the views were great and we enjoyed the space and tranquility away from the bustling crowds...watching shadow chase and guard her ball! thanks for showing us Lenka! x
Worth a whole day. The cathedral was wonderful, and the little houses on Goldsmith lane showed how the servants and others lived. The changing of the guard is not what it is cracked up to be--but OK.
Prague visit. Theatre good ,weather bad. Restaurants acceptable. buildings need alot of renoivation. Had a real old world atmosphere
Magnificent. Wow, you really could spend a day here taking in the many wonderful sights. If you don't have the time visit the cathedral and basilica. You will not be disappointed.

great day's outing. Starting early and strolling across Charles Bridge on the way is a great plan. We took the tram up, but I went back the next day and walked up Nerudova St which is worth doing - lots of fine buildings and Castle Square is worth spending some time exploring too. You can easily fill a day up here. The only negative was getting charge twice on my visa for our tickets - but they fixed it up when we complained.

Big, beautiful, nice view. A lot of thinks to see, excellent view of prague. There is no lense to make justice to this view. I took a cab to the castle and then I walked to the city, 20 or 30 minutes of nice stuff to see and to take pictures. In winter time be well prepared for the cold and that is it. On your way to the city you can cross by Charles Bridge.

a very big attraction and well worth a visit. Probably one of the best castles we have visited, although it is not like a normal castle. From the bottom there are a lot of steps to climb but the views on the way up are well worth the climb. there is a quicker way if you take a tram to the top but you would miss the nice views and the guards on duty at the front gate.It does get busy so the best time to visit is early morning as it opens about 9.30 in winter. Lots to do there, you could see a lot for free if you do not need to go inside the buildings. You can buy a short ticket or a long ticket, the dfference is about a fiver.The longer ticket gives you the castle history museum and actually it is a large museum and full of good exhibits and it is very well done and you need 45 mins to an hour minimum if you do a quick visit in there. The tickets are valid for two days and you may need one and a half days to see it all. You can only go in each thing once so take your time.Golden lane is great and well worth a visit and you can only get in there with either a short or long ticket.The toy museum is very well done and only costs 70 to go inside.There are some toilets in the castle area but they cost 10 to go inside but they are spotless. We preferred to have a hot wine in a restaurant for 50 and get a free toilet break.You do not get any free maps of the area, you have to buy them.Cafe Galleria is well priced and very friendly and has lovely homemade cakes.The Old Palace is very good, not much information in there though.The treasury is not included in the ticket and it is very expensive so advise you give it a miss.The cathedral tower is also extra.Rosenberg palace is only on the long ticket, it is not a great place and can be done in ten minutes. It does have some interesting gargoyle exhibits though so worth a look if you have the long ticket.They change guards with a parade every day at noon.
Great browsing whether you buy a tour pass or not. Gothic architecture. You can get the picture fine by walking around outside. The tours and passes give you more of the same
Huge Castle grounds. Many great walks around the castle area. So many buildings to see. We opted for the short tour and still saw a lot. Plan on a whole afternoon there!

Take the Tram!. I see a number of people who say they walked up to the castle. Rather take the tram and walk back at your own leisure, and stop at all the little places. Note the names of the houses - often depicted with statuettes or artwork, as there were no numbers originally. Climb into a powder tower along the way and make sure you go to the top, and have a beautiful rooftop view all around. On a clear day the photography can be astounding. See the old and new sometimes cheek-to-cheek.

Interesting.. We went to Vysehrad. It was hard to find but that was our mistake. Its a really easy walk from the red metro line C. We just made it more difficult. We did eventually get there. The church was interesting and so was the cemetery. The weather was not very nice so we did not get to take full advantage of the site. We did have coffee and honey cake in one of the cafes which was outstanding.
Grand and palatial. Though called a castle - it's a grand palace with a number of surprises. I recommend visiting the area, but wear stout shoes and expect a lot of walking.

Worth the Walk Uphill. We walked across the Charles Bridge and straight up to the castle. We enjoyed the walk and were glad we didn't take transportation to get there, it is definitely worth the walk uphill. The Castle area itself is a must do while in Prague.

Excellent views over the rooftops of Prague. Quite a bracing walk up the hill (you can take a tram! ) across Charles bridge and up through Mala Stana to the castle. Lots of little shops and cafes to explore on the way.! The view from the top looking over Prague is amazing.!

Take the full tour - worth it !. We took the full tour of the castle region - the cathedral is fantastic, one of the most beautiful in Europe. Another interesting and well arranged part is the museum of Prague, everything has an explanation also in English, things are well marked, takes approximately one hour long. The "Golden street" is included in the tour - from 16.00 o'clock it is free but in winter it is already dark so I think it is advisable to approach it earlier in order to take some photos in daylight.
up hill all the way. its quite a walk up but man its worth it the view of the city is just the best the Castle is quite something on the way up there are some very nice shops
Must see. Amazing views and history. So much to see in this area. You could walk forever in the many streets, and enjoy the views and shops.

Must do.. After a few days in the tourist hustle and bustle of Stare Mesto, we heeded a recommendation and headed out to Hradcany. It will give you a whole different perspective on living in Prague, with few tourists and a lot of lovely buildings and views. Plan it as a break from the craziness, and have a coffee or lunch at the little cafe near the church.

very big and very beautiful. although crowded with tourists, it is a lovely place. quite big, so it took us a couple hours for the short tour. the audio guide was quite useless, way too long making it impossible to listen.

Wow. We took a guided tour of the city which included a visit to the castle grounds, we were very impressed with what we saw and so wished we had more time to go back and explore the castle in depth, as the tour was only a highlight type.

Very unique and great views of city. Although we did not formally tour any of buildings in the Castle District, we spent several hours up in the area walking among the different buildings, climbing the cathedral steps and enjoying the panoramic views of Prague. As the largest castle complex in the world, I am glad we didn't miss it simply because we were "toured out"!

Walk from the Charles Bridge. The Castle is located on a hill overlooking the Charles Bridge and River but walk up the hill if you love beautiful buildings; it is an art lovers paradise and all of them are in very good condition.

Just wow!. The castle district kept me and my boyfriend entertained all day, it was such a stunning area and we were fortunate enough to have some nice weather to enjoy walking around. It was a highly interesting place with a lot to keep people entertained, perfect for us as a couple but we also saw plenty of families enjoying themselves.
Lovely buildings. Take your time to stroll and remember to look up and enjoy the architecture that is all around you. The buildings are beautiful and you will be glad you took the time.

Where to go in Prague, there.... After a long walk from the center, this is a compulsory place to visit if you are in Prague. Do forget the Golden Line if you are over there. I missed it for the first visit.

Wear comfortable shoes and take in the history!. It's not easy to traverse the steep streets but the historic walk is well worth it. Outside of the Castle itself, this area was not as crowded as the old historic center.

Amazing!. The Prague Castle is honestly its own district. It is about 18 acres and you can easily spend the day there. I recommend getting the public transportation up to the top, but walk down. The view is great! There were tons of people everywhere... except when I went into the castle and other things to see. At the end of the Golden Lane there is a really neat torture chamber/prison that is worth the price of admission. Again, most people were just walking on the grounds and not looking at the main attractions. Pretty cool... All the WC's also charged you every time. Most were just 10 koruna.

Historic Castle Quarter. The Castle Quarter was well preserved and offers a good feel of the history of Czech Republic. There are several photo spots offering panoramic views of Prague. Worthy of a second visit.

If you get to the district, enjoy and then go to the castle. One way or the other, does not matter what you visit first, do the while round trip, you will enjoy the walk from the bridges to the district and to the castle and back. wear good shoes, there are couple of hills
Castle on High. I guess Average is a little unfare as we only visited the Castle on a tour and did not go inside, however it did appear a long way from the centre.

A good visit. The castle area is elaborate, as you would expect. We were there just after the guards put on their winter uniforms - and that was interesting.  The whole of Prague is just filled with amazing sights - the Castle is just one of many

Worth it. It grows on you as you start climbing up to reach the castle...it's a beautiful prelude to castle ....enjoy the walk and music...don't miss out catching up with newly weds who pose for their wedding albums

Worth the hike, especially to see the cathedral. We hiked up to the castle quarter and arrived a little breathless, but awed by the incredible view and the opportunity to see St. Vitus Cathedral up close.Prague Castle, founded in 870 AD, is the largest medieval castle in Europe. The history here is fascinating, for over a thousand years the Czech’s were ruled from Prague castle. Even today the area houses the offices of the Czech president.The castle is guarded by the castle guard. A Changing of the Guard ceremony takes place every hour at the front gates. The ceremony at noon includes a fanfare and banner exchange.We did not take the whole tour but enjoyed walking around the grounds and visiting the church. For our tastes, St. Vitus was the best site to see in the quarter and should not be missed.

Our three day visit to the Christmas markets contd.. Unfortunately, our visit to this area was on the worst day of our trip.It was quite a climb in snow and ice conditions, but we made it. Most of the time we were looking down to avert a fall, however what we did see was amazing.What beautiful buildings. The hierarchy lived in so much luxury in those days. Unfortunately the cathedral was closed as it was the afternoon.Coming back down the hill using all those steps in such weather was, for me quite scary!
Best part of town. Certainly full of tourists but there are out of parts and more remote areas to have a look adn experience. Try numerous expositions and try to get off the beaten track.

Beautiful wiev of Prague!. To stand in the area of Hradcany was a great experience. Everything was beatiful and well kept. Very interesting - and like going back in time. I could allmost see the people fromn 1700's walking around.

Tourist heaven. The castle is the largest in Europe - and what a place it is. The entire area contains some absolutely stunning buildings in pristine condition and the views over Prague city are superb. WOrth a visit just to view the buildings

Can spend a day. We bought the whole package and checked out all the museums, church, watched the changing of the guard, and walked the surrounding area. We actually took a bus up to the castle and eventually wound our way back to the old town area.

Give it a whole day. Fistly go up the more gentle incline rather than all the steps. If you have a whole day it is definitely worth buying the full ticket. We had been there before so wanted a different experience. Not mentioned in our guidebook was a toy museum. This is definitely worth the small entrance fee and not to be missed!

You'll need a whole day. If you want to see everything, you need time. There are so many different buildings, so much to see, and the views across Prague are great. Don't miss Zlata ulicka (Golden Lane), but try to see as many of the palaces as possible too. They're all different, all stunning.
Realm of the Castle. Hearing about the different styles of architecture for the churches was interesting. The view of the city is spectacular.

Castle tour. We went on the Castle city Walking Tour of Prague, our guide was John Paul. We really enjoyed the historical facts and modern day stories that he was able to present. It was very cold but on the whole, we kept moving and saw a good deal of the Castle district in 3 hours. Well worth joining the tour to hear a little more about what you are looking at when walking through this amazing castle.
Stunning. The castle, church and the surrounding area are all so beautiful. Even with tourists everywhere, it did not feel touristy. A MUST SEE.

Take the time to enjoy it. We didn't plan our day as well as we should have. We did arrive just before noon so that we saw the changing of the guard, which was great. We then just walked the length of the castle, stopping only to go in the cathedral and the Lobkowicz castle. I wish we'd put more time into it and seen more of what's available. We should have studied the guide books more before we went. It's a nice place to spend the day.

A Vast area. We did a very short wander with our guide and it is fascinating. We could not do it justice in the time we had. I suggest giving this are and perhaps the lesser town area a whole day to fully absorb all that is here.

A maze. We had a private guide with us to show us the way. But if you don't have one , get a good map and guide , its a maze. I would say more of a palace than a Castle. You can see the changing of the guards which is nice. Not much to see here but good view of the city from here.
City Within A City. There are museums and shops in the castle district that make it a city within a city! The toy museum is cool for younger kids.

Beautiful cobbled streets inerlaced with tourist shops. It is fun to explore these cobbled ancient streets. Some great shopping too but probably too many souvenir shops. The crossing of the Charles bridge is a terrific highlight too but crowded.
Worth a visit. The Prague Castle is beautiful and a must see. Worthwhile to check out this site. The short tour is recommended.

Awesome afternoon. The Castle district was amazing. We loved the cathedral and liked walking around, but couldn't believe the museums up there NOT included in the Castle tix. The Sternberg musem and the Rosenberg museum, amazing art! One had five or six Peter Paul Reubens, huge famous pieces too. One Rembrandt too.
lovely but very steep. steep hill to the castle. apparentlly there is a tram there but we walked. there are many quirky and interesting shops on the way up the hill

Castle. Well worth a walk around. The castle is located at the top of a large amount of steps though so be ready for a long arduous walk as this is the only means of getting up there unless you have a car!.

This is what Prague is about.. Really big complex! You need a lot of time to go through it, but it is really beautiful. There is the cathedral, the castle, a really pretty street that has small houses that were given as privileges and other buildings.

Castle and Cathedral wow!. The whole left side of the river is just awesome! Everything!! The castle and cathedral were just amazing. The Golden street was really interesting and the walk down the hill through the wine vines was just breathtaking.

Clean, smart and varied. We bought a "short castle visit" which was just right, and visited all we were able. Cathedral, castle , church, street etc . All worthwhile. Not busy either. Immaculate conditions- very clean, well signed, a lovely relaxing morning,

A big part of what makes Pragus special. We wandered through on our own, visited the toy museum and a few shops, stopped for a photo with the palace guards. Its is a lot like Budavar in Budapest; its impressive, a big part of the cities identity but has the potential to be so much more.
When we are back in Prague we will go back.

Great castle. The church on the castle grounds was fantastic. Really like the armor display along the outer wall. Sculptures are interesting. We have been to more than a few castles and this one is worth the trip.

A beautiful walk. Very clean with beautiful buildings. On the walk between the monastery and the Palace there is a very nice flower shop where I purchased some roses that were beautiful and the healthiest, strongest that I have ever seen. I thought they were artificial when I first handled them.

The largest working castle complex in the world. Hradcany consists of palaces, halls (Vladislav's Hall is so spacious, jousting matches were held here), a Cathedral a basilica, towers, stables and galleries. The president's offices are located here.

Mixed emotions. No doubt that the Castle District (Hradcany) is the major place to visit in Prague, you can spend the whole morning here. It includes within its walls the St Vitus's Cathedral, the old Royal palace, the Picture Gallery, the Golden Lane, St George's Basilica, the Powder Tower and the Dalibor Tower. Let's go one by one... St Vitus Cathedral is absolutely a must, in spite of having closed the access to the crypt. The Royal Palace is not a big deal, it is very little what you get to see of it. The Picture Gallery is quite small, one would have hoped to find a bigger collection of paintings; still you can enjoy some Rubens and Reni, and a curious Paulus Roy "Triple portrait" made with a grid-based technique more than 300 hundred years ago. St George Basilica is nice, but you can no longer visit the huge collection of art at St Georges's Convent... What happened with those works of Czech art? Forget the Powder Tower, full of military uniforms, and even the Dalibor Tower, a place of torture. Don't buy the full ticket, it is not worth. Just visit the Cathedral and walk around a couple of hours.
Lovely buildings. We walked down from Petrin Hill into castle district. It was nice to walk around a slightly less congested part of town, and see all the lovely buildings, including some embassies.
What A Castle. Spent severall days in Prauge on a home Exchange. The Castleand surrounding area is fantastic. The tour I was on got me to all the right places. Don't miss this.
Prague Castle. We spent several hours visiting the castle. We watched the changing of the guard and visited the church and the alley which housed the former workers cottages. A very interesting day.

Amazing views. Get the 22 tram as otherwise facing a steep climb up! Lovely views from the top. We didn't pay to enter the castle bust still found plenty to do - we spent about 3hrs exploring this area. Beer from the monastery is definitely worth a taste but be prepared to pay for it!

Impressive structures & wonderful views.. Many interesting and attractive buildings to admire, seeing the Lennon wall is fun, viewing the sprawling city from the high vantage point helps you appreciate the size of this beautiful city!

What castle?. First thing first, this is not a castle, unless you call a bunch of old churches and government buildings a castle. And the only thing worth seeing in there are the two churches/cathedrals.
Don't pay the silly money for castle district ticket, everything worth seeing, if there is any, can be seen for free.

Must see when in prague. Absolute must, shame to miss it. Take tram 22 to prazskyhrad stop and follow directions to main entrance of castle, 10 minute walk. If you get of early at malastranska you will have to walk uphill. The courtyards and golden lane is nice to see,great views and we walked to petrin tower from here, funicular wasn't working. View from petrin tower good. Lots of steps. Walked down into mala strana and across Charles bridge back into old town.
Plenty to see and do. Wander around this historic area. Visit the contemporary art Museum Kampa right by the river not far from the Charles Bridge.
Must see in Prague.. The Cathedral itself, with the Mucha windows is wonderful. The many other buildings are interesting.

Take a walk about and get lost!. This is a spectacular place to be! Take a walk away from the crowds and get lost in the small streets out west and take a turn up the hill and into the forests. You might be lost but you'll end up having a great day :)

Scenic. Attractive architecture and views in the area surrounding Prague castle. At one point there is a lovely panoramic view accross the Vlatava river to the Old Town Square and the Zizkov TV tower in the distance.

Can't Visit Prague Without Going to Hradcany. Yes this is an area heavily infested with tourists but you cannot visit Prague without going to the Castle. We did not find the tickets too expensive (check what it costs to get into Wesminster Abbey in London!) There is a lot of history and national pride tied up in the area. Great views of the city as well. Hint: take transit or a taxi over to the Castle and walk back over the Charles Bridge.

Expensive to visit places we didn't want to go.. We were hoping to walk round and visit some of the places in the Castle District. However most of them needed a ticket to enter - which we didn't object to paying. There were only 2 ticket options available - a "minor" ticket and a "major" ticket. Both of these were fairly expensive and allowed us entry into things most of which we didn't want to visit. While we accept that there will always be a charge to visit amazing places, we would have liked the option of planning and paying for only those we wished to visit.
The Castle. This is a must. Start at the top of the hill and work down it is easier. The views of the city are spectacular and the history of the castle fascinating.
Enjoyable day at the castle. What can I say, so historic and enjoyable, but get there early, the bussloads of tourists really can be overwhelming in the mid-day.
Excellent Sights. We toured the castle district for part of the day. The castle is beautiful and well-maintained. It is a must-see in Prague. The views of the old city from there are great too.

Wonderful. Spent a whole day up here. bought the PlanB ticket to get into some of the Palaces and away from the crowds. Lots to see. Changing of the guard with music at 12noon - extra special one on first Wednesday of the month. I even caught a motorcycle display team and a marching corps of guards. If you only have limited time - all the buildings are free after 6pm.

Quite a hike if walking. Be warned - this is quite a hike if walking but well worth it for the views alone. The changing of the guard at 12MD is not to be missed but falls well short of the London experience.

Another Prague delight. We spent two days in this area. The main entrance is spectacular and we enjoyed the changing of the guard, which happens every hour. The gardens are lovely and we really enjoyed the history of Prague exhibition.

Plenty of steps. Gorgeous - great views of Prague - the cathedral is definitely the main attraction, and the castle is more of a manor house than an embattlemented castle, if you see what I mean. But well worth walking up and the gardens are great, too.

Killer views. The whole casle area is fantastic and the views of the city from there are a knockout! We were bowled over by the architecture and wandered the streets and discovered great shops, restaurants and cafes for a coffee or a great Czech beer

To have the best experience, get a guide. I can't help but feel we left without really understanding this area properly. We hit all the spots we thought we should go but still left feeling pretty unfulfilled. St Vitus was great but nothing else was anywhere as near as memorable. For so many people to be impressed by everything inside these walls, either we are too spoiled through our travels or we did something wrong. It probably would help to know more about the history from a guide so one could connect a little more with what you are exploring.

Getting lost here is the best part of it.... There are very few places in Europe that can match the beauty of the Hradcany! Leave your car behind at the hotel and spend a whole day exploring on foot. And there is even a great, multi story Starbucks at one of the squares, if you get tired of appreciating everything "old world".

Beautiful area to wander. Can't beat St. Vitus and all the fantastic sights to wander and explore in this area. Beautiful views over the city - be sure to wander slowly and enjoy the details. So much to see even if you don't go inside a single place!

Be there at midday - Ruritania lives!. At 12.00pm each day, a little piece of 'invented' tradition plays out in the main square. Out guidebook described the guards as 'Camp Guards' - rather apt, given the highly decorative uniforms. Musicians play from windows high in the surrounding buildings, but the tune owes more to Thunderbirds than Souza. Invented by Theo Pisteck (I kid you not...) in 1989, the guard-changing provides an amusing backdrop to the history of the place. Watch out for the ripp-off perpetrated at the Mystick restaurant at the top of the square - the only place in Prague that doesn't display prices and to which you are invited to enter by happy, smiling waitresses. Don't be tempted, if you are - don't eat the 'complimentary' crisps: if you do - don't be surprised by the bill!

Huge. I loved the castle area because it was like being in a little girls princess dream. I also liked it as there were places to sit and relax for a good Czech beer and take a break from walking. We went to a yummy restaurant there as well..it was hidden down a side of steps. The name was HOST and it had spectacular view as well. I loved the Golden Lane too but all of this is quite touristy so be prepared. No problems with pic pockets, etc. Clean and enchanting.

A maze of palaces. We wallked up to the Castle from Charles Bridge. Stop to enjoy the views as you ascend. Would suggest you get there early as the area becomes very busy. Make sure you take in one of the tours

I mean is good and in good condition but... But we have plenty of cathedrals, palaces and castles around europe, havent we? nothing really spectacular compared to Vienna Palaces, spanish cathedrals or Paris sights. But all in al lis OK

Busy, Busy, Busy. The Castle District is worth visiting, but it's crowded, expensive, and, of course, touristy. Everything you want to see in the Castle costs you money, so be prepared for that. The views back over the city are worth the short walk up the hill. It's not as steep as some people would lead you to believe. Walk up from to the castle from the Charles Bridge side and walk down into Mala Strana from the eastern side that goes through the vineyard. Great views from everywhere.

Castle District. Do the walking tour, with the company in the yellow T shirts, they take you through the whole district and make everything so interesting and lots of fun! Its a great way to sight see, and so affordable!

Nice half day. Definitely visit the castle district - prague castle and the loreta. The castle district offers beautiful views of the city. We did the 'short tour' and think that was a good value, allowing us into all of the exhibits and areas we wanted to see. Note - you can only visit each building once with the ticket so make sure you take a good look around before leaving.
Cannot have too much Castle. I love Prague Castle and the whole castle experience. It is a day of sightseeing. So worth it and gives you fabulous views of the city.

Nice. The district felt a bit much to my liking. It was so crowded and there were so many cathedrals and places to go to that we ended up just walking around a bit and not doing much. Admittedly, it was the 4th day and we were exhausted ...
I preferred the vine area better.

Great Views. You might want to visit the Castle district just for the views if you've seen too many castles on your trip already. You can walk a crazy amount of steps etc to climb to the top of the hill, but you can take the tram or sign up with a tour like we did. The view alone is worth the visit.

castles in the sky. Prague is full of palaces and castles. The Castle district is exciting and colorful, but also so crowded! The views and churches are gorgeous. The changing of the guard was colorful and not to be missed.

Impressive!. Lots of places to visit within the castle grounds, and many places are free. You can see all the courtyards and parts of the cathedral, and such great history here! There is a changing of the guard ceremony on the hour, with the bigger fanfare at noon. It's a good time to avoid the crowds and get inside the castle! Don't skip out on the overlook area at the back of the castle, above the terraced gardens, or the gardens themselves. Very beautiful views of Prague from this vantage point.
My favorite!. This castle was bad to the bone! I loved this entire area, as we saw the changing of the guarde, and other cool historical things that were happening. This place is a MUST!

Walked over Charles Bridge, tram to Castle!. By the 3rd day we felt comfortable walking everywhere.....so we walked from hotel, through Old Town, over Charles Bridge, caught the tram (figuring out the ticket machines!) and went up the hill to the Castle.....the church within the castle wall was amazing, as was the castle itself. Great day there!
Take a tram to the top. Unless you like walking uphill, simply take tram 22 to the top and walk very slowly down, taking in the views, shops and cafes. Very busy round the castle.

Interesting but not exceptional. We did a tour of the church and old palace. the church was nowhere near as interesting or beautiful as most we have viewed in Europe. The old palace was actually boring. I liked the Golden street with the small houses and stories behind the people who lived there.

missing the majesty. The Castle District is an amazing destination, no question. Castle, museums, Golden Lanes, cathedrals, changing of guards, all for one convenient and not trivial price...I guess it just felt way too touristy for me. I really liked the surrounding neighborhood more than the castle grounds. The architecture within the castle grounds is a bizarre mixture of gothic, romanesque, oriental, and mid-20th century architecture. You have to go, but be prepared for the tourist treatment. The gardens next to the Castle walls were a delight, with beautiful views of the city.
Nice at night. This city offers the views of Prague at night. The castle glows on top of the hill, large and proud. This was an amazing stop, be sure to bring water, the trek up the stairs is long.
Castle District of Prague. Very picturesque with so much history. It was so relaxing walking through this area. Some nice restaurants and cafe's too.

Huge complex needs a day. Start early and you may see about thirty percent of the place. You could spend a week there and still not see everything. Stunning views of Prague make it a must see place as well as the great buildings. Didn't have time to see everything.

Worth a visit. We were lucky enough to see the changing of the guard and also a special event at the castle where some religious event was happening which was lovely to watch. The guards are so smart and friendly too, if you can get to the front at 12 noon you get treat to a fanfare. You can buy a ticket to some of the castle for 250 or all of it for 350 k. You cannot just go to Golden Lane you have to pay for a ticket. This was a slight disappointment as it was only a few shops and the guide book depicted more. A lovely walk up to the Castle though, Enjoy.

must see. the highest point in the centre, it covers many things from St Vitus cathedral to lovely old Golden Lane ( fee but worth it for the alchemists street and tiny houses/shops) and old palace buildings with huge and very magnificent vaulted hall with many huge windows that saw the defenestration of Prague. Start your day up here and then walk down with great views to cross the river.

Breathtaking Views. The whole area is far larger than I realised, and you can spend many hours strolling through the streets. A wonderful mix of activities and interests, in an inspiring surroundings. Highly recommended. Don't miss the guard changing shifts.

Best View In Town!. Its a must do on anyones visit to Prague. Take a walk right to the top to really appreciate where you have just come from (if you do have walking difficulties it is possible to take a taxi most of the way). There is a lovely wine bar at the top situated within a small vineyard a nice way to relax and get your breath back after the walk up.Don't forget your camera, best view in town!

Must do. We spend a day at the Castle District. First took the tram up the hill to avoid the walking up the till and was able to visit the parks and then the Prague Castle area. Loved it. Found great and cheap cafe bars and beautiful buildings. Did this ourself without a guide. I found that I enjoy this better than Old Town.

Wow. What a must see when you visit Prague. Leave a few good hours at least. St Vitus Cathedral is beautiful from the outside. If you want to see inside, do go on a Sunday unless you want to attend the service.

Great experience. Awesome photo scenes on this tour. Actually got to see changing of the guards but not be as laid out as London's version but it was still nice to see Prague style. Wasn't too crowded maybe because we got there pretty early in the morning. A must see.

A must see. We took a cab here from our hotel in Old Town. It is worth the trip and the Castle is a must see for first time visitors to Prague. The area is vast so this is a day trip. There is a lot to see in this area such as the Palace and St Vitus Cathedral. The view of the city is also breathtaking from this vantage point.

Must see, but oh the crowds. This area is just charming, and the castle is a must see. Expect big crowds! Make sure you buy the special pastry on the walk down the hill. You'll know it when you smell it.
Castle on the hill. I loved the view from the castle, the guards and wandering around and enjoying the musicians. Luckily we had dinner there in the evening, again overlooking this magnificent city.
Lots of history. Great views of Prague from this very historic area. The wealth of days gone by is still evident here. Beautiful buildings and scenes.

castle area. The castle area is like a town within a town, plenty to see including a few palaces (no longer in use) and of course the castle. There are cafes and monuments and a great trio playing all the time except when the guards changed over.

Prague history !. I loved this district. All the cafes, shops and apartments. I spent many an hour milling about here, sometimes you'll see a wedding or two at the top as people come to take photos. Also, the sentries at the entrance to the castle are great for photos !

Worth the visit. On the day we went there were no English tours but we walked up the night before and they would not tell us that, they said we had to come back after 9:15 to see what times the English tours were, and then the next day they tell us there are not any. Whatever! But at least they have an audio guide you can purchase and all the signs are in English and Czech so you can figure out what is what. The Golden Lane is just a crammed street filled mostly with overpriced shops and is along the exit, but they act like it is actually an attraction that you paid for, REALLY, that part was not worth it. The part of the castle that you can go through on the short tour is very short, the best parts are the St Vitus Cathedral and St George Chruch.

Our hotel location. We were right down the long hiss from the castle...the walk up is charming, filled with shops and cafes...we sat outside every time we could and enjoyed trying the Czech wines and beers
beautifull and nice view. Just go to the spot and enjoy. Walk throu the gardens and have a nice view of the city. We had lunch in the pavilion on the hill and that is a exelent spot.
what a view. bit windy during the winter-time but just grand stuffed with great, tiny, cozy, hidden restaurants. The Cathedral is grand! and who doesn't appreciate the cobblestone paved roads :)
well preserved!. Everything there is amazing. I would recommend to stay in Prague a minimum of 3 days because it is an amazing place and cheap!!The castle district offers great views of the city!

amazing. to use an overused word, an amazing place. once we had negotiated the million steps ( well, a bit of an exaggeration, maybe a hundred or so, it just felt like a million!) the view was superb. we watched the changing of the guard at the gate and then went into the complex. lots of different things to see, cathedral, church, museum, Prague story and tiny old houses. we were there for 6 hours. a well spent 350Kc (£12.50)
Fascinating, well preserved and well renovated. Excellent audio tour available for the castle complex, which I'd recommend over the huge group tours

About the tickets. My "Excellent" rating is for the Castle District as a tourist destination, it does not reflect what I think about the ticket system. That would be significantly lower.They sell combination tickets for a number of sites. There are different tiers covering different attractions. You can not buy an entry ticket for a single particular site. Even if you just want to see, say, Zlata Ulicka you have to buy an expensive combination ticket that includes other things. We bought the most expensive ticket for 350 CZK (almost $20) pp. With that we had entry to most buildings and sites that we were interested in and some that we didn't care about and didn't waste the time to go. However, it did not include entry to all sites like somebody else stated in another review. We wanted to visit the Treasury and that was not covered. It would have been another combination ticket. By the way, they do this in other tourism centers in Prague, too. We wanted to see the Jewish Cemetary and found out that the ticket for the Jewish Quarter, which included the cemetary, was 300 CZK...
Too many tourists. Can hardly appreciate the sites. way too many tours and guides. Save it until late afternnon when the tours are back on the buses.
castle. exeptionally beautiful and fascinating took almost 4 hours to look round and then there were places we did not get to see saw the changing of the guards .

Very Impressive. In spite of lots of tourists, this area is full of gorgeous and impressive buildings. Worth a visit, but be prepared to spend a lot of time...there are many buildings to look at and visit. Be prepared for a steep climb to the castle grounds themselves.
Historic. Wonderful walk to the area. Historic sites in good condition. Beautiful vistas of the city from the castle area.
Good. When you visit prague, you have to go there.I went walking, since the charlies bridge until the castle.Was a very good trip, the views, the stores, restaurants.
Spend a Day Here-Outstanding Museums. We devoted an entire day to visiting all of the Museums in the Castle Complex in addition to having been it the Lobkowiez Palace the day before.

Brilliant View. The height of Prague, from here you can view the entire city. Very busy, but well worth the visit. It is possible to work or to catch a bus, I suggest you take a ride as it is a quite steep climb.

Well-maintained, easy to visit. We visited St Vitus, Golden Lane, St. George's Church and had lunch in the Lobkowicz Palace. There are several cafes and shops within the complex. Note that tickets are required if you want to visit Golden Lane.
Tickets and turnstiles.... Buy the ticket you need (the higher rate gets you into all the attractions). Lots of walking up and down and on cobbles so wear 'sensible' shoes.
The Views!. This is just a lovely area of the city. The walk from Charles Bridge although a little uphill was pretty. The views from the Castle District are breathtaking.
Panoramic view. Panoramic view on the city, street musicians (kind of a national orchestra) singing romantic songs about mama's warm hands... almost made me cry

Definitely visit during sunset. I would suggest to go there in the afternoon to strall around and stay there till teh sunset as the sun will be setting behind you and you will have amazing view over the Town and Charle's bridge. If you like taking pictures, it will be worth it to stay there. There are lots of places where you can find great panoramic views!

Nice place to spend a day. Very nice place. If you a there with some friends you can easily spend a day. You can even have a nice walk around the castle. Great views of prague. Nice architecture inside the castle

beautiful place. lovely place, watched the changing of the guard. very busy at certain points in the narrow streets. need to be quite fit and mobile to manage the hills and the steps. the gardens were an oasis of calm.

go on the hop on hop off. but ticket, it;s valid for 48 hours and a great way to see the city. We took the bus up to the castle district and spend several hours there before heading back down. Great day ,

the importance of history. if you climb up to the Castle Distric and you enter the Hradcany you will directly be taken by the feeling of takin part in midle European history. There is a mention of Maria Theresia, there are so many familiar names! In addition the district is perfectly renovated and leaves you with impressions to take home.
Fantastic. This was my highlight of the trip and the only thing I really wanted to do ..... The site was brilliant and would recommend !!

Magnificent views over Prauge. Take a stroll in the Castle District, admire the beautyful architecture and take a pus in one of the many water holes. You have to visit this if you are in Prauge. You can go there, either by foot, or by tram.
Grand and impressive.. Really enjoyed the architecture and historical views of and around the castle district. Very clean the people were extremely helpful and friendly.
Great views of the city. It is greener up near the castle. There are some parks to walk in which was great as the weather was hot whilst we were here.

Like a fairytale. The whole of the Castle district is well worth a visit.... we only did the short visit which was around £10 each and it was absolutely perfect. The grounds are well worth a vist on their own and you don't have to pay for those.

Tourist trap but beautiful. The short tour takes you through several sites including "Golden Lane" which is the most commercial of the bunch. It is essentially a look at life in the old days but at its core is the commercialization of it - instead of traditional looks, little stores selling Czech arts are placed throughout - handmade soaps, lotions etc, toys, marionettes, etc are for sale. There are some references and replications of old life there - a soldier's quarters, and a psychic's dwelling but you exit out into a restaurant before you reach the tunnel to go down and out of the district. Still worth it.

so many castles, so little time. Yes, you have to do one more castle. Its worth it. I love the Czech people and their history! We did the segueway tour first then this: Nice to get the historical perspective prior to walking tour
Magnificent City View""". Excellent place for tourists, the best position for special photos of Prague...You need make the money exchange previous, because on site the rates are not good...

Night visit the best!. We visited the Castle during the day and at night, and can recommend the Prague Experience's night-time tour (our guide, Rebekah was a great raconteur) when it is most atmospheric and the crowds have gone. We also saw Golden Lane at night - what a pity there is an extra entrance fee to visit it during the day.
Cobble stones. Everywhere in Prague is cobble stones, but here you have hills to contend with as well. Check out local transport - it's so cheap. It gets quite hot so carry bottle of water with you

Lovely day out!!. was a lovely day out.Well worth the visit.Cost around £25 for a family ticket and took us a full day to fully take in all the beautiful sights.The cathedral is absoblutely amazing and took 1000 years to build and is huge!!

A bit of culture. So much to see from the cathedral through to Golden Lane and the old dungeons. Well worth a visit and to see it all will take a day. Be warned, there are a lot of steps to get up to the castle!!

Atmospheric area for a stroll. This is a lovely part of Prague. We walked from Petrin Hill to Strahova Monastery and then to Loreta which is in the castle district. Really interesting places, lovely architecture and once you're up to the top of the hill, reasonably easy walking. Plenty of cafes and coffee shops for a snack or lunch. Can be a bit crowded - we were in Prague in August so quite a number of your groups on their way to the Castle. Well worth spending some time here though - lots to see
Super views!. Even though on crutches with a broken ankle, made the effort to get to the castle. Super views, amazing Church, and the vineyard is a must visit! ;-))
So good we went twice. We thought we could do this in about 4 hours. In fact it was so interesting that we went back on the second day. Moral of the story - buy the all-inclusive 2 day ticket.

Sensational. The whole area is fantastic and we loved the castle. Yes you can walk up to the castle, but we found the No 22 tram travels up to the top of the hill and the stop is right outside the castle. We went back in the evening when the crowd had thinned and we went to the concert at St Georges Basilica. It was a beautiful program and was well worth it. A good tip was to buy tickets the day before, we received quite a good discount so chose chairs rather than the pews!

A lot to see.... There is so much to see in the Prague Castle district. Not only is there the various cathedrals and castle building but I would also recommend visiting the exhibit 'The Story of Prague Castle' which gives a great overview on Prague Castle's history and the Czech royal families.

A steep climb to see a lot of tourists!!. Insanely busy with queues to get into everything. Best part was the Toy Museum tucked away where you had great views of the castle without the hustle and bustle
Castle District. Absolutely a part of the top 10 list of things to see and experience. Very charming and clean and lots of great architecture along with cafes and shops. Its a must see
worth the walk. Walked up here in extreme heat- should have got a bus, but good to see all the sights en route. Fascinating area- full of different parts- buildings in different styles, and gardens.
Beautiful place and sight. Beautiful area, many things, museums, churchs, gardens, quarters, squares, buildings, .. great sight. Another must of this town.

Too much to do but so interesting. The area around the Prague Castle is huge, I did a three hour walking tour around the area and the outside of the castle and there is so much to see. Lots of hill/stairs to climb but well worth the effort.
the Castle. We had a beautiful warm sunny day wandering through the church and castle grounds a most enjoyable day

Historic and impressive. The castle district and the castle specifically are historic and impressive. The district does get a bit crowded but people were polite. The shop street down from the castle was interesting too. It gets a bit touristy.
excellent. Worth doing a 2 hour tour from Wencesles Square which takes you right up to Prague Castle, beautiful sight and views over the river and town. Worth every penny.

A must visit. Enjoy the Castle Area with vthe hostorical Slata Ulicka (Golden Lane) (one advice; read Franz Kafka. He lived here 1916-17), - visit the St.Vitus cathedral and the old palace, - but don't forget also the area around the Castle.....
Worth a look. Just great to look at the architecture, visit some of the old buildings and look around the gardens and palace environs

Get away from it all. This district, with its castle complex, is teeming with people--tours, families, beggars, street musicians. However, if you strike out away from the main sights into one of the residential areas or parks, especially down the hill on the other side of the castle, you will find cool respite. Even if you are descending from the castle towards the Charles Bridge, try going a bit right of the castle steps to one of the steep streets. Like magic, you will be on your own, and will be able to find a nice bistro or bar where you will be invited to linger.

Breathtaking Views. Was worth the walk to this ara especially the views over Prague. I went about 20 years ago and you could not really all this area well. The lane where the goldsmiths used to live was free at that time, but now you have to pay to walk down there which was a little disappointing. Worth a visit all the same. There was some building work going on at this time, but it did not detract from the visit and from the old palace could see some stonemasons at work.
Magnificant. The Greatest Castile I ever visited prepare to walk a lot...it take four to six hours to see the whole castile but worth it and walk down to the charles bridge

Well worth the climb from the Charles Bridge!. The whole area is far larger than I realised, and you can spend many hours strolling through the streets. Most people visit St VItus' and the castle, but the whole district is interesting and atmospheric so I'd suggest it deserves more time.

Dat in the castle district. Walk around, stroll, take in the magnificent views, sit down for a light meal, enjoy the music and peoplewatch. A wonderful mix of activities and interests, in an inspiring surroundings. Remember there are many ways to get here so look closely at the map and choose the one that suits you.
Big area. Was really worth the effort climbing up the overview over Prague was magnific it was so many buildings and a nice place just to be at

Get an audio guide for a great day out. We visited the castle armed with our PocketVox audio guide (available cheaply online - a laborious voice to listen to, but informative). I believe you may be able to get an official guide at the castle, but I'm not sure.The walk is fairly steep, but shouldn't be too much of a problem if you can walk freely. There are shops and cafes on the way if you need to pause.The castle has 3 courtyards, each with it's own bit of history (get your guide!). The third courtyard contains the impressive St Vitas Cathedral. You can enter one end free, but armed with your audio guide you'll want to pay the small entrance fee and get closer. In particular you can see the many chapels, and the 2 tons of silver that make up the chapel for St John of Nepomuk.Attached to the cathedral is the South Tower. Great views, but be warned it's 287 steps up a circular staircase without any stopping points. You do get a medal as your reward though. Note that entry to this tower is not covered by the "view everything" ticket.The Royal palace is also well worth a visit. Again, there is very little information in English, but your guide should tell you exactly which window had bodies hurled through it (the Defenestration of Prague) which led to a long war.Inside the third courtyard you should also visit St George's Basilica.Golden Lane is OK to visit if you purchased the "view everything" ticket, but I'm not sure otherwise.We set out early and spent the whole day there, and we didn't even visit the galleries. Shame, as the pictures in my book show the rooms are worth a look all by themselves.Oh, and there are copious gardens to wander through as well.Eating facilities are so-so, but a simple lunch was all we wanted..Be prepared with a guide, pay to enter buildings and you get a full and interesting day at the castle.
Not really a castle. Its ok but not as big as they say, there's not much to see and it certainly dosn't warrant a tour guide. The gardens are pretty.
Get a guide. There is a lot of history here, but not a lot of it is apparent without a guide. The cathedral and surrounding buildings are interesting only when you know their backstory.

A lovely walk in Letna. If the castle area is getting too busy with tourists, escape by taking a walk eastward to the Letna Gardens perched on a terrace high above the Vltava River. The views are wonderful. Stop at the Hanavsky Pavilion for coffee and cake, the Metronome, with its boots (!), while it's still there (a photo of what was previously on the site is at the Museum of Communism) and then relax at the beer garden. A long walk but worth it.

Great Castle and Views. The walk to the top from the Mala Strana is steep, very steep. The walk through the castle is worthwhile. You can enter and see the interior and I'm not sure that is as worthwhile. The vistas from the castle looking out over the city feature some of the best photo opportunities I've ever seen.

Love it. It is a nice area to spend at least a half day over there, there are nice hotels and many little restaurants, walk to some side streets and enjoy a nice cold drink at the coffeehouses or a hot coffee

Castle 250CK ticket not worth. Tram 22 help avoid the steep hill climb. Entrance fee 250CK is not worth. Nothing much to admire. Peep into st virus cathedral without paying and turn back. Funicular train to petrin hill is a worth ride (24hour ticket is applicable). Chinese resaurant behind KFC is cheap, Large fried rice is 59CK.

Hradcany are a must but I would skip the interiors. I have been to Prague several times and have visited all the usual tourist venues of the Prague castle in the past. I did not visit them this year, because going inside the castle buildings has become pretty expensive and time consuming, not to mention the huge crowds. If your time in Prague is limited, go by all means to the castle, but it's probably not essential that you purchase the 2 day pass (or even the 1 day pass) and view all the interiors included in the passes. I think you would utilize your time better by strolling through the public areas of the castle and visiting less crowded attractions such as St. Nicholas Church, Bethlehem Chapel, or the Old Town Hall. I was at the castle at the end of June and it was jammed packed with visitors. Instead of going through the churches, I paid 80Kc for admission to the Castle Gardens (on the hill between the Castle & Petrin) and there I was practically alone and really enjoyed my walk down, with spectacular views of the city below me at every turn and delightful gazebos, statues, foutains, etc. at practically every step.

One of the largest castle complexes you will see. Well worth the visit, but take the #22 tram from in town to the castle stop and then visit/walk down to the city. Get the audio guide. Make sure you go through the audio guide in increasing numerical order or you will end up walking back up the hill!
Wonderful Castle. I believe this is one of the largest castles in Europe. Prague has a rich and turbulent history. It is a fasciniting city.

Exceptional but not for the infirm. Need some time to visit this area and take it al in. Up a very steep hill so get the hop on off bus or train to the top and walk back down through lesser town and over Charles bridge. A must see
a must see. We went there few times (bought 2 day passes) and once after 6pm, when it was much more relaxing and great for pictures.

Beautiful area. The Castle district is on the opposite side of the river from the Old Town but is definitely worth visiting - just so much history and architecture and gardens - a photographer's paradise.

Step back in time. Tram 22 is the best way to get there, and then you can walk through Hradcany to the castle and on down through the vineyards below. This area has been very well preserved and although there are the usual shops selling tourist tat, they are much less obtrusive than in the Old Town.

must see. Try to avoid the weekend when the summer crowd is so large it overwhelms the place. You have to wait in lines--avoid weekends! Aside from that, buy the 'short ticket' which lets you into as much as you can handle without overload. And do get the audioguide, or you won't know what you're looking at--there aren't many english subtitles.

Wonderful Visit. Old world charms abound in the Castle district with charming architecture and cobble stone streets. It’s an uphill climb just to reach the foot of Prague Castle but the walk is definitely worth it for the sights along the way. There are also plenty of bars and restaurants where one can rest and get some refreshments. For visitors who prefer a more leisurely way of seeing this part of Prague, tour trolleys are readily available.

great place to walk. we nearly didn't go through the Castle area...but are so glad we did, The gardens are spectacular and the view is too good to be true ....do yourself a favor and go walking here...

Interesting but lacking information. While the castle is definitely beautiful - yet crowded - we couldn't help but feel a bit uninformed as only few of the interesting sites had information available in writing only in Czech.

Short tour ticket. The short tour ticket was great, with access to the main areas of the castle complex. The most impressive was St. Vitus, and the least was the bottom floor of the Royal Palace (we didn't make it upstairs). Lots to see and an obvious major stop when visiting Prague.
Charming. Beautiful for romantic walks! I enjoyed it very much and whilst walkin throught "Hradcany" you realize how beautiful city it is!

A Full Day to Appreciate the History & Beauty!. There is so much to see here...the monistary, the churches, the castle, the art. Even the little cafe restaurant inside the castle area was a delight. A must see for any visitor to Prague. Stunning!
Nice Area to Explore. Nice shops and restaurants but it pales in comparison to the Castle itself. Steep streets lead up to the castle district from the river level but it is worth the effort.
Come for the view. Steep walk up and down, but the view and churches are well-worth it. Look for local artists selling original watercolors.
Castle Outside. The whole complex is beautiful. A visit to the Palace was dissapointing, very simple. Hardly any exhibitions.

A walk worth everything.. When we did this walking tour with our guide Keith, the temperature was really in the high 30's but it was worth all the leg cramps and all. The history of the place is fascinating. From experience, July could be hot so put a lot of sunscreen, put on a cap and good sunglasses and take along drinking water.
Great place to take photos. The panorama of Prague was beautiful, and the Church in the castle district was magnificent. It is worth going there for a couple of hours to take photos.

Amazing place. A must visit while in Prauge. Don't read the reviews nor guides - just go discover it by yourself and then read something about it .... you will discover it for the 2nd time. Highly recommended.
Don't miss the guard changing shifts...quite funny

Beautiful. Make sure you allow a full day here. So much to see. Make sure you get to see changing of the guard which takes place on the hour every hour. So many beautiful buildings and once at the top breath taking views of Prague.

From medieval to modern. Government offices, church buildings, galleries, too much of a good thing. Worth seeing, but pace yourself. This could be an all-day outing. It's fun to identify the different parts of the buildings that date to the 14th, 15th...up to the 20th century when construction was still ongoing.

Fabulous Castle. The castle is well worth a visit. We had joined a tour group/open deck bus at the Old Town Square which took us to the Castle. The tour was really informative and made the visit to the castle all the more enjoyable. The changing of the guard at mid day was quite fun to watch. Views from here are lovely.
Worth the hike. Castle and all the surrounding palaces makes for a nice place to just absorb all the beauty. The hike can be a bit much for those out of shape or run the stairs if you are in shape.
Not bad. I guess its one of those things you should see when in Prague, but there are much better things to do though. The view isnt bad though.
Very touristic. Room for everyone, not too many cars. Nice view over the city

Disappointing. Before we came to Prague we were always told the "Castle" was the central focal point of Prague. From a distance it stands out on top of the hill, when you get there it somewhat disappointing. The Cathedral is magnificent but the rest of the grounds are not very exciting.

Nice area. All the things you can see in the Castle distric are not worth it. The Rosenebrg Palace was disapoting. Also the Power Tower was disapoting. The Golde Lane was nice and the Cathedral was very nice.
beautiful but touristic. I would recommend it, but I expected more, there are a lot of tourists and you must pay for everything

Full-day activity. We didn't go into the castle itself- but we had TONS of fun walking around and exploring outside. You truly get all kinds of people there- there were Pragueians taking wedding photos and tourists taking pics of them haha.The big hill leading up to the castle is lined with shops and eateries. The hill is pretty steep, so people who have trouble with that should plan ahead. I did see cabs taking people to the top of the hill.The view is beautiful, and you can really get a sense of how people lived and what they did way back when. We were walking along these trails just outside of the castle, and when you looked up and saw the castle walls, it was amazing to think that those had been there for hundreds of years and that hundreds of years ago there were people doing exactly what I was doing right now!A really great experience- I got some really great pics!
Great place!. Definitely one of the best views to see the whole of Prague, very busy place covered in tourists! Still a good place to see though!
fun stop. Walking around in this area is nice, and you'll get a workout! If you're in Prague for more than a day, definitely make the trek to the castle and wander around the area for a while.

Perfectly touristic !. The place is huge and needs some walking to do and different areas of castles have different things to offer . You can see the guards marching. The view of the city is amazing from there . When pragues tourist sites/brochures advertise, they usually have this typical view of the city with orangish roofs ........

Lovely part of Prague. A lovely area to walk around completely for free, the castle grounds and just seeing the courtyards and buildings from the outside was lovely. It wasn't too busy either, as long as you avoided the changing of the guard time.

Lots to see and very touristy. There was a lot of ground to cover. The castles and gardens were beautiful. We felt it was a bit lacking in antiquities ... somewhat sparse. Certainly wasn't lacking in tourist vendors. It seemed as if they were trying to sell you something around every corner. Well worth the trip - we only did a couple of hours but could have easily spent a half to a full day exploring the different venues.
Great View. A visit to Prague is not complete without a visit to Hradcany. It is a complete area that is interesting and has a great view of the city of Prague.

Big castle. If you are going to visit the castle, then make sure that you have got time enough, there is plenty to see. Walks in the gardens, the tower of St. Vitus Cathedral, The Golden Lane etc. Remember walking shoes.

the castle worth the steep climb. he castle area overlooks the city and river below,its set5ting majestic,like straight from a fairy tale castle,sorounded by old houses and buildings and cobbled streets and sqares

A must when in Prague. Really enjoyed exploring the castle. Changing of the guards every hour was enjoyable as well. Be prepared for lots of walking on cobblestone. We didn't get to see it at night, but it has to be magical! Don't miss this!

Avoid the crowds - go early or late. We visited the Castle District late one morning and it was a complete mob scene. It was almost imposible to get a decent photo because of all the people. When the changing of the guard occurred, I thought people would get trampled by the hordes trying to take pictures.We returned that evening after dinner, and what a difference. With very few people around, you could take fantastic photos, including the guard change with no one blocking the view. Also, sunset photos from the castle area are terrific.We liked it so much, we returned the following morning around 8:30 AM and had the place to ourselves. We could take all the pictures we wanted without other people being in the shot. We bought tickets for St. Vitus church at 9 AM when it opened and were the only people in the church for a while. Again, great to take photos.My advice, if you want to get the beauty of the castle district, go very early or in the evening.

start at top. Like most reviews start at the top by either getting the hop on hop off bus (worth it-two day pass) or the mini train.
Wait for the guard change in a spot with a good view.

Interesting area to visit. The Castle district in Prague was an interesting area for us to visit. It is up on the hill, but it was easy to reach as it is well connected by trams and buses. We took the tram upto the Strahov Monastery and then made our way down from the monastery to the Castle and St Vitus Cathedral ( use the upper road not the lower road). We visited the St Vitus Cathedral, the castle, went down a steep path to the gardens and sat there for a while, before taking the stairs down to the lower level near the river. Apart from the buildings, the views from the Castle district are excellent. One should take time to enjoy those views.

Nice to know about old glory.. It was really very nice to have a visit there. All the castle, structure, statue, sculpture were really enjoyable. The place is a very big place. I will recommend any one to spent a more than 6 hours on the museum of the castle district if he/she want to know really in a detailed way.
A lovely way to spend the day!. With lots of great views, great history, and plenty to do, the Castle District is another must-see!

well worth the long walk. it looks beautiful from the Charles bridge, and is longer to walk to than you realize, but well worth the effort. Get a ticket that gives access to 4-5 other museums all within 15 minutes walk away, and stop for lunch on way down the hill at the winery museum.
Mixed. The cathedral was good, but Powder Tower was a little dull. No need to see it all.

Marvellous Hrad. When in Prague you must see The biggest castle in The World. You can spend a whole day checking every possible detail. You have a lot of things to see. We recommend that you buy The complete tour. It is money well spent.Just don't expect to eat well in The restaurants that you get inside The castle. The Quality of the Food is very poor, for The price that you pay.

Impressive castle, lovely view.. Great view over the town from the hill next to the castle. Lovely gardens below, nice restaurant outside the cathedral. We were lucky to see a string quartet outside the gates playing the Moldava about the river that runs through Prague - it's now my ringtone on my mobile!.
Lots to see. Various achitecture made this interesting. The door handles, gargoyles, arches and windows are amazing to see.
Lots to See. The variety of buildings at Hradcany is interesting, but the crowds can be overwhelming.
Very beautiful.. Can get busy but the views on Prague and the Castle ground are STUNNING! Open til about 11p.m and no entry fee so do go for a late night stroll, its beautiful!
have to see it. situated on the hill bit off city centre but lovely views and part of history

Castle trip. Superb views of the city. Changing of the guard every hour, but at 12 noon each day there is an impressive show with fanfares. Didn't have time to visit inside but probably interesting. Very steep path up to castle but convenient from Kampa Island

No need to hike up- tram 22 takes you to the top!. A great guide recommended visiting the castle distict from the top down, by taking tram 22 to the top and walking down hill. After 3 days of walking prague and aching feet we owe him a big thank you for that tip.The district is stunning, the views unforgettable. You haven't seen prague if you don't see it from above. It's simply breathtaking. Our favorite parts other than the views were the cathedral and the toy museum.
favorite area in Prague. Spent 2 mornings here wandering around. While we didn't enter any paid attraction we enjoyed the sights taking a ton of pictures, Really felt like were stepping back in time.

Don't forget the backstreets. Hradcany is a special place, but everybody wants to visit, inevitably making it very crowded. I've found the less well-known lanes near the Castle to be an antidote to all the bustle. Particularly recommended is a wander along the backstreets around Hradcanske namesti, the large square in front of the main entrance to Prague Castle.Walk along Kanovnicka, which leads off the northwestern corner of the square, and keep going. You'll soon come to Novy svet, a narrow, twisting lane where you feel as if you've been transported back in time. This cosy, intimate part of Hradcany is in striking contrast to the grandeur of the Castle and the adjacent palaces, but no less worth a visit. If you want to ecape the crowds and do some aimless wandering in one of the most evocative corners of old Prague, you should visit this part of Hradcany. But make sure you wear suitable footwear - even by Prague standards, the cobbles are murder!

The views are amazing!. It's quite a hike up, but the views are amazing! Even if you don't take a tour of the castle itself, the castle district is a wonderful place to walk around, explore the grounds, and take in the views.
