It is evident why they call Prague the "Golden City" from up here. We went in the late afternoon and stayed until the sun began to set. It was beautiful the way the afternoon sun shone over the city and the old buildings appeared to glow. The way the castle area is lit up at night is also gorgeous. The grounds are free to wander around. The district is rather large with plenty to see between the castle, cathedral, Golden Lane, great views, etc. I would plan to stay at least a couple of hours even if you don't take a tour of the inside of the castle. Other than the views, one of the best parts of our visit was seeing the Changing of the Guards which takes place every hour on the hour.This is a must-see while in Prague!

more great views of the city. this is another hilltop location where you will have great views of the city. they change to guards at the castle frequrntly for the tourists. the while are is very nice. worth the hike. I lost a few lbs. hiking up and down the hills in Prague
A Must See. Gorgeous grounds and buildings, extremely ornate Gothic cathedral, stunning views.
Old buildings without much interest. Only the Lobkowocz Palace and the Cathedral make the district worth visiting
Good condition. The views from the castle over Prague are breathtaking. So much history. Do look at the US and UK embassies.
worth the visit if only for the views!. wonderful place to take in the views of the city even if you don't go into the castle!

Lots to see!. You need at least 4-5 hours to see it all. Its a big area. The cathedral was beautiful! When done be sure to see the area below the castle. Lots of shops and museums and great places to eat. We spent a hole day in this area.
Loved it!. After walking all day, just across the bridge a couple blocks up on the right, spend the $20 to get a Thai Leg/foot massage! Heaven! Best $20 I spent all week!
A Wonderful Place to Stroll. There are wonderful cafes lining the squares in this area. Also, many beautiful parks just below the castle.

Worth the trip. The castle area is worth the trip up the hill to see. Caught the changing of the guard at the palace, saw the church and other building on the site. Nice views of the city from there as well. I do recommend seeing this.

Nice view of Prague on boths sides of the river. The bridge was exremely crowded by tourists, artists and musicians. Getting a good photo was a bit difficult. But the views from here over the river and to the Castle district are great.
The flagship of Prague. A good castle, superb history being told within its walls, enough for English speakers and great views over the city as well as a nice walk to get to.
Wonderful district. Go there very early in the morning and you will not regret. Nobody around and these romantic streets will be all for you two.

Worth a visit. On the quieter side of the river from the main tourist areas, the streets are almost deserted by comparison. There is a sense that you are taking in an older place in time, and the buildings seem to reflect this.The castle is very imposing, looking out over Prague. The history here is undeniable, dating back hundreds of years. I was impressed.Not much else to do over this side though, and if you are looking for good restaurants they are well spread out.
lots of castles. Lots if castles and palaces (they are different here). Lots if walking

Panoramic views and susprisingly peaceful. You get to see a surprising amount of the castle without having to pay the entrance fee, so don't avoid it on a cost basis. Great views of the whole town and lovely gardens
Average. In my opinion, the Castle looks more like a Parliament than a Castle.
Beautiful Castle. There was some renovation being done when we were there. Try to go with a guide so you don't have to wait in a long line.

The Castle is worth a visit. Get a full ticket that lets you into almost everything but make sure you wear comfy shoes. Lot of walking.
It's very historic and sets out well the struggle to become independent.
Just Beautiful.... I can't pick a specific thing to like other than the whole experience. I found it just magical and truly beautiful. Second only to Florence, Italy in my books...
Magnificent!. Amazing that you can just wander around the courtyards and not pay a penny! As we were there to see as much as possible we did not visit any venues inside!!
Exciting. Walking up Neruda Street to the castle steps, taking in all of the sights, seeing the old-time addresses on the houses was such a treat. If you like Old World Europe, you'll love this!
you have to go. you have to visit this place. Really nice! When we were there there was a concert of classic music

What a View!. If you want to get a picture that is so big you need three cameras to fit it in, this is where you need to go! It's windy up there, tie your hat down. But get your camera ready! It's breathtaking!

interesting. This "Castle" is not what we usually think of when we hear the word "castle." This area consists of several different buildings, including a very impressive church, the Bishop's residence and various government offices. Because this area is elevated, the view of the city is expansive and presents quite a photo opportunity.

Cannot miss. Fascinating and beautiful. Whole castle complex including Prague Castle. Didn't bother getting the tour tix since you can walk through the entire area free. Don't really like standing in line to traipse through buildings with a large crowd of tourists. Confusing on how to get there unless you're with a tour group, and there were many! I suggest taking a cab there so you don't wander the many non-straight Prague streets. You'll have plenty of walking once you're there and walk back down. If you find the tram that takes you up/down from the area, that's a good deal since it takes you straight down. The tram cost is about $2 for unlimited hour and a half (only takes koruna change). Full day tix are only slightly more. Worth it to see the city and get your bearings.

lovely medieval architecture. seems to be where all the embassies are taxis waiting in this area will charge you about twice what it cost to get there .please please be careful . 3 kinds of taxis , the ones you phone for are fair priced . the ones on the official ranks cost between 40 and 100 % more .the ones you find on the streets are out and out crooks will charge you between 300 and a 1,000 times more .
Gorgeous. Hradcany is a must. The best time to go is at night. You can't get into any of the buildings but there aren't any people there and the grounds are open for exploration.

Nice walk around...wear comfortable shoes!. Be prepared to walk alot around and within the castle area...there's lots to explore and see. the buildings have a lot of intricate art work and carvings...
WOW!!. Never seen anything like that castle. You have to see it from both perspective - nearby, and from distance.
lots to do. the castle itself is the largest in the world and you can do crossbow shooting, see loads of coats of arms and its like going back in time
Nice. You can Walk or take tram 22 or 23 to avoid the stairs, have a great view on Praha. Don't Ice cream there it is not good
Well worth the climb. We did the short tour which included Castle, Cathedral and Golden lane. Spent about three hours and enjoyed it all.

Lots to see and lots to walk. This is a must see sight in Prague. We took a tram up the hill so that we didn't have to walk it. We bought the bigger ticket for the sights and paid for the audio too. The audio is very expensive and only can be used for three hours. Beware that you will not see everything in three hours. We went to the castle, cathedral and picture gallery first. Then I ran to return the audioguides because you have to leave a 1000 krona deposit. Unfortunately I then did not have it for everything else. The castle section is very large and if you enter from the front, it goes downhill. I am the ultimate sightseeing person and was totally beat by the end. Maybe you could miss parts of it. I wanted to go to the gardens at the bottom was was too tired.. The view is lovely on the way down and there are some cafes that you could relax at on the way.
Castle Delight. There is so much to see in the castle. Plenty of tourists and tour groups, but it is large enough that the crowds are manageable.

Castle area. Lots to see - uphill walk but 22 tram very cheap. Lots to do - we bought a short visit ticket which was quite enough. Changing of the guard at 12 noon but difficult to see it all because of the crowds,

Awesome views. Loved the variety of architecture - worth doing a walking tour to understand the history a bit. Great views of the city and of course looking up to castle from Charles Bridge makes for excellent photos

A scenic workout. Hradcany is full of amazing architecture, adorable streets, cute cafes and interesting shops. Plus, it has tremendous views of the river and Charles bridge and old town. A great place to wander and explore while burning some calories climbing up and down some hills. Don't worry you can stop in a cafe and get the calories back with some goulash and beer.
See another side to Prague. After visiting the Castle, take time to explore the side streets around the main road back to the Charles Bridge. Beautiful, and yet slightly less touristy.

Amazing. MAKE SURE YOU WALK UP THE RIGHT ROAD LOL!!! We walked up the road next to the castle and to sayit's steepis an understatement!! (it was that difficult we actually walked past the castle because we didn't see it!!!lol)
Touch of history. Very nice view to the Czech history and old atmosfere.

Get a workout and be awed. The grounds of this palace are the size of a small city, so be prepared to walk. You can avoid the hills getting there by taking the trolley, but once there, you will find many steps and ramps. We loved the exercise. The palace itself is awesome. We bought a combo ticket and visited many of the sites within the palace. The basillica of St. George is the oldest structure and you can see the difference between the squared walls and flat ceiling compared to the later vaulted construction. The old palace was pretty stunning. You start at the indoor jousting room, where horses came inside with their riders. Every room is more stunning than the next, and in two of the rooms there is a great display of garnet and crystal. Tip- the prices are very competitive there with outside vendors, and you can be sure of the quality. If you see something you like, buy it. We made the mistake of waiting, then did not find anything comparable in town. Too late for us. Don't make our mistake. Shop around other shops first and you will be in a better position to recognize the high quality craftsmanship and the reasonable prices. The golden lane is an interesting row of dwellings built into the old wall fortifications. It is worth going up into the top section and walking past the armor displays. There is a booth where, for a couple of dollars you can try your hand at shooting a crossbow. St. Vitus Cathedral is every bit the elaborate cathedral you would expect in a palace. Worth a visit to see the paintings, statuary and windows. There is an incredible window by Alfons Mucha that is worth the visit on its own.

Not as good as I thought it would be.. Not a castle as such but a group of buildings. We had a short tour ticket and it was a mistake, but even then some of the places were closed. Getting a ticket took 20 minutes as the ticket man kept going away and it was most annoying

Once a year.... The Wallenstein Palace is also site of the Czech Senate, and it is open to the public only once a year - on May 8. Lucky for me, that was the day I was there. The gardens are beautiful. I waited 2.5 hours to get in, and was able to tour the Senate chambers. Unfortunately for English speaking tourists, the tour of the Senate was 100% in Czech. It is a beautiful building steeped in history.

a surfeit of riches. you're in danger of cultural and sensory overload here. You will need a full day to fully appreciate the riches on offer here. Or, as I did, do it in two halves to give your eyes and brain time to fully assimilate what's on offer. St Vitus Cathedral is the obvious jewel in the crown but I found the Schwarzenburg Palace with its bonkers patterned stonework more engaging. The Royal Summer Palace set at the eastern end of the Royal Gardens adds a personal dimension to a national treasure

Beautiful area, with less crowds.. Lots of wonderful buildings, parliament and embassies, very high security in area. Utterly charming. Unless you have great stamina, do not use the steps to the castle, walk the parallel street and have a more gentle climb. Great tram stop in the square from which you can get across the river and to the Old Town. Buy a ticket from the local tabac shop and travel all day.
excellent, but not much signage. The Castle complex is a must see, however, the entrances to each site are not intuitive or always clearly marked.
Very cool. There is so much to learn and don't miss the guard change....the Czech soldiers are HOT!
Walk down the History. Opt for a walking tour with an experienced guide. The insights and the data provided was enlightening.

Prague's Royal Seat. Fantastic opportunities abound if you get there early. The crowds are a killer! Buy your ticket ahead of the rush by going very early. There is a lot to be seen here, and one could easily spend a whole two days exploring the castle, churches, the Golden Road, and the gardens. During summer there are all sorts of castle concerts going on in the afternoons and evenings. There are also a couple of "haunted" castle tours on offer from businesses located at the castle end of the Charles Bridge neighborhood.

Biggest coherent castle complex in the world. buildings of various architecture style. It is biggest coherent castle complex in the world with an area of 7.28 hectars, 570 meters in length, 130 meters wide. It consists of a large-scale composition of palace and ecclesiastical building of various architecture style. The most outstandign places are St. Vitus Cathedral, Basilica of St. George, Old Royal Palace, Loreta Monastery, and Golden Lane. You buy combined ticket for whole Prague Castle.
An unusual castle area - many buildings.. Don't miss the changing of the guard in front of the government palace.

You need a full day for this. The castle is as big as the travel books make it out to be. Buy the full deal tickets and take everything in. And walk up to it so you appreciate the size and scope of the entire castle area. No visit to Prague would be worth talking about if you had not been to the castle.
A lot of steps. You need your walking shoes for this and the climb up may tax some people, but it is worth it. Gets very busy after 10.00 am when all the tour groups descend.

Get there early. Get there early to see much of the castle area before the tours arrive. The Changing of the Guard at noon is worth seeing but get there at least 20 minutes before it starts so you can get a good view

If you like churches, this is for you. We wandered down from Petrin Hill, having taken the funicular to the top. On a hot day this is definitely the way to approach Hradcany as everything is now downhill, and the hills are steep.We came across an attractive church initially but sadly it was closed, but there was an excellent information board outside.Moving on downhill we came across abeautiful building which looked just like the type used by the Gestapo in all the films. Surprisingly this was exactly what it was, and right opposite another beautiful church - what a pair of buildings to be in such a juxta position.Still moving down we came across numerous palaces, and fountains, and statues, and everyone of interest. Past the Cathedral, and onto a fantastic viewpoint which seemed to look ever all of Praha.Finally down to St Vitus' vineyard, and some beer and cake. What a day.
Beautiful. not much else to say which hasn't been said already. The views from the hill is spectacular and breathtaking. We walked through the paths down the hills and loved every minute.
coffe with president. great building..soldiers are super..bring camera with you..
Way too crowded. Had to queue so long just to get into the church. Try to go early to avoid long queues. View of Prague city was fantastic though.

Takes at least two days. Because the ticket is good for two days, take your time and come back instead of getting warn out. Try to get there early or late in the afternoon to avoid to large crowds. Have a pilsner at the castle.
Prepare for a full day visit.. Great views. Lots of musems. the visit to the castle and all the area will take you the full day.
Enjoy the walk. Lots of hidden jewels and lovely walk around the area.
Enormous Castle area. Some great gardens and fantastic buildings could easily spend all day there, Many places to eat and drink close by The "changing of the guards" was worth waiting for.
so nice. to walk the castle and palace grounds as well as the picture opportunities of the city and castle
Fantastic view. Go there at noon and watch the changing of guards. Take tram 22 up and walk down is a better choice. A view one should not miss in Prague.

Classic castle and cathedral area. Great example of medieval architecture, worth at least a half day of wandering around. We bought the short visit ticket which was plenty. It included the castle, cathedral and Golden Lane, which you can't see without a ticket.
Must Do. This is probably the one attraction along with the Astronomical Clock that everyone visits. Fun and insightful visit into historical Prague.
Gotta love a castle. Saw the changing of the guard at Prague castle. beautiful building
Lots of hills!. Fantastic buildings and architecture. Very hilly this side of the river. Good walking shoes a must.

Prague Castle. Quite a day out, easilly accessible from Metro system, attended a 1 hour lunchtime misic recital, had a tasty lunch at the same place Lobkowicz Palace. Buy the 4 place ticket (250Kc) to view buildings. If OAP(65) take ID for discount.

Short visit but worthwile. We opted for the short visit. I think we did it right.After the castle, go to the Petrin Hill, located in the gardens between the castle and the river...there is a small reproduction of the Eiffel tower. And, tip: There's a lift!

a must see in Prague.. This place is amazing. Lots of history and a lot of time is needed to visit properly. Spectacular views of Prague and the river and Charles Bridge from here. Crowded, therefor one should go early.

May 2012. Magnificent. There is so much to see that we only had time to view the varous buildings form the outside. We did manage to go into the cathedral which was beautiful. You need several days to take everything in that the area has to offer.

Lots to see. You can wander through the castle free, and in the palace gardens, but if you want to go inside some of the more interesting parts you pay. The history of Prague castle was worth it we thought.
Fantastic. We went on a walking tour and this was well worth it!

One of the best part from Prague. I was in the Prague center more than hundred times, but I visited Castle District maybe only three times in my life. I remember adage: The darkest place is under the candlestick.
This place is amazing, nice buildings, old streets. You can feel the history.
Sometimes very crowded, but worth to visit.
Castle, gardens, cafes, shops everything you want. Spend sometime around the castle - very relaxing and interesting.

Lovely buildings with many quiet corners. Many major sites here with some fantastic buildings, the castle gardens below the castle are beautiful with a small charge to see some of them. This district is very quiet at night (few resturants and cafes in the evening)

Too many people, but fun just the same.. The last time I was on this bridge was in 1977. It has changed. It is fun to stroll across, but it has become a virtual marketplace. On weekends it is almost impassable.Go early in the day!
Crowded! But beautiful. Definitely worth the visit but very crowded with tour groups. Go early or late.

Great History. A must see in Prague, you could easily spend a day here. We opted for the 'medium-sized' tour which took us 2-3 hours which was perfect for us. Be prepared for the walk up the hill/all the steps if you're older/not as fit as you'd like to be!
Magical place. Tons to see. Try climbing some tower (there are several options, with equally breathtaking views) to get a view of the entire city. Absolutely gorgeous.

History. We took the tram #22 up to the castle district. Make sure you get on the right direction. We messed up and took an hour tour of Prague that we would of never seen trying to get to the castle.
Old glory of Prague. see the royal palace and the castle. the view of the city from Hradcany is beutiful

Beautiful area with all the main buildings. Really pretty buildings, I liked that they're all in the same area... We had a lovely tour by Discover Walks in which he explained all the history in Prague.

Interesting historical site. The complex is huge and impressive, but very crowded. We liked best the St. Vitus Cathedral, especially the stained glass window by Alphons Mucha. The tiny houses of Golden Lane were interesting too, with good descriptions posted in English. The other two sites were a very old Romanesque Church, undergoing renovation and with no explanations in English, and parts of the 13th century castle with replicas of the crown jewels. There were only some brief descriptions in English and not much to see. Changing of the guard, every hour at every entrance, was entertaining. Views across the city from the palace walls were spectacular and there are some beautiful gardens.
1000 years of history. Just keep walking and you will see something that is amazing.
Take the tour. Allow at least a long morning or afternoon to see it all. Take in a concert if you can.,

Beautiful area. Getting to the castle, you walk through a beautiful area where most of the buildings have architectural details to spy. Unfortunately, most are tourist shops but I guess that is to be expected. We went in April and it was not yet too crowded. The castle does not have much to see inside, but explore the grounds a bit.
Amazing. its like a collection of small museums in addition to a cathedral and amazing royal gardens.. its a must see

Love it up above the city. Take the tram ! Spend a day. Return in the evening when the buildings are floodlit. There is always something to see Cerimonial guards stand on duty (and don't mind their pictures being taken)
Interesting Castle District. Castle district definately worth a visit. Very interesting

A Big Tourist Attraction. Other than Charles Bridge this is probably the biggest and best tourist attraction in Prague. Sat on a hill overlooking the rivers and the city this is a must for anyone visiting Prague. Very clean and tidy well patrolled with guards on all entrances. Quite enchanting around the area with lovely walks and quaint streets with small tourist shops, bars, cafe's and restaurants dotted around the cobbled streets. The walk down through the castle and grounds to the city is well worth the experience. Walking up is harder work so take your time.
uhhhh...... the place when I want to live forever, the magical view of Golden Prague...

What a delight. We visited the Hradcany Complex (Castle Complex), which was surprising bustling with tourists from all over the world (actually, not so many Americans). Over the course of the morning, we saw palace guards coming and going, the main Basilica (outside only since it was closed on this day), a toy museum and several old administrative buildings dating back to the 1700′s.There several exhibits across the whole complex that would be a delight for both young and old. We were there on a cold rainy day, but thoroughly enjoyed Hradcany.
Hardcrany. The whole area, the palace and adjacent squares were amazing and worth paying to visit.
Night tour. we did a night walking tour with McGees...absolutely wonderful! Even though it was pelting rain I would do it again. Such a different perspective on this area.
A must of the Prague visit. Even if you are not a sightseeing type or are in Prague for other reason, go there. You won´t regret.
Wandering near St. Vitus Cathedral. This is an interesting area to visit. Take half a day to wander around poking your nose into every corner.
Great. The views are superb and the live music and changing of the guard a pleasure to hear and see. Can get very crowded as lots of tours flood in from about 10 am.
Dont miss it. A beautiful place for a walk with picturesque view of Prague from the hill. Have in mind that pubs there are quite expensive.

Biggest castle at the world. A castle, that starts to be constructed on IX century, that dominates the city, and you can see it from everywhere. It has free access to the main attractions (the Saint Vitus Cathedral) and a paid one to visit other sites like the gardens (open from April to October).You can take the up hill walk from Mala Strana like a part of the tour, visiting Hradcany, the Loreta square and church, and the so many bars to take a czech beer. At the street plates, look to the word HRAD to reach the castle.
castle. love the inside of the church in the castle and the changing of the guards

Hradcany. This is the Prague Castle district, with small and paved streets, going up and around the Castle. I liked the old architecture, it's well preserved, with some quite places, but mainly crowded with tourists.

First stop. The most impressive part of Prague. Views, buildings of all ages, history and culture in the vast castle complex, cathedral, art galleries and more. You can buy a ticket for the whole lot (though a couple of the nine attractions have separate entry costs. Take time to walk the winding cobbled lanes around the outside, too.

Praha Castle. Loved the castle and the surroundingsThe view from the highest part of the castle grounds was awesome as you could see the entire city of Prague from there The architure was superb and if you have time spend at least five hours here enjoying the interiors and walking the castle surrounds Take a picture when the guards change quite similar to the changing of the guards in London Liked everything here except it was so cold on the first day of Spring
beautiful castle. The cathedral was beautiful. Gardens gorgeous! Having to pay to walk down the lanes in part of the castle- think it should be free.

Was OK, didn't see the hype.... Was OK, just don’t expect a real castle; it is more of a palace, and a bare palace at that. Only do the short tour. Golden Lane was probably the best part of the Castle area. There are a few cute little houses, but overall we weren’t impressed. Probably one of the better things to do in Prague, but that doesn't say much...
Guess what? That old-looking Church was built in the '20s. It's like Disneyland in there, except with nothing to do.

Nice church, amazing view.. The ambiance is great. The view is amazing if the day is sunny. Go upstairs to the top of the St. Vito church requires nice health and physical preparation...You need half a day at least for this programme, in order to enjoy all this local offers.

Grandeur and great views. The grandeur, space, range of buildings both small and grand. Huge spacious and uncrowded squares, cobbled streets to wander round and great views of Old Town and New Town. Disappointingly and misleadingly the Long Visit ticket did not include the Great Tower, and you need a good guide book

Can't miss while in Prague!. On the top of the hill, by the river view, you will find the most amazing and beautiful architectonical building in this Golden City called Prague! Make sure you plan this visit a time ahead and spare a lots of time to explore this location. Don't forget to visit the Golden Lane - to get the feel how tall local people were while back that age and also what they did and how they lived! Beautiful place for the President's Palace!
Lovely!. Really liked this area of Prage, very attractive, quaint, nice to stroll around and with good views.
Castle in the air. Extensive castle grounds and lots of different buildings to explore. Can find food and drink at stalls within and a good reward for the climb up the hill.

Beautiful castle. Beautiful castle with stunning views. Was sad that we were too early to see the gardens in full spring. It actually snowed a little on Easter this year. Very easy to get to by tram. Grounds are free to roam around.

Immense in size!. We decided to visit the castle on a whim as it was cold and wet and didn't particularly want to be outside. How glad I was that we went there. It is quite big in size, almost like a small town. Lots to see and do there, such as St. Vitus Cathedral, Golden Lane, etc.
A must see.
Disappointing. Only the cathedral was worth a look and the changing of the guard. Castle itself disappointing and you had to pay for the Golden Way which is a row of shops!,

Beautiful by day,Spectacular at night. I was lucky enough to experience this both by day and night. By day it was beautiful but crowded. You could buy either a short stay or long stay ticket which enabled you to go inside different buildings. We got the short stay ticket (250 Kc- about €10) which allowed us into St Vitus cathedral, the royal palace, St George's Basilica and Golden Lane. I found this price a little excessive to be honest. The cathedral is pretty and Golden Lane is very cute but still. At night the complex is left open so you can walk through but can't go inside any buildings. I found it nice and peaceful at night and a lovely stroll if you have the time.
Great views. Lovely walk from Petrin Hill down to the Castle. Lovely views of the city.
Fantastic. Visiting the Caste is a must!! there is nothing not to like, steeped in history and beauty.

The world's largest castle!. Loved the Golden Lane! Loved the History of Prague Castle Museum! What a splendid location all this is. Disliked: lack of public toilet facilities and the closer to the entry one was, the more expensive the mulled wine was... a bit of sharp business practice that... it's cheaper toward the southern side, closest to the river.

NOT THE SORT OF CASTLE I EXPECTED. When we think of castles automatically you think of Windsor, Balmoral etc, so we were a bit disappointed that it is a collection of different buildings which of course includes the cathedral as well. We didn't visit it all, but managed to see the Exhibition which was very interesting; the Senate gardens and building is wonderful and they do a season of free concerts as well. The walk up was okay but not suitable for impaired walkers, the view was fantastic, the castle gardens were good but very little flowers at this time of year, expected to see daffodils and tulips etc, but we imagine that when all the roses are out it would be wonderful. We did go back for a second visit but did not buy the all inclusive as we were I am afraid to say "cultured out".
Would recommend. Well worth a visit, try to see changing of the guard at 12

Golden lane is a must!. My favorite place in the castle is actually a site that some people miss. The golden lane, on the left side of the inner walls of the castle, is where goldsmiths and later the army or artists used to live. The tiny houses are a charm and inside some of them you can actually buy souveniers.
loved it. just great buildings and loads to look at altho you need to be fit to walk up the hill that take you to this area

Bring a sweater. WE visited the castle district in Feb. It was actually warmer outside then inside some of the buildings we visited. Bring a sweater and don't miss the Golden Row at the end of the district. Very interesting.

So much history.. This castle is the location where the Kings of Bohemia, Holy Roman Emperors and presidents of Czechoslovakia and the Czech Republic have had their offices, as well as the home of the Czech Crown Jewels. We were shocked to discover that Prague Castle is the biggest castle in the world (according to Guinness Book of Records the biggest ancient castle) at about 570 metres in length and an average of about 130 metres wide. Once we saw it, we weren’t surprised – this wasn’t a castle, it was a complete neighbourhood of churches, palaces, halls and gardens and one of the most beautiful cathedrals we’ve ever seen, whose architecture represent virtually every style of the last millennium. Don’t miss the changing of the guards, which happens every day at noon in the front courtyard.We made our way around the cobblestoned steps, necks craned looking skyward the entire time. We stopped at a café in one of the gardens for a (very expensive) beer, and headed back down into town. We didn’t actually tour the inside of any of the castle (it was too nice a day to be stuck inside for hours!), but you can find ticket prices and opening times here. http://www.hrad.cz/en/prague-castle/prague-castle-tourist-information/tickets.shtmlGreat hike up to the castle, great views from the top, and the most stunning cathedral we've ever seen. Definitely a must-see while in prague!

Use a personal tour guide. I used Prague Walker to get a personal tour, and I'm SOOO glad I did because it's so crowded with bigger tours, so my husband and I got a great experience despite the crowds. The tour guide had a wealth of information, and we left on cloud nine!
Excellent break. In the old town square. A must see. Take care as it does not perform all day

Uphill Climb!. We walked up to the castle but people with impaired mobility would probably need to take a taxi. It is a steady climb but well worth the view of the city. There are lovely shops along the way that are worth a visit.

Early evening magic. This is a lovely place for a walk at any time, but it's at its most magical in early summer evening when the lanterns have just been lit, the air is still soft but not scorching and the old atmosphere begins to reclaim the set. It¨s totally worth it just to wander around and breathe in the centuries.

Superb castle - don't miss it. The combined entry ticket is great value. It is valid for 2 consecutive days which we found really helpful. We were amazed by the vaulting in the Hall and sneaked back in for a second viewing!

Beautiful and fascinating area. Just when you think you can't cope with any more beauty and architectural genius in Prague, you stroll up the hill past lovely old commercial and residential buildings only to find that it opens out into a magnificent vista at the top. Just go, you need to see it for yourself.

The castle covers a lot of ground.. We took a castle tour with www.discover-prague.com with a Czech guy who also taught English and was a musician. He made the tour very interesting and answered every question we threw at him. This tour is not suitable for people with impaired mobility.
lovely grounds. the Castle has fabulous grounds. Advice, go in April when the gardens open!
Historic, clean, organised, fantastic view of Prague.. You can and see most of it without paying. Check out the changing of the Guard at 12:00 (Midday)

Its hard work walking. we walked to the castle, which was a huge mistake. Its all up hill, and tiring. when up the hill, u can go into the castle grounds for free. I wish we had stopped there really. We paid 500kc to a half day pass. That only let us into 4 areas. and one of these areas was free to get into anyway.the other areas was a nunnery, a royal palace that had nothing in there just empty rooms with no decoration and false jewels made up from the local school, and the last one was golden lane. This is a narrow row of houses where they want u to buy something, but you are paying to get in there in the first place!!!overall, I'd get the number 22 tram up for the lovely views, take pics with the guards and DO NOT EAT AT THE TERRACE OUTSIDE THE CASTLE ON THE HILL. VERY EXPENSIVE AND WASNT SURE WHAT THE MEAT WAS IN THE HAMBURGER BUT IT WASNT BEEF!!!!!!!!!!!!!!anyway, havee a look at castle, then walk bk down.

A Must See. Interesting historic site. You need a half day to do it right. It gets crowded on weekends even in March. Go during the week if possible. Our visited was affected by large tour groups. Expect to walk a lot. Great views of the city are bonus.

Step into the past. The Castle district is amazing! Everything is so mysterious and reminded us of the Middle Ages. The castle has its own “town” inside it but then outside it was surrounded by beautiful houses, shops, i can just imagine the plebeians working there for the royals! It is very cute; we loved it! Wear comfortable shoes; it is all uphill!!! Great workout!
Great place - a must. go there! great view. leads to other places you have to visit.
go back in time. if you can handle the hilly walk it is well worth it to take in the beauty of the architecture and feel the buzz of the place.

So many places of interest - nice area to walk around. We enjoyed the walk around this district. It is not a very large area but lots of places of interest including to St Nicholas Cathedral which charged for entry but no guideso I went in myself and left hubbie to walk in the square outside.

Well worth the visit!. Quite a long climb by the Old Castle Stairs but there is a tram instead. Said to be the most complete castle and cathedral in Europe it is very grand with its own "changing of the guard". it does have to be visited although we did not enter any of the museums, etc..as time was short.
Huge and nice. We got tired to climb up to the hill, but the view of the city was worth every step. Unfortunately it was late afternoon, so there was not much to do there.

No words to describe it. One of the most fantastic arquitecture sites in the world. Full of different styles, from the Romanesc to Renaisance and Gothic, you will find all in here. Book at least half day to walk around and get a guide if you can to fully appreciate this place.

Beautiful & breathtaking. It is a very beautiful castle and you can take endless pictures here. After seeing this castle, all the other castles fade in comparison.
A picture perfect moment from Charles Bridge. So fairy tale like :)
Based here.. Plenty to see in this district, Castle, Cathedral and many other sites of interest. the hotel we stayed in (The Golden Star) was located at the bottom of the cathedrals new steps.

so big, but closing early!. amazing how big it is, view on the old town is great, buildlings, church are so beautiful. a same i go not go inside the church as it close around 4pm. but overall did a quick tour and i like it a lot.

prauge castle march 2012. the castle is more of a fortress with a large catherderal inside, very beautiful when it is lit up at night, the guided tour helped us to understand the history of the castle, and the guards at the front were very impressive, lovely views of prauge from the top so take some pictues, a very imformative trip around the castle, although we did not get to walk around the gardens which was a bit dissapointing

Beautiful Architecture and Perfect Place to Stroll. The Castle District is stunning, clean and a great place to get exercise, fresh air and take in the amazing views and atmosphere of the city of Prague.
Enjoyable to wonder through the town. Do this without a time table, take your time and enjoy the journey.
amazing. This place is one of the most attractive places in Prague. I really liked the city. People are very welcoming and friendly.
Views. The grounds are beautiful and the views from the tower are a must

Fantastic views from the top, unmissable. we visited Prague castle in February and walked along nerudova street to get to the entrance, the castle area is really good there are a lot of different places to visit and I would suggest buying a combined ticket that will gain you entry into the various places, rather than paying individually, you can get them for 250kc or 350kc, and you also have to pay 50kc for a license to take photos, well worth it. There is a ticket booth inside the 2nd courtyard, go past the entrance where the guards stand, and then through to the next courtyard, and it’s on the left.We saw the changing of the guards while we were there, and it’s very interesting.From the top there are some fantastic views of Prague, its worth it just for the views.And I can recommend golden lane, lovely street with little houses that used to be lived in, so interesting.It took us about 3 hours to get round everything and that did not include st vitus cathedral because it was closed when we were there, which I was gutted about.

walking. We first walked over the bridge on our way down from the castle, vendors on bridge very arty as expected.We walked back to the bridge the same evening and it was well worth the walk,same beggars on the bridge but lovely in the dark with the castle illuminated.Always felt safe ,use common sense though as with anywhere.

Beautiful for wandering but not much else to do. I love this place purely to wander around the streets, mooch around the castle (the free bits as it's quite expensive to get in) and maybe stroll off to Petrin Hill, the shops aren't up to much and the overabundance of restauarnts doesn't seem to stretch this far, so purely for shilling out rather than for shopping or eating.

Large Castle Complex. This is not a midevil castle. We misunderstood. It is a large complex. You can walk around and choose which portions you would like to see. Then you choose which tickets you'd like to have.

Worth the cost of the tour!. The tour of the castle is well worth your time and money, but try to beat the large group tours there by arriving first thing in the morning - exploring the neighborhood in the area is a bit limited, but the stairs and street linking the castle with the Mala Strana is a fun walk with some good snack or lunch options.
Worth the effort to get there!. Need to climb steep hill to get there but once you finally get there, you can see the entire city, besides the complex is really amazing!
Worth the trip.. The views and the houses in the square are something to behold. The changing of the guard tops it off.
Iconic. One of the world's most famous bridges with stunning day and night views of the river, Castle and Petrin Hill.

a day of wonder. we timed it just right to see the changing of the guard at midday,lots of pomp etc.You really do need a whole day to take in everything at the castle.One warning,if like my wife you have difficulty walking it can be hard going,lots of steps etc.

Spotlessly clean. Again the many historical buildings were an eyeful for tourists - and a lot of them even on a very chilly morning. it's not too difficult to go from one site to another. There were long queue at the front of the castle but no one knows what for so we didn't bothered to queue and just made our own way into the castle area. It will take a full half day if you visit all the interiors of the many buildings. It's your personal choice.
Prague castle at night. It is very nice when the lights change the atmosphere of the place and especially in February there is only a few people at 7pm

great way to spend your time in prague. castle is very interesting.it is very big and a bit tiring to if you want to see all but worth it:)the view is very beautiful from the top and u can have some delicious pancakes:)and there are very cute little shops to buy souveniers.have fun!

It's Why We Travel. Every corner reveals something wonderful. We did a walking tour, and were thrilled by the history and architecture. I can't imagine a visit to Prague without a day in the Castle District.
GORGEOUS. So much history in one place! Worth a visit but make sure you wrap up warm. This was the coldest we felt the whole time we were in Prague because its up so high!
Need A Fully Day. A full day was spent in Castle District - recommend buying an all inclusive ticket - excellent value
Visit everything here. Take your time and do the lot (need to buy combined ticket) from St Vitus Cathedral to Golden Lane to Palace itself
Nothing to get too excited about. Ok but not a must see in my opinion, I think there are a lot nicer things to see in Prague
lovely. beautiful views over prague and old buidings worth walking round

Great views of Prague. Lovely walk around the castle and great views over Prague. Can either walk up, not a bad walk or get the tram, either way its a great place to spend a few hours, gets very busy though.
great architecture, beautiful interiors. a bit of a hike up lots of steps but well worth it
NICE!!!!. its on a high ground so be prepared to walk up hill
Quaint & Wonderful. Lovely area to walk around in, even if you don't actually go into the castle itself. There's a lot of bars and cafes to choose from and siome stunning views across the city.
Changing of the guard. At 12 noon every day! a must see, all the parafinalia of the guards is magnificent

Must be seen.. Just walking the grounds, looking at the architecture, and the stunning views out across the city is worth half a day. Admission inside, especially if the crown jewels happen to be on display, should be worth the wait in line. There are many beautiful areas in Prague to explore, and this is one of them not to be missed.

Adults Beauty and the Beast. Go up at night, and when its cold. You will be the only person walking around. Gorgeous old antique lampposts, cute medieval winding cobble stone paths, beautiful gothic cathedral in the background. My favourite part of prague for sure! I felt like I was in a fairytale.

The Ultimate Must. Even in January, the line for entrance tickets was 200 m long! Maybe if you come early and avoid the tourist bus crowds, it's easier to get tickets. Any of your guide books will tell you this is a must-see!
Really nice. Look around. Try to go here in the evening to photograph the sunset, then take a taxi downtown to have a nice italian meal :)

Worth a visit. In my opinion you should visit the castle. There is a ot to see even if you don't purshase a ticket to go inside.
Surrounding areas are the same as prague centre with shops and restaurants.
Many steps to climb. worth a visit, best to have a Castle map so you don't miss anything. Tickets need for entry to many things
Prague castle. One of three sights to see in Prague. It is sooo huge you couldnt realize. Only downsize is you have to pay entrance fee for church

Magical.. Lots of fun around the square when the clock chimes on the hour. Again, watch your wallet or handbag! Beautiful beautiful clock, so unusual. Climb to the top and take in the stunning views of the city.

Steeped in history. The castle district of Prague incorporates the Palace, St Vitus Cathedral and several other magnificent historic buildings. Our visit only lasted a few hours as it was very cold and rainy; however you could easily spend a whole day here. Don't miss the view over Prague from the terraces. It is breathtaking!
Fantastic views. The largest castle in the world, well worth the visit and breath taking views of the city. Take the steps up if you need a workout after a big meal

Fantastic!. When we got to the top of the hill and saw the buildings it certainly had the WOW factor. So clean. The view from up there are amazing. You can see all over Praque and for miles around. Worth the climb up the hill.
Worth a wander. This part of Prague is beautiful, littered with cafes, restaurant, bars and galleries, it enhances an afternoon stroll in a very pleasant way.

Hradcany Castle. Although you will be there with every other tourist in the city, this is a must see. Coming up with the street car on the west end, you see the entire grounds, the 'chapel', the enclave of government buildings - all of which are beautiful and unique in their own way. exiting on the east, you have wonderful views of the city as well as an option to walk through a small vineyard and enjoy a glass of wine.
Amazing!. There is so much to see here: the castle, the cathedral, and the cute, mostly residential quarter just up the street from the castle

Huge!. This isn't really castle, it is more like an area. It is a huge cathedral, various countries embassies, tourist shops, cafes and hotels. It is worth a look around, but i wouldn't set aside more than a few hours to tour the area.
Fabulous. go there in summer, there is a Shakespeare festival outside in the middle of Hradcany

Another "must see". Everyone who visits Prague will visit the Castle District. Best early morning before the bus tours arrive. Gets especially busy during the changing of the guard, but this is still worth seeing if just for the musicians standing in the upstairs windows playing, what sounded to us like the theme from "Thunderbirds".

Largest Medieval Castle in Europe. You can spend the better portion of your trip to Prague walking around this castle area. If you are coming across the bridge it's a bit of a hike up to the top not to mention walking around so wear good shoes.

Really cool old castle. everything was enjoyable and interesting about our visit to the castle. It seemed like there was something around every corner. My son enjoyed shooting a crossbow, my husband liked all the torture devices and the castle firetruck, and I liked the overall historic feel. Touristy but not overdone.

Nice old castle, great view from there over the city. The castle itself is very nice and the surroundings as well, from there visitors do have a great view. The area is quite expensive if you want to have lunch or dinner.
Castle. Very atmospheric with helpful information dotted about.
Mindblowing history. This is a must see! You can easily spend a day up here. Take good walking shoes and a camera

Unbelievable History. So vast, so beautiful, so grand. Very crowded despite the freezing temperature. Hated having to leave it. Loved the view and glad our tour commenced at the top., Not long enough there.
Great for walking. Old buildings and little traffic. Walking the cobbled streets helps with the atmosphere

Excellent place for family and friends!. This is also one of the true jewels of Prague and 'not to be missed' place. One should really be having a good appetite for walking if you want to explore this whole place! The whole castle area is awesome with magnificent views!
Castle area was awesome. The castle area was awesome with many great sites. As New Years eve grew closer it became very crowded, as to be expected.
The creme de la creme of Prague. Although a fairly strep climb, the whole area is so worth visiting.

Stunning. The area is almost overwhelming so I would recommend that one visit the area at least twice and stick to a plan of sightseeing. The castle itself could take a full half day and one can get to the rear of the castle by tram or walk up the front area from the Charles Bridge (a long walk). There is so much to see in the nearby historical area (walking down from the castle) that it takes another half day to see it all. Alternatively stay in accommodation in the area so your walking tour is reduced and catch a tram down to the other incredible sights such as charles bridge and Old Town (Stare Mesto)
Wonderful views. A real sense of history about this place. Don't think I would have liked walking round the hilly, cobbled areas if it had have been icy though!

Definitely worth a visit. The walk up can get steep at times, but it's defninitely worth going up. There are great veiws of the ity, and plenty to see. The changing of the guard is always a big deal. The architecture is quite impressive aswell.
Yo've got to see it. Don't miss the Castle District. You haven't been to Prague if you miss this area!
Worth a visit. Lots of places to see and things to do. Scenic with lots of chances for photos.

Remarkable. We went to the Castle area & bought the long stay visit ticket for CZK 350 per person which includes Cathedral of St. Vitus, Old Royal Palace, permanent exhibition "The Story of Prague Castle", St. George's Basilica, Convent of St. George - National Gallery, Golden Lane with Daliborka Tower, Prague Castle Picture Gallery, Powder Tower, Rosenberg Palace and you can use it for the next 2 days. We did the first full day & then the second day we came back to do the golden lane & tower. The castle & all the buildings are really amazing & the history is very rich. Don't expect Versailles, it has it's own beauty. Wear comfortable shoes & take water with you.
beautiful view. You can see the city from there, and enjoy the architecture and the orange roofs

Architectural and historic bliss. Wealth of old buildings with amazing architecture housing museums and galleries. Changing of the guard every hour, but is worth seeing at noon outside the Royal Palace, when there is a musical fanfare.
Lovely views. A lovely area to walk although a little crowded. The guards seem to be a big tourist attraction and the buildings are magnificent.
Quaint. More of an old palace than a castle. Great views. Worth the climb.

loved the area. This is what fairy tales are inspired from. The castle district is a colorful and architecturally stimulating place to be. The buildings are alike but different if that makes any sense. The district sits on a hill which helps you imagine what life was like "way back when" when not everyone lived within the castle walls. This picturesque part of time was fun to walk around with all it's unique shops and cafes. Take your time and enjoy the scenery from on top of the hill and the complete district.

Hradcany. I think another reviewer said it best when he/she proposed to visit during the evening only because of the spectacular views. As soon as those lights are lit all over Prague city, it's trully amazing.
Poor lunch. Limited venues for lunch dining on this side of the Charles Bridge
Half day visit is not enough. We were on a tour and I would have wanted to stay longer and explore the gardens.

Best for history & culture. Prague Castle is the largest ancient castle in the world. The complex dates from the 9th century & includes the Gothic St Vitus Cathedral, the Vladislav Hall & the Renaissance Belvedere summer palace. The Castle boasts a number of treasures; the recently unveiled Princely Collections are a must-see.Golden Lane is an area that you pay extra to see. It's a row of charming 16th-century small houses where author Franz Kafka lived. Many buildings are now souvenir shops. The area was reopened to the public earlier in 2011 following renovation work. From here you can stroll down the new castle steps to Mala Strana.The Castle is an important part of Prague's heritage and deserves at least half, if not most, of one day. Crowds were evident even in December & I fear that in summer crowds could be overwhelming.
Great walking tour. We elected to take the limited family tour (entry to 4 locations in the castle complex). It was perfect for us. The 4 year old was wiped after.
always worth it. always worth it, even if you do not pay to do the full tour. the views are still amazing.

Beautiful to wonder around. Loved climbing the hill to see the castle then going inside the cathedral, changing of the guards is cool since no security or fences they walk right up to you (very different than London thats for sure!) was a great afternoon and lots of good coffee shops and restaurants on the way to keep you going.
Lovely morning trip. Great time to go up is in the morning where you can go across Charles bridge and be at the top with plenty of time to see the change of guard around midday.

wow. What a collection of architecture and history. go and learn how to shoot an crossbow, while you learn about the history of prague, the era of the habsburg and all others who occupied and utilized prague. see golden lane and kafkas haus number 22 and the prison cells, as well as the cathedral and the old basilika... amazing.

BIG PLACE WITH LOTS OF HISTORY. This was my 2nd visit to the castle. Much of the history is stripped down in the sense that there is only the shell of a magnificent building whilst the inside is bare and you have to use your imagination. Fair enough. The only exception are the little houses in 'Golden Street' (I think that is the name) which have been inhabited by artefacts and decorations from the days of their residents,some of which were there up until 1920s, Such a variety of building styles is amazing, and the size of the complex is formidable. Delicious hot chocolate from a vendor in the grounds behind the cathedral.
Just okay. Go up if you need to see Prague Castle. Once you cross Charles Bridge, it is just a tourist trap. Go if you need free internet; there is a Starbucks
Very interesting indeed.. Didn't get to go in the paid for parts as much was closed for the lying in state and funeral of Vaclav Havel. Good anyway though and the cafe serves excellent hot chocolate!

Nice area for a romantic walk. Don´t miss Nový svět (A New World) street and Loretto.Or a so-called Domeček (A Little House), place where many Czech patriots have been tortured by the Commies in early 50´s!

Perfect place to wander around for a few hours. The place is amazing if you love to take photos and just wonder around aimlessly on the small cobblestone streets. Loved the panorama towards the city. The Golden Lane is also very nice to visit, and you can do this for free after 16.00.

Nice place to wander. We love to wander around and see the buildings with plenty of photo opportunities. It's quite pricey to see the Castle itself and the Golden Lanes but still a nice place to visit. The views are great over Prague too from the top of the hill.

Narrow, hilly streets. On the hill around the Prague Castle, this area contained narrow streets, with rough cobblestones and compact little stores, café and restaurants. The area had a quaint old charm. The views looking back over the river into Prague 1 were fantastic, as was Petrin Hill rising to the south. Some lovely little street and walkways can be found. A lovely part of Prague to wander and explore.

Worth the walk to the top. Great views.. Nice walk up to the top. Need to purchase separate ticket for admission to room with crown jewels (did not do), not sure if any of the rooms are open for public to see. Peeked in the windows and saw lots of empty rooms. Worth the walk up, anyways/
Castle. The castle is slightly disappointing as it does not fulfil the pre-conception of a fairy-tale castle.
Beautiful and in good condition. Wished we had had more time , and our tour could have included seeing the interior of the palace
A little town in itself!. So much to see, amazing place. Half a day should be set aside for this.

Amazing place for photos. The castle complex is large. I didn't go inside but spent hours pouring over the grounds and taking photos. You are high up and the views of the city below are amazing. There's a lot of ground to cover and walk up - do not use the tram or you will miss a lot of shops and lovely views.
buy the full tour. Don't scrimp, buy the full tour (self guided) and see the entire complex, there is so much to see and it is well worth the money.

Uphill but not in a bad way!. Great walk from the Old Town across the Charles Bridge and up the hill to the Castle. Lots of little shops and cafes. If you have kids in buggy, don't let go on the way back down! Lovely area worth a visit.

Breathtaking View of Prague. The views of Prague from the Castle District are outstanding and a must see for anyone visiting Prague. We spent about 4 hours walking the entire Castle District and enjoyed the major attractions of the Monastery, Loretto, Castle and Cathedral. We returned on another day to tour Lobkowicz Palace and highly recommend the museum, cafe and chamber music concert (combo ticket available online on their website - be sure to get the audio guide). Be sure to wander the artist/residential area of the District where you can find the building used as Mozart's home in the movie "Mozart" (we had a guide that pointed it out or we would have missed it). The District is crowded with tourist so be sure to visit early in the day to avoid some of the crowds.

Very impressive. The Castle District is one of the stops on the Hop on Hop off bus so it is very easily accessible (or you can catch a local tram). Allow yourself a whole day here as there is so much to see. And make sure you have lots of room on your camera's memory card because the buildings are quite spectacular as are the views overlooking Prague. The Poets Cafe in the gardens is a lovely quiet place to enjoy a light meal or just a coffee.

Stunning views. Free to walk through the complex and the changing of the guard is very accessible as long as you don't mind elbowing the other tourists. Stand outside the railings on the northern side of the first coutyard for the best view
Excellent views over the city. tour the castle and cathederal and complete with a leisurely strollthrough mala strana to the old town. The views of the city are spectacular from the castle ramparts.

Need a week to really enjoy it.. While it was cold and rainy, the grounds were still pleasant to stroll in and the individual buildings were fascinating. I would choose a couple of things to do there and do them at a leisurly pace.

Up Petrin Hill and Over to the Castle.. We went up the funicular to Petrin Hill, enjoyed the rose garden and photos from space. Then walked across to the Monestary where we had a lovely little lunch, and beer. Great views. Walked down to the castle and then caught the tram back. Very doable , but not much signage, just follow the other tourists.

Castle Great but tickets are a rip off. Great but beware the castle tickets. They make you buy tickets for five things when most people are only interested in one or twoEating on the baclony of the upmarket restaurant/snack bar was wonderful with magical views
great views of city. There some great views of this beautiful city from here and some reasonable restaurants too, amongst the tourist traps. Wear good shoes as its all steps and cobbles!
needs a 2-day visit. must start the visit from up near Kepler's statue and then walk down..this huge complex definitely needs a 2-day walk around to fully enjoy it.
Great afternoon!. Don't miss the Prague Castle when you visit Prague... we skipped the paid tour inside the Cathedral.. saw all we needed to see without adding any cost.

Prague's must see. Prague Castle is a must see for any visitor coming to Prague for the first time. No matter your interests or time you have, in the whole of the Prague Castle complex there is something to fit everyone's taste and time limits.
Great way to spend the day. We spent the day in the Castle District and the entire family had a great time. Not to be missed!

A Trip Back in TIme. There are a lot of beautiful things to see in the Castle District. Truly charming and of course St. Vitus in amazing but the rest of the area all together is what makes it so special! It's like a story book village you only read about as a child.

around the castle. Behind the castle there is a residential district Novy Svet which we missed but you might like to consider. Some great pubs where the locals drink with very reasonable prices and excellent beer of course {mind you the pubs are smoky so be prepared to air your clothes afterwards}.
richy. very wide and richy palace you walk there in a very nice atmosphere with the rest of visitors
Tour. Nice to do the tour 'old town + castle' with the oldtimers!

Much to see and do in this special area. Hradcany provided us with easy access to many attractions. For a single fee you can visit many of the most important areas in Prague including the seat of the government. We saw the changing of the castle guards, lots of brides, the Prague Castle Orchestra (a group of 4 street musicians playing Czech music), stores, lovely old buildings, museums, restaurants, the house of Tycho Brahe, etc. etc. This area is a place to spend several days.
Touring the houses. The houses and the park is great. Walking up and down each street is a joy.
Prague Castle. Disappointed that it was not marked well with signs informing you what you were viewing. Many buildings were closed and it was extremely crowded.

Castle is the star±. Walk across the Charles Bridge and climb slowly up to the Castle
to enjoy this wonderfully maintained series of old buildings. There is an excellent little art gallery with some superb paintings. Also tucked away in the garden a lovely little cafe with tables and chairs out in the sunshine±
Nice. Nice to walk around , some lovely places to eat and drink.
GREAT CEREMONY. Very impressive, particularly the changing of the guard ceremony etc. There is plenty to see here, unfortunately we couldn't see the main gardens.

Excellent area. Started at Loreta where the church and museum are extremely interesting. Wandering through the lanes admiring the buildings and eventually entering the main square in front of the castle is a great way to to spend a morning or afternoon. It is hard to choose between the cafes but the 'hole in the wall' near Hradcany Nameski sells delicious sausages!
The view. Historic place. Full of beauty sites. In a hill, so be prepare to walk. Wonderful view of the city, the river and its bridges.

Strahov Monastery + Beer, Loreto. Walk away from the madness in front of the castle/cathedral and crowds reduce considerably. Very pleasant almost traffic-free area with much to see. Disapponting that the church at Strahov cannot be visited (a most unfriendly sign here) but the west doors are open so that the interior can be seen. The libraries are impressive though (admission charge) and there is a microbrewery in the grounds. Nearby is the Loreto (Loreta), a quiet peaceful spot with small numbers of tourists paying the admission charge. Church, Sancta Casa, Cloisters and Treasury Museum all in the price.
beautiful area. we stayed here and thought it was a great area because easy for public transportation but less hectic than old town

The height of Prague; Palace, president, cathedral, park. One the heights overlooking the river and the rest of Prague is the fortress that Prague Castle.  It now houses the offices of the President of the Republic, the main cathedral and many former castle buildings that now house offices of the government and museums. Behind the main castle area is a nice park where is located the orangery buildings and the belvedere. I found it a beautiful and restful place to absorb the majestic views of the city. There are also wonderful views from the walls at the front of the castle where you can view all the special buildings that house the embassies below in Mala Strana. I like the little toy shop that sells traditional wooden toys, which is inside the castle complex. You can't visit Prague without seeing Hradcany.

Visit the golden lane and the nearby metronome park. The golden lane is charming, as well as the other small streets in the area. The area in front of the main entrance is also very nice with very regal buildings and not as touristy as the old town square. From here you also have some very nice views over the city.To the other side of the castle is the metronome park. Very nice area for walks with some glorious views of central Prague. The Russian-style house is also beautiful and has a nice café with grand views (once again!). To the end of this park is the entrance to Prague's newest and most enjoyable attraction: the Technological Museum.

Highlights are the St. Vitus cathedral and the Golden Lane. While the castle and mausoleum are interesting, the highlights of the castle district are St. Vitus Cathedral and the Golden Lane. A combo ticket will get you access to all four for 250 CZK (around $13).To get to the castle, take tram 22 from outside Mala Strana metro station. It's only a couple of stops.

A must see - the iconic image of Prague. I had to write this review after seeing a new review posted today calling this area 'rubbish'. I cannot imagine such a description of the castle that is the most photographed view of Prague and one that is instantly recognizable. True, it does not look like an English castle, but it housed kings for hundreds of years and is now the seat of the Czech government. I wonder if he took a tour of the inside of some of the buildings? Where jousts were held in the grand halls, and where disgraced politicians were thrown out of windows (the famous defenestrations!). I am heading to Prague again in October and look forward to visiting the castle again. Please do not pay any heed to that other posting. Prague is a wonderful city to visit, and this is just one of its great places - which also includes, by the way, the Golden Street with the original houses from hundreds of years ago (one where Franz Kafka lived for a short time) and where many movies have been filmed (including Amadeus). After visiting the castle, head over to the Estates Theatre where Mozart himself conducted the world premier of Don Giovanni.

total rubbish. firstly there is not even a castle there, its basically a collection of buildngs on a hill, main buildng is a cathedral which looks like every other cathedral in the world, both inside and out, then there are some other office block type places arranged roughly in a rectangle around it , its no different to anything you will see in the old town, jewish quarter etc the only use for this place is as a backdrop to a foto, if you stand on a bridge at sundown and take a foto with it in the background its quite good but don't waste the time or money going there go instead to karlstejn castle which is actually pretty awesome - see separate review

Love the hills and all the walking among great old buildings. Have been on the castle side a lot of times and up in the hills of Prague. Its fantastic and give a great impression of this incredible city.And of course on this side of Charles Bridge you will find a lot of restaurants/bars/cafes with a panoramic view over the city. Also walking along the river is very nice.

Impressive old castle be prepared to walk. The old castle is situated high above the old and the new town in Prague so either you take a long bus ride or you go up by yourself. I can recommend going up from the new town which leads you to two inetresting churches on the way and give a nice view on Prague. But be aware it is a steep climb and can be hard in case you are not fit. In the castle you do have two museums, one church, lots of statues and paintings and a lot of impreessive sights. Most of the attractions inside are for a fee but the hwole atmosphere of an emperor building something to impress kings and emperors is for free so you can go there nowadays and either feel impressed or happy that everybody now can get into it. A certain do not miss in Prague.

Spring at New World and Castle District - Photographic Review. New World street in the morning is place, where time had brought to a stop in 16th century - working class district of people employed at the court of the emperor Rudolph II have not undergo any important change since then. I love to take my bicycle and get there early morning with my camera and then continue via fabulous Baroque Loreta to Strahov view. At spring time the beauty of these places is enhanced with cherry trees and magnolias in blossom.....

Dont miss it. To be in Prague and not ot visit Prague castle (called Hradcany) would be a huge mistake. The advantage of this monumental building is the convinient location in the Prague center. You can easily walk from old town square over the Charles bridge (800 years old) up to the castle. The trip takes not more than 2 hours incl some stops in souvenir shops. The castle itself is quite big and includes beautiful gardnes with whole Prague views and fanstastic church in the middle. To see the castle you dont pay any entrance fees just if you want to enter exhibitions or galerries then ofcourse...dont forget to walk through golden gate which is also part of the complex...

we didn't go inside the castle but was worth a look around. we went up to the castle and had a wander around and went in to the cathedral which is all free, i read many reviews that said it's not worth it to pay to go inside so we didn't bother. the view from the front gates over the city was awesome as everything was covered in snow but i think the view from the east side near the Lobkowicz Palace was better.

Visit in the morning, visit during the night. Hradcany are totally crowded almost every day between late spring and early autumn, so in order to have some breathing room you have either to get up very early (this means: be here around 9 am) or visit the castle around midnight. I recommend doing both: come during the night for the atmosphere; but then come in the morning (not necessarily the day after) for the cathedral and museums. If you start really early, you can get almost everywhere without queuing. But should you wait some 10 minutes to see the changing of the guard, for example - you're lost and the tour groups will be your doom.Don't miss: the St Vitus Cathedral, the Golden Lane and the basilica.
Great castle, great views!. we got there using the tram, easy trip. The castle itself is specatcular, the views gorgeous.

Don't pay for the castle!. We've just returned from Prague and if I can pass on one tip it's this: DON'T pay for entry for things! The Hradcany (castle) is very interesting but after queuing for 45 minutes, paying £15 each for a ticket and an extra £15 for an audio guide, we realised as we walked around that pretty much everything is free anyway to get into! It just gives you a fast route to the cathederal and the only bit worth paying for was Golden Lane but alone it's about £4. We'd paid for the basic ticket which included along with the usual free attractions, entry to 3 others - the Golden Lane (a lovely lane of shops and an interesting museum corridor of armoury), an old chapel which was nice (one stone room) but after 2 minutes you'd see it, and the palace - sounds better than it is - it was the old palace which again, was a huge stone hall! I think the full price ticket would have been about £20 each. Nothing is signed in English so unless you pay for the audio guide which is like a 1980s mobile phone, it's all pretty irrellevant. I know it sounsd like I'm impatient or unwilling to 'absorb culture' but quite the opposite - I studied the Hapsburgs at university for 3 years and still had trouble working out what things were! Best advice is to enjoy the architecture and amazing views from up there and save your money!

The walk to the Castle. We went in May 2009 for a long weekend, and were in Prague on May 1st. Was a bit busy, but the Old Town Square and the walk through the pedestrian streets filled with little shops across cobble stones was like being in a fairy tale. The Charles Bridge is spectacular and the walk up to the Castle was beautiful. We were lucky the weather was not too hot for walking, but was pleasant to sit and have a beer in the sun. We did find a cafe on the way to the Castle up a flight of steep steps. It was called the Mystery Cafe. What a rip off! We were stupid enough to not ask how much the beers were. They charged us £5 per beer! Now I know the rate of exchange is rubbish at the moment, but that is disgusting. In other cafes we were charged anything from 22 crowns to about 49 crowns. But in this place it was 100 crowns a beer. So avoid this bar like the plague.Apart from that had a wonderful time. :) Prague is beautiful and stylish and i loved it.

Fresh snow in Prague Castle District. It is the best time to come to Prague and walk to Prague Castle and surrounding Castle district and enjoy fairy tale winter conditions. Snow and frost wil last full week!See photographs from today Monday 16th of February.

Excellent walk. Hradcany is the best area of Prague for walking and getting lost in the maze of streets. There are small alleys everywhere, views of Charles Bridge and the Castle. There are also very good views of Mala Strana, Petrin Hill, and Old Town. You can start at the top near the castle, or from the bottom by crossing Charles Bridge and turning right. There are bars, art shops, and few other people. Be warned there are many stairs.
